DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Bus, Two Trucks Collide, Leaving Seven Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with 17 hospitalized, crash scene, description of icy roads and gusts, other details. PICKS UP 13th graf, `Palmer was ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto OGD2
DOC.TEXT: A tractor-trailer collided Tuesday with a Greyhound bus and a truck on an icy highway, killing seven people and injuring 41, authorities said. Seventeen people were hospitalized, four in critical condition, after the 9 a.m. accident on Interstate 80 near the Wyoming line. The bus, en route to Chicago from Salt Lake City, had more than 40 passengers. Greyhound dispatcher Bill Moore said he could not provide an exact count. All of the dead were passengers on the bus, said sheriff's Sgt. Robert Berry. The bus driver and one of the truck drivers were among the injured. At the crash scene, coats, luggage and other debris were strewn around the bus, which lay on its right side. Frozen hams from one of the trucks also littered the highway. Berry said authorities searched luggage for clues to passengers' identities. A witness, Blaine Whimpe of Morgan, Utah, said a westbound truck apparently slid into the eastbound lanes, colliding with a second truck and the bus. The bus turned on its side, he said. ``I could see the bus. There were people up on top of the bus pulling people out. Everybody that came out of the bus that I had seen was hurt, broken arms, legs, cuts,'' Whimpe said. ``They were just all moaning and groaning and freezing. They wanted a warm place to get into.'' Whimpe described the road condition as ``terrible.'' The Highway Patrol siad the roads were extremely icy, with winds gusting to near 30 mph and falling snow making driving treacherous. The National Weather Service estimated that visibility in the area at three-quarters of a mile. The injured were taken to Evanston Regional Hospital in Wyoming, 10 miles from the accident, where 14 people were admitted, including a woman in critical condition, said spokeswoman Janet Kolb. Three others with head injuries were flown to Salt Lake, one to LDS Hospital and two to the University of Utah Medical Center. All remained in critical condition late Tuesday, nursing supervisors said. Passenger Stuart Palmer of Buffalo, N.Y., said the bus driver could do nothing after one of the trucks slammed into the left side of the bus, forcing it off the road and down a 35-foot embankment. Palmer was released from the hospital with a broken ankle and a bruised knee. The accident closed both eastbound and westbound I-80 from Evanston to Silver Creek Junction, Utah, for five hours. In Washington, the National Transportation Safety Board said it was dispatching a team of investigators to look into the accident. Greyhound officials were also dispatched to Emory, Moore said, but he declined further comment until a report was filed by the company's representatives at the scene. The Wyoming Army National Guard armory in Evanston was opened for passengers on the bus who had nowhere to go. The Utah Highway Patrol set up a hotline for families of accident victims, said Sgt. Gary Whitney. The number is 801-965-4518. Last week, twelve people died in an 83-car pileup on a foggy stretch of Interstate 75 near Chatanooga, Tenn. More than 50 people were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Six Cities Chosen as Finalists for Baseball Teams
DOC.TEXT: Six U.S. cities, three of them in Florida, have been selected as finalists for two new baseball teams. Proposals were selected Tuesday from Buffalo, N.Y., Denver, Miami, Orlando, Fla., St. Petersburg-Tampa, Fla., and Washington. Eliminated from the running were Nashville, Tenn., Charlotte, N.C., Phoenix and Sacramento, Calif. The National League has said two new teams will begin play in 1993. Their home cities will be selected by next September. ``The cities on the list are the best in terms of market size, government commitment to support baseball, and stadium facilities in place or planned,'' said Doug Danforth, head of the league expansion committee.

DOC.HEAD: Events Leading to Civil Rights Case Arrest
With PM-Evers Case, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of events in the case of Byron De La Beckwith, arrested in Tennessee after being indicted again in the 1963 assassination of civil rights leader Medgar Evers: -June 12, 1963. Evers, the Mississippi NAACP field secretary, is shot in the back outside his home. -June 21, 1963. Beckwith is arrested by the FBI on a civil rights complaint. Authorities say his fingerprint was found on the telescopic sight of a rifle found near the scene. Beckwith claims the rifle was stolen from his home. -Jan. 27, 1964. Beckwith's first state trial on a murder charge begins with an all-white jury. The trial ends in a hung jury on Feb. 7. -April 6, 1964. Beckwith's second trial begins, again with an all-white jury. Jurors report they are deadlocked on April 17. -1969. The murder charge against Beckwith is dismissed. -1973. Beckwith is arrested in New Orleans and convicted of possessing dynamite without a permit. He served five years in prison. -October 1989. Published reports say the Mississippi Sovereignty Commission, a now-defunct state segregationist watchdog agency, screened potential jurors in Beckwith's second trial. Prosecutors later announce they found no evidence of jury tampering. -Oct. 3, 1989. Evers widow, Myrlie, asks that her husband's murder case be reopened. Jackson City Council, NAACP and others support reopening the case. -March 11, 1990. District Attorney Ed Peters announces there are new leads in the Evers case. -Dec. 17, 1990. Beckwith is arrested in Tennessee on a fugitive warrant issued by the state of Mississippi.

DOC.HEAD: Third in a Series
Part III: Liberals, Conservatives Battle for the High Ground
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
With LaserPhoto, AP Graphic, Series Logo
DOC.TEXT: Liberal-conservative barricades within the nation's churches have limited religious groups' ability to help Americans develop a common ground to discuss moral issues. The third installment of a four-part series, ``Unholy Wars: Religion in Public Life,'' examines the consequences. ---

Religion in America was simpler in the 1950s. The phrase ``under God'' was added to the Pledge of Allegiance, Catholics, evangelicals, Jews and Muslims kept a low profile, and a pecking order helped a community's most prominent citizens gravitate toward mainline Protestant institutions such as the Presbyterian and Episcopal churches. But then a series of sociological changes shook nearly 3{ centuries of Protestant hegemony, ranging from the rapid rise of evangelicalism, to the surge of Catholics to equal Protestants in income and education, to judicial rulings limiting the influence of religion in public life. In explaining what happened in his Midwest community, one mainline Protestant executive told Hartford Seminary Dean William McKinney, ``You have to understand the neighborhood changed when the whites moved out and the Irish Catholics moved in.'' The demographic shifts have not led to a passive changing of the guard, but to what some observers see as increasingly bitter divisions between liberals and conservatives that threaten religion's traditional role of supplying society with a common set of moral standards. ``Religious people have got to get their act together,'' said Dean Thomas Ogletree of Yale Divinity School. ``If we're unable to talk to one another because we're so divided, the larger society is wise to say, `Let's keep religion out of it because they'll just mess it up.' '' In a 1984 Gallup Poll, 31 percent of religious conservatives held negative stereotypes of religious liberals, while only 7 percent found similar faults with themselves. The range of intolerance was even greater on the religious left, where 41 percent held negative views of conservatives, while only 3 percent said liberal sterotypes were valid. ``The division is at least as strong, if not stronger than it was five years ago,'' said Robert Wuthnow, a Princeton University sociology professor who has studied the issue. America may be heralded as a haven for religious freedom, but it also has a history of religious bigotry. At the founding of the country, most states had laws discriminating against Catholics and formally establishing either Anglican or Congregational churches. Strong anti-Catholic and anti-Semitic attitudes existed into the 1950s, despite a veneer of placid tolerance epitomized by President Eisenhower's declaration that, ``Our government makes no sense unless it is founded on a deeply felt religious faith - and I don't care what it is.'' But the '60s and '70s saw unprecedented ecumenical advances, fueled by such things as a broad range of religious groups working together on the civil rights movement, Pope John XXIII opening the windows of the Catholic Church to the world with the Second Vatican Council, and a series of theological statements from Christian groups apologizing for their past anti-Semitism. ``I think if you look at any long time line, the trend is only up,'' said Jacqueline Wexler, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews. But many observers say the resurgence of Catholics and born-again Christian evangelicals into the public arena has brought about a renewal of religious prejudice. Thirty percent of the respondents in a Gallup survey last year said they would not welcome religious fundamentalists as neighbors. By comparison, only 5 percent said they would not welcome Protestants in general or Jews. At a Reformation Day service in October at Yale Divinity School, Lutheran theologian George Lindbeck lamented that anti-Catholicism has become in some corners ``the anti-Semitism of intellectuals.'' McKinney, who is studying mainline Protestant executives and who authored ``American Mainline Religion: Its Changing Shape and Future,'' agreed. ``I think anti-Catholicism is the last respectable American prejudice,'' he said. The liberal-conservative barricades cross denominational lines. Many religious conservatives, who tend to emphasize spirituality, prayer and Bible study over social concerns, have begun to form their own organizations within mainline churches. The Good News movement in the United Methodist Church, the Presbyterian Lay Committee and the Episcopal Synod of America are examples. In more conservative denominations such as the Southern Baptist Convention, those who favor greater acceptance of divergent theological views also have formed their own lobbying groups, such as the Southern Baptist Alliance. But the liberal-conservative divide may not be as wide as each side might think. Princeton's Wuthnow said his research indicates conservatives are more tolerant and socially concerned than liberals think they are; some conservative churches, for example, have established programs to help the homeless and counsel the unemployed. In the Brookings Institution study ``Religion in American Public Life,'' A. James Reichley said many religious conservatives approach the abortion struggle with the same ardor liberals fought for civil rights. ``On the issue of abortion, they believe it is the liberals who are countenancing mass destruction of potential life, while fundamentalists, in alliance with Catholics, stand up for the most vulnerable of all forms of human life - the unborn,'' Reichley said. At the same time, Wuthnow said, liberals are more devout in their faith than conservatives think they are, as shown by a renewed interest in evangelism and Bible study. Bishop Herbert W. Chilstrom, spiritual leader of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, said more than 9,000 of the denomination's 11,000 congregations ordered tapes of a church-sponsored faith-development program. ``That's indicative of a very deep hunger for faith development among our people,'' he said. And partnerships are being fostered. For the first time in a generation, religious groups across the board now are forming coalitions on issues ranging from apartheid to pornography. ``Many religious leaders have a sense of being in the same boat. They sense, as they once did not, the danger of religion being totally driven out of a public role in society,'' Reichley said. Pressure has grown in recent years to consider on secular grounds issues ranging from abortion to nuclear war, as more people view religion as a set of divisive, sectarian interests, Wuthnow said. When you take out the moral values supplied by religion, he said, ``Then what becomes important are issues of economics, political expediency, practicality.'' Those are the wrong guidelines to use for deciding issues such as euthanasia, genetic engineering, allocation of limited health care resources and even whether the nation should go to war, Wuthnow and others said. In the new religious climate, the ability to compromise is seen as a high moral value, said Ogletree, of Yale Divinity School. ``The alternative to compromise is moral anarchy or religious conflict,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Standing Up For a Much-Maligned Holiday Treat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Some Scrooges say it's ``those little red and green things'' that make them think you'd have to be nuttier than a fruitcake to eat one. Others drag out the joke. You know, the one about there being just one fruitcake that gets passed around and around and around. ``It's the only thing that everybody doesn't like, except lutefisk,'' the humorist Calvin Trillin says, referring to a Norwegian dried cod dish. But have you ever eaten fruitcake, Mr. Trillin? ``I think I had a bite once, 20 years ago. It was before I knew. I was an innocent,'' he says. ``Probably it was Christmas, the fire was going, the presents were being unwrapped, or maybe they already were unwrapped.'' Fruitcake has had its share of humiliation. Johnny Carson and columnist Russell Baker have poked fun. Nearly a third of the people surveyed by American Express a couple of years back said it was the worst gift of all. Well, Mr. Trillin, Mr. Baker and all you other naysayers, enough already. ``It's sort of an annual plague,'' said Susan Purdy, author of the cookbook ``A Piece of Cake,'' who argues there's more to fruitcake than men of this ilk know. ``I'm not going to sit here and tell you that when you hear a fruitcake joke, it doesn't make you kind of mad. It does,'' said W. Dale Parker, a vice president at the granddaddy of fruitcake bakers, Claxton Bakery Inc. in Claxton, Ga. Parker's family business bakes 5 million pounds of fruitcake a year. ``Obviously, there's a lot of people out there eating fruitcake,'' Parker said. ``We get some rave reviews, that it's just like the one grandmother wanted to bake but couldn't,'' boasts Father Andrew of the Holy Cross Abbey in Berryville, Va., where each year the Monastery Bakery turns out 13,000 traditional fruit- and nut-studded cakes laced with brandy. So, Mr. Trillin, how do you suppose these companies stay in business? People ``are buying them, and they're giving them to other people. But that doesn't mean they're eating them,'' he said. ``I've been given a lot of fruitcakes as gifts.'' Richard Sullivan of the Glace Fruit Processors admits some fruitcakes taste like sawdust. His father always got one for Christmas that was ``dense and bitter. I never liked the thing.'' Ah, but then there are good ones. ``They have to have wonderful fruits,'' said Purdy, who uses mangoes, papayas, apricots, dates, nuts, dried apples, pears and plums. She advises: ``Avoid little red and green and yellow things.'' ``A good fruitcake to me is like eating candy,'' Sullivan said. ``I just love it.'' Melvin Gordon, president of Paradise Fruit Inc. in Plant City, Fla., said he doesn't know how fruitcake got such a lousy reputation. He notes that his industry sells 50 million pounds of candied fruit a year, and if he could talk to Mr. Trillin, he'd say: ``Fruitcake has been around a lot longer than you and I.'' Even some particular fruitcakes can claim that. In ``Enough's Enough,'' a new collection of Trillin's columns, he mentions a family in Michigan ``that brings out an antique fruitcake every Christmas, a fruitcake that for some reason was not eaten at Christmas dinner in 1895 and has symbolized the holidays ever since.'' Mr. Trillin, meet Morgan Ford of Tecumseh, Mich., keeper of a cake baked not in 1895, he says, but in 1878 by his great-grandmother. When she died early the following year, the cake was forgotten for a while. Today, it's in an airtight glass box, Ford said. ``There's a musty rum smell there yet,'' he said. When his uncle, then 86, took a bite a couple decades back, Ford said, ``He had to cut it off with his jacknife, sliver it off. It doesn't look too appetizing to me.'' As if to ward off the inevitable, Ford notes right away that his uncle lived two more years. ``If I make it to 86 - and I'm 70 - I'll taste it then,'' he said. But he could be persuaded to give into temptation by Johnny Carson, who has poked fun at the cake. ``If he'd take a bite,'' Ford said, ``I'd take a bite.'' Go ahead, Mr. Trillin, joke about ``heirloom'' or ``antique'' fruitcakes. Age can be a virtue. The late James Beard, often called the dean of American food, once wrote that his mother baked fruitcakes a full year ahead, and kept some of her wedding fruitcake for a quarter-century by periodically lacing it with cognac. The ancient Romans, Purdy said, baked fruitcakes called ``satura,'' Latin for a ``full dish'' and the root of the word satire (perhaps the Romans had one up on you, Mr. Trillin.). Martha Washington made one for family holidays. Before refrigeration, the sugar and spirits in fruitcakes acted as preservatives. As recently as 50 years ago, no one chortled over fruitcake. ``Our taste has changed. We don't like things that are too heavy, too sweet,'' Purdy said. ``We're talking about an antique cake in contemporary life, and it's trying to make the transition.'' So, go ahead, take your potshots, Mr. Trillin and Co. But, honestly, wouldn't you be in a holiday funk if nobody at all remembered you with a fruitcake? --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Mary MacVean comes from a long line of fruitcake lovers, and nevers lets a December go by without eating or baking some - with or without the little red and green fruit.

DOC.HEAD: Cookies and Christmas: A Match Made in the Heart
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Defense of Fruitcake; PM-Cookie Sampler
LaserPhoto NY303 of Dec. 12
DOC.TEXT: There are December nights when Beverly Nyberg, who works all day, looks up from frosting ginger cookies and finds it's 3 a.m. ``It's a mad rush. That's the essence of Christmas cookies,'' said Nyberg, a commercial artist at a New York advertising agency. Why do it, then? ``For tradition, for love,'' she said. Her mother, now nearly 80, used to make at least 30 kinds of Christmas cookies. Nyberg's 20-year-old son already is asking what kinds mom is making this year. Her favorites are thumbprints, a sugar cookie covered with nuts and rolled in a ball. A thumb stuck in the middle before baking leaves a depression just right for frosting or jam. Throughout December, cooks everywhere take out traditional and new-found recipes, baking nights and weekends to fill old shoe boxes or tins with cookies, carefully layered with wax paper, to freeze until Christmas. ``Yeah, your body complains'' from the effort, Nyberg said. But the payoff is ``the enjoyment that everyone is walking by and grabbing cookies off the plate when it comes to the D-day of Christmas.'' Food historian William Woys Weaver of Devon, Pa., said he tries new cookies each year, but always returns to old favorites such as a German cookie called chocolate apeas. ``I made some for some children last week and a little girl said, `These even taste like Christmas.' I said, `Good, good, that's just what I want to hear,' '' Weaver said. ``Nothing represents the spirit of loving, nurturing and giving more than a homemade cookie,'' Rose Levy Beranbaum writes in her new book, ``Rose's Christmas Cookies.'' ``They're always exactly the right size, they look so appealing, they taste so delicious; they're satisfying but not too filling,'' Judy Knipe and Barbara Marks write in ``The Christmas Cookie Book.'' In many homes, the morning before Christmas, the shoe boxes and cookie tins come out and gift baskets are arranged for delivery later that day. Little hands take delight in decorating cut-out sugar cookies with sprinkles and red hots, some to be left that night for Santa Claus. Marks will make eight or 10 kinds of cookies this year, including ginger pecan slices, chocolate orange chunk cookies and lemon drops, carrying on a tradition learned at the elbow of her mother and other relatives. Especially her dad's Aunt Marie. ``I would get so exicted, and a month before Christmas I would go over on Saturdays and bake with her,'' Marks said. ``Getting to go somewhere all by yourself at 7 or 8 was really something.'' Much of the year, home baking is something of a lost art. The Nestle Toll House Kitchen in Purchase, N.Y., cites studies showing that only 35 percent of the baked goods eaten last year were made at home. But nearly all the people surveyed said they bake for the holidays, Nestle said. ``Cookie'' comes from the Dutch, koekje, the diminutive for cake. But cookies are easier to make and more forgiving of the novice's mistakes than cakes, Beranbaum said. Americans have always loved Christmas cookies, Weaver said. Colonists could afford sweets only for special occasions. And while Christmas cookies in the shapes of animals and people were made for children, they appealed to everyone, he said. ``It was a release, a fantasy food in a sense. ... The adult who's making camels and what have you, I think they're going back to childhood a little, don't you?'' Weaver said. ``Of course, they taste very good, too.'' Among the earliest cookies were gingerbread, which came both from Germany and from England and Scotland, Weaver writes in ``The Christmas Cook.'' By the late 19th century, refined sugar, eggs and flour were available to most people, and the cast-iron stove gave homemakers more control over baking than they had at the hearth, he said. That, combined with a wave of immigration, broadened the home cook's repertoire, which now includes cookies from much of the world, he said. In her Greenwich Village apartment, Beranbaum shows off what look like stained glass windows: sugar cookies with intricate cutouts, filled with crushed sour balls that become translucent when baked. She also bakes exquisite, delicate snowflakes that sparkle when hung from the branches of a lighted tree. Beranbaum's book has traditional, elegant cookies; down-home green wreaths made with marshmallows and cornflakes; even brownies. In ``The Christmas Cookie Book,'' the sharing is evident from the many recipes with a name attached: Amy's molasses puffs, Renata's vanilla crescents, Holly's ginger crisps. When Beranbaum worked in the test kitchen of the Ladies Home Journal, her first story was on cookies, for the Christmas of 1975. But Christmas has long been part of this Jewish New Yorker's life. ``I grew up with the feeling that in New York, Chistmas was a joyous cultural celebration belonging to everyone and not restricted only to those who observed it as a religious holiday,'' she writes. Because of her book, Beranbaum doesn't have time to bake cookies for family and friends this year, but she likes one way of considering her situation: Give a gift of Christmas cookies and you spruce up one holiday. Give a book that teaches how to bake them and you feed Christmases forever.

DOC.HEAD: Cookies Make Christmas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Christmas Cookies; PM-Defense of Fruitcake
DOC.TEXT:
Here are two Christmas cookie recipes:
Lebkuchen, from ``The Christmas Cook,'' by William Woys Weaver (Harper Perennial, $18.95) A traditional German Christmas cookie, large, thick and chewy. Yield: Approximately 7 dozen 8} cups all-purpose flour 2{ tablespoons baking soda 1 tablespoon ground cloves 1 tablespoon ground cinnamon 1 tablespoon ground cardamom 4 cups ground almonds { cup plus 2 tablespoons chopped citron 2 cups plus 3 tablespoons honey 2 cups plus 3 tablespoons unsulfured molasses 4 tablespoons brandy
Sift the flour, soda and spices together twice. Add the ground almonds and citron. Mix the honey and molasses in a saucepan and heat to a gentle boil. Remove from the stove. Make a hole in the center of the flour, and add the honey mixture while still hot. As you stir this into the flour, gradually add the brandy. Work this up into a ball of dough, cover and set aside to ripen in the refrigerator for eight days. The dough will rise in bulk as it ripens. On the eighth day, roll out the dough \-inch thick and cut into 2{-inch rounds. Set these on greased baking sheets, cover and store in a cool place overnight. Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. Bake the cookies 12 to 15 minutes, or until fully risen and pale brown on the bottom. Cool on racks. As they cool, the cookies will harden. Store in airtight containers.
---
Stained Glass, from ``Rose's Christmas Cookies,'' by Rose Levy Beranbaum (William Morrow and Co. Inc., $19.95) Yield: 4 dozen 3-inch cookies 2} cups bleached all-purpose flour { teaspoon baking powder { teaspoon salt Two-thirds cup sugar 1 cup unsalted butter About half a large egg, lightly beaten 1{ teaspoons pure vanilla extract [ teaspoon lemon extract 1 cup sour balls
Soften the butter. In a mixing bowl, cream together the sugar and butter until fluffy. Add the egg and extracts and beat until blended. In a small bowl, whisk together the remaining dry ingredients. On low speed, gradually add them to the butter mixture and mix just until the dough can be gathered into a ball. Scrape the dough onto a sheet of plastic wrap and use the wrap, not your fingers, to press the dough together to form a thick flat disc. Wrap it well and refrigerate for at least 30 minutes, preferably no longer than three hours. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Separate the sour balls into individual colors and pulverize them separately in a blender or food processor. Place each color in a small container and set aside. Using about a quarter of the dough at a time, roll out the dough to [-inch thickness between two sheets of plastic wrap or on a lightly floured counter. Cut out cookies with a three-inch cookie cutter, spraying or greasing the cutter as needed to prevent sticking. With a small, angled metal spatula or pancake turner, transfer the cookies to cookie sheets lined with aluminum foil and greased. If you are planning to hang the cookies, make small holes with the blunt end of a wooden skewer. Cut out shapes for the stained glass in each cookie with small cutters or with a small sharp knife. Use the tip of a small sharp knife to fill the holes with candy pieces, filling just to the top of the dough. Bake for 10 to 12 minutes, or until the cookies are lightly browned and the candy has melted completely. For even baking, rotate the cookie sheets from top to bottom and front to back halfway through the baking period. Watch carefully toward the end of baking to see that the candy does not start to carmelize and turn brown. Allow the cookies to cool completely on the sheets. Carefully peel off the aluminum foil. Store in an airtight container, between sheets of wax paper, at room temperature. Will keep several weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Diplomats and Jews Say Road to Dignity Paved with Anti-Semitism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB5 of Dec. 11
DOC.TEXT: Aryeh Levin doesn't quite know what his title is. Israeli consul general? Israeli envoy? ``I'm the head of a diplomats' group,'' he said, chuckling, ``with the questionable title of ambassador.'' Two years after his arrival and two months after the Soviet Union said it would end its 23-year diplomatic rift with Israel, Levin still waits to raise his country's white-and-blue flag at an embassy in central Moscow. The Kremlin has said bureaucratic problems are delaying full consular ties. Levin blamed the ``demon'' of anti-Semitism, which he said pervades certain ministries and nearly reaches the top levels of government. It's a perception that looms large for Israel and Soviet Jews. Both hope to cultivate a deeper Jewish presence in the Soviet Union even as tens of thousands of Jews emigrate. ``We need a developed Jewish life,'' said Leonid Stonov, a prominent Jewish activist. ``We need to increase Jewish dignity.'' Israeli officials and Soviet Jewish leaders said emigration no longer defines their attitude toward the Soviet Union, as it did during much of the Cold War. Cultural and religious expression for Jews, and trade and social exchanges for Israel, now are nearly equal to emigration on their list of priorities. More than 130,000 Soviet Jews have emigrated this year to Israel, driven in part by increasing anti-Semitism. Several thousand more have gone to the United States. About 300,000 Soviet emigres already live in Israel. Of the 1.4 million Jews still in the Soviet Union, about 250,000 live in Moscow. Jews who remain can celebrate their holidays openly and attend Hebrew schools in major cities. A new law on religion guarantees the right to such practices, many of which formerly were prohibited. Groups have emerged to promote everything from Zionism to Jewish theater. Last December, 250 such groups formed the Confederation of Soviet Jewish Organizations to protect Jews and coordinate their activities. ``Our goal is to secure the survival of Soviet Jewry as part of world Jewry,'' said Mikhail Chlenov, a co-chairman of the organization. Anti-Semitism remains an obstacle. For decades, the Kremlin painted Israel as a racist state bent on taking Arab land. ``In the realm of foreign affairs, where the general `new thinking' is like a stream, there are little eddies on the side of this larger current,'' Levin said. ``These little eddies are the anti-Israeli attitude, the concept of a world Zionist conspiracy.'' He said those attitudes had delayed restoration of full consular ties, which would allow Israel itself to issue visas to the hundreds of Jews who want to leave. The Dutch Embassy now represents Israel in the Soviet Union and issues the visas. Israel and the Kremlin agreed Sept. 30, after three years of warming relations, to upgrade the delegations in each other's capitals. During that period, Levin arrived in Moscow and his delegation moved back into the building it occupied before ties were severed over the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. Despite the announcement, the state of relations has not changed. A Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman blamed ``slow-moving bureaucracy.'' Levin said ranking Soviet officials told him privately they must proceed slowly because of ``an anti-Semitic mood.'' ``They're using it as an excuse and they are at the same time suffering from it,'' Levin said. He expressed optimism that full diplomatic relations could be restored within a year unless anti-Israeli and anti-Semitic elements prevail, Levin said. ``They all have their own Pavlov reactions to anything that has to do with Israel,'' he said. ``They have to get rid of this, and I'm glad to say they are thinking along these lines ... But it will take time. ``People who deal with Israel today in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs are not Hebraists, they're Arabists. This does not explain everything, but it goes a long way to explain a few things.'' Vladimir Nosenko, a Middle East analyst at the Institute of World Economics and International Relations, echoed that view. ``They have an old perception about the role of Israel in the Middle East, and I'm afraid our bureaucracy is very strong,'' he said. ``Our anti-Zionist propaganda several years ago created the basic anti-Semitic problems we have now.'' Israel hopes diplomatic ties will increase trade and cultural contacts, Levin said. Nosenko said the Soviet Union needs Israel's agricultural know-how. The two countries have exchanged visits by farming experts, and Levin said Israel's agriculture minister would travel to the Soviet Union soon. The confederation of Jewish groups is working to open synagogues and may run candidates for the Soviet parliament, said Chlenov, the co-chairman. ``There is a feeling that Jews were sitting in the far corner of a big room, and only now they're trying to come out into the center,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Years Later, Walsh Still Prosecuting Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence E. Walsh ends his fourth year as Iran-Contra prosecutor today fighting to preserve his most important convictions and pry evidence from unwilling witnesses to complete his investigation. Congress and much of the public appear to have forgotten, or at least lost interest, in the biggest scandal of the Reagan administration. But a grand jury continues to hear evidence in the case, and Walsh says he will decide by spring whether to seek new indictments or conclude his investigation. In the meantime, Walsh gets a chilly reception from the Bush administration, whose hard-line stance on releasing classified documents scuttled the prosecution of former CIA agent Joseph Fernandez. He endures the editorial taunts of conservative commentators. One recently compared him to a dinner guest who won't go home. His office is still dueling in closed court proceedings with Oliver L. North over the former White House aide's refusal to give more testimony to the grand jury. North scored a major victory earlier this year when a federal appeals court set aside his three felony convictions for his role in covering up the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and the diversion of profits to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. The decision bodes ill for Walsh's other major triumph - five guilty verdicts earlier this year against former national security adviser John M. Poindexter, convicted of lying to Congress and obstructing its investigations. Poindexter's appeal is set to be argued Feb. 28. And now Walsh is fighting a rear-guard action against Jeffrey Toobin, a former junior associate of his office who wants to publish a book about the Iran-Contra investigation that the independent counsel contends would expose grand jury secrets. Toobin has filed suit against Walsh in New York. ``I have never felt in the center of friends,'' said Walsh, a former federal judge and Wall Street lawyer who is a month shy of his 79th birthday but looks at least 10 years younger. ``This has always been a lonely place.'' But Walsh, who shuttles between Washington and his home in Oklahoma City, said his investigation achieved its goal of uncovering the wrongs of the Iran-Contra affair. ``The central actors have been pretty well described,'' he said in an interview, while acknowledging that ``the supervisory and support roles may never be fully exposed.'' When the investigation is over, ``we will have substantially a full story, but there will undoubtedly be enclaves that aren't fully developed,'' Walsh said. Eight participants have been convicted, including Poindexter, North, former national security adviser Robert McFarlane and arms dealers Richard V. Secord and Albert Hakim. Just last week, Thomas G. Clines received a 16-month sentence - the longest prison term imposed on an Iran-Contra defendant - for failing to report on his tax returns all the money he earned brokering the arms deals. The grand jury is trying to determine whether other former Reagan administration officials could be prosecuted for misleading Congress about the covert operation to arm the Nicaraguan rebels. These former officials include Elliott Abrams, a former assistant secretary of state, and Donald Gregg, an adviser to then-Vice President Bush and now ambassador to South Korea, said sources familiar with the case who demanded anonymity. Walsh refused to comment on any aspect of the grand jury investigation. He is preparing to ask the Supreme Court to revive North's convictions. The appeals court had ruled that televised testimony North gave lawmakers under a congressional grant of immunity may have unfairly seeped into his trial. That ruling gives Poindexter powerful legal ammunition for his appeal. Like his former subordinate at the National Security Council, Poindexter gave congressional testimony on condition that his words would not be used as evidence against him. Walshdeclined to comment on the wisdom of the congressional grants of immunity, but he acknowledged they posed a major stumbling block for his investigation. The Iran-Contra affair is most often compared to the Watergate scandal that forced President Nixon's resignation. But Walsh said there are important differences that pose different problems for his investigation. ``This isn't Watergate, where you have a burglary and a simple coverup. This is a very complex operation at the very highest levels of government,'' he said. Unlike the investigation by the Watergate special prosecutor, Walsh's probe has never definitively answered the question of the president's role in the scandal. But Walsh said the Iran-Contra investigations produced an unprecedented collection of Ronald Reagan's statements, particularly a seven-hour videotaped deposition the former president gave for Poindexter's trial. ``It's rare the public has been given his own view rather than the second-hand view of the investigator,'' Walsh said. ``We have given the public the raw facts.''

DOC.HEAD: No Sign of Withdrawal, Cheney Said
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 14 grafs new; one graf transition; picks up antepenultimate graf; which is still antepenultimate graf
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Tuesday the Pentagon has no evidence that Saddam Hussein is planning any withdrawal of troops from Kuwait and is instead pouring additional infantry into the occupied emirate. Cheney was asked about comments Monday by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that Saddam might try a ``ploy'' like a partial withdrawal just before the United Nations's Jan. 15 deadline to quit Kuwait. He said he did not rule out such a move but said Iraq's military maneuvering indicated no pullout was in the offing. The defense secretary, en route to Saudi Arabia to discuss with ground commanders U.S. contingency plans for war, said the administration's resolve to restore Kuwait would not melt if Saddam gave up some of the conquered territory. ``If he is planning to withdraw, we certainly haven't seen any evidence of it,'' Cheney told reporters traveling with him before his plane landed to refuel at Shannon, Ireland. ``He might move the pieces around on the board but our objective is for him to get all of that stuff out of Kuwait, not half of it, not 75 percent of it, not 10 percent of it - all of it'' Cheney said. Cheney was accompanied by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, on their first joint visit to Saudi Arabia. The Cheney-Powell trip begins with two days of military strategy sessions in the Saudi capital of Riyadh, where the two will meet with American commanders and ranking Saudi officials, including King Fahd. Cheney and Powell then plan to split up for two days of pre-Christmas visits with some of the 270,000 American troops in the Persian Gulf region. Cheney and Powell conceded some of the reinforcements the United States is sending won't make it there by Jan. 15, and that some will arrive but still not be ready for combat, perhaps not for weeks after the Jan. 15 deadline. Yet Cheney insisted ``we have an offensive capability should that be required.'' ``Most of the force will be there by then but obviously there is additional work to be done before you would identify them as combat ready,'' Cheney said, including testing equipment and getting used to the desert. Powell declined to answer several specific questions about the Pentagon's plans for war, saying he did not want to tip his hand to Saddam. ``I want him to sit there in beautiful downtown Baghdad and worry his butt off about it,'' Powell said. The joint visit will give Cheney and Powell their first opportunity to sit down together with the U.S. field commander, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, and to assess the status of the U.S. deployment less than a month before the U.N. deadline. In Washington, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Wednesday the U.S. troop level has passed the 270,000 mark, and that another 220,000 allied air, ground and naval troops were in the region as well. Williams said the number of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and souther Iraq continues to grow and now is more than 510,000. He said there were concerns raised within the Pentagon about the security risks of a joint Cheney-Powell trip. ``But I think whatever considerations about that are outweighed by the desire for them to spend some time together discussing the operation and how things are going, spending some time with the commander in chief of the operation,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Nab Soviet Red Cross Workers Trying to Steal Aid
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Red Cross officials were caught red-handed trying to steal parcels of humanitarian aid donated from abroad and intended for distribution to the needy, sick and elderly, Izvestia reported. The head of the Red Cross office in Moscow's Perovo District, assisted by 10 women employees, had set aside parcels containing sausage, canned meat, chocolate, coffee, sugar, vegetable oil, macaroni products, cigarettes, ballpoint pens, toothbrushes, dresses, men's suits and children's clothing, the government newspaper reported in Monday's editions. Hundreds of tons of food, medicine and other aid has been flowing into the Soviet Union from abroad in recent weeks as governments and organizations try to alleviate some of the shortages afflicting the beleaguered Soviet economy. The newspaper did not say which countries or organizations had donated the goods, nor did it identify the Soviet Red Cross officials involved. It also did not say how police discovered the alleged theft. A court suit has been filed against the Red Cross workers, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebellious Talk in the Conservatives' Ranks
DOC.TEXT: Ask prominent conservative thinkers what they think of George Bush's presidency and you get unanimity: they don't think much of it. Increasingly, conservatives are dismayed over Bush's direction and going public with their feeling that he has betrayed what one of them, David Keene, calls ``the ideological base of the Republican Party.'' And increasingly they tell of hearing talk about running some true-blue conservative against Bush in the Republican primaries of 1992, if only as a token protest. They agree, though, that there's scant chance of denying him renomination. It isn't only the president's abrupt abandonment last summer of his anti-tax stance that roils conservatives, although that rubbed them the most raw. They also complain of the bill he signed to ensure the rights of disabled people - which they say smacks of welfare statism - and they point to Bush's program to reinvigorate the Clean Air Act, which they see as just so much more social engineering. ``Just too much government,'' is how Tom Winter, editor of the conservative newspaper, Human Events, summarized the right wing's grievances. Even more, the chemistry isn't right. Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, said conservatives feel that Bush remains ``part of the establishment that most of these folks fought for so many years.'' They chafe over the White House's ``cavalier dismissal of (Ronald) Reagan and all he ever stood for,'' he said. And they resent the way the Bush administration treats conservatism ``essentially as an interest group,'' Keene said. The president's latest moves - the installation of moderates Lynn Martin as secretary of labor and Lamar Alexander as secretary of education - are unlikely to win any applause in the conservative camp. When William Bennett, a true conservative hero, changed his mind last week and said he would turn down the offer to become Republican national chairman, some GOP hard-liners assumed he'd been shoved overboard. ``It took Richard Nixon six years to destroy the Republican Party,'' Burton Yale Pines, vice president of the Heritage Foundation, told The Washington Times. ``Bush has done it in two years.'' To test the depth of dismay with Bush, a reporter telephoned conservative thinkers and read them this paragraph, written last week by conservative columnist Joseph Sobran, also a senior editor at National Review: ``Conservatives now spend most of their time trying to figure out how, and with whom, to replace Mr. Bush ASAP. They dread the prospect of his running again in 1992. Even more, they dread his winning. Many of them would rather see even a liberal Democrat in the Oval Office, on the principle that your enemies can't betray you the way your friends can. And a Bush defeat would allow conservatives to take back the Republican Party.'' Those questioned didn't agree that they spend most of their time conspiring to dump Bush, but they all had heard such talk. And all expressed dismay with the president's performance, especially on tax and domestic matters. The about-face on ``no new taxes'' was the fulcrum of discontent. R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr., editor of the American Spectator, called it ``a gigantic error.'' Patrick McGuigan, editorial writer for the Daily Oklahoman in Oklahoma City, said it was ``capitulation.'' Winter labeled it a ``fiasco.'' To George Gilder, economic idea man for conservatives, it was ``appalling.'' ``When Bush abandoned that issue, he virtually destroyed the party,'' Gilder said. The conservatives' complaint about Bush on taxes, said Martin Anderson, domestic adviser to Reagan, ``is not that he didn't succeed but he didn't fight.'' Still, conservatives aren't ready to lead an all-out rebellion, they said. ``Republicans are monarchists at heart,'' said Paul Weyrich, president of the Free Congress Foundation. ``No matter how much the king may be unpopular, they tend to stay with the king.'' But, said Pines, ``If George Bush three months from now is doing the same things that George Bush is doing now, then Sobran will have turned out to be very prophetic.'' Sobran's idea ``is not a majority position,'' said Robert Bork, who was Reagan's rejected candidate for a Supreme Court seat. ``If Bush were defeated in '92 and Democrats retained Senate control, they would have between three and four Supreme Court appointments, probably, and that means you'd have 20 or 25 years of an extremely activist Supreme Court and I don't think conservatives want that,'' Bork said. ``You can't beat somebody with nobody,'' said Anderson, now back at California's Hoover Institution on War, Peace and Revolution. ``Does Sobran have a candidate?''

DOC.HEAD: Met Opera Presents `Faust'
DOC.TEXT: The first ``Faust'' performance of this Metropolitan Opera season failed to enthrall. One wonders if it's partly because the scenery, new last season, grows on one in the wrong direction. The sets, changing by revolving on the Met's turntable, make the 16th century look like a desert with adobe buildings and ruins. Neil Rosenshein sang the title role acceptably on Monday night except for an irritating push on high notes that sounded more like a shriek than a ring. Diana Soviero didn't stir one as Marguerite. Best were James Morris, a deep, rich-voiced, nimble Mephistopheles, Gino Quilico, sounding warm and clear as Marguerite's brother Valentin, and Susan Quittmeyer, even more clear, as Valentin's friend Siebel. Quittmeyer, singing a young boy, has a warm voice that doesn't spread its tone. It's a happy-sounding voice that one could listen to a long time without tiring. Off stage, she is the wife of Morris. He was the only principal on Monday who sang his role when this production was new in February. Thomas Fulton conducted, sometimes swelling the orchestra over Rosenshein's singing. The lighting people were working doubletime as lighting effects changed by the minute. There also were some special effects for Mephistopheles, like a ring of fire and then smoke around him, his shadow which moved differently from him in the church scene, and blasts of fire during which he disappeared. Applause during the evening was polite rather than enthusiastic.

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Commandos Show Iraqis They Can Survive on Raw Rats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to DELETE extraneous word. ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: HAFR AL-BATIN, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Elite commandos from the Egyptian 3rd Army, which stunned Israel in 1973 by secretly crossing the Suez Canal, showed they can survive on anything - even raw rats. It wasn't surprising that the commandos successfully blew up three houses Monday and repelled an armored assault in simulated attacks against the Iraqis in the Saudi desert, about 30 miles from the Kuwaiti border. But the eight commandos showed the real Egyptian mettle when they tore into live rats, rabbits and chickens with gusto and ate them raw. ``If you're behind enemy lines, if you don't eat, you'll die,'' an Egyptian officer told Lt. Gen. Khalid Bin Sultan, commander of Arab-Islamic forces in Saudi Arabia. The general, swatting an occasional aggressive fly, sat cooly in a chair watching the desert survival feast. The meal started with a raw egg, quickly followed by a raw potato. Then came a cooked egg, wrapped in soil and baked by a blaze started with a rifle shot into a campfire doused with gasoline. Out of a carton, two commandos then pulled a pair of live chickens and proceeded to wring their necks. The commandos then pulled each chicken apart, feathers flying, and stuffed them into their mouths. Two live rabbits were skinned and similarly devoured. The final course was live rat, minus the tail. ``I love it,'' Prince Khalid, a nephew of King Fahd, said when asked how he liked the meal. ``That is a typical, standard function or capability which any Special Forces unit conducts - even in the United States, by the way.'' U.S. Special Forces teams are assigned to all Arab and Islamic forces under Khalid's command, but they operate in obscurity. Among other training drills, the teams have been trying to help coordinate U.S. air strikes with Arab ground operations. This was put to a test in Monday's exercise. U.S. A-10 anti-tank aircraft swooped in low over the simulated enemy column, which was also being attacked by Egyptian M60 tanks and 155mm howitzers. But the American attack planes only made a few passes, apparently flying off because they weren't expecting ground explosions. The Egyptian and Syrian armies, both battle-tested, are considered the toughest in the 110,000-strong Arab and Islamic force deployed in Saudi Arabia. Egypt's 20,000 troops include the 3rd Armored Division and the 3rd Mechanized Division, part of the 3rd Army which started the 1973 Mideast War but was eventually encircled by Israel and forced to retreat. Gen. Salah Mohammad Al-Halaby, the Egyptian commander, said his troops in Saudi Arabia were Egypt's best fighters. Prince Khalid told about 1,200 Egyptian troops sitting in the desert sun that the 1973 war ``restored the Arab dignity and destroyed the Israeli security theory and put an end to the concept of the undefeatable enemy.'' After his speech, the prince and his entourage drove a short distance to a carpeted tent for lunch. On the menu: traditional Arab food of roast goat and chicken and potatoes and tomatoes stuffed with ground meat and rice.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed, 20 Wounded in Gunbattle Between Former Contras and Army
DOC.TEXT: A battle between former Contras and the Sandinista soldiers left 11 dead and 20 wounded in the bloodiest such outbreak in months, the army said Monday. About 60 demobilized rebels seized a police post Sunday in Jalapa, 125 miles north of Managua, Col. Antenor Rosales said. The army drove out the former rebels and captured 30 of them in the fighting, Rosales said in an interview on state-run television. He gave no breakdown on the casualties or other details. The Contras, who fought the leftist Sandinista government during its 10 years in power, agreed to give up the fight in June after Violeta Chamorro was elected to the presidency and took office as part of a coalition. But the Contras claim Mrs. Chamorro has reneged on her promises to give them aid and land, and strong antagonism persists between the Contras and the Sandinista-controlled armed forces and police.

DOC.HEAD: NTSB Says Captain's Fatigue Caused Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: Government safety investigators say little can be done to force ship captains to rest, even as they ruled ``acute fatigue'' a primary cause of Rhode Island's worst oil spill. The National Transportation Safety Board said Monday that the captain of the Greek tanker World Prodigy had been on the bridge 35 consecutive hours when the ship ran aground off Newport, R.I., on June 23, 1989. But the agency said there is little the government can do to force ship captains of foreign-flag vessels to rest before reaching a U.S. port. ``Hopefully what we can do is attenuate foreign ship operators that fatigue is a major hazard to transportation safety,'' said NTSB Chairman James L. Kolstad. ``We see it in all modes of transportation. Clearly we saw it in this particular accident.'' The board unanimously approved a report detailing how ``acute fatigue'' led Capt. Iakovos Georgoudis to make a series of dubious orders and miscalculations in the hours leading up to the grounding. The spill of 289,000 gallons of No. 2 heating oil sent ribbons of pollution toward the Rhode Island coast in slicks as long as five miles. Shell fishing, swimming and pleasure boating were halted in some areas. The NTSB ruled out intoxication, drug use or crew incompetence as possible causes. Board staffers described Georgoudis as well-organized and conscientious but said his sense of duty led him to overwork. Georgoudis told investigators he took several short naps on the bridge but remained there because he was worried about the weather and heavy ship traffic. He had sent subordinates off the bridge to perform routine tasks and was himself distracted with cargo calculations as the ship approached the shallow water of Brenton Reef off Newport, R.I. Georgoudis was off by more than a half-hour in his estimate of when the tanker would arrive at its rendezvous point with a boat carrying the harbor pilot and also made a slight but crucial course miscalculation that sent the ship on the wrong side of a warning buoy, officials said. The NTSB said the Rhode Island State Pilotage Commission contributed to the spill by failing to require that harbor pilots notify inbound vessels of exactly where they plan to board ship and guide it into port. Had that been done, the board said, the tanker would have waited to take on an experienced local pilot before proceeding through the reef area. Vernon Dunlap, chairman of the pilotage commission disputed the NTSB conclusion. ``The vessels are always told that the pilot will board,'' Dunlap said. ``The problem here was that the vessel arrived 45 minutes early. (Georgoudis) arrived at the pilot boarding station and continued right across it.'' Attorney Thomas Walsh of the Boston law firm Bingham Dana & Gould, which represents tanker owner Ballard Shipping Co., said the NTSB appeared to be overplaying the fatigue issue. ``I don't know where in the record there's any evidence of `acute' fatigue,'' he said. The spill has spawned lawsuits against the shipper by the state, boaters, shell fishermen and others seeking damages totaling about $40 million. The suits have been consolidated into a single case pending in U.S. District Court in Providence. Ballard pleaded guilty to federal Clean Water Act violations and paid a $1 million fine. Georgoudis was fined $10,000.

DOC.HEAD: Outgoing Mayor Says He'll Remain a Public Servant
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, who leaves office next month facing a jail term for drug possession, says he intends to remain a public servant. ``After 30 years in public life, I will not change,'' Barry told city workers in a farewell address Monday. ``I will remain in that army of people committed to making a difference.'' In a speech both conciliatory and confrontational, Barry also warned against the evils of drug use and proudly outlined his accomplishments. Barry, who is appealing his conviction on a cocaine-possession charge and six-month prison sentence, said he is ``healthier today, clearer today than ever before in my life.'' ``We need to stop using cocaine and other illegal drugs,'' said Barry, who has admitted to alcoholism and dependence on two prescription drugs s well as occasional cocaine use. ``If we expect our children to forgo illegal drugs, we must not condone the use of legal ones ... like alcohol. ``I leave here with no regrets, but joy, and relief, quite frankly, that we can move on to a new life,'' the 12-year mayor said. ``We have fought the good fight.'' Barry, who does not yet have a job, has been exploring the possibility of a teaching position at the city-run University of the District of Columbia, aides said. In a reference to the racial divisions that his arrest and trial produced throughout the city, Barry urged residents of the nation's capital to ``put our hearts together in love - love for our city, love for our brothers and sisters of every race.'' But the mayor also assumed a defiant tone in highlighting the broadened involvement of minority-run businesses in the city's contracting procedures. ``Some people don't like what we are about,'' the former civil rights activist said in explaining his commitment to minority contracting. ``We have opened up the door of government to people who couldn't share in the process. ... That is a legacy no one can take away from us.'' And in an emphasis on healing political divisions, Barry also pledged his full support and cooperation for Mayor-elect Sharon Pratt Dixon. Barry was accompanied at the 45-minute speech by his wife Effi, who moved from the couple's home to a separate apartment several weeks ago. The mayor praised his wife as someone who has ``risen to the occasion and has basically written the book'' on how to be a good wife. Mrs. Barry, who is negotiating a contract to write a book about her life with the mayor, smiled at that remark.

DOC.HEAD: Economists See Fed Reducing Rates to Battle Recession
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve, which has already eased credit three times since late October, will reduce interest rates further in coming weeks as it battles what may turn out to be a worse-than-expected recession, many economists predict. These analysts, however, think the central bank will not move as aggressively to lower rates as the Bush administration would like because of lingering inflationary pressures stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis. The debate over how much and how fast to cut interest rates was expected to be the primary topic today when top Fed officials gathered behind closed doors for their final monetary strategy session of 1990. The minutes of those deliberations will not be released for six weeks, but in advance of the discussions, many economists were looking for a fourth modest step toward easing credit. ``The Fed has to ease because the economy looks so rotten,'' said David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. While the administration still says it is unclear whether the nation has entered a recession, economists said recent statistics showing a big jump in unemployment and a three-month slide in industrial production are unmistakable signs that a downturn has begun. ``I don't think there will be a doubt among members of the Fed that a recession has begun,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. ``The debate will come over how much more to do in light of what has already been done.'' In the past seven weeks, the central bank has pushed the federal funds rate down a quarter point three times, sending it from 8 percent to 7.25 percent. The funds rate is the interest that banks charge each other for overnight loans. Many economists believe the Fed will signal a desire to push the funds rate down another 0.25 percentage point but hold off doing so until after the report on the December jobless rate is released Jan. 4. That will give Fed policymakers time to assess other economic statistics, especially reports on whether inflationary pressures are subsiding. Some analysts suggested that the Fed may go further and cut the discount rate, the interest the central bank charges to make loans to commercial banks. A reduction in the discount rate is the most dramatic signal the Fed can send of its intentions to ease credit in order to boost economic growth. While analysts were in basic agreement that further small reductions in the funds rate would be coming in the months ahead, there was no consensus on whether the discount rate would be cut. Some economists argued that the Fed will be hesitant to cut the discount rate while inflationary pressures remain at current high levels. They said that overhanging all of the Fed's deliberations is the threat of war in the Middle East, which has the potential to send oil prices and inflation soaring. ``A war would be a very unfavorable environment for the Fed to be trying to ease domestic interest rates,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer. He said the Fed will likely make only modest easing moves until the situation in Middle East becomes clearer. Even if today's meeting produces nothing more than a small 0.25 percentage point cut in the federal funds rate, many economists said that would be enough to prompt banks to cut their prime lending rate from 10 percent where it has been stuck since last January. That would be good news for businesses and consumers because the prime rate is used as a base to calculate more than one-third of fixed-rate and adjustable-rate consumer and business loans. Wyss said he was also looking for mortgage rates, which dropped to a three-year low of 9.51 percent last week, to stay low but not fall much further, perhaps dropping to 9.25 percent by early spring.

DOC.HEAD: Little U.S. Government Money in Aid to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's aid program for the Soviet Union will cost U.S. taxpayers very little unless the Soviets fail to pay back the money they borrow from commercial banks, officials say. But a study due to be released this week concludes that massive Western aid would be wasted unless the troubled Soviet economic system is improved, official sources said Monday. Instead, the report recommends giving the Soviets help in carrying out fundamental economic reforms, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The study, conducted by the International Monetary Fund, World Bank and two European-based development groups, comes on the heels of a weekend summit at which Western leaders ordered $1 billion in emergency aid for the Soviets and approved spending more than that amount on technical assistance during the next two years. Last week, Bush promised a $1.3 billion loan guarantee package, including up to $1 billion to buy U.S. farm products and up to $300 million to purchase U.S. manufactured goods. The Soviets have been scrupulous about repaying their debts, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher said last week. ``Of course, we'd be liable if they default,'' Barbara Clay, a press officer at the U.S. Treasury, said Monday. Under the program outlined by Bush, the Soviets would borrow from commercial banks to buy the food and manufactured goods. The U.S. government contribution will consist of a guarantee for those loans: if the Soviets fail to repay in three years, the United States would pay the banks 98 percent of the principal and about half the interest. In addition, the U.S. Agency for International Development will coordinate medical aid to be provided by private organizations. The agency may help pay the private groups' administrative costs, AID spokesman John Riddle said. The Soviets have paid cash for billions of dollars worth of grain and other food bought from this country. The Commodity Credit Corporation, the U.S. agency that guarantees the loans for food purchases, said that without a government guarantee the Soviets might not be able to get the loans at all. ``Nobody wants to make a three-year loan on something that's going to be eaten up in a few weeks,'' explained Deputy Director Robert S. Simpson. The loan guarantees for manufactured goods will be offered through the government's Export-Import Bank. The bank has not lent to the Soviets since 1975. Bank spokeswoman Ann Frye said the loan guarantee would encourage commercial banks to give the Soviet Union better terms than it might otherwise get, including a break of up to 1 percent on the interest rate. The study's findings, according to the official sources, were pessimistic and depressing because they describe a system even more backward than expected and practically paralyzed by inefficiency and confusion. ``No amount of aid will make a real difference. The system simply cannot absorb it. The pipe is so porous that very little would reach its intended target,'' said Ilya Prizel of the Johns Hopkins School for Advanced International Studies. Prizel said ``a political statement'' in the form of food aid to help Soviets get through the winter might shore up President Mikhail S. Gorbachev or even help induce the kinds of reform that are necessary. But, Prizel said, ``what they need is technical assistance, everything from entrepreneurial and managerial assistance to logistical assistance, as well as traditional advice, such as how to set up a central bank.'' The Soviet currency, the ruble, is not traded on international exchanges and its value inside the country is in a free fall; the price of goods bears little or no relationship to the cost of production; inflation is accelerating at a pace difficult to measure; and manufacturing plants are almost universally old, inefficient and unable to compete in world markets.

DOC.HEAD: Subsidized Apartments Sit Empty While Need Escalates
With PM-Homeless Count, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Louvenia Lewis has been on the waiting list for a subsidized apartment for a year. The Boston Housing Authority tells her she'll have to wait at least 2{ years more. But Lewis, 52, a nurse's assistant and divorced mother of five boys, doesn't have that much time. Because her job was cut to part-time, her rent exceeds her income and the landlord is threatening eviction. It makes her even more anxious to know there are 1,630 subsidized aparments in Boston sitting empty, largely because there is little incentive to fill them. Public housing authorities get the same federal subsidy whether their buildings have vacancies or not, as long as they promise to fill them eventually. An estimated 1 million families nationwide are on waiting lists for subsidized housing, and more than 91,000 subsidized apartments are vacant - enough for nearly 220,000 people, or all the homeless in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles combined, according to figures from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. Many of the apartments need only routine maintenance. ``It's a scandal,'' said John Donahue, a spokesman for the Chicago Coalition for the Homeless. ``They have to open up those places.'' The nation's capital, for example, has 2,295 empty apartments, enough to accommodate 46 percent of the 12,000 people on the waiting list. Of those units, 1,697 are awaiting repairs. ``A small number of vacancies is normal,'' said Joseph Schiff, assistant secretary for public and Indian housing at HUD. ``This many vacancies is not.'' Schiff said HUD is pushing for an end to subsidies for empty units. In Boston, about 1,000 vacant apartments are awaiting renovations. ``It's a case of deliberately not wanting to fix them up,'' said Cushing Dolbeare, executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless. ``There are a lot of housing authorities that don't want to house a lot of homeless people.'' Housing administrators defend their handling of the vacancies. ``The problem is that when somebody doesn't give you the money to fix the unit, there is no great incentive to do anything about it,'' said Mike Nail, director of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials, an umbrella organization of public housing professionals. Boston housing officials say many apartments remain unoccupied because applicants reject them. Some reject high-rises because they are afraid the elevators will break down; others don't want small efficiency apartments, which account for three-quarters of the vacant units. Some shun public housing for fear of crime. ``Just because someone is low-income or homeless doesn't necessarily mean they can be forced to take any housing anywhere,'' said Dale Mitchell, the Boston Housing Authority's assistant administrator. HUD is urging an end to the practice of giving applicants a choice of assignments, but the housing officials say that would send the rejection rate skyrocketing and leave units empty even longer. ``Public housing authorities are getting beaten up because they can't fill these vacant units,'' said Nail. But he added, ``It's like triage. When you have a limited amount of resources, you have to decide how best to allocate those resources.'' In the meantime, some groups have taken matters into their own hands. Church volunteers started fixing up some of Chicago's 7,020 vacant apartments. In Boston, a non-profit agency has temporarily housed homeless elderly people in 16 empty public housing units it took over.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Fed-Interest Rates, PM-Bank Crisis
DOC.TEXT: ``The Fed has to ease (interest rates) because the economy looks so rotten.'' - David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. --- ``I don't think there will be a doubt among members of the Fed that a recession has begun. The debate will come over how much more to do in light of what has already been done.'' - Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. --- ``A war would be a very unfavorable environment for the Fed to be trying to ease domestic interest rates.'' - David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., a government securities dealer. --- ``A recession is going to have the impact of lowering inflation, but the size of improvement will be somewhat limited.'' - Economist John Silvia of Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago. --- ``Any strengthening of the Bank Insurance Fund can and should be financed by the banking industry, not by the American taxpayers.'' - L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., testifying before a House subcommittee. --- ``We need to make certain that the taxpayers of this nation ... are not asked to bail out the banks.'' - Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., chairman of the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Nature of Albania's Reform Unclear
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Stalinist Albania seems to have taken a giant step by permitting its first non-Communist party, but many emigres and others are skeptical the change is genuine or sufficient to contain popular anger. Caught between a reluctance to relinquish a 46-year monopoly on power and a desire to avoid mass violence, the Communist leadership has sent a series of contradictory signals in the past week. President Ramiz Alia, who a month ago denied any need for competing political parties, has now pledged that reform is irreversible. Yet his government has to date kept all but a handful of foreign journalists from reporting independently on the historic events in his land. It has also so far failed to accord the new Democratic Party of Albania legality. Appeals from the new party for calm appeared in official media during last week's riots in four cities, but media have not carried details of its program or profiles of its leaders. This puts the founders of the new party in a state of suspended animation: working furiously on a program, yet under pressure not to antagonize authorities apparently willing to take reform seriously. The founders' caution has also bred suspicion. ``We don't know who these people running the new party are,'' said an Albanian intellectual who recently fled to Greece and spoke on condition his name not be used. He noted that economist Gramoz Pashko, who has close ties to the Communist elite, helped found the new party. ``Just as in Romania and Bulgaria, the governing party is pretending to put on a new face to subvert opposition to it. The people rioting on the streets are the real opposition to the regime.'' In a country of 3.2 million people run for decades by a small, secretive elite, intellectuals have automatically enjoyed both privilege and close ties with the leadership. Yet they are among the few groups with the courage and power to organize in a country in which critics traditionally faced death or jail. And the mystery that surrounds so much of what happens in totalitarian countries means these intellectuals cannot be sure who was involved in last week's violence. Some echoed official language, talking of ``dark forces'' and hinting that what one called ``some kind of new dictator'' was behind last week's riots in Shkodra, Elbasan, Durres and Kavaje. Ismail Kadare, the renowned Albanian author who defected to Paris in October saying he despaired of seeing genuine democracy in Albania, told the French newspaper Le Figaro last week: ``I fear a counter-attack by conservative Albanian forces.'' If there is a power struggle between old-time Stalinists and reformers in the ruling Albanian Labor Party, last week's violence could have been provoked by the conservatives. Yet popular discontent at economic misery and decades of repression is so high that the protests likely were spontaneous outbursts, particularly in industrial centers like Elbasan, a city of 80,000 in central Albania with a huge steel mill employing some 15,000 workers. Elsewhere in the Balkans, similar mystery surrounds much of politics. To this day, for instance, debate rages in Romania over last year's ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu. Was it in fact engineered by disillusioned Communists and the military riding a wave of popular protest to seize control themselves, or was it the true result of a popular uprising? Even the legitimacy conferred by election victories on the ex-Communists who took over in Romania and Bulgaria this year has proved insufficient for them to forge the consensus needed for the harsh economic reforms they recognize as inevitable. Romania's president, Ion Iliescu, opened negotiations Monday on getting some opposition parties into the government. A coalition government is to take office in Bulgaria after strikes and economic chaos forced the Socialist government to resign. Albania's elections, scheduled for Feb. 10, will be a test of the Communist party's willingness to accept democracy. Again, this puts the new party in an awkward position. In a backward country with poor communications and limited resources all controlled by the Communists, the Democratic Party faces an unequal contest in February. Pashko said Monday that the new party has therefore asked for a postponement of the elections. But that carries the risk of popular anger rising beyond anyone's control. ``The reforms need to be realized in a short time,'' said Nedim Vlora, an Italian professor of Albanian origin at Bari university. ``The situation is desperate, and when a population is desperate, it attacks. It is essential that there be both economic and political reforms.'' Burhan Kalaya, who fled Albania for Italy three months ago, said relatives reached by telephone in the Albanian capital of Tirana paint a ``confusing'' picture of optimism about change and despair at food shortages and other hardships. Such confusion prompts calls for the clear commitment to change that Albania certainly must make if it is to meet the human rights standards of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe it says it wants to join. ``If they want us to believe in their claims of change, let them allow Christmas to be celebrated in religious ceremonies,'' said a prominent Greek Orthodox critic of Albania, Bishop Sevastianos of Konitsa, near the Greek-Albanian border. It is precisely such decisive acts, however, that seem to rankle Communists accustomed to decades of absolute power who fear the consequences if they let control slip from their hands. ---
EDITOR'S NOTE: Alison Smale, Vienna bureau chief of The Associated Press, has covered Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union since 1980. She recently spent a week on assignment in Albania.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco VDT Safety Law Wins Final Approval
DOC.TEXT: The nation's toughest law protecting users of video display terminals went to a noncommittal Mayor Art Agnos after winning approval from city supervisors, who called it cutting-edge legislation for a high-tech age. Union leaders and victims of VDT-related injuries cheered when the ordinance was approved 7-4 Monday. The Board of Supervisors approved it 8-1 in a preliminary vote last week. ``I'm ecstatic,'' said Becky Hogue, a Pacific Bell operator who wears plastic splints on her wrists because of weakness from years of using computer keyboards. ``I suffered so much, but now maybe others won't have to go through the same pain.'' The Chamber of Commerce opposed the measure, saying its high costs would drive businesses away. The law would force the city and businesses with 15 or more employees in San Francisco to spend millions to provide safer workplaces for people who use desktop computers at least four hours a day. Adjustable swivel chairs, glare shields, detachable keyboards, tables with sufficient leg space and special lamps are among items that would be required during the next two years. Violators would face penalties of up to $500 a day. VDT users would also be allowed 15-minute breaks every two hours, and an advisory committee would monitor information about the health effects of VDT use, including those from radiation. ``This is a message to the nation that this is the next wave of worker safety issues,'' said Supervisor Nancy Walker, who co-sponsored the ordinance. ``It has to start somewhere, and frequently things start at the local level since the federal and the state have not been able to do anything, really.'' Agnos said he supports the spirit of the measure but has misgivings about its cost. He has 10 days to act, during which time he plans to meet with business and labor leaders. If Agnos rejects it, the board needs eight yes votes to override his veto. ``I want to sign VDT legislation that both labor and business can hold up as a model. VDT legislation is an issue whose time has come,'' Agnos said. The only similar ordinance, passed in 1988 in Suffolk County on New York's Long Island and bitterly opposed by business owners, was overturned a year later by a state court on the grounds that the local government lacked authority to make such rules. That decision is under appeal. City budget analysts estimate businesses will spend $31.5 million to $76.5 million during the next two years to comply with the measure, while the city will spend $1.4 million to $6 million. Jim Lazarus, vice president of the Chamber of Commerce, said businesses need longer than two years to replace office furniture that doesn't meet the requirements. The VDT Coalition, which represents unions, computer workers and community groups, cited studies that show the law would save businesses money through increased productivity and reduced injuries.
