Among the problems associated with regular work at a computer keyboard are nerve damage to the wrists and fingers, back and neck strain, eyestrain, sleep disturbances, chronic headaches, nausea and fatigue. One case of a wrist ailment known as carpal tunnel syndrome can cost $70,000 when lost time and productivity are factored in, said Laura Stock of the Labor Occupational Health Program at the University of California at Berkeley.

DOC.HEAD: Braces and Plaster Body Parts: Homage to a Saint
LaserPhoto NU1
DOC.TEXT: A child's shoe peeling away from its 2{-inch-high wooden sole, an abdominal truss, metal leg braces and plaster body parts all hang in a small shrine here. ``I can remember, when I was real small they had all the crutches, the braces, all around the altar, tacked up there,'' said Albert Hattier, 61. They are offerings of thanks to St. Roch, who cared for victims of the Black Plague in the 1300s and himself survived the disease. The faithful left them at the National Shrine of St. Roch, built in 1875 after a yellow fever epidemic. The items include models of healed organs and braces and crutches left by people who no longer needed them. Similar offerings are found in a number of European churches in a practice that dates at least to the Middle Ages. ``These devotional offerings are a particularly Latin expression,'' said the Rev. John P. Ford, a historian at Catholic University in Washington. ``Other people ... will give a window or a pew or a pulpit or candlesticks.'' Catholic churches in many U.S. cities with large Hispanic congregations have special rooms for such ``milagros,'' said Leonardo R. Anguiano, a staff member at the Mexican-American Cultural Center in San Antonio, Texas. Most often, he said, they are tiny silver replicas of arms, legs, heads or other body parts. ``Sometimes they leave crutches, sometimes they give thanks with a wedding dress, sometimes with little baptismal outfits,'' he said. Those at the Shrine of St. Roch, situated in a poor and working-class neighborhood a few blocks outside the French Quarter, were moved from the altar in the 1950s during renovation to a tiny room next to the chapel. The room is paved with marble tiles, most inscribed ``Thanks'' or ``Merci.'' A few tiles show the cured part: a hand, a leg, a stomach. ``Thanks to St. Roch for my eye,'' reads the inscription on one. There is a 4-foot statue of St. Lucy, patron of people with eye troubles, in her traditional pose: a quill pen in her right hand and a pair of eyeballs - anatomically correct down to the optic nerves - on a plate in her left hand. Hattier, whose grandfather was superintendent of the adjacent cemetery and who was himself superintendent from 1953 to 1985, said a second, full-sized statue in the room is that of a woman who was cured after praying to St. Roch. ``I think she had arthritis or something like that,'' he said. Other hooks hold doll parts and feet, hands, a leg, an ear, a breast and even a brain made of plaster. A tag reading ``Hector A. Boesch. Gratitude'' is pinned to St. Lucy. A pair of eyes is scratched on a smaller tag hung with it. Boesch, 50, said his mother left the tags. He credited his doctor with saving his eyesight after a scratched cornea became infected in 1974 but said prayer may have helped him recover from an aneurysm a year earlier. ``While I was under the knife at East Jefferson Hospital, the doctors gave up on me,'' he said. ``I think ... the power of St. Roch and some of the saints of my mother and grandmother who prayed for me may have helped.'' ``Personally, I think it's a little superstitious,'' said Boesch's sister, Liz Miranda, 41. ``But if it makes them feel a little better, why not?''

DOC.HEAD: Attacks Prompt Anguished Question: Punishment Or Compromise
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For nearly three years, the Palestinian uprising consisted mainly of street battles in the occupied territories, a war of stones far removed from most Israelis' daily lives. But a series of fatal stabbings on the streets of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem has brought the Arab revolt closer to home. Growing fear among Israelis has prompted calls for harsh punishment of Arabs who attack Jews. It also has renewed debate over whether Israel should continue to occupy the West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. The independent Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth called this week for a solution ``based on physical separation between us and the Palestinians.'' The leftist Al Hamishmar said legislators' calls for the death penalty and massive Arab expulsions would only worsen the conflict. ``The only solution lies in a separation of the two nations and a political settlement, which the government has been unable to reach,'' the paper said in an editorial. Few believe the right-wing government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is prepared to yield any of the territory captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. Only recently Shamir spoke of his Likud bloc's historic commitment to keeping all the land from the Mediterranean to the Jordan River. But leftist Parliament member Dedi Zucker, who advocates trading land for peace, believes growing anger and fear over the stabbings are shifting public opinion toward getting rid of the territories. ``I can't remember in the last 10 years when my argument was accepted so well among people that I meet,'' Zucker said in an interview. ``They say, `Yes, there is no hope for us living together.''' He warns that if a peace process is not launched soon, the anti-Israeli attacks may accelerate. ``I fear in the coming year we may witness some horrendous, horrible terror activity,'' Zucker said. It will be born, he said, out of ``Palestinian desperation, a lack of hope.'' From the December 1987 start of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation, leaders of the revolt discouraged the use of firearms and attacks on Jews inside Israel. But the guidelines began collapsing after the Oct. 8 riots on Jerusalem's Temple Mount, in which 17 Palestinians were killed by police gunfire. The fundamentalist groups Islamic Holy War and Hamas, or Zeal, have since urged armed revenge for the deaths. Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab said the massive use of live ammunition by police on people armed only with stones had made many ordinary Arabs feel restraint on their part was useless. ``Some people now feel they can cross the green line,'' he said in a reference to the pre-1967 demarcation between Israel and the territories. Since Oct. 8, seven Jews have been stabbed to death and at least 19 wounded in attacks by Palestinians inside Israel. Palestinian anger over the Temple Mount incident also has strengthened support for fundamentalist Moslem groups, which advocate the destruction of Israel, at the expense of the Palestine Liberation Organization, which has been pushing for a two-state solution. ``I am hoping the Israelis decide to do something with a credible organization that still has some weight or face the possibility it will be left with organizations it cannot deal with,'' Kuttab said. Instead of compromise, however, right-wing politicians have responded to the latest attacks by urging even stiffer retaliation against Palestinians. After Hamas claimed responsibility for the latest stabbing deaths of three Israelis last week, the government ordered the deportation of four Hamas leaders and the arrests of hundreds of Moslem activists. Defense Minister Moshe Arens promised that the deportations ``will not be the last,'' and Science Minister Yuval Neeman urged expelling 1,000 uprising ``ringleaders.'' Others demanded banning all 110,000 Palestinian workers from entering Israel. Israeli military analyst Zeev Schiff believes such tactics will backfire. ``Israel is still at the stage where many in the public feel that an angry reply will solve the problem,'' he wrote in the daily Haaretz. ``But it is clear that we are nearing a critical stage, where more and more people will understand that it is impossible to solve a civil war through military means only and that we need aggressive political steps.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Eileen Alt Powell has been a correspondent in the AP's Jerusalem bureau for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Winery Worker Sentenced to Gas Chamber in Rampage
DOC.TEXT: A winery employee who shot and stabbed to death six relatives and a co-worker in a rampage last year was sentenced to the gas chamber after a plea from his father-in-law for swift and certain justice. ``Why drag this thing out for years?'' Robert Richards asked at Ramon Salcido's sentencing Monday. ``He admitted he did it. He's showed no remorse.'' Salcido, 29, was convicted Oct. 30 of the 1989 murders of his wife, mother-in-law, two daughters and three others in California's wine country. He slit his daughters' throats and left them for dead at a dump; one, now 4, survived. Under California law, the case will be automatically appealed. California has not executed anyone since 1967. About 280 prisoners are on death row. Richards, taking advantage of a California law that lets crime victims address the court prior to sentencing, urged Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell to follow the jury's recommendation for the death penalty. ``What a coward,'' Richards said. ``He ambushed a man, and besides that he's a killer of women and children. What is that? What kind of man was this?'' Salcido showed no emotion as the sentence was announced. The Mexican-born defendant said through a translator that the slayings occurred ``at a time or a moment when I was drugged or intoxicated. I do not recall what I did.'' ``I ask everyone to forgive me for the things that I have done and all the grief that I have caused the family,'' he said. Prosecutors said that Salcido was angry at his wife because their first child was fathered by another man. Salcido was captured near his birthplace in Los Mochis, Mexico, within a week of the slayings. The judge rejected a defense request to delay sentencing until Jan. 17 to let Mexican officials prepare a request that Salcido's life be spared under a no-death clause in Mexico's extradition treaty with the United States. Slain were Salcido's wife, Angela; daughters Sofia and Teresa, 4 years old and 22 months; his mother-in-law, Marian Louise Richards; sisters-in-law Ruth Richards, 12, and Marie Richards, 8, and winery supervisor Tracy Toovey. Only Salcido's daughter Carmina survived the rampage.

DOC.HEAD: Former Tennessee Governor Nominated Education Secretary
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Lamar Alexander, a former governor and president of the University of Tennessee, may well be the man who can make George Bush the education president, say those who know him. Even detractors of his reform programs credit Alexander with generating interest in improving public schools and higher education in Tennessee, where as many as one in five adults is functionally illiterate. Bush on Monday nominated Alexander, a 50-year-old lawyer and son of teachers, as education secretary. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Lauro Cavazos, who was forced to resign last week. ``No governor in the country is so clearly identified with the imperative to improve education in America,'' the president said. He said the former two-term governor was ``at the forefront of the movement to restructure our nation's schools.'' Relzie Payton, president of the 42,000-member Tennessee Education Association, praised Alexander's education efforts - with some reservations. Bush ``evidently lacks the basic knowledge of what it takes to be education president,'' she said. ``Lamar Alexander, I think, has a basic understanding. He made education a No. 1 issue and it became the discussion item on everybody's agenda.'' ``For that we can say, `Hooray,''' she said. Alexander said that as education secretary he will work to improve the nation's grade schools and training and adult education opportunities for American workers who need new skills for the changing workplace. Alexander entered politics as an aide to Sen. Howard Baker of Tennessee and later worked as an aide in the Nixon White House. He won the governorship on his second try in 1978, serving until 1986. State law prevents a third term. He has been president of the 40,000-student University of Tennessee since 1988. Education was the cornerstone of his second term as governor. His $300 million Better Schools program, outlined in 1983, gave teachers higher pay based on their education levels and performance, expanded basic education curriculum, put computers in junior high schools and added more math and science teachers. In 1986, he finished second to Massachusetts' Michael Dukakis as the most effective governor in a survey by Newsweek magazine. Doubts now are being raised about the Better Schools program's effectiveness, particularly the merit raises. A recent study also suggested the program was biased toward whites and women. Ms. Payton complained Alexander failed to consult her organization before launching it in 1984. Alexander on Monday refused to state his views on a government ruling that would deny federal funds to colleges that grant scholarships based on race. But he noted that the University of Tennessee offers scholarships to poor, minority students, and said, ``My general disposition would be that when you're wandering through constitutional thickets, that a warm heart and a little common sense sometimes are helpful.'' Praise for Alexander's nomination was quick and widespread. - Richard F. Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, called Alexander ``one of the best people in the country'' in background and understanding of education. - Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said he hoped Alexander would not be as zealous as others in the Bush administration in pushing ``school choice'' as the key to reform. ``School choice'' lets parents decide which school to send their children to. - Ernest Boyer, head of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, said, ``Every signal suggests that not only does he have strong commitment but a realistic sense of what the priorities should be. It seems to me that he's looked at reform more broadly. There is nothing in his past record to suggest that he'd be narrow or ideological.'' Alexander received a law degree at New York University and later supplemented his income as a law clerk in New Orleans by playing the trombone in a Dixieland band at night. He has known Bush since 1968 and was once touted as his 1988 running mate.

DOC.HEAD: `Home Alone' First for Fifth Straight Week; `Havana' Bombs
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: ``Home Alone'' had first place all to itself at the nation's box office, while the blockbuster ``Ghost'' drifted out of the top 10 for the first time in nearly six months. ``Home Alone,'' a comedy about a twerpy kid left home while his parents go to Paris, earned $11.6 million over the weekend. It has been the nation's most popular movie for five straight weeks, Exhibitor Relations Co. reported Monday. The film passed the $100 million mark Monday after making $99.3 million through the weekend. No film since last year's ``Look Who's Talking'' has held first place for so long. Meanwhile, Robert Redford's ``Havana,'' set during the Cuban revolution, opened shakily, making just $2.2 million for ninth place. ``Ghost,'' the supernatural tearjerker starring Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore, fell from the top 10 for the first time in 23 weeks. It was 13th, with $840,508, for a whopping total of more than $200 million. In second place for the weekend was the poorly reviewed sequel ``Look Who's Talking Too,'' making $8.1 million in its premiere. It stars John Travolta and Kirstie Alley and features the voices of Bruce Willis and Roseanne Barr. In third was the romantic fable ``Edward Scissorhands.'' Starring Johnny Depp as a young man with shears for hands, it made $6.3 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Home Alone,'' 20th Century Fox, $11.6 million, 2,017 screens, $5,760 per screen, $99.3 million, five weeks. 2. ``Look Who's Talking Too,'' Tri-Star, $8.1 million, 1,576 screens, $5,140 per screen, $8.1 million, one week. 3. ``Edward Scissorhands,'' 20th Century Fox, $6.3 million, 1,023 screens, $6,183 per screen, $6.6 million, two weeks. 4. ``Dances With Wolves,'' Orion, $4.5 million, 1,196 screens, $3,739 per screen, $38.4 million, six weeks. 5. ``Misery,'' Columbia, $4 million, 1,302 screens, $3,074 per screen, $26.1 million, three weeks. 6. ``Mermaids,'' Orion, $3.515 million, 920 screens, $3,820 per screen, $3.5 million, one week. 7. ``The Rookie,'' Warner Bros., $3.513 million, 1,862 screens, $1,887 per screen, $10.9 million, two weeks. 8. ``Three Men and a Little Lady,'' Disney, $2.7 million, 1,286 screens, $2,116 per screen, $39.8 million, four weeks. 9. ``Havana,'' Universal, $2.2 million, 824 screens, $2,640 per screen, $2.3 million, 1{ weeks. 10. ``Predator II,'' 20th Century Fox, $1.2 million, 1,312 screens, $898 per screen, $25 million, four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Priest Says if Elected, He Wants to Improve Life for the Poor
With PM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, likely the next occupant of the Presidential Palace, is for Haiti's impoverished masses a savior come to deliver them from their misery. The 37-year-old priest has enormous support from the people and has promised to sweep out tyranny and usher in an era of democratic rule. But he is loathed by many of Haiti's traditional power brokers: the army, the business community, rural landowners and Roman Catholic and Protestant church leaders. Opponents see him as a populist demagogue whose presidency poses the threat of a theocratic dictatorship. Although official returns were not expected until late today, international observers said Aristide was projected to win Sunday's elections - the country's first-ever democratic vote. The priest has said his mission is to make life better for the poor - the slum dwellers and peasants he has associated with for years. He is slight, bespectacled and soft-spoken, yet capable of crowd-rousing oratory. For years he preached to the poor from a church in the capital's slums. He shared his feelings, telling his parishioners when he was depressed, shedding tears publicly without shame. He operated a home for street-hardened boys. He first decided to run for president to counteract the candidacy of Roger Lafontant, self-proclaimed chief of the dreaded Tonton Macoute militia used by the Duvaliers to terrorize the populace into submission. Lafontant, later disqualified from running, calls Aristide a Communist and has said he will block his way to the presidency. Born the son of peasants in the southern coast town of Port Salut, Aristide was sensitized at an early age to the country's stark poverty by the Roman Catholic Salesian Order. He joined the order in 1982, and was ousted in 1988 for allegedly fomenting revolution. Aristide is an advocate of Liberation Theology, a belief popular among Third World priests that the church should be involved in the struggles of the poor. He remains a priest, but cannot lead Mass or deliver radio sermons. Under Vatican regulations, priests cannot hold public office and Aristide has said he would quit the priesthood if he won the election. ``Jesus was not a priest. He was a man fighting for justice,'' he said recently. ``Aristide is the figurehead of a messianic movement, the incarnation of a collective dream,'' says Laennec Hurbon, a specialist on religious movements in the Caribbean. ``His responsibility to his following is not the same as that of a politician to his constituency.'' Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights activist and former priest, called Aristide a ``great communicator.'' ``Aristide is a poet; nourished by biblical imagery, he is a master of the vernacular Creole,'' he said. ``Unlike the other candidates who told the people what they thought, he helped the people express themselves.'' Aristide gained a nationwide following from radio broadcasts of his strident sermons against successive military regimes that have ruled Haiti since Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled the country in 1986. He has been the target of three assassination attempts, most recently in 1988 when army-backed thugs stormed his Saint Jean Bosco church during Mass and killed at least 12 parishioners. Aristide has not outlined a political agenda to carry out his campaign promises. Playing on messianic symbolism and patriotic fervor, Aristide has stumped nationwide. He calls his campaign Operation Lavales, or ``Torrent.'' Its emblem is the fighting cock, which represents Haiti's coming sunrise.

DOC.HEAD: De Maiziere: From `Hero' to `Spy' in The Blink of an Eye
DOC.TEXT: Lothar de Maiziere, who a year ago led East Germany to democracy and unity with the west, has resigned from the reunited nation's first government following allegations that he was once a police informant. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said Monday there were ``indications'' de Maiziere and a man code-named in files of East Germany's Stasi secret police as ``Czerny'' were one and the same. He said there was no proof, however, that de Maiziere knowingly worked for the secret police of the former Communist nation. De Maiziere has denied the charges, but resigned from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government as minister-without-portfolio and said he would not be a member of Kohl's new Cabinet. He kept his seat in the new Germany Parliament, but resigned his leadership positions in the Christian Democratic party. The resignation of the soft-spoken de Maiziere, who often said he preferred playing viola to playing politics, illustrates how hard it will be for the united nation to escape the repercussions of East Germany's past. As one of Germany's truly historical figures, the man who built and held together former East Germany's young, fractious democracy is by far the biggest casualty so far. But he was not the first and likely won't be the last. De Maiziere, a professional viola player in East German orchestras during the 1960s, spent most of his adult life as a lawyer under the old Communist regime. A deeply religious man, he made a name for himself by defending concientious objectors and political dissidents. He also was a member of the Christian Democrats, an approved, relatively ineffectual party that received money from the Communist government but put forth an image of independence. In November 1989, after the Communist hard-liners were ousted by the peaceful revolt, he was chosen to lead the party as it tried to remake itself in the image of its West German namesake. When the Communists agreed to free elections in March, de Maiziere's party formed a coalition with two other conservative parties and began advocating swift unity with West Germany. Another lawyer, Wolfgang Schnur, was chosen to lead the coalition, but Schnur resigned March 14, four days before the elections, amid allegations he, too, had been an informant for the secret police. De Maiziere, 50, was hastily chosen to replace him and led the coalition to resounding victory. After German unification on Oct. 3, de Maiziere was among four East German officials added to Kohl's expanded Cabinet. One day after the election, new reports surfaced alleging that de Maiziere had been a paid Stasi informant who even had an identity card and a code name. The government said Monday the evidence was inconclusive, but accepted his resignation. Schaeuble said the investigation would continue. The Stasi had hundreds of thousands of informants who spied on their colleagues in government, factories, offices and schools. Non-conformists were harassed, intimidated and denied decent wages. Former Stasi agents often claim they should not be singled out because virtually everyone in a position of influence or privilege worked with them. Eastern German politicians have said privately that the Stasi spent the waning days of Communist rule concocting false information intended to implicate prominent people.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech NASA Can't Keep Its Buildings in Good Repair, Report Says
DOC.TEXT:
NASA can't keep its earthbound buildings in good repair, according to a governmental report. The space shuttle's garage leaks; high voltage transformers are corroded; one cooling tower collapsed from an accumulation of ice, and faulty wiring caused a fire in a control room - all because of poor maintenance, the congressional General Accounting Office said Monday. NASA has given little priority to preserving its facilities, most of which are at least 30 years old, and ``there is no standard maintenance system within NASA,'' the study said. ``Many of NASA's facilities have not been adequately maintained and are in degraded conditions,'' it continued. ``In addition, several serious incidents have been caused by the facilities' deterioration, including a fire and a steam line explosion.'' John E. O'Brien, assistant deputy administrator of NASA, called the report ``a useful assessment'' and said the agency is in the process of correcting the problems.
---
DOC.HEAD: Accord Could Double Emigration of Ethiopian Jews
DOC.TEXT:
The Marxist government of Ethiopia has reached an agreement with the United States and Israel to more than double the number of Jews it allows to emigrate. Under the agreement, reached last month in the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa, President Haile Mengistu Mariam will allow up to 1,000 Jews to leave for Israel every month, officials said Monday. A previous agreement, negotiated by Israel last year after it resumed diplomatic ties with Ethiopia, allowed 400-500 to leave every month but was violated by Mengistu last summer. From July through October, no Jews were allowed to leave. Israeli and U.S. officials estimate some 20,000 Jews are stranded in Addis Ababa, after trekking there from their homes in northern Ethiopia to escape famine and civil war and await flights to Israel. Activists in Israel claim some 250 of their brethren have died of disease and hunger while waiting.
---
DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Attacks Capital Powerbrokers
DOC.TEXT: New York Gov. Mario Cuomo maintains the nation is in a recession as a result of 10 years of Republican economic policies and argues that only the federal government can spur a recovery. ``The states have done all they can'' to raise taxes and cut services, the three-term Democrat said Monday in a speech at the National Press Club. ``Don't tell me it's hard. I know it is. But that's why you're there,'' he said of policy-makers in the White House and Congress. ``It is not a lack of options. It is not a lack of ideas. ... It is simply unwillingness so far to make the hard decisions.'' Cuomo, who has been on the short list of presidential possibilities for six years, said the nation failed in the 1980s to respond to crack, AIDS, homelessness and an eroding education system. He lambasted the ballooning deficit during the decade and the annual interest bill country must pay on the $3 trillion national debt. ``That's the part that gets me and most governors,'' he said. ``That's $200 billion that doesn't put a computer into the hands of one child, doesn't fund one hour of research, doesn't provide a single meal for one hungry person.'' Cuomo said the supply-siders of the 1980s ``really did think that all you needed was capital'' to create economic growth and prosperity. He called those policies simplistic and unfair and said they left the nation fundamentally weakened. ``It is time for the captain to change course,'' he said of President Bush, adding that investment is needed in the labor force of the future as well as in bridges, roads, technology and energy. Cuomo made a point of saying he supports Bush's posture in the Persian Gulf. ``I do believe he needs to go to Congress (before starting a war), but he has not ruled that out,'' the governor said.

HBO Pictures has begun filming a movie about former White House spokesman James Brady and his fight for survival after being shot during the 1981 attempt on President Reagan's life. Beau Bridges of ``The Fabulous Baker Boys'' plays Brady in the film, whose working title is ``The James Brady Story.'' Crews filmed the assassination scene Monday, and on Wednesday they're scheduled to simulate the presidential motorcade. Brady and his wife, Sarah, are consultants on the movie. ``Primarily, it is the story of Jim's and my family getting through the trauma, more than the handgun-control aspect of it,'' said Mrs. Brady. ``But I think it will probably bring a lot of attention to the subject.'' Brady was struck in the head by a bullet that nearly killed him and left him with permanent impairment of his mobility and speech. Reagan fully recovered from wounds he suffered in the attack by John Hinckley Jr. --- PARIS (AP) - Britain's Prince Charles, a harsh critic of modern architecture, told French Culture Minister Jack Lang he admired columns installed at the Palais Royal in 1986. Charles found the columns by Daniel Buren ``very beautiful and very strong,'' Lang said Monday after he met with the prince. The contemporary-style columns have generated lively praise and criticism since their installation. The Culture Ministry is at the Palais Royal. ``The prince's taste is more toward preservation of the tradition, but he has a certain receptivity to the modern,'' Lang said. The two discussed the renovation of the Tuileries Garden in Paris and the ambitious France Library project under way. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Conductor Kurt Masur, named in April to direct the New York Philharmonic, will begin a season earlier than expected. ``I am very happy,'' Masur, 63, said Monday. ``It means we have no time in between to wait for something.'' Masur, also music director of the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, Germany, and a guest conductor of the London Philharmonic, was to begin in the 1992-93 season. Instead, he will conduct opening night next fall and the first and third weeks of the season, which were to have been conducted by Leonard Bernstein. He died earlier this year. Masur will conduct nine more weeks during the season. Masur is here to conduct Mendelssohn's ``Elijah'' this week. It was to have been led by Bernstein. Zubin Mehta, the current music director, leaves at the end of this season. ``Until now I felt like a burglar breaking into the musical life of an orchestra,'' Masur said. ``Zubin and myself are very good friends but I didn't want to disturb.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - With the Joffrey Ballet $1.8 million in the hole and attendance slumping, director Gerald Arpino was on the verge of getting the ax, but he decided to wait it out for ``the principle of the thing.'' Wages were frozen, production costs slashed and fewer engagements were made. Box office receipts have increased with ``The Nutcracker Suite.'' Now Arpino has managed to reduce the ballet's debt to $800,000. ``Business is not as usual,'' he said. ``It can never be that again because we now have recognition of our ideals.'' Arpino founded the dance troupe in 1955 with the late Robert Joffrey.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer 6 the Oldest Operating Spacecraft After 25 Years
DOC.TEXT: Pioneer 6, built to study the sun for six months, is still doing its job 25 years later, offering critics of NASA's whiz-bang ``superprojects'' proof that simple is better. ``After 25 years, we are relearning the importance of simplicity and reliability, and the value of science as the focus of the American space program,'' said Rep. George Brown, incoming chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology. The California Democrat spoke Monday as NASA and TRW Inc., which built Pioneer 6, held a day-late anniversary celebration of the spacecraft's Dec. 16, 1965, launch from Florida. Pioneer is now the oldest operating spacecraft. The barrel-shaped $6 million spacecraft compares favorably with ``helicopters that fall out of the sky and amphibious assault vehicles that sink,'' said Fred Wirth, Pioneer 6 deputy project manager. ``The government does sometimes purchase things that work, and Pioneer 6 is one of them.'' The 140-pound spacecraft provides lessons for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, bedeviled by problems with the Hubble Space Telescope, shuttles and other ``huge superprojects,'' said Brown, whose committee oversees NASA. He said the simple-is-better view of the space program was confirmed by last week's report from a government advisory panel. The group said NASA must focus on unmanned scientific spacecraft and put less emphasis on the shuttle, manned planetary missions and the proposed space station and aerospace plane. Pioneer 6, which was 131.9 million miles from Earth on Monday, ``has traveled 15.4 billion miles without a single stop at a service station,'' costing a measly four-hundredths of a cent per mile, said TRW spokeswoman Montye Male. Pioneer 6 was built to serve as ``a solar weather station'' and make the first detailed measurements of the sun's atmosphere. It collected information about solar flares, allowing the government to protect astronauts from intense radiation outbursts and to predict disturbances that periodically disrupt communications and electric power grids on Earth. It also studied the back side of the sun for the first time, measured solar wind speeds of 1.44 million mph, tested Einstein's theory of relativity, helped track sunspot cycles and in 1973 measured the tail of Comet Kohoutek. To observe Pioneer's anniversary, a NASA tracking station at Goldstone, Calif., tuned into Pioneer's radio signal for about 90 minutes Monday. A computer converted the normally inaudible signal into rapid-fire beeping played at news conferences at the California Museum of Science and Industry in Los Angeles and at Ames Research Center in Mountain View, near San Francisco. In Los Angeles, officials also cut a big yellow cake, which was frosted to look like the sun and had a Pioneer 6 model suspended above it. Three of Pioneer 6's six science instruments still work, although only two can be turned on simultaneously because the spacecraft's solar power cells are wearing out. Wirth said he couldn't predict how much longer Pioneer 6 will survive. Newer spacecraft have usurped much of Pioneer's value to scientists, and it sends data to Earth only about twice a year because of demands other spacecraft place on NASA's tracking stations.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Medication Records Often Err For Patients Over 65, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Hospital records often err in listing medications that patients older than 65 were taking before admission, posing a risk of serious treatment errors, a study suggests. Sixty percent of records in the study contained at least one error in listing ``important'' medications, and 18 percent had three or more errors. The analysis excluded over-the-counter drugs, cold medicines and medications applied to the body. When those drugs were included, 83 percent of hospital records contained at least one error. Mistakes in medication records mean patients may not be given drugs they need, or they may get unneeded drugs that cause harmful side effects, said researcher Dr. Mark Beers. He cited the case of a patient whose records failed to note she was taking an oral diabetes medication. The drug was not continued in the hospital until Beers pointed out the error, he said. Another patient was given a blood-thinning drug because his record said he was on the medication, when in fact the treatment had been stopped months before, Beers said. The error created a needless risk of bleeding, Beers said. ``We found some really clinically very important problems'' that could lead to complications, prolonged hospital stays and perhaps even death, said Beers, of the University of California at Los Angeles. ``I expected to find some errors, but the number of people involved and the quantity of errors and the kinds of drugs involved were much greater, much more serious than I had speculated,'' Beers said. The study appears in the November issue of the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society. The 60 percent error rate is high enough that ``I think every patient and every doctor would agree that's scary,'' commented Dr. Jerry Avorn of Harvard University Medical School, an authority on medication use by the elderly. While most such mistakes will not cause any trouble, the high frequency means ``it's just a matter of time and the law of probability that some unpleasant clinical outcome is going to occur,'' he said. Part of the problem is that ``physicians are not as preoccupied as we should be with taking a medication history,'' Avorn said. Another factor is that sick or injured patients are often unable to give a comprehensive list of their medications, Avorn and Beers said. Beers recommended that people of any age carry an updated list of current medications with them, including the name of each drug, the dosage and how often they take it. He also recommended that patients older than 65 be asked a second time about their current medication use a day or so after admission, by a nurse or pharmacist who can devote 15 or 20 minutes to a thorough interview. The study involved 122 randomly chosen patients who were admitted to a university hospital or a community hospital. Their average age was 77, and all were older than 65. The work focused on older people because they tend to use more medications than younger people, change prescriptions more frequently and are more vulnerable to side effects, Beers said. Researchers checked records written by doctors at the time of admission and then carefully interviewed the patients within two days of admission to get their own list of medications for comparison. For ``important'' medications, records for 52 percent of all patients omitted at least one drug, while records for 22 percent listed a drug that the patient was not actually taking. Omitting a drug not only means that a patient may not get a needed medication in the hospital, but it also deprives doctors of a clue to the patient's medical status, Beers said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Columbus Commission Under Financial Scrutiny
DOC.TEXT: The head of the presidential commission organizing the 500th anniversary celebration of Columbus' voyage to America says he has submitted his resignation amid questions about his and the panel's finances. John Goudie, a Miami Republican and real estate businessman, was quoted as saying in The New York Times today that he sent a letter to President Bush announcing his resignation from the unsalaried post. Goudie, who was appointed by President Reagan in 1985, denied any wrongdoing. ``It's time for me to bow out,'' he said, adding that the commision needed ``some favorable publicity.'' There was no immediate word on whether Goudie's resignation was accepted. White House spokesman Sean Walsh had no comment on the report. A House subcommittee has been looking at whether the Christopher Columbus Quincentenary Jubilee Commission has awarded contracts properly. Some of the arrangements under scrutiny involve friends of Goudie's, the Times said. The congressional panel plans to hold hearings next year into the running of the commission after an audit by the General Accounting Office, the newspaper said. The 5-year-old commission is $600,000 behind on an agreement with Spain, which has built replicas of the three ships Columbus led to the New World, because Texaco Inc., a main sponsor, has stopped its donations, the newspaper said. Texaco and Goudie said the money was halted because of a contractual dispute. Goudie said he is resigning because publicity over the Texaco incident has jeopardized a pledge from the Chrysler Corp. One member of the commission, Virgil Dechant of Hamden, Conn., said he knew nothing of a resignation by Goudie. Dechant said that to his knowledge, the commission had no particular financial problems. Another member of the commission, Mary Jane Checci of Washington, also said she knew nothing of a resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Comb Streets in Annual Homeless Count
DOC.TEXT: Scores of volunteers climbed through fences into vacant lots strewn with broken glass and searched rat-infested alleys early today in Boston's annual count of the homeless - the nation's only tally of its kind. Armed with walkie talkies, more than 100 volunteers set out at midnight and combed 35 zones in a count that helps other cities estimate their homeless needs. Another increase in the homeless population was expected this year. Homeless people encountered by the volunteers were often offered a bed or food. In most cases, the volunteers simply counted the bodies where they found them in subway stations, behind trash bins, on benches and roaming around. ``Hi, how are you? You wanna go to a shelter?'' Mayor Raymond Flynn asked a women curled up in the doorway of an ice cream store. Her puffed up face lay on a pile of possessions. ``No shelter,'' the elderly woman, named Suzy, replied, gripping her blanket in the relatively mild winter night. Temperatures were in the 30s. ``I see her there every night,'' said Flynn. ``She's mentally ill. She needs medication. You try to get her to go to a shelter and she'll get very, very violent.'' Suzy was marked on a chart, just one in the dozen street people he and three volunteers recorded in their zone. Flynn and other city officials said Boston is the only major city to hit the streets for a head count of its homeless. Officials combine the count with a survey of hospitals and shelters to calculate Boston's homeless population. The figures, which will be tabulated this week, are used to lobby for money, determine where to build shelters and develop services. ``We really make the promise no one will go without a shelter bed,'' said Ann Maguire, executive director of Boston's Emergency Shelter Commission, a city office. ``This is how we make sure we can accommodate all of them.'' In 1989, 3,830 homeless people were documented, an 11 percent increase over the previous year. Currently, $3 million is spent on beds and services for the homeless. Homeless advocates and city officials said there probably would be an increase in the number of homeless this year. Maguire said the past four head counts have accurately portrayed the homeless population. Last year, 128 men and 29 women were found on the street. `If we don't find too many homeless people on the streets, we feel we're successful at sheltering them,'' Richarch Weintraub, director of the city's three shelters. In a subway station, Flynn and the volunteers found a man in his 30s bundled in a coat and his arms curled around his head asleep at about 1 a.m. on a bench in a passage. Asked if he wanted to go to a shelter, he said, ``Leave me alone.'' Another man was propped up on a bench sipping coffee, holding a bag from a doughnut shop. Volunteers tried to get him to a shelter, but the man was incoherent. Other people showed signs of drinking. An intoxicated man was persuaded to enter a homeless shelter. Flynn's national Task Force on Hunger and Homeless is due to release a major study Wednesday. The mayor said it will show increased demands for things as simple as soup kitchens and bread lines and is likely to show a dramatic rise in the number of mentally ill homeless people. Flynn, a Boston native who knows many street people by name, covered Zone 13 without the help of a map. ``See these little cots?'' Flynn, said pointing to a row of foam rubber mats tucked behind a trash bin not far from the Combat Zone, the city's red light district. ``They hide their clothes here, their little goodies.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down Slightly, Stocks Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched down against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while share prices surged. The dollar closed at 133.03 yen, down 0.07 yen from Monday's finish of 133.10 yen. After opening at 133.17 yen, it stayed in a narrow range between 132.90 yen and 133.23 yen. Traders said there were no new factors to move the market. Spot trading totaled a slim $3.6 billion, down from Monday's $5.9 billion. ``It's difficult to sell, and it's difficult to buy. It's a totally uninteresting market,'' said Katsunobu Motohashi, a dealer at Yasuda Trust and Banking. With the Middle East situation still uncertain, market players were playing it safe before the Christmas holidays, he added. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues closed at 24,424.02 points, up 336.11 points or 1.40 percent from Monday's close. Volume on the first section was estimated at 350 million shares, up from the previous day's 277.8 million. Stronger bond prices and speculation that the Bank of Japan might ease credit encouraged buying, traders said. ``People are starting to believe that short-term rates are going to fall next year,'' said a dealer at a U.S.-based securities firm. The market's mood was boosted partly by the firmness of the Nikkei index, which remained above 24,000 points despite selling pressure Monday, traders said. ``The test now is how much we can stimulate the energy of the market,'' said a dealer at Cosmo Securities Co, who spoke on condition of anonymity. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 88.18 points as of 5 p.m. (3 a.m. EST) from Monday's 87.82-point close. Their yield stood at 7.030 percent, down from 7.100 percent on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Found Burned Beyond Recognition on Bridge
DOC.TEXT: Dental records were used to identify the body of a 15-year-old girl who was strangled and so badly burned that workers who found the corpse under a bridge thought it might be a mannequin, police said. Police said the body of Zipora Yagodajev was found Monday under the Williamsburg Bridge in Brooklyn. Detective Lisa Guerrero, a police spokeswoman, said there was evidence the girl had been sexually assaulted. The girl, an Israeli immigrant, disappeared Sunday after telling her mother she was going to a store, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Baker OKs European Talks With Iraq to Avoid War
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that he would not object to Europe-Iraq talks on the Persian Gulf crisis, and expressed confidence that European leaders will accept nothing short of a complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. The European Community was expected to decide later today whether to schedule a meeting between Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis, who would represent the EC. ``We support all diplomatic efforts to try and resolve this crisis peacefully and politically,'' Baker said as he entered NATO headquarters for the second day of meetings with other foreign ministers. He dismissed suggestions that such discussions would give Iraqi President Saddam Hussein the impression of a split in the alliance arrayed against Iraq. ``Those kinds of talks will not lead Iraq to think there's a division when the message continues to be the same message,'' Baker told reporters. On Monday, after Baker warned that Saddam might try to get the world to accept a partial pullout from Kuwait, the NATO ministers issued a communique saying they wanted Iraq's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. De Michelis had planned a meeting with Aziz in Rome after the Iraqi's scheduled talks in Washington with President Bush. But the Bush-Aziz talks, set for Monday, were scrubbed in a dispute over dates for a subsequent visit to Baghdad by Baker. The Iraqi government has asked De Michelis to agree to meet Aziz anyway. De Michelis refused to answer when asked about the meeting. Other ministers, including British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, said on Monday that they would prefer that Aziz make a stop in Washington first. The NATO foreign ministers' statement Monday said the gulf crisis can be settled peacefully only by a ``complete Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait.'' ``We have not decided to go to war,'' Belgian Foreign Minister Mark Eyskens said. ``We are all in favor of a peaceful solution. The choice between peace and war is in the hands of Iraq.'' All NATO allies except Iceland, Luxembourg, Germany and Turkey, have sent ground, air or sea forces to the gulf region. Turkey has reinforced troop deployments along its border with Iraq, and the other nations have provided aid to the gulf force. On Monday, Baker told NATO allies that Saddam he expects may pull some of his troops out of Kuwait by Jan. 15 - the U.N. deadline for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait - in an effort to split international opposition. ``We need to anticipate Saddam's possible moves, be prepared for a partial withdrawal ploy and coordinate closely our responses,'' Baker said at the start of the two-day meeting of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Baker also appealed Monday for more military and financial help to bolster the U.S. deployment in the gulf and economic aid for nations suffering from the crisis, most notably NATO member Turkey. Turkey borders Iraq and has suffered millions in trade losses because of the U.S. embargo against Baghdad. By mid-January, Washington will have deployed over 400,000 troops in the gulf region.

DOC.HEAD: School District Fights Lawsuit Brought By Ponytailed Boy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf to DELETE extraneous punctuation. Hearing begins 10 a.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: School district lawyers headed for court today to ask for dismissal of a lawsuit filed on behalf of a 8-year-old who has been banished to a classroom of his own for refusing to cut his 7{-inch ponytail. Zachariah Toungate has refused for almost three months to conform with school rules. School lawyers were to ask a state judge to dismiss a lawsuit filed by the boy's parents, who say the third-grader should be allowed back into class on the grounds the policy is discriminatory because it doesn't apply to girls. A state judge earlier denied a temporary injunction that would have allowed Zach back into class. School officials have kept the boy in an 11-by-13-foot windowless room dubbed ``an alternative education setting.'' He eats by himself, plays by himself, and, at a cost to the district of $35 a day, is given a substitute teacher. He has no physical education or music classes. Zach's grades haven't suffered because he is receiving individual instruction and has few distractions, school officials said. His mother said the isolation is wearing on him. ``It's getting real hard on him now,'' September Toungate said. ``He's real frustrated, but he says, `I want to keep my tail.''' School Superintendent Paul Flemming said last week, ``The question is not hair. The question is, are you going to allow a student to willfully violate a rule?''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Computer Chip Points to Libyan Connection
DOC.TEXT: A computer chip found in the wreckage of Pan Am Flight 103 suggests a Libyan planted the bomb that blew the plane out of the sky over Scotland, CBS says. British police discovered the evidence last summer while combing through the fields around the village of Lockerbie, where the plane crashed Dec. 21, 1988, the network reported Monday. All 259 people on board and 11 other people on the ground were killed. The computer chip, lodged in the bomb's detonator, matched a bomb part carried by a Libyan agent arrested in Dakar, Senegal, 10 months before the New York-bound Boeing 747 was destroyed, CBS said. ``It was constructed and put together in such a way as to have a Libyan signature to it,'' Vince Cannistraro, former chief of the CIA counter-terrorism section, told the network. Previously, investigators suspected the bombing had been carried out by a bomb-making cell based in Germany and acting on the orders of Ahmed Jibril, leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. In turn, investigators believed Jibril was working for Iran to avenge the deaths of 290 people aboard an Iranian jetliner shot down in the Persian Gulf in July 1988 by the USS Vincennes. But investigators have concluded Jibril had to change operatives when his German bomb-making cell was uncovered by German police, and that he turned to the Libyans, according to CBS. The evidence, according to the unidentified investigators, is the computer chip, which is different from those the Jibril bombmakers were known to use. They used a switch triggered by the plane's altitude; the Lockerbie bomb was a Swiss-made timing device of the type traced to the Libyan agent, the report said. In addition, the Toshiba radio preferred by the German bomb-making cell for concealing explosives was a single-speaker model, while the Lockerbie bomb, parts of which were in the wreckage, was a twin-speaker model, CBS said. The Libyan operative was spotted in Malta one month before the Lockerbie bombing, CBS reported. The radio bomb was put aboard an Air Malta flight there and later transferred to Pan Am 103, it said. A Libyan connection was also reported last week in the London newspaper The Independent, which quoted unidentified high-level sources close to the inquiry into the crash. Asked about the Independent report on Friday, a spokesman for Scotland's senior law officer, the Lord Advocate, declined to comment on what he called ``media speculation.'' Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt, Germany, changing planes at London's Heathrow Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted in Slaying Prompted by Belch Over the Phone
DOC.TEXT: A man was convicted of killing another man in a feud that began a month earlier when the victim belched at him over the phone. Wayne S. Davis, 26, was found guilty of murder Monday by Circuit Judge J. Warren Stephens and could get up to 22 years in prison at sentencing next month. Davis shot Howard R. Helmick, 22, on March 22 while Helmick was hitting the defendant's car with a baseball bat. ``He started it by burping,'' Davis testified. ``He stuck his nose in my business.'' According to testimony, Davis' relationship with his girlfriend was souring when he called her apartment on Feb. 26 to talk about it. A friend of the woman, Tanya Wright, testified that she and Helmick, her boyfriend, were at the apartment and that Helmick took the telephone and burped into it, then hung up. Ms. Wright said that a few minutes later, Davis kicked in the door to the apartment and asked, ``Who burped on the phone?'' She said Helmick admitted he was responsible, and a fight ensued. Witnesses testified that over the following weeks, the two continued to argue.

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Killed In Mine Explosion, 10 Still Trapped
DOC.TEXT: Rescue teams worked today to free 10 miners trapped underground by a coal mine explosion near the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator that killed 12 miners and injured at least 30, news reports said. The Mongolian newspaper Unen said the cause of Monday's explosion was not known. A Mongolian Embassy spokesman in Beijing said government investigators had been sent to the mine in the town of Nalaikh, just east of the capital Ulan Bator, to determine what caused the explosion. The embassy spokesman, who did not give his name, said 12 people were killed. A source in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator said rescue teams were trying to reach 10 trapped miners. China's official Xinhua News Agency said a 32-member rescue team from a Soviet mine in eastern Siberia was sent to assist in rescue efforts. Xinhua said the coal mine is 60 years old, with an annual production of about 600,000 tons.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed today in quiet, early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said they expected the dollar to remain in a narrow range until the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. ``The dollar continues to be underpinned by war talk, and until that gets out of the way I don't think that a further move downward will happen,'' said Peter Kane, chief corporate dealer at Credit Suisse in London. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.07 yen to a closing 133.03 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 133.10 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: -1.4880 German marks, up from 1.4867 -1.2745 Swiss francs, down from 1.2747 -5.0683 French francs, up from 5.0578 -1.6760 Dutch guilders, unchanged -1,124.35 Italian lire, up from 1,122.75 -1.1575 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1572 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9310, up from $1.9290 late Monday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $376.00 per ounce at midmorning, down from $377.00 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $375.90, down from $377.00 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 37 cents to close at a bid $377.31. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $3.97 a troy ounce, from Monday's $3.96.

DOC.HEAD: Youth Gets 38 Years For Pelting Motorists With Rocks
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager convincted of hurling rocks at passing motorists on the Capital Beltway last May has been sentenced to 38{ years in prison. Prince George's County Circuit Judge William Missouri on Monday sentenced John L. Burgess, 18, of Forest Heights, on a total of eight felonies and 28 misdemeanors. ``You are young, and it grieves me now that I must impose this sentence upon you,'' said Missouri. ``But it also grieves me that Destiny Morris will never rise above the (mental abilities) of a third- or fourth-grader,'' Missouri said. Miss Morris, now 16, was among 30 people in 24 vehicles who were injured in the May 27 attack. Once a promising artist, she has undergone intensive threatment and therapy since the attack. She returned to her home this month. Burgess, who could have been sentenced to a maximum of 415 years, confessed that he two others threw dozens of rocks at motorists for fun. Another youth, Donnell Petite, also has been convicted in the case, and a third, Maurice Ford, will stand trial in February.

DOC.HEAD: Detective Accused of Taking Mob Bribe, Gotti Still Jailed
DOC.TEXT: Reputed Mafia boss John Gotti paid off a police officer for a tip that authorities had bugged the office of a Gotti cohort, police say. Detective William J. Peist, 43, was stripped of his shield and guns and put on desk duty after refusing to cooperate with the FBI, police said Monday. Peist faces departmental charges for failing to cooperate. No criminal charges were immediately filed. Meanwhile, the judge in Gotti's racketeering case Monday postponed until Friday a bail hearing while he considers a defense request to close the hearing to the public. Prosecutors have said six tapes made from listening devices planted in the Ravenite Social Club in Little Italy, one of Gotti's hangouts, will show that the so-called Dapper Don is a threat to the community and does not deserve bail. In a letter to U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser, defense attorney Gerald L. Shargel claimed Gotti's rights to privacy and a fair trial would be violated if the tapes were played in open court. The New York Post reported Monday that one of the tapes revealed that Gotti paid at least $10,000 to a police officer for tipping him off to another wiretap. Federal agents recorded a conversation between Gotti and co-defendants Salvatore ``Sammy the Bull'' Gravano and Frank ``Frankie Locks'' Locascio during which they agreed to bribe a public servant, authorities said. Peist, a 16-year-veteran with four departmental awards, passed a tip that police had bugged Gravano's S&G Construction Co., police said. Gotti, Gravano and Locascio were arrested last week and charged under federal racketeering statutes with murder, gambling, loansharking, obstruction of justice and other crimes. All three were being held in jail. Gotti is accused of ordering the 1985 assassination of his predecessor, ``Big Paul'' Costellano, to take over the Gambino crime family, which prosecutors describe as the nation's most powerful criminal organization. A fourth defendant, Thomas Gambino, was arrested on loansharking and gambling charges and freed on bail.

DOC.HEAD: Rain and Snow East From the Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Snow and rain extended east from the Pacific Northwest today, while clear skies prevailed from Southern California to West Texas. A storm moving south from Alaska brought wintry weather to the northern tier of states. In Kotzebue and the lower Kobuk Valley in Alaska, wind chill factors were 50 degrees below zero, the National Weather Service said. Snow advisories were posted through at least tonight in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and North Dakota, while high winds and snow were forecast in Wyoming. Wind chill factors near 60 degrees below zero were forecast tonight in North Dakota, where a winter storm watch was also in effect. Up to 6 inches of snow fell Monday in northern and western Iowa. Authorities blamed the weather for one fatal traffic accident. Hundreds of travelers were stranded because of hazardous road conditions. Thunderstorms were forecast for the South, with snow flurries and rain in the Midwest. Heavy rain was forecast from the Great Lakes to New England. Sunny skies and mild temperatures were forecast from Southern California to West Texas. Record highs were broken or tied Monday in several Texas cities, including 82 degrees in San Antonio and Austin and 83 degrees in Houston and Corpus Christi. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 92 degrees at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Iraq Claims More Than 2,000 Children Died Due To Sanctions
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's health minister claimed today that 2,042 children under age 5 have died because of shortages in baby food and medicines brought on by the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with his country. The minister, Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said, blamed President Bush for the deaths in a statement distributed by the official Iraqi News Agency. ``Documented evidence of this high rate in childrens' death will stand to condemn the crimes committed by Bush and his partners,'' INA quoted the minister as saying. He said 600 of the children died in hospitals this month, mainly due to shortages of vaccines that caused the spread of contagious diseases like measles, diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough. Said claimed on Dec. 3 that 1,416 children had died because of shortages resulting from the sanctions the U.N. Security Council imposed on Iraq as punishment for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Western diplomats in Baghdad have discounted the reports of shortages, noting that the Security Council decided in October to allow shipments of essential food and medicines to Iraq. The diplomats note that since mid-October, nearly 120 tons of medicines have arrived from humanitarian groups worldwide, earmarked for Iraqi children. Most of the shipments were in exchange for Western hostages helped by Iraq until President Saddam Hussein announced a blanket release on Dec.6. Last week alone, Iraq's Red Crescent, the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross, announced it had received a shipment of 22 tons of medical supplies from the Italy and another 28 tons of the same from the United Nations' Children Fund, UNICEF. But government hospitals still report shortages of vaccines, antibiotics and baby formulas and tell patients they should bring their own. Iraqis say they can buy medicines at pharmacies and on the black market but the prices are at least five times higher than normal. Some diplomats and medical personnel in Baghdad suggested last month that Iraq might be stockpiling medicine in case of war and that some of the reported shortages resulted from profiteering. A government rationing plan enforced in September limits each child under age 1 to three 16-ounce cans of baby formula a month. At government subsidized stores, each can costs 750 fils, or 2.25 dollars at the official exchange rate. Iraqis are forced to supplement their babies' diet with powdered milk bought on the black market for as much as 40 dinars per kilogram (2,2 pounds). That price amounts to $120 at the official rate and is beyond the means of many Iraqis.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Accepts a Resolution Critical of Israel
DOC.TEXT: The U.N. Security Council has for a seventh time postponed voting on a resolution deploring Israel's deportation of Palestinians from the occupied territories. But the United States, which had stifled any resolution linking the Palestinians to a Middle East peace conference or assailing Israel too harshly, agreed during debate Monday to support a carefully critical proposal. Council President Abdalla Saleh Al-Ashtal of Yemen said he was not certain which of several amended resolutions might be put to a vote Wednesday, when the council meets on the issue again. He said various Western and non-aligned drafts would have to first be reconciled. The resolutions under consideration also call for an international conference to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict. The postponements of the votes over the past two weeks have largely been the doing of the United States, which fears its support for a peace conference would be seen as a concession to induce Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq insists it will not consider pulling out unless Israel moves to relinquish the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, which it seized during the 1967 Middle East war. Israel's decision last week to deport four Palestinian leaders of an extremist group apparently pushed the United States closer to the position of Security Council members who want to improve the safety of Palestinians in the occupied territories. The deported Palestinians were leaders of a group that claimed responsibility for murdering three Israeli civilians outside Tel Aviv. But many Palestinians say they prefer death to deportation from the land they call their own. Saturday's deportations order were Israel's first in over a year. The U.S.-backed draft resolution ``deplores the decision by the government of Israel, the occupying power, to resume deportation of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories.'' It also requests the U.N. secretary-general urgently monitor the safety of Palestinian civilians and make new efforts to help them. It was not immediately clear whether the proposal goes far enough to satisfy the council's strongest Palestinian supporters. Another proposal under consideration states that an international peace conference on the Middle East, properly structured and at an appropriate time, could promote a comprehensive settlement. The United States has indicated it would support a carefully arranged conference at an unspecified time. Israel has rejected any deployment of U.N. personnel in the Israeli-occupied territories as an infringement upon its sovereignty. It has also rejected most proposals for an international conference on the Mideast situation.

DOC.HEAD: More Iraqi Reservists Report For Duty Amid Buildup
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of reservists reported to their army units today in a mass mobilization begun a day after Iraq's rulers declared once again that they would never surrender Kuwait. ``We are ready for the decisive showdown, if thus God wills. But many heads will roll and many thrones will fall,'' said a statement from the ruling Revolutionary Command Council. The Defense Ministry on Monday ordered all able-bodied 33-year-old reservists to report for duty by Thursday for short training periods before being assigned to ``active duty.'' The reservists began reporting today, according to officials at mobilization centers. President Saddam Hussein said last month that he would call up some 250,000 reservists. Most of the country's 230,000 other reservists had already been activated following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Monday's move was Iraq's third major callup of reserves in recent weeks. Men aged 30-32 were ordered to report for military duty last month, as were 60,000 farmers who had earlier been exempted to help boost food production to counter United Nations-imposed trade sanctions against Iraq. The London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies estimates that Iraq has 904,000 men ages 18-22 and 1.3 million in the 23-32 age group. Saddam has placed an estimated 500,000 men in the Kuwait theater facing a 28-nation, U.S.-dominated force that by mid-January is expected to total around 650,000 men and women. Iraq's regular army has 500,000 soldiers, some of whom are deployed on its borders with Turkey and Syria. The United Nations Security Council last month ordered Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face military action. In its statement Monday, the government said it wanted peace but would not capitulate to Western demands to abandon Kuwait unconditionally. Iraqi authorities have intensified preparations for war in the last couple of weeks, ordering owners of buildings to provide bomb shelters and expanding first-aid and civil defense training. The state-run al-Jomhuriya daily said Monday that civil defense authorities have opened 342 training centers in the capital of 4 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Millions of Dollars Wasted by City on Office Rentals.
DOC.TEXT: Offices that will cost the financially strapped city government $1.2 million a month barely will be used Philadelphia's comptroller says. The city, which may miss a payroll payment in 10 days unless it gets a cash infusion, in January is taking over 600,000 square feet of space it agreed to rent three years ago in a deal to keep Cigna Corp. from leaving the city. Jonathan Saidel, Philadelphia's comptroller, said the city plans to fill only 12,323 square feet - about 2 percent - in the two office buildings the company has vacated. ``We found that much of the $1.2 million monthly rental payment for the Cigna space will simply be a waste of taxpayers' money since the city has no effective plans for moving city departments into the space as it becomes available,'' Saidel said in an audit released last week. Saidel, accusing city administrators of ``grossly inadequate'' handling of office space costs, said lease costs for the city have skyrocketed. The city budgeted $36.6 million for rent in the 1991 budget year - up 56 percent from the $23.4 million of fiscal 1990 and more than six times the total rent of $5.4 million in fiscal 1980. The report said the city's system and procedures for renting office space were in disarray and millions of dollars are wasted each year on rent. Mayor W. Wilson Goode did not immediately respond to a request through his press secretary for comment on the audit. Public Property Commissioner Andres Perez Jr. was not in his office Monday and unavailable for comment, a secretary said. Philadelphia has overspent its $2.1 billion budget by some $240 million this year. Unless it receives a cash infusion, the city has warned it will not meet its payroll as early as Dec. 28.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Offers $108 Million in Aid to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Japan today announced a $108 million package of emergency food and medical aid to the Soviet Union, but stressed that its policy of withholding ordinary assistance from Moscow remains unchanged. Japan is making its first offer of food aid to the Soviet Union as a humanitarian gesture, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said. A longstanding dispute over the ownership of small islands off northern Japan has prevented Tokyo and Moscow from signing a treaty to formally end World War II hostilities. Japan has been reluctant to extend aid to the Soviet Union. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said Japan's basic position on economic assistance to the Soviet Union remains unchanged but that humanitarian aid is being offered because the ``situation is deteriorating very rapidly.'' The package consists of $3.8 million in food aid and an equal amount in medical aid, both to be delivered through the Red Cross; up to $100 million in food credits through the Export-Import Bank of Japan and government tax support for organizations that help the Soviet Union, the Foreign Ministry said. The ministry had delayed deciding on food aid because of reports of a bumper Soviet harvest. But Watanabe acknowledged that problems with transportation and organization had created food distribution problems. Indeed, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama expressed concern Tuesday that food from Japan would not reach its intended destination. ``We would like to ask Soviet authorities for cooperation to make sure our assistance will properly reach the destination,'' he said. Kazuhiko Togo, the head of the Foreign Ministry's Soviet Division, said the government had a tough time deciding on the aid plan because of the political strains between the nations. ``Where to draw a line between humanitarian aid and ordinary aid was a very difficult decision,'' he said. The European Community has pledged $2.8 billion in aid to the Soviets, and the United States will extend the Soviets $1 billion in agricultural credits.

DOC.HEAD: Mary Christmas Says This is a Merry Time of The Year
DOC.TEXT: Mary Christmas says it wouldn't be a merry Christmas without a little merriment about her holiday moniker. ``It's a good conversation piece and I never get tired of people laughing about my name,'' said the 38-year-old mother of three. Sometimes, however, her name can get her in a pickle. For example, phone conversations can became more than a bit twisted when she picks up at the Horry County Alcohol and Drug Abuse Commission. ``I've had several people hang up on me in the last week,'' Mrs. Christmas said. ``But once they find out my name really is Mary Christmas, they never forget it.'' Her 13-year-old daughter, also named Mary Christmas, also said the name is cause for unwanted attention. ``All my teachers call on me to do stuff for them because they can't remember anyone else's name,'' the eighth-grader complained. There are other drawbacks, too. ``One time a woman wouldn't cash my check. She refused to believe anyone could have the name Mary Christmas,'' Mrs. Christmas said. ``And this time of year it's particularly strange because people call out `merry Christmas' and I'm constantly turning around to see what they want.'' Mary Christmas was not always Mary Christmas. She was Mary Alice Allen until 18 years ago when she married Kent Christmas, who works at a local car dealership. ``At first, I never really thought about it because my friends usually called me `Mary Alice,''' she said. ``Then, other people started calling me Mary Christmas and it stuck. No one ever just calls me `Mary.' It's always `Mary Christmas.'''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pentagon Says Two Largest Defense Firms Could Go Bankrupt
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon audits revealed McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp. have a ``possible chance of bankruptcy,'' a newspaper reported today. The financial health of the nation's two largest defense contractors has been debated privately all year, but the September audits by the Defense Contract Audit Agency are the first official word on the subject, according to the Los Angeles Times. The Pentagon's accountants found that the financial condition of the two firms had deteriorated this year, but their ability to complete projects under contract was not impaired. A General Dynamics spokesman told the Times he had not seen the audit, but said, ``It is unfortunate that matters related to that were leaked at this particular time.'' McDonnell Douglas' chief financial officer, Herbert Lanese, said any prediction of bankruptcy was ``ludicrous.'' The company also discredited the criteria on which the Pentagon made its conclusions. The formula in question is the ``z-score,'' a weighted average of ratios that considers sales, operating profits, retained earnings and working capital as a percentage of total assets, and market value of stock as a percentage of total debt. Auditors gave McDonnell Douglas a z-score of 2.27, or a ``possible chance of bankruptcy.'' A score of 1.8 or lower means a ``probable chance of bankruptcy.'' General Dynamics got a score of 2.42, also indicating a ``possible chance of bankruptcy,'' according to the audit. Private defense industry experts also questioned the Pentagon's findings. ``If I had to rely on the government for my financial analysis, I would be in a lot of trouble,'' said aerospace analyst Howard Rubel of C.J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell. ``One of the problems that exists in any form of government second-guessing is that they don't understand what they are doing.'' McDonnell Douglas does have two debt-laden projects: the C-17 cargo jet, which is exceeding its contract ceiling by $600 million, and the A-12 attack jet, facing an overrun of $500 million.

DOC.HEAD: Mom Tosses Baby, Then Collapses in Fire
DOC.TEXT: A 2-month-old baby trapped in a burning apartment house was saved by two quick-thinking passersby who used a trenchcoat to catch the infant after her mother dropped her out of a fourth-floor window. The baby, Amanda Morales, fell 40 feet into the arms of Bruce and Karen Pane, a brother and sister who were driving by the house in Brooklyn Monday morning when they heard the young mother screaming for help. The pair used Karen Pane's coat to catch the baby, who escaped serious injury. ``There's no way you can blow a catch like that,'' said Bruce Pane, 35, an avid softball and touch football player. ``I've made a lot of pressure catches, but none with that much pressure on it.'' The mother, Susan Seymour, 20, then staggered away from the window and collapsed. Firefighter Chris Gafney climbed a flame-engulfed ladder, crawled through smoke to find her, and brought her out. Seymour was in critical but stable condition today with smoke inhalation and second-degree burns over less than 5 percent of her body, said a New York Hospital spokesman. Amanda was in satisfactory condition for treatment of smoke inhalation, said a spokeswoman for Methodist Hospital. ``I feel so high. I really feel good about what we've done,'' said Karen Pane, 32.

DOC.HEAD: Toddler Killed When Barbell Falls on Him
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old boy was killed when he pulled a barbell onto himself from a weightlifting bench near his bed, police said. Warren St. Omer was pronounced dead after being rushed to St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center on Sunday night, said Sgt. Richard Borofsky. The boy had apparently reached up from his bed and grabbed the barbell, which extended over his bed from the weightlifting bench, police said. The barbell, which had about 110 pounds of weights on it, fell on the boy's throat and suffocated him, police said. The death has been ruled an accident, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Signs Tough Gun Liability Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 8 grafs new to correct by showing that bill already signed by mayor. Picks up 9th graf pvs, Congress normally
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia has approved the most far-reaching gun control bill in the nation, a measure to make manufacturers and dealers liable for deaths and injuries caused by semiautomatic weapons. Mayor Marion Barry Jr. said today he has signed the bill, which cannot become law until reviewed by Congress. ``I think we have to take all measures to try to get the guns off the streets of America,'' Barry said on WTTG-TV's Fox Morning News. ``The manufacturer has to begin to take some of the weight. We don't need those guns on the streets.'' Barry said everybody who touches guns used in homicides should be held liable.
