The measure, which was approved by the city council last week, would give private citizens the right to sue for damages from manufacturers and sellers of semiautomatic weapons, regardless of where the makers and dealers do business. ``It's time for these merchants of death to pay a price,'' said council member William Lightfoot, who co-sponsored the bill. ``We can set a very meaningful precedent.'' Officials in Washington, which has the nation's highest homicide rate, say that since January 1988 about 70 percent of the 8,500 guns recovered by police have been traced to dealers in neighboring Maryland and Virginia. The bill will face strong opposition from the National Rifle Association when it arrives in Congress for a 30-day review period that begins when Congress returns to legislative business Jan. 23. Congress normally lets new city laws stand, but controversial measures sometimes become platforms for ideological debate and are defeated. A lobbyist for the NRA, Carl T. Rowan Jr., called the bill ``frivolous'' and said it would ``not have any impact on the violence. I don't think it stands a chance in court.'' The NRA was instrumental earlier this year in the defeat of three congressional proposals to ban semiautomatic weapons. Michael Beard, president of the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, said he believes the bill would survive a court challenge, although no real precedent exists. A top aide to Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., chairman of the House District of Columbia Committee, said Dellums would support the measure. But the office of Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., who also is on the committee, said letting such a law stand would be ``unconscionable.'' President Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, has said the White House also will look at the matter. The bill is based on product-liability law, which allows individuals to seek monetary damages for death or injury to themselves or family members caused by a particular product. In such cases, juries or judges decide the amount of damages after a trial on the individual's lawsuit. The city already has one of the strictest gun laws in the country. Sales are banned and private citizens are prohibited from owning weapons unless they were purchased and registered before 1976. Still, the murder toll keeps climbing, from 369 two years ago to 434 in 1989 and 465 with just 14 days left in 1990. ``By damn, it's time to stand up,'' said council Chairman David Clarke, who co-sponsored the bill. ``If we can begin to take the profit out of the gun trade, it will have an effect on our lives.''

DOC.HEAD: 11 Killed In Shootout As Battle Looms On Military Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to emphasize the fighting and to say no breakdown given on casualties. Pickup 6th graf pvs ``Mrs. Chamorro...''
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of former Contras seized a police post and battled the Sandinista army in fighting that claimed 11 lives and left 20 people wounded, the highest casualty toll during Violeta Chamorro's presidency. The violence occurred as Mrs. Chamorro prepared to veto a 25 percent cut in the military budget that the Sandinista People's Army said would push Nicaragua into ``chaos and a bloodbath.'' Col. Antenor Rosales said the fighting took place Sunday when 60 rebels seized a police post in Jalapa, 125 miles north of Managua. The army put down the uprising and captured more than half the former Contras, he said in a interview on state-run television. Eleven people were killed and 20 wounded, Rosales said. He did not say how many of the dead and wounded were former Contras. The U.S.-backed Contras agreed to give up their 10-year-old battle in June. Their leftist Sandinista foes were defeated at the polls in February by Mrs. Chamorro's conservative United National Opposition coalition. Mrs. Chamorro has reduced the size of the army - which with the police is still controlled by the Sandinistas - and promised the demobilized Contras land and support for their resettlement. But her efforts at reconciliation have fallen short of former fighters' expectations, and strong antagonisms persist between the Contras and the armed forces and police. Interior Ministry spokesman Frank Cesar said Monday the government is investigating the clash in Jalapa, which he said, ``in no way contributes to the reconciliation and pacification of the country.'' In a television broadcast, Cesar condemned a series of attacks on UNO elected officials that began during the weekend. A bomb destroyed the car of an UNO lawmaker Humberto Castilla and part of his home in the southeastern town of Juigalpa on Saturday. Castilla, a hard-liner who pushed for the army budget cuts, was out of the country at the time. No one was hurt in the blast. Grenads were fired Sunday and Monday at the homes of several other coalition mayors and deputies who backed the budget cuts. No injuries were reported in the offensive that UNO blamed on army members. Mrs. Chamorro, returning Monday from a Costa Rican summit in which Central American presidents addressed demilitarization of the region, said she wants to reduce the Sandinista army's size. But she said, ``We can't do things overnight.'' She has cut thousands of soldiers from the ranks of the army, and the 39-member Sandinista bloc in the National Assembly opposed the military budget reduction, saying it would mean firing 10,000 more. On Sunday, the army took full-page ads in pro-Sandinista newspapers and ran television spots to publicize a three-page communique that said some legislators were pushing Nicaragua into ``chaos and a bloodbath'' by voting for the budget reduction. ``As humans that we are we cannot throw into the street the army or any civilian,'' Mrs. Chamorro said Monday. Mrs. Chamorro is treading a fine line between the polarized positions of the powerful Sandinista party and the 14-party UNO coalition, whose 51 deputies in the 92-member National Assembly voted in unprecedented unity for the military budget cut on Friday. The leglislature includes two independents. Since taking office in April, she has weathered paralyzing Sandinista union general strikes and a series of roadblocks by sympathizers of former Contras. The dissidence from both sides has erupted in violence but the shootout Sunday claimed more lives than any incident before.

DOC.HEAD: 28 Albanians Use Rafts To Reach Yugoslavia
With PM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-eight Albanians used improvised rafts to cross the Bojana River and enter Yugoslavia early today, the state Tanjug news agency reported. It said the group was made up of six children, four women and 18 men. More than 600 Albanians have fled to Yugoslavia this year, and Tanjug said 207 used the Bojana River as their escape route. The report gave no further details. Albania, isolated by hard-line Communist rulers for decades, last week became the last European state to allow creation of an opposition party. The Democratic Party of Albania was formed Wednesday by a coaltion of students and intellectuals following several days of protests. Late in the week, violent anti-government demonstrations occurred in several Albanian cities, and more than 150 people were arrested. Albania announced limited reforms in May, including liberalization of travel restrictions and abolition of the death penalty for those fleeing the country.More than 4,000 Albanians were allowed to leave in July after taking refuge in Western embassies in Tirana, the capital. Despite the changes, many Albanians have continued to cross into neighboring Yugoslavia and Greece without government permission.

DOC.HEAD: Haitians Revel in Apparent Election of Firebrand Priest
With PM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: Miami's Little Haiti became cloaked in red-and-blue Haitian flags while chants erupted of ``Titid! Titid!'' - the nickname of the priest many Haitian-Americans hoped would become the island nation's next president. The revelers' celebration Monday was of the apparent victory of Jean-Bertrand Aristide in Haiti's first democratic elections. The thousands of cheering, dancing Haitian immigrants still awaited the official outcome of Sunday's presidential election. But projections made by 800 foreign observers showed Aristide winning by as much as 70 percent of the vote. Final results were not expected until late today. Amid the joyous din of what looked like a massive street party, members of the crowd spoke feverishly of the priest who first became prominent ministering to Haiti's poor. ``This is the greatest day in the history of Haiti,'' said Mona Michel, a director of the Haitian Refugee Center Inc. The educator joined hundreds in the crowd, prompting Miami police to close off to traffic for about a block of the street running through the heart of the city's Haitian neighborhood. Michael Besile carried a live red rooster, the Aristide trademark ``coq qualite'' - ``quality rooster.'' ``It's going to be better now. He's a good person, a person we know will do good,'' Besile said. Haitian-Americans disappointed by a succession of corrupt, despotic leaders said they have confidence that Aristide - depicted in some of their posters as being physically blessed by Jesus Christ - can bring about change. On street corners, youths sipped from bottles and cans wrapped in brown paper bags and tapped out lively rhythms on just about anything that made noise. One heavyset woman stood in the middle of the street shouting out over and over ``Thank God! Oh, Thank You God!'' Police reported no problems. During the last such celebration in Little Haiti, marking the fall of the Duvalier family regime on Feb. 7, 1986, some Duvalier loyalists were attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Safety Takes Back Seat to Modernization of Nukes
DOC.TEXT: Safety of the nation's nuclear weapons was not given the same urgency as modernization of those systems to meet military requirements, a special review panel said today. Three of the nation's leading physicists, in a report to the House Armed Services Committee, also expressed concern over the absence of ``quantitative safety standards'' for the dispersal of plutonium. Plutonium, a highly poisonous component in a nuclear device, could be released from a weapon by a fire or conventional explosion as well as by an atomic explosion, the panel said in its 44-page report. ``Although plutonium dispersal is a much less threatening danger than a sizable nuclear yield, it is nevertheless a potentially serious hazard, particularly if the plutonium is aerosolized in a chemical detonation,'' the panel said. Its members are Dr. Sidney D. Drell, deputy director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center; Nobel laureate Dr. Charles H. Townes of the University of California at Berkeley and Dr. John S. Foster, head of the Defense Science Board. The Armed Services Committee empaneled the three in May after questions were raised about the safety of several nuclear weapons systems, including the short-range, air-to-ground attack missile, known as SRAM-A. Since that time, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has taken the SRAM-A off alert bombers of the Strategic Air Command. In the report, the panel said that since the 1950s and the height of the Cold War, the government gave special consideration to changes in the system to meet defense needs, and safety was not treated similarly. ``Modernization and improvement programs gave priority to military requirements,'' the report said. ``Safety in general was not viewed with the same urgency.'' Modification of the system has moved slowly and, due to budget constraints, the emphasis has been on acquiring new weapons. ``In anticipation ... many older ones remain in today's nuclear stockpile that do not meet present nuclear weapons design criteria,'' the panel said. It recommended, among other things, that all weapons be equipped with modern enhanced nuclear detonation safety systems and that all nuclear bombs on aircraft be equipped with insensitive high explosives and fire-resistant pits within the weapons. ``These are the two most critical safety features currently available for avoiding plutonium dispersal in the event of aircraft fires or crashes,'' the report said. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said the report calls for a reassessment of the nation's priorities for nuclear weapons, with safety ahead of military effectiveness. ``Improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations gives us breathing space to begin planning now for a nuclear arsenal that is cheaper and smaller than the one we have today, as well as safer,'' Aspin said. The ranking Republican on the committee, Rep. William Dickinson of Alabama, said the panel of physicists ``correctly notes that many of the safety problems identified to date have been or are in the process of being fixed. Nonetheless, the panel did express the view that there is still room for improvement.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Retirees Ordered to Active Duty for Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 8, Those recalled, describing those recalled. ^By ROBERT BURNS
DOC.TEXT: Today's ``volunteer'' Army is looking for more than volunteers. For the first time in nearly three decade, the Army is searching out military retirees - especially those with medical skills - and forcing them back into uniform. As the buildup of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf surges toward the 400,000 level and the United Nations deadline nears for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the Army is digging deep into its personnel records for help in supporting the force. Lt. Col. Henry H. Hanrahan, an Army planner, said Monday that an initial callup of 15 retired physician assistants was approved last week, and about 200 other retirees probably would be involuntarily recalled for active duty over the next month. It is the first involuntary use of Army retirees since the 1961 crisis over East Germany's erection of the Berlin Wall. Hanrahan said in an interview that about 4,000 Army retirees have volunteered for duty in the gulf crisis, but that involuntary callups were needed because there aren't enough volunteers with the skills needed most. The Army is especially eager to get more medical specialists in uniform. About 150 volunteers have been put on active duty, and about half of those are performing medical duties in support of Operation Desert Shield, Hanrahan said. Approximately 300 more volunteers are likely to go on active duty over the coming month, he said. Those recalled would consist of former officers who retired after 20 or more years of service. Retired military officers aren't required to maintain any active association with the services. But a service secretary has the authority to force retired personnel back into uniform if it is deemed necessary for national security. The Army's increasing need for medical skills reflects a broader trend within the U.S. military as tens of thousands more American troops are deployed to Saudi Arabia and the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline approaches for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The Navy last week disclosed that it is deploying two additional 500-bed mobile field hospitals in the projected combat zone in Saudi Arabia and that it plans to call up 8,000 reservists to increase Navy medical support. The Navy announced Monday that 769 Navy Reserve members, including many medical specialists, are being ordered to active duty. Last week it called up about 2,300 medical reservists. Hanrahan said that in adition to the retirees who have volunteered for duty, about 5,000 members of the Individual Ready Reserve have offered their services, and about 1,000 of those have been placed on active duty. ``These are not Rambo types. They see that their country has a need and they want to be a part of it,'' Hanrahan said. The IRR is the second echelon of reservists, mostly former enlisted personnel and officers. They cannot be involuntarily called to active duty under the Aug. 22 reserve callup authority issued by President Bush. The presidential order allows the callup of up to 200,000 members of the Selected Reserve - members of the National Guard and Reserve who are required to train one weekend per month and attend a two-week training session once a year. Members of the IRR generally are not required to train. There are 278,000 Army members in the IRR. The Army faces an increasing need for individual volunteers to perform duties such as truck driving, water purification, medical service and graves registration, Hanrahan said. Some also are needed to fill out the three National Guard combat brigades placed on active duty for possible deployment to the gulf, he said. The Army is concerned about a recent drop in the number of IRR volunteers, Hanrahan said, noting that about 600 who had offered to serve had backed out. Over the next month the Army expects to need500 to 800 more volunteers from the IRR for active duty, beyond the 1,000 volunteers already put in uniform, he said. And if the gulf crisis erupts into war, the need for individual replacements will greatly increase, he added. Members of the Individual Ready Reserve can volunteer by calling the Army Reserve Personnel Center in St. Louis at 1-800-325-2660.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives Federal Employees Half-Day Off on Christmas Eve
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today gave all federal employees a half-day off on Monday, Christmas Eve. His order closes all federal departments and agencies early on Dec. 24, but allows department heads to require certain workers or offices to work a full day if needed ``for reasons of national security or defense or for other essential public reasons.'' The order did not specify a quitting time, but most offices were likely to close around noon, local time. Bush's order did not extend to the following Monday, Dec. 31. Government offices are closed both Dec. 25 and Jan. 1. The order does not affect state or local government employees.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says It Useless to Talk About U..N. Resolutions ^With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says direct talks with the United States would be useless if the Americans only reiterate U.N. Security Council resolutions on the crisis, it was reported today. ``We have already read them (the resolutions), we know them and we rejected them,'' Saddam told a Turkish television journalist. The 25-minute interview is scheduled for broadcast later this week on state television, but excerpts were released today. The United States has said any talks would center on reminding Saddam of the U.N. demands that Iraq withdraw unconditionally from Kuwait by Jan. 15 and allow the return of the legitimate Kuwaiti government. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed the emirate six days later. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz had been due in Washington on Monday to meet with President Bush. But the visit was put off after Saddam rejected U.S. proposals for a date to meet with the Secretary of State James A. Baker III. In the interview, Saddam again ruled out any concessions on Kuwait before the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is resolved. If it is settled, he said, ``we can make similar concessions'' on Kuwait. The United States has consistently rejected any such linkage of the Persian Gulf crisis and the Palestinian problem. ``Those who want respect for the international laws and Security Council decisions should first solve this 23-year-old problem and comply with laws and council decisions before using double standards,'' Saddam was quoted as saying. Saddam also said Iraq posed no military threat to Turkey, which complied with U.N. trade sanctions against Iraq by cutting off an Iraqi oil pipeline.

DOC.HEAD: Former New York City Mayor Hit With Rock in Old City
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with new quotes, CORRECT attribution on radio quote, details about treatment, reason for Koch visit. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former New York City Mayor Edward I. Koch was hit in the head with a rock today as he toured Jerusalem's old, walled city with Mayor Teddy Kollek, witnesses said. Koch and Kollek continued on their walk through the narrow alleys of the Old City, and Koch did not appear seriously hurt, reportedly suffering only a scratch on the top of his head. The former mayor later told reporters: ``I know the stone wasn't meant for me because everyone likes me.'' He also said he hoped American Jews would ignore such incidents and show their support for Israel by coming to visit. ``This shouldn't make people afraid,'' he said. ``It should make them angry.'' Witnesses said Koch and Kollek were walking on David Street, a narrow lane of tourist shops in the Christian Quarter, when a stone about one inch in diameter was thrown toward them. The rock bounced off a store awning and hit Koch on the top of the head, the witnesses said. He used a handkerchief to stem slight bleeding. Bonnie Boxer, a press aide to Kollek, said city officials put two adhesive bandages on Koch's wound, which was described by city officials as a scratch. ``If you had a head of hair like mine, nothing would have happened,'' Kollek quipped later. Kollek, 79, has thick gray hair; Koch is balding. Koch told radio station WNEW-AM in New York that the rock ``obviously was thrown to cause fright, but it didn't frighten Teddy Kollek and it didn't frighten me.'' After today's incident, Kollek retrieved the stone and gave it to Koch as a souvenir, the witnesses said. The two then proceeded without further problems to the neighboring Jewish Quarter. They did not have a police escort, witnesses said. There were no reports of arrests in the case. Stones have been the main weapon of the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation. Jerusalem's Old City is part of the area Israel annexed after the 1967 Middle East war. Palestinians consider it occupied. Koch, who turned 66 last week, is a long-time supporter of the Jewish state. He was in Israel as a guest of the city of Tel Aviv, where a street was dedicated in his name over the weekend. On his visit today, Kollek showed him sections of the Wailing Wall - also known as the Western Wall - that have been unearthed by archeologists and soon will be open to the public. Koch described it as ``touching history.'' Shops along David Street were shuttered in a strike called by the Moslem fundamentalist group Hamas to protest Israel's plans to deport four Hamas activists. The deportations were ordered last week after the stabbing deaths of three Israelis blamed on Hamas.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Advised To Be Cautious In Travel
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is advising U.S. citizens to be careful in traveling to Romania, the East European country where tens of thousands of students and workers are on strike in an effort to pressure the government to step down. Large street demonstrations in Bucharest, the capital, and the cities of Timisoara and Brasov ``could involve significant unrest and be a potential threat to the safety of foreign visitors,'' the department said Monday in a travel advisory. It said transportation services also may be disrupted by strikes or other labor unrest. U.S. citizens in Romania were advised to register and keep in close touch with the U.S. Embassy in Bucharest.

DOC.HEAD: Captive Breeding Program Getting Green Light
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service says it is prepared to issue permits allowing the capture of eight to 10 Florida panthers a year for the next three to six years in an effort to save the endangered species. The Florida panther is a subspecies of cougar, also known as puma or mountain lion. Although it once roamed much of the Southeast, it is making its last stand in southwestern Florida. Only 30 to 50 adult animals are believed to survive. ``As it stands now, you've got the whole population clustered in one corner of southwest Florida. Just one hurricane is all it would take to wipe out the whole species,'' said Dennis Jordan, coordinator of the Florida Panther Interagency Committee, a group of state and federal wildlife agencies. Captive breeding, which could begin next month, is only one part of the effort to save the Florida panther, said Vicki Boatwright, spokeswoman for the federal agency's Southeast regional office in Atlanta. ``The most important part is habitat preservation,'' she said Monday. Congress has provided for expansion of parks and wildlife refuges in the area to protect habitat for the animals. The panthers use about 2.2 million acres of land, of which about 1.2 million acres is publicly owned. It won't be too hard to find kittens, said David Maehr, a Florida biologist. Six of seven adult females being tracked by radio collar have given birth this year and the seventh is believed to be pregnant. Analyses conducted by the Florida Panther Interagency Committee concluded the species would be extinct within 40 years under prevailing conditions. Final approval of the captive breeding program would allow the state to capture up to six kittens and four older animals in the first year and up to six kittens and two older animals in following years. Applications to be part of the breeding program have come from several Florida zoos, including the Jacksonville Zoo, Tampa's Lowery Park Zoo, the Miami Metrozoo and the White Oak Plantation at Yulee.

DOC.HEAD: Phalange Party Official Slain in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Assailants shot and killed an official of the right-wing Christian Phalange Party today in the first major challenge to the government's latest effort to end Lebanon's more than 15-year-old civil war. A police spokesman identified the victim as Sami Abu Jawdeh, a jewler who also heads the Phalange Party's branch in the Zalka district. Two unidentified gunmen stormed his jewelry shop and shot him with silencer-equipped pistols. He ``died instantly of four gunshot wounds in the skull and chest,'' the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The gunmen escaped in a waiting car, he said. The spokesman said the killing ``apparently was politically motivated. The gunmen did not steal anything from the shop. They shot him and escaped.'' But police said they had no indications as to who was behind the killing. Zalka is part of Greater Beirut. Lebanese Army units were deployed in Beirut and its immediate surroundings Dec. 3 under a plan to end militia control, reunify the capital and pave the way for a final settlement to the civil war that has claimed more than 150,000 lives. Security conditions had improved following the militia pullout. Greater Beirut stretches along a 15-mile coastal strip from the Dog River in the north to the Damour River in the south.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, California Company Agree To Operate U.S.S.R.'s First Golf Resort
DOC.TEXT: As if food shortages and ethnic unrest are not enough to keep the Soviet Union busy, the nation is actually seeking new hazards. Only they're the kind you find on the golf course. A team from the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Affairs and American International Golf Resorts have reached an agreement to finish and operate a country club and recreation center outside Moscow. The 285-acre, 18-hole golf course in a birch and evergreen forest is expected to be completed next year. It is believed to be the first of its kind in the Soviet Union. A recreation center, including a luxury hotel, is expected to be completed in 1992, according to American International, of Greenbrae, Calif. The resort initially will be used by diplomats, foreign businessmen and tourists. But eventually Soviet citizens will be able to enjoy the delights and frustrations of golf with visitors from other countries. ``It will be a meeting ground,'' said Ivan Ivanovich Sergeev, the deputy director of Diplomatic Corps Service Bureau, a division of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, who spoke through an interpreter. ``It's not purely a commercial enterprise. It will enhance the trust between these people.'' Five hundred memberships in the resort 18 miles west of Moscow will sell for the equivalent of $50,000 to $100,000 each - far above the reach of the average Soviet citizen. But John Lisanti, American International's chairman and chief executive officer, said it will not be long before some Soviets have enough rubles to take up the driver and putter. ``A lot of fortunes will be made in today's Soviet Union, and we believe in the very near future many Soviet citizens will make some of those fortunes and will be able to buy memberships in this resort,'' he said. The joint venture agreement, reached at a Palo Alto law firm on Friday, calls for Lisanti's company to contribute $30 million, or half the cost of the project. Private investors will have a 50 percent stake in the course and receive half the profits. The Soviet government will own the other half of the resort and keep the other half of the profits. American International also will help market the club throughout the world to draw visitors. Noted golf course architect Robert Trent Jones Jr. of Palo Alto is designing the course. The Soviet Union hired Jones in 1988 to build the 7,000-yard, par-72 course. The club will include townhouses and areas for tennis, swimming, tobogganing, cross-country skiing and restaurants. The 175-bed hotel was completed a year ago but will be expanded by 100 rooms.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Reject Talks With Iraq Although US Wouldn't Object
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 22 grafs to COMBINE pvs, UPGRADES sourcing, UPDATES with Iranian comment on possible war. Pickup 19th graf pvs, `In Baghdad today...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHR1, NY6
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today gave European allies the go-ahead for talks with Iraq as long as ``mixed signals'' are not sent. But the European Community decided not to hold such a meeting now, officials said. In another development, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was quoted as saying any U.S.-Iraqi talks would be useless if the American side only repeats United Nations demands to withdraw from Kuwait. Meanwhile, thousands of Iraqi reservists reported to army units today on call-up orders from their rulers for all able-bodied 33-year-old reservists. Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council said ``many heads will roll and many thrones will fall,'' if war breaks out in the gulf. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz had planned talks this week with Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy, the European Community chairman. European leaders put the meeting on hold after talks that had been scheduled for Monday between Aziz and President Bush were scrubbed. Baker said today he had no problem with a European meeting with Aziz. European Community foreign minsters reconsidered the matter, then decided against any talks unless Iraq holds talks with the United States first, officials said. ``A meeting will take place if Aziz goes to Washington first,'' said Irish Foreign Minister Gerald Collins. ``We must maintain the pressure on Iraq,'' said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the community's executive body. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry today criticized the EC's earlier refusal to hold talks, accusing the Europeans of trying to ``appease'' the United States. Baker, speaking at a news conference after a two-day meeting of foreign ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Belgium, said: ``We support ... any diplomatic efforts that might result in a peaceful solution.'' ``The one thing we do discourage,'' he said, ``are discordant messages, mixed messages or mixed signals.'' The Bush-Aziz talks on Monday were scrubbed over differences on the timing of a subsequent trip to Baghdad by Baker. Saddam has sought to hold the meeting Jan. 12, which Bush says is too late. Bush has said Saddam's intransigence on the issue signals his lack of willingness to leave Kuwait as the coalition lined up against him insists. A Turkish report today quoted Saddam as saying direct talks with the United States would be useless if the American side merely reiterates U.N. Security Council resolutions on the crisis. ``We have already read them (the resolutions), we know them and we rejected them,'' Saddam told a Turkish television journalist in an interview to be broadcast this week on state television. Excerpts were released today. Saddam also repeated his demand that a withdrawal from Kuwait be linked to a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The United States has repeatedly said the issues are unrelated. Iran's president, meanwhile, said if Iraq finds itself under attack by the U.S.-led forces, the Baghdad government itself would bear the responsibility. The official Islamic Republic News agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, quoted Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani as saying ``we are feeling very uneasy over the fact that the Iraqi people may be hurt by the Americans.'' But he told a group of college students in Tehran that ``the responsibility for this rests with the Iraqi regime,'' IRNA said. Iran and Iraq fought a 1980-88 war, but Baghdad moved to make peace with Tehran after it invaded Kuwait. In Baghdad today, Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said said that 2,042 children under age 5 have died of disease and malnutrition because of shortages in baby food and medicine resulting from a U.N.-ordered trade embargo. Said claimed on Dec. 3 that 1,416 children had died because of the sanctions. Iraq has offered no proof of the claims, and diplomats in Baghdad have discounted the reports of shortages, noting that the Security Council decided in October to allow shipments of essential food and medicines to Iraq. In Iraq, thousands of reservists reported to their army units today as part of a major military mobilization to counter a feared offensive by the U.S.-led multinational force. On Monday, the Defense Ministry ordered all able-bodied 33-year-old reservists to report for duty by Thursday for short periods of retraining before being assigned to active duty. It was Iraq's third major callup of reserves in recent weeks. Most reservists served in the military during the 1980-88 war with Iran. In other gulf-related developments: -Yevgeny Primakov, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top aide on the gulf crisis, said the departure of 2,500 Soviet workers from Iraq has been delayed only by technical matters and the desire of many to remain until their contracts expire. There had been speculation Baghdad was trying to hold the Soviet contract workers as hostages. -The Japanese Foreign Ministry said today Japan would quickly respond to a request from the U.S. military for $300 million worth of vehicles, computers, medical supplies and other goods. Japanese corporations plan to donate 20,000 stereo headsets to the U.S.-led multilateral forces, the ministry said. -Prince Charles will visit British troops in the gulf this weekend, Buckingham Palace said today. Charles' wife, Princess Diana, will fly to Germany on Wednesday to visit families of British soldiers serving in the region, the palace said.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Issues Engulf Parliament Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Gorbachev saying Soviet should vote this winter on treaty referendum. Pickup 3rd, `Several parliamentarians...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB7
DOC.TEXT: In a stormy session of the Soviet parliament today, Moldavians walked out to protest the presence of rival groups and legislators heatedly debated a Union Treaty designed to hold the nation together. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he wants Soviet citizens to vote this winter in a referendum on whether to sign the pact. ``I introduced a suggestion to hold a referendum, and those who don't want a union, let them go and secede,'' Gorbachev told reporters in the parliament building's lobby. But he reiterated his demand that any secession must take place within the framework of Soviet law. ``It's a divorce process,'' he said. During the second day of the Fourth Congress of People's Deputies, the Ukrainian Communist Party leader reportedly said the national legislature could deadlock over Gorbachev's proposed treaty. Several parliamentarians among the 440 scheduled to speak on the treaty expressed hope it would be signed. But others rejected the document, assuring protracted debate at the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies. ``We won't sign the Union Treaty. There is no chance of that now,'' said Dimitru Matkovsky, one of about two dozen Moldavian deputies who left the cavernous Kremlin Palace of Congresses today. Matkovsky said his delegation was angry that the Congress had invited as guests representatives of two ethnic groups seeking autonomy within Moldavia. He said Moldavians would not participate in the session until the groups left. Sitting in the hall were representatives of the Turkish Christian minority, Gagauz, from southern Moldavia, and Slavs from the eastern Dniester region. Both groups have declared autonomy in their corners of the republic. Ethnic turmoil and disputes between the central government and the republics have so far prevented negotiations over the Union Treaty. In a state-of-the-union address Monday, Gorbachev said the greatest threat to the Soviet Union was not economic decay but the secessionist movements. He proposed a nationwide, popular referendum be held on the concept of the treaty, which would form a new federation of the 15 Soviet republics. All republics have declared some form of sovereignty since March. The declarations have paralyzed power in the country, worsening food shortages and hastening economic collapse. The treaty would preserve central control over national security and such key industries as transportation and energy, and natural wealth such as gold and diamonds. Most republics want more independence in such areas, as well as to make their own economic decisions. In an interview published in Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, Ukrainian Commmunist Party boss Stanislav Gurenko, also a parliamentarian, told Pravda that the Union Treaty issue could deadlock the Congress. ``I am afraid that deputies may split on political issues and, above all, on a Union Treaty,'' Gurenko said. Gurenko also said some legislators ``have in some or other measure lost touch with what is happening in their republics. ... This, too, may create some additional difficulties.'' Gorbachev wants the Congress to endorse the Union Treaty, although only the legislatures of the republics have the power to approve it. If the national legislature is deadlocked, however, the treaty's future comes into question. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel today rejected the Union Treaty referendum. ``There never was a free expression of the will of the Estonian people'' about their forced incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 ``and there was no referendum then,'' Ruutel told the Congress. Byelorussian Communist Party chief Anatoly Malofeyev urged the deputies to support the treaty as a way out of the political and economic crisis, the state news agency Tass reported. Anatoly Sobchak, a Congress deputy and the mayor of Leningrad, told Tass he supported the Union Treaty to break the paralysis of power. Newly appointed Interior Minister Boris Pugo, apparently trying to reassure deputies who fear he will crack down on independence movements, said the republics' demands for sovereignty were inescapable. He said in a Tass interview, however, that he needs Congress' approval for more power to combat a nationwide breakdown of law and order. The Congress is expected to last 10 days. It is also scheduled to debate constitutional amendments to strengthen presidential power by adding a vice president and replacing the 89-member Council of Ministers with a Cabinet of about 15 people.

DOC.HEAD: 9-Year-Old Ballet Dancer Dies in Traffic Accident
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old ballet dancer on tour with the Indianapolis Ballet Theatre was struck and killed by a pickup truck, police said. Paul W. Bryant of Indianapolis was pronounced dead at Mecosta General Hospital about an hour after the accident at 6:30 p.m. Monday in Big Rapids Township, according to officials at the Mecosta County Sheriff's Department. Bryant's 7-year-old brother, Matthew, also was involved in the accident and treated for an ankle injury. Police said a pickup truck swerved to avoid the boys as they crossed a road. But the truck struck Paul, and a second vehicle also hit the youngster, police said. Neither driver was injured. Members of the ballet company planned a memorial service before tonight's performance of The Nutcracker Suite at Ferris State University. The victim was in one of 12 supporting roles held by children in the ballet. ``It's important for us as fellow dancers and fellow human beings to do this,'' ballet director Dace Dindonis said of the tribute. ``Dance is such a spiritual art form and that is what we want to emphasize, now, more than ever, is its spiritualness.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Criticized for Picking Priest as Winner in Haiti
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with capital quiet, comment from Aristide opponents, no new results. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAP1,2
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - A supporter of the former Duvalier regime today criticized the United States for saying a leftist priest apparently won the presidential election before complete, official results were released. He said such a move could incite violence in Haiti. The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a fiery champion of the poor, won as much as 70 percent of the vote in Sunday's elections, which also chose a new legislature, according to projections by the 800 foreign observers. The capital, Port-au-Prince, was quiet today after Monday's wild jubilation by Aristide's supporters and a shooting incident that left a woman dead. With slightly more than 1 percent of the estimated 2 million votes counted, Aristide had 70.6 percent; former World Bank official Marc Bazin 12.6 percent; agronomist Louis Dejoie Jr. 6.9 percent; and evangelical preacher Sylvio Claude 2.7 percent. Seven other candidates were in the race. The Electoral Council released the partial results Monday, but did not indicate when further results would be made public. It gave no explanation for the delay. Bernard W. Aronson, assistant U.S. secretary of state for inter-American affairs said Monday of Aristide: ``We fully respect him as the apparent president-elect of Haiti and look forward to closely working with his government.'' But a spokesman for Roger Lafontant, self-proclaimed leader of the Tonton Macoutes and of other supporters of the former 29-year Duvalier dictatorship, said the U.S. government had picked the winner before the results were in. He said that move ``could put people in the streets who will incite violence.'' ``The American government can't decide who won. It's against the law. You (the United States) don't have the right,'' said Serge Conille, executive-secretary of Lafontant's party, the Union for National Conciliation. Lafontant returned from exile this year and announced his candidacy, but was barred from running for president by the Electoral Council. ``We'll decide after the results are in how we are going to act, but it won't be in a violent way,'' Conille said. A spokeswoman at Bazin's party headquarters said he would not commet on the election until final results were in. Dejoie conceded defeat Monday. ``We are very disappointed, but we are democrats. If that's what the people want, it's okay,'' said Danielle Bazin, a party official and sister-in-law of Bazin. About 70 percent of the registered voters cast ballots Sunday for president, a 110-member National Assembly and local officials. Observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States said the vote was orderly and without fraud, despite delays and some irregularities at voting stations. Tens of thousands of Haitians poured into the streets Monday morning, singing and dancing, honking car horns and blocking traffic with their jubliant celebrations of Aristide's presumed victory. But at midday, police wearing gas masks fired into a crowd celebrating outside St. Jean Bosco Roman Catholic Church, killing a pregnant 44-year-old woman, then running her over in a blue pickup truck, witnesses said. Assassins attacked the church in September 1988 as Aristide was saying Mass, killing 12 people and wounding 70. Aristide escaped and went into hiding. An army statement denied responsibility for Monday's shootings, saying police had fired into the air to disperse demonstrators threatening to lynch an undentified man. Police in Haiti are under the authority of the army. The capital was nearly deserted as Haitians fled indoors, fearing more violence from holdovers of the Duvalier family regime, ousted in 1986 when Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled into exile. The only other time Haitians had a chance to freely choose their leader, in November 1987, 34 voters were shot and hacked to death at polling stations by thugs supported by the army. The vote was canceled. Aristide would take office on Feb. 7, the fifth anniversary of ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier's departure. Roger Lafontant, who led Duvalier's feared Tonton Macoute militia, said last week he would ``do anything'' to keep Aristide from becoming president, saying Haiti would ``never be delivered to communism.'' There has also been concern that the United States would not be pleased by the election because of Aristide's leftist ideology and anti-American rhetoric, which was toned down in the last few months. Aristide was expelled from the conservative Salesian order in 1988 for allegedly inciting the poor to revolt. He is a proponent of Liberation Theology, which encourages the poor to fight for their rights instead of waiting for an eternal reward.

DOC.HEAD: Simpson Named Assistant Chief in Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: David Simpson, news editor in Atlanta for The Associated Press, has been promoted to assistant chief of bureau. The appointment was announced Tuesday by Hank Ackerman, who succeeds Carl Bell as Georgia chief of bureau on Jan. 1. Simpson, 32, joined the AP in Atlanta in 1982, and was named news editor in 1989. He grew up in Huntsville, Ala., and received a bachelor of arts degree from the University of Alabama. Before joining the AP, Simpson worked for The Tuscaloosa (Ala.) News and the Selma (Ala.) Times-Journal. He succeeds Charlotte Porter, who has been promoted to chief of bureau in Phoenix.

DOC.HEAD: Government-In-Exile Agrees to Hand Over Symbols of Authority to Walesa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs, Walesa to get symbols of authority, National Assembly convening Friday and Saturday. Pickup 4th graf pvs, ``Justice Minister...''
DOC.TEXT: Poland's government-in-exile will hand over its historic symbols of authority to Lech Walesa at a ceremony Saturday after his inauguration as president, a spokesman for Walesa said today. Parliament Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz has called the National Assembly into session on Friday and Saturday. The assembly is to formally approve the election results Friday and witness Walesa's inauguration Saturday. Andrzej Drzycimski, a Walesa spokesman, said representatives of the government-in-exile were in Warsaw to discuss a ceremony to be attended by Ryszard Kaczorowski, president of the London-based government that dates to World War II. The transfer of symbols means the government-in-exile will cease to exist. Walesa, who won election Dec. 9, is expected to receive the insignia of power from Kaczorowski at Warsaw's Royal Castle, former seat of the presidency, after being sworn into office as president. On Monday, Polish authorities said they are investigating three generals and five colonels in the 1970 shootings of striking workers along the Baltic Coast that left at least 45 people dead. Walesa, then an unknown electrician in Gdansk, was among the leaders of the 1970 strike over food price increases that prompted the crackdown by security forces. The protests helped pave the way for the birth of the Solidarity free trade union movement a decade later. Justice Minister Aleksander Bentkowski did not name the officers under investigation, but said the initial order to shoot the workers was given by the late Wladyslaw Gomulka, then the Communist Party leader. A final decision on whether to put the eight officers on trial will be made by March, Bentkowski said. ``At present we have enough evidence to present charges against eight persons - three generals and five colonels who were directly involved in the events,'' Bentkowski told state television Monday night. ``I think that revealing their names is not proper now as the investigation is under way. We plan to end the proceedings by the end of March,'' he said. The Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper reported today that the military prosecutor had already presented preliminary criminal accusations against the eight. The newspaper said that unless the accused prove that they were acting in self-defense or out of higher necessity, they could be charged with homicide or abetting homicide. Official Communist accounts say 45 people, including 28 in the cities of Gdansk and Gdynia, were killed by security forces in the December 1970 anti-government protests, which began when workers went on strike to protest food price increases. Many people believe the death toll was higher, and investigations are being conducted to see if names of additional victims can be found. Victims of the 1970 shootings were buried secretly, often without family members being informed. Bentkowski said that so far 160 witnesses have been questioned in the case. He said Gomulka's order to shoot the protesters was relayed by the late Prime Minister Jozef Cyrankiewicz to Gen. Grzegorz Korczynski, the army commander in Gdansk. The strikes led to Gomulka's replacement as party leader by Edward Gierek, who remained in power until he was toppled after the August 1980 strikes that resulted in the founding of Solidarity. Walesa, who led the 1980 strikes, insisted that those who died in 1970 should not be forgotten. At Solidarity's insistence, a monument to the slain workers was unveiled in December 1980. On Sunday, the 20th anniversary of the killings in Gdansk, Walesa returned to the monument to pay homage to the slain workers. ``Solidarity was born from their blood,'' said Walesa.

DOC.HEAD: Edward Gnehm Is an Ambassador in Waiting
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Edward Gnehm, known to his friends as Skip, is usually the life of the party. But not this holidy season. ``People keep coming up to me at these Christmas parties and saying: `Didn't we give a going-away party for you six months ago?''' He says he and his wife are thinking of giving a ``we're still here'' party. Gnehm was packing in preparation for his post as the new U.S. ambassador to Kuwait when Iraqi President Saddam Hussein invaded that country Aug. 2. But that doesn't mean Gnehm is out of a job. On the contrary. He's been putting his experience - as a former deputy assistant secretary of state and a former deputy secretary of defense - to maximum use. Gnehm, who speaks Arabic, has traveled far and wide to recruit the support of Arab countries for the administration's anti-Iraq coalition. From Algeria in northern Africa, to Iraq' next-door neighbor Jordan, Gnehm has been making the U.S. case. His recent visit to Jordan was particularly emotional for Gnehm. He served in Amman as the deputy ambassador several years ago and still has friends there, many of whom berated him for U.S. policy on Iraq. Gnehm is determined he'll take up his ambassadorial post, although Kuwait will probably be a different country - more Adds Marian's 10-year-old neighbor, Carla Oliva: ``They're not just books to read for enjoyment. They teach you a lot of things . .. like how life is different for different people and how to get along with each other.'' Although Martin weaves serious themes into her books, she chooses not to address such weighty topics as sexual or substance abuse of any kind. It's not that the issues shouldn't be dealt with, the author said. ``I think there are a lot of girls who would benefit from reading about (them), but there are also first-graders out there who are reading these books and those subjects are too heavy for them,'' she said. So Martin sticks to more manageable problems, including the perennial trials of youth: ``Questions about their self-esteem, their self-worth. How important is it to be pretty, to be popular? All sorts of things that we worried about when we were younger. I don't think those things ever change.''

DOC.HEAD: Norwegian Vessel Sinks, Two Crewmen Killed
DOC.TEXT: A Norwegian freighter sank off Taiwan's southern coast Tuesday following an explosion, killing two crewmen and injuring at least one, a port official said. Twenty-three other crewmen were rescued by a Taiwanese vessel shortly after the freighter, Bow Reidun, sank about 90 miles south of Kaohsiung Port, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the vessel had been en route to Singapore from Japan. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known. The vessel had been used to carry chemical materials but was unloaded when the blast occurred, the port official said.

DOC.HEAD: Hamas Activist's Mother Says She Taught Her Son To Hate Israelis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Suzan is cq in 10th and 16th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: The mother of a Moslem fundamentalist ordered deported from Israel says he was a boy when he learned to hate Israelis for confiscating the family's land. Inaam Alami said she repeatedly took her seven sons to see the 375 acres once owned by her family and cultivated by tenant farmers. The area is near the Israeli town of Ashkelon. ``I told them from the beginning that the Jews took our land, and that the Jews should be killed for it,'' said Mrs. Alami, 62, who wears the floor-length dress and head scarf of observant Moslem women. Her son Emad, 34, is to be expelled as a leader of Hamas, the outlawed Moslem fundamentalist group that wants to destroy Israel and create an Islamic state in all of Palestine. He was ordered deported after three Israelis were stabbed to death on Friday. The army blamed Emad Alami and three other Hamas activists forl of the Gaza Strip. In Jebaliya village, Qnuih's partially paralyzed mother, Halime, who is in her 70s, said she was in bed when soldiers came for her son. ``They wouldn't let me say goodbye,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Carried Off on Ferry Ride to Florida
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia began the first leg of a two-day ferry flight to Kennedy Space Center today, NASA said. The Boeing 747 carrying the orbiter on its back took off at 7:03 a.m. Spokesman Don Haley said the 747 was scheduled to refuel at Biggs Army Airfield in El Paso, Texas, and would continue on to Barksdale Air Force Base in Shreveport, La., for an overnight stay before continuing on to Florida. If bad weather prevents the aircraft from going to Louisiana, the ferry crew will stay at Kelly Air Force Base at San Antonio, Texas. Columbia was launched Dec. 2 on a science mission. The seven-man crew operated telescopes in the payload bay to gather infrared and X-ray data from celestial objects. The mission was marred by problems controlling the telescopes but astronomers were elated by the data Columbia succeeded in bringing home. The planned 10-day mission was shortened a day when rain was forecast for the landing site. Columbia made a late-night touchdown on Dec. 10. The ferry flight from California was delayed two days by bad weather.

DOC.HEAD: How Long Could Iraq Wage War? It Depends on Pre-Embargo Stockpiles
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's ability to wage a prolonged war depends heavily on its military parts stockpiles, and analysts believe the trade embargo has left some critical weapons systems especially vulnerable to shortages. Saddam Hussein learned early in Iraq's war against Iran to build parts inventories and has spent billions manufacturing his own weapons and buying from other nations. But Pentagon and private analysts believe the combat stress on high-maintenance systems such as radar and jet fighters would drain Iraq's supplies, forcing it to cannibalize for parts and eventually leaving some sensitive systems weakened or inoperable. Absent combat, CIA Director William Webster has told Congress, Iraqi forces probably can sustain current readiness for nine months, with perhaps some erosion of air force capabilities in three to six months. Over the past decade Iraq has developed an arms industry that produces small arms, ammunition, artillery shells and some spare parts for tanks and other equipment. But Iraq is not believed capable of making engine and electronic parts it would need to keep its most sensitive equipment running in prolonged combat. Instead, Iraq would be dependent on reserves and perhaps underground arms markets. U.S. officials say there is no evidence of major cracks in the embargo. ``We think we clearly have been successful in closing off the flow of spare parts and military supplies from the Soviet Union and France, which previously were his major suppliers,'' Defense Secretary Richard Cheney told Congress. There have been several intervals since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait when Iraq's air forces have cut back patrol and training sorties, leading to speculation that parts already are scarce. Pentagon officials are reluctant to discuss intelligence on Iraqi stockpiles, but one source said Saddam is believed low on parts for French Mirage jets and probably would suffer shortages of components needed for radar systems if hostilities erupted and those installations were attacked. But Iraq has considerable stockpiles of most conventional equipment, the source said. ``He'll reach a point when systems will start to go down all over the place,'' said Bernard Trainor, a retired Marine general who visited Iraq near the end of the Iran-Iraq war. But Trainor also said that at the time of his visit Iraq had impressive stores of spare parts and had hired a Japanese company to computerize its inventories. ``Saddam should have a pretty good handle on what he needs and can plan accordingly, both in terms of strategy and in prioritizing what they look for in the markets,'' Trainor said. The Soviets have provided the United States information on Iraq's purchases of spares for Soviet-made equipment ranging from tanks and artillery to antiaircraft missiles and MiG-series fighters. And the United States has access to Israeli intelligence. These official analyses are somewhat suspect, however, because of Iraq's frequent dealings in the shadowy ``black and gray'' arms markets. ``Exactly what they have in the way of stocks and spare parts, nobody knows,'' one Army analyst said privately. ``But they are very sensitive to the fact that repair parts and repair times are costly and degrade combat power, so they plan against that.'' Most analysts believe Iraq would have aggressively stockpiled while planning the Kuwait invasion, remembering that in the early weeks of the Iran-Iraq war periodic shutoffs of Soviet parts hurt Iraq's fighting capabilities. ``When they go out and acquire something, they are very different from most Third World countries,'' said Lt. Col. Douglas V. Johnson, coauthor of a recent Army War College study of Iraq's military. ``They think of all the spare parts and repair stuff up front.'' James Blackwell of the Center for Strategic and International Studies said Saddam likely had enough spares to support the Kuwait invasion and a possible invasion of Saudi Arabia. ``If that's the case, then even if the embargo is 100 percent successful he can last a long, long time,'' Blackwell said. Potential sources of spares, the embargo notwithstanding, are arms traders in the Mideast, Asia and Central and South America. Before the Kuwait invasion, Iraq was spending an estimated $1 billion a year to import parts. It is now cash-poor because of the embargo and probably would quickly exhaust currency looted from Kuwait if it found spares on the black market. Libya is a potential source for additional financing, as are shady Mideast banks and financiers. Unclear is whether Iraq can complete arms deals if it has cash. ``If you've got cash, you can buy just about anything short of a nuclear weapon,'' said the Army analyst. ``But the price will be high in this market and the question is, how much cash does he have?'' Intelligence agencies track underground arms deals and Blackwell said the United States should be able to block Baghdad-bound shipments. Trainor was less optimistic. ``Saying you've got a handle on the illegal arms markets is like saying you've got a handle on the drug market,'' he said. ``I just don't believe it.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says More U.S, Iraqi Troops Deployed
DOC.TEXT: An additional 10,000 American troops have arrived in the Persian Gulf area since last week, and Iraq has added 10,000 soldiers in and around Kuwait, the Pentagon said today. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the U.S. force in the gulf now numbers ``more than 270,000'' soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines. By late January that number is expected to reach 430,000. Iraq now has 510,000 troops in the area, Williams said. He declined to discuss their exact locations. The Iraqis have added about 60,000 troops to Kuwait and southern Iraq over the past three weeks, according to Pentagon figures. Nations allied with the United States against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait now have about 220,000 troops in the area, Williams said. That is the same number Williams reported last week.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to correct category code
The Unkindest Cut of All
DOC.TEXT: Arun Vohra was only trying to be a good citizen when he warned the state highway administration about a diseased pine tree in front of his house. His reward: The state cut down seven healthy trees. The pine still stands. Vohra joined the state's Adopt-a-Highway program last spring, pledging to keep the woodsy road in front of his house free of trash and debris. In due course, Vohra spotted a pine tree that appeared to be infested with borers and called the State Highway Administration. The tree was in front of his house, but on state property. ``I felt the tree was dangerous and told them it was going to fall over and kill somebody, and if it hit overhead power lines there might be a big tragedy,'' he said. Days later, Vohra returned home to find that two other pine trees, three blooming dogwoods and a giant lilac tree had become victims of what he calls the Bethesda Chain Saw Massacre. The neighboring pine still stood. ``These were just awesome trees,'' Vohra says about the six that were cut down. ``You don't see that kind of trees every day.'' He got on the phone to the highway administration. ``The guy I talked to said, `We're sorry, it was a new man; he didn't know what he was doing,''' Vohra says. ``I guess he just went crazy with the chain saw.'' He was told that the holes in the pine he originally called about were made by woodpeckers whose foraging for bugs doesn't hurt a tree. Vohra says he called a couple more times, finally letting the matter drop until November. Then, he talked with Henry Page, the man in charge of the tree crews. ``He came to my house. I showed him the tree ringed with holes. He said, `Yes, yes, this tree has to come down. It's too close to power lines,''' Vohra says. Page told him the tree was too big for state crews; he'd have to call in a contractor. Vohra said he marked the pine tree with a ribbon, so there would be no more mistakes. But there was. The latest victim lay on the ground, neatly sawed - a cedar tree that had been 80 feet to 100 feet tall, by Vohra's estimate. The pine still lived. The Montgomery Journal, a daily county newspaper, wrote the story under the headline: ``They came, they sawed ... they blundered.'' ``I was just absolutely in shock,'' Vohra said. ``I acted a little crazy; I tried to call the governor of Maryland at the governor's mansion. I called the county police.'' And his state delegate. And his congresswoman. And the state department of natural resources. The next morning he telephoned Page. ``I said: `You cut down the wrong tree. You cut down a cedar, that lovely cedar tree.' He said: `The cedar is the one you pointed at.' I said, `We never discussed the cedar tree, that's 15 feet away.''' The Journal quotes Page: ``The dogwoods and lilac, that was a mistake. This particular time they just went in and made a boo-boo.'' But he insists Vohra pointed at the cedar and not the pine - which Page says is perfectly healthy. And so the pine remains. Vohra, deprived of the trees that shielded his property from the road, says he has ``a book on trees I'm going to give the state highway people so they know what a tree looks like.''

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Europeans May Regret Farm Subsidy Stand
DOC.TEXT: The European Community may suffer major political and economic damage by refusing to compromise in world trade talks over U.S. proposals for deep cuts in farm subsidies, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday. If it comes to an agricultural trade war with the EC, said Yeutter, the United States is prepared to fight. Negotiations among 107 nations in the so-called Uruguay Round of trade talks collapsed Dec. 7 in Brussels after the EC refused to bend on U.S. proposals on major farm trade issues, including cutbacks in internal price supports and export subsidies. The United States, backed by Australia, Brazil and other major exporters, sought sharp reductions in subsidies, while the 12-nation EC, Japan and Korea were against the plan. Efforts are being made to reconvene the talks in mid-January, but Yeutter said further negotiations would have little chance unless the EC is prepared to change its hard-line stance. But Yeutter told reporters he thinks some internal pressures are developing in favor of a reassessment of the EC position. Yeutter said he was Europe last week in the aftermath of the Dec. 7 breakdown and found the community to be ``very embarrassed by what happened in Brussels.'' The community ``will probably not concede that publicly, but the fact is they suffered a major geopolitical defeat in Brussels, with essentially all of the world leaving with dissatisfaction and disappointment in the EC position,'' he said. ``A lot of folks in Western Europe are chagrined by the present status of the Uruguay Round and are concerned that the (EC) may bear the lion's share of the blame for failure, should it occur,'' Yeutter said. Consequently, he said, a number of ``working level'' people in the EC are trying to reassess the bloc's position in hopes the stalled talks can be rejuvenated. But Yeutter said he didn't know at this point whether this can translate into changes at the EC's leadership level. ``I'm pessimistic about the potential outcome (of the talks) so long as the community maintains its present intransigent stance,'' he said. Earlier, in a telephone news conference with broadcasters, Yeutter he was not ready to tip off the EC what the United States might do if the Uruguay Round of talks fail completely. But Yeutter predicted that the EC potentially could be forced into spending all its allotted funds in 1991 trying to maintain high supports and export subsidies to keep pace with the United States. Of course, he said, the EC then could replenish its coffers but ``they would have to make a conscious decision'' to spend more on agriculture than they do now. ``We'll be spending more money, too, of course, and we'll have to find the financial resources to do that, and a lot of other countries will, as well,'' he said. Yeutter also hinted at other possible U.S. trade actions in case the trade talks fail but declined to be specific. ``I want them to be uncertain about what our response would be - and a bit frightened by the potential,'' he said. ``So, I'm not going to discuss publicly what the United States might do.''

DOC.HEAD: Professor Charged in 1982 Murder
DOC.TEXT: An Indiana State University professor was charged with murder today in the 1982 slaying of a 23-year-old man, authorities said. Professor Robert David Little, 53, surrendered to authorities hours after being charged with the murder of Steven Agan, said Teresa Baker, secretary to Vermillion County Prosecutor Larry C. Thomas. A hearing was scheduled later today. Little, chairman of the Department of Library Sciences at the Terre Haute university, has denied any wrongdoing. University officials said they would have no immediate comment on Little' status. Convicted murderer Larry Eyler claimed last week that Little assisted him in the 1982 mutilation slaying of Agan. Eyler was convicted and sentenced to death in the 1986 murder of a 15-year-old Chicago boy. He is in jail awaiting sentencing in Vermillion Circuit Court after pleading guilty to the murder of Agan. Agan's body, with multiple stab wounds, was found Dec. 28, 1982, in a field near Newport, about 40 miles north of Terre Haute. Eyler testified Thursday he and Little were looking for a sexual adventure when they spotted Agan and picked him up, eventually driving to an empty house where the slaying occurred. Eyler, 37, was identified in court documents as a suspect in the murders of 23 young men in Indiana, Illinois, Kentucky and Wisconsin from 1982 to 1984.

DOC.HEAD: LA Execs Send Sunglasses and Moisturizer To U.S. Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles executives playing Santa Claus sent a jet to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday carrying gifts they thought U.S. troops need in the desert: designer sunglasses, expensive cologne, toy cars and moisturizer. Troops watching the products being loaded onto trucks seemed a bit perplexed. Gucci sunglasses? ``That's outta there. Pilots wear Ray-Bans,'' said Capt. Rick Allison, 29, of Fort Walton Beach, Fla., with the 50th Tactical Airlift Squadron. And 15,300 bottles of moisturizer? ``We're lucky to get a shower. Who needs moisturizer?'' said Lt. Mike Smith, 30, from Little Rock, Ark., a member of the same squadron. High-top sneakers that would cost $130 per pair? ``There you go. This is getting better. I need a size 10,'' said Capt. Terry Isaacson, 28, from Duluth, Minn., another 50th squadron man. The largesse was part of an effort by employees of MGM Grand Air, who figured executives willing to pay $1,200 to fly from LA to New York might donate some nifty gifts for America's armed forces. A two-week gift drive netted 15 tons of goods, which arrived by jet Tuesday, so much that gift wrapping was dispensed with. Tons more was left in the United States by ``Operation Desert Cheer'' and will be sent along later. There was something about the clothes, cassettes and personal care products that said California. There was also something that said the donors were a little unclear about the life of the troops in the desert. One manufacturer sent pool cues. Another sent compact disks. A third sent electric drip coffeemakers. Others were obviously more attuned to the troops' tastes. The list of items on the plane's manifest included Frisbees and footballs and 2,000 music cassettes. The Los Angeles Lakers sent hundreds of jerseys and an autographed basketball. One toy manufacturer send 7,200 Hot Wheels toy cars, saying it had received requests from soldiers. ``I think they want to send them back to their kids in the states,'' said Leigh Kimball, director of marketing for MGM Grand Air. Former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, sent a large Christmas card, as did the Salvation Army. Mrs. Fields Cookies sent 20,000 of its confections. ``Those will be gone in a day,'' said Isaacson. One flight attendant, Patty Fonte, 25, of Los Angeles, took the trouble to bake and wrap her own cookies, which were wolfed down by troops on the tarmac. All at once, the troops realized there were several young female flight attendants watching the goods being loaded onto trucks for distribution in the desert. ``Hey, the stewardesses. Are they on the list?'' asked Isaacson.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Revokes Bail For Accused Kahane Killer
DOC.TEXT: A judge, disclosing that he had been threatened, revoked $300,000 bail for the man accused of killing Rabbi Meir Kahane. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Schlesinger said there was a strong likelihood that El Sayyid Nosair, 35, a native of Egypt, would flee. Among them was a passport Nosair held in a different name. The judge also noted that officials had found some cyanide in Nosair's locker where he worked as a city heating maintenance man. Schlesinger said the cyanide could be used to poison someone or commit suicide. The $300,000 bail had been stayed by the judge pending today's hearing, and Nosair had not been released. The judge said he believed prosecutors had a strong case against Nosair, who is accused of gunning down the Jewish leader at a Manhattan hotel on Nov. 5. During the bail hearing, the judge also disclosed that he received numerous death threats and attempts to influence him via telephone messages and mail. His admission prompted defense attorney Michael Warren to ask that Schlesinger remove himself from the case, which the judge promptly denied. Schlesinger said the threats and attempts to pressure him would not affect his handling of the case. The next hearing in the case was set for March 4.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Kill Security Guard, Steal Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf pvs, `Police found...' to CORRECT age to 67. Pickup 3rd pvs, `About 100...'
DOC.TEXT: ST-JEROME, Quebec (AP) - Thieves killed a security guard at a Canadian Forces armory today, took 20 semi-automatic rifles from a vault, then stole an army jeep to get away, police and the army said. Police found the body of the security guard, Armand Robert, 67, after responding to an alarm at the Royal 22nd Regiment armory. Robert's head was wrapped in a plastic bag, said Capt. Guy Lizotte, an army spokesman. About 100 weapons, including machine guns, are normally stored in the vault, but only the semi-automatic rifles were stolen. Robert, who had worked at the armory for 17 months, was the only guard on duty at the time and failed to make a scheduled telephone check-in with military police early today, said Lizotte. ``He didn't report in and we couldn't reach him,'' he said Lizotte. ``When we called municipal police they told us the alarm had gone off at 2:14 a.m. When their police car arrived, they found the murdered guard. Then they discovered the vault was opened.'' The thieves stole a jeep from a garage beside the armory and fled, police said. The vehicle was found nine hours later on the outskirts of St-Jerome, 30 miles northwest of Montreal. There were no immediate indications as to who stole the weapons or how many thieves were involved in the break-in, police said. There was no ammunition in the vault, Lizotte said. Robert was employed by a private security agency and was unarmed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Try To Reach Right-To-Die Patient To Feed Her
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with 20 arrests, comment from hospital director, chaplain, minister one of those arrested.
DOC.TEXT: Protesters tried to get to the hospital room of right-to-die patient Nancy Cruzan to reconnect her feeding tube today but guards halted them insidter in the morning because some of the protesters blocked the stairwell to the second floor, which also serves as a fire exit. State Trooper Dan Banasik, who helped remove protesters, said all refused to give their names and said they would stay and fast until Ms. Cruzan dies or her feeding tube is reinserted. Jasper County Probate Judge Charles Teel ruled last Friday that Ms. Cruzan's parents could remove the feeding tube that had kept their comatose daughter alive for seven years. Teel's ruling ended a landmark legal fight. He said he believed there was ``clear and convincing evidence'' that Ms. Cruzan would want to end her life. The protesters tried to get to Ms. Cruzan's second floor room at the hospital. Most were blocked by guards in a stairwell and a shut-down elevator. But 11 members of the group got to the second floor where they were confronted by 15 police officers. They did not get into Ms. Cruzan's room, where Joe and Joyce Cruzan were with their daughter. The Rev. Ted Coleman, a Mount Vernon minister on chaplain duty at the hospital, said the Cruzans were aware of the protests. ``They said they were aware. They said, `We're private people. We just want to be left alone,''' he said. ``If you're going to kill her, just put a pillow over her head,'' said one protester, who identified himself as Gary Tebbets of Kansas City. Other protesters refused to give their names to reporters - all identifying themselves as ``Nancy Cruzan.'' The Rev. Joseph Foreman of Montreat, N.C., who announced Monday he would lead 40 activists in an attempt to force-feed Ms. Cruzan, was one of those arrested. ``The best we can do is not cooperate with anyone trying to starve an innocent person to death,'' said Foreman, director of Prisoners for Life, which he describes as a pro-life group. Foreman is director of Prisoners of Christ, a pro-life prison ministry based in North Carolina. Dr. Ronald Cranford, a Mineapolis neurologist who had examined Ms. Cruzan, said she would probably die within about two weeks of the tube's removal. Ms. Cruzan suffered severe brain damage in a car accident near Carthage on Jan. 11, 1983. Doctors have said her condition is irreversible. Teel ruled in favor of disconnecting the tube in 1988. But the Missouri Supreme Court overturned it. After the U.S. Supreme Court's decision, the case was returned to Teel to determine if Ms. Cruzan would want to be allowed to die. Ms. Cruzan suffers from seizures, vomiting, bleeding gums and severely contorted limbs.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0569, AM-Gun Control transmitted Dec. 17 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following or a more in-depth story that will move shortly on this line.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Dec. 17 that the District of Columbia City Council was expected to give final approval on Tuesday to a bill that makes manufacturers and dealers liable for deaths and injuries caused by semiautomatic weapons. Final passage actually came last week. Mayor Marion Barry said Tuesday that he had signed the bill Monday. It still must undergo the 30-day congressional review required for all district legislation before it can become law.

DOC.HEAD: Private Program Aims to Create Housing for the Homeless
DOC.TEXT: The secretary of housing and urban development, Jack Kemp, announced on Tuesday a privately financed housing program for the homeless that will be encouraged with government tax breaks. The Federal National Mortgage Association is investing $10 million in the project, which will initially finance 600 units of rental housing for homeless and low-income people around the country. The program will target the homeless by, typically, creating small apartments, including some with one room and a shared kitchen. Both new buildings will be constructed and existing ones will be rehabilitated. Rents will be based on the ability to pay and will be subsidized with federal, state or local funds. This is the first time that low-income housing tax credits enacted by Congress in 1986 have been aimed at helping the homeless, said David Maxwell, FNMA's chairman and chief executive. Companies can earn income tax credits by putting money in a newly created investment fund, Corporate Housing Initiatives. While the bulk of the housing units will be for the homeless, some will house physically disabled and elderly people with very low incomes. The project is a ``progressive, bleeding-heart conservative approach'' to the problem of homelessness, Kemp quipped at a news conference. He said the program is an important step toward the goal of involving the private sector in attacking one of the nation's most serious social ills.
