FNMA's partner in the program is the Enterprise Foundation, which will help homeless and low-income residents obtain counseling, job training, child care and other services. Arranging social services as well as housing will provide an added boost to help the homeless ``move up and out of poverty,'' said Enterprise Foundation founder James Rouse. ``We have to look into deeper needs as well as provide housing.'' Local community development groups will screen potential participants in the program. The tax credits, which became law in 1986, have drawn $4 billion in private capital and spurred the development of 125,000 low-income housing units. FNMA's $10 million investment is the first of what the new initiative's sponsors hope will be many more corporate investors. Regulated by HUD, FNMA is a congressionally chartered private corporation supporting low- and moderate-income housing. Estimates of the number of homeless people in the United States range from 300,000 to 3 million. The U.S. Conference of Mayors found in a report in 1989 that the lack of affordable, low-income housing was a main cause of homelessness. Other causes were cited as unemployment, mental illness and drug and alcohol abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Believes Americans Would Support Military Action Against Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with new material, editing.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he believes Americans would support military action against Iraq if needed, but he conceded that the support would erode if the battle became a drawn-out one. ``The agony of Vietnam is still with us,'' Bush said at a news conference. At the same time, Bush said he does not believe Iraq's Saddam Hussein knows what he is up against. ``I think he basically is at best uncertain as to whether this force will be used against him,'' Bush said. ``What is essential to get the peaceful resolution is that he realizes he cannot prevail,'' Bush said. Referring to the inability to nail down a date for talks between Saddam and Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Bush said he was ``about where I was a couple of weeks ago'' when he proposed the talks. Bush said he is still hopeful a date can be nailed down for Baker to meet with Saddam Hussein. Bush was asked how long the public would support a war if Saddam did not comply with a United Nations deadline of Jan. 15 for withdrawing from Kuwait. ``I think that if the United States has to do its part to implement the United Nations resolutions, I believe the country would support that,'' Bush said. ``But I don't think that suppoprt would last if it were a long, drawn-out conflagration. I think support would erode, as it did during the Vietnam conflict.'' But, Bush said, ``This will not be, in my view, that kind of confrontation.'' Bush was asked if he would initiate offensive action against Iraq if necessary. ``I'm having the darndest consultations with Congress you've ever seen,'' Bush said. ``I hope I don't have to cross that bridge because I want a peaceful solution to that problem.'' He heatedly rejected the argument that ``there's some kind of racism in this deployment'' because of the disproportionate number of blacks and other minorities serving there. ``I reject it out of whole cloth. It's simply not true...This is the all-volunteer army,'' he said. He said the volunteers knew what they were getting into when they signed up. Underscoring the impending deadline for Iraq's withdrawal, Bush on Monday summoned ambassadors from 28 countries that have sent forces to the Persian Gulf since the Aug. 2 invasion. The United States alone has committed upwards of 430,000 troops. ``None of us wants war but none of us is prepared to accept a partial solution,'' the president said. ``There can and will be no negotiations for concessions and no rewards for aggression.'' Referring to Saddam, Bush said, ``I think at some point he will realize that this force, which is overwhelming, that is now being arrayed against him would be devastating. ... That's what the United Nations stated should happen, that he ought to get out or all available means should be used.'' In a decisive vote last month, the United Nations authorized the use of all means necessary to evict Iraq from Kuwait unless it pulls out by Jan. 15. ``And I want to see the United Nations resolutions fulfilled right on schedule,'' Bush said. Meanwhile, a U.S. Army planner said the service was ordering some retired personnel to active duty for the first time since the 1961 Berlin crisis. An initial callup of 15 retired Army physician assistants was approved last week, and about 200 more retirees probably will be involuntarily recalled for active duty over the next month, said Lt. Col. Henry H. Hanrahan. As the Jan. 15 deadline approaches, the Army and Navy have been increasing their deployment of medical specialists and equipment to the gulf area. Bush said he would not be opposed to Baker and Aziz meeting in a third country to break the stalemate on scheduling. However, he said, ``What I'm not going to do is shove these meetings right up against the United Nations deadline.'' Bush said Saddam ``does not understand the debate in this country'' as members of Congress and former military leaders argue that sanctions should be given more time to work before force is used. ``He thinks it means that our country is divided and we cannot go forward to do our part in implementing the U.N. resolutions,'' Bush said. ``And he's just as wrong as he can be.'' Aziz had been due in Washington on Monday to meet with the president. But that visit was put off when the two sides could not agree on a date for a return meeting by Baker with Saddam in Baghdad. Bush has said he wants Baker to meet with Saddam no later than Jan. 3 while Saddam has proposed a Jan. 12 meeting.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Actor Charlton Heston predicts that epic films like ``Ben Hur'' or ``Lawrence of Arabia'' will soon be as obsolete as silent movies. The movie, ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids' cost more than `Ben Hur,' so that means they don't makemovies like that,'' Heston said in an interview this week on the syndicated television show ``Personalities.'' ``They will never make a `Lawrence of Arabia' again. They will never make `Bridge on the River Kwai' again, which is too bad,'' Heston said. ``But we got to make those movies and I'm glad we did. ``People make fewer films now,'' Heston said. Heston, 67, also decried the high price of a movie ticket. ``You know, I just found out - because I get into a lot of movies for free - that they're charging $7 to go to a movie in Los Angeles now. Now, that's terrible.'' Heston won an Academy Award for his role as Judah Ben Hur. The film, about Roman rivalries in Jesus' day, is known for an 11-minute chariot race that Heston has said is the greatest action sequence ever filmed. --- MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP) - Country entertainers Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson are joining forces to develop a club where they can perform from time to time. The club, to be called ``Waylon and Willie's Cafe,'' will be on the city's Mud Island tourist park which is undergoing renovation as a companion project to the Great American Pyramid. The pyramid, a 32-story, stainless steel structure, is scheduled to open next summer. Mud Island, a struggling nearby tourist park, is being refurbished to become ``Festival Island.'' The island and pyramid, though both owned by local government, will be run by private companies controlled by businessman Sidney Shlenker. Jennings, in Memphis for a performance Monday night, said the club he plans with Nelson will have about 200 seats. Jennings said he and Nelson will perform there several times a year, but he didn't say exactly how many that meant. Mud Island is a three-mile-long sandbar in the Mississippi River. Most of the island is being developed as residential property. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Singer Julio Iglesias says he knows his limitations and that means his world is on a sound stage, not a movie set. Iglesias said he decided not to pursue an acting career because ``I am the worst actor on earth,'' the singer confessed in an interview to be shown on ``The Joan Rivers Show.'' ``I did a film 20 years ago and when I saw the film again, I felt guilty and embarrassed,'' he said. ``I need to sing,'' Iglesias told Rivers, but ``I don't need to spend two hours singing in a movie.'' Iglesias admits he would ``love to do that - it's such a nice situation to be an actor,'' but he says, ``I can't make it.'' --- CHICAGO (AP) - Patrick Lilley, the actor who played Eddie Munster in the 1960s television series, ``The Munsters,'' has pleaded innocent to charges that he robbed his limousine driver outside a suburban gas station. Lilley, 37, of Gardenia, Calif., entered the plea Monday before DuPage County Circuit Judge Edward Kowal. The actor and John P. Sullivan, 32, of Chicago, were in a rented limousine Nov. 2 when they allegedly robbed the driver of $140, authorities said. Lilley, who used the stage name Butch Patrick in the hit television series, was in the Chicago area making appearances at Halloween parties and signing autographs for fans, police said. He had been to two bars and was on his way to a Naperville hotel when the robbery occurred. Police said no weapons were involved in the robbery. Sullivan also has pleaded innocent.

DOC.HEAD: DEA Says Exhaustive Review Found No Evidence of Role in Flight 103 Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The Drug Enforcement Administration told Congress on Tuesday it reviewed more than 1,600 case files and found nothing that would even remotely support news accounts that a DEA undercover operation was entangled in the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland. The agency has consistently denied such reports, and the Justice Department, after a month-long special inquiry, said Dec. 4 there was no evidence to link the DEA and the December 1988 bombing, which killed 270 people. ``I assure you that those allegations are unfounded and that DEA had no part in this terrible tragedy,'' testified Stephen H. Greene, DEA assistant administrator in charge of operations. The DEA denied such allegations a year ago, but they resurfaced in October when both NBC and ABC reported that security at the Frankfurt airport, where the New York-bound flight originated, had been relaxed to accommodate DEA investigators who were tracking U.S.-bound drug shipments. The suggestion was that terrorists had taken advantage of the purported ``controlled delivery'' operation to smuggle a bomb aboard the plane. Greene told the House Government Operations subcommittee on government information, justice and agriculture that the agency, in the wake of the latest reports, reviewed more than 1,600 case files from 1984 through 1989 for any sign of an operation similar to the one described in the media. ``This file review revealed nothing even remotely resembling the alleged operation,'' he said. Greene told the subcommittee that security checks are never bypassed in controlled delivery operations - in which agents allow narcotics shipments to proceed to their ultimate destinations as a way of tracing them to key pushers. Greene and David Westrate, assistant administrator in charge of planning and inspection, scoffed at the notion that agents may have acted outside of agency policy and allowed a package to bypass security in defiance of rules. They said controlled deliveries are carefully run operations involving many individuals at both departure points and destinations as well as messages between American embassies and Washington. As a result, such an operation could not be hidden by an agent, they said. Greene said that in the fiscal years 1984 through 1989 the DEA ran only three such operations through the Frankfurt airport and none of them utilized a Pan Am flight. He said no controlled delivery was in progress at the time of the bombing, which killed 259 aboard flight 103 and 11 persons on the ground in the village of Lockerbie, Scotland. The news reports suggested that a DEA operation code-named ``Corea'' or ``Courier'' allowed the package containing the bomb to bypass security. ``There was no operation code-named `Corea' or `Courier' or anything similar to that name,'' Greene told the panel. ``DEA had no operation under any name which facilitated the free movement of drug couriers from the Middle East or Cyprus through Frankfurt an onward to London and the United States.'' ``On behalf of DEA, I would like to offer our sympathy to the families of the victims of flight 103,'' Greene said. ``These recent allegations against the DEA have just added to their grief.'' On Dec. 4, Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said the Justice Department inquiry, which involved the FBI as well as the internal DEA review, demonstrated that ``DEA had no investigative or operational activity in effect on Dec. 21, 1988 that involved the use of pan Am Flight 103 or Frankfurt International Airport.'' Greene testified that in 1987 the DEA ran a controlled delivery operation that traced a drug shipment from Lebanon to Cyprus to Frankfurt to New York and finally to Cleveland. He said TWA flights were involved but not Pan Am. Also in 1987, he said, German authorities in Frankfurt notified the DEA of a narcotics shipment that originated in the Mideast. It was allowed to proceed to Boston via Lufthansa, he said, where arrests were made. In 1983, Greene said, Frankfurt authorities notified the DEA of a shipment, which proceeded to Chicago via Lufthansa, then on to Detroit aboard and American flight and finally to Toledo, Ohio, where arrests were made.

DOC.HEAD: Only Woman Briefing Generals Wants To Make A Difference
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: First Lt. Patricia Mills had put in her papers to leave the Army before Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. Now, she's the only woman briefing the U.S. military command in Saudi Arabia. ``I just want to make a difference,'' said the 26-year-old intelligence officer who grew up in North Salem, N.Y., but currently lives in Atlanta. Immediately after the Aug. 2 invasion, she withdrew her papers, at least until the Persian Gulf crisis ends. Since she arrived here in late August, Ms. Mills has been working a 12-hour overnight shift tracking Iraqi ground movements so she can brief Lt. Gen. John J. Yeosack, the army commander, in the early morning. Despite her inside information, she said she doesn't know whether there's going to be a war. ``Some days, I think it's going to happen and it's going to be bad, but there are other days I think the longer it goes, the less likely it is that they're going to shoot,'' she said. Every day except Sunday, Ms. Mills stands before an array of strategic maps in the army's war room briefing Yoesack and his staff for anywhere between five and 20 minutes. She also helps prepare the morning intelligence summary. ``She is the only female daily `talking dog,' as briefers are called in the military, and she's a damned good one - composed and together,'' the senior Army ground intelligence officer in the gulf said on condition of anonymity. ``She's clearly a top-flight performer. ... She's articulate, quick and has a way of cutting through the fog of too much information.'' Ms. Mills said she has probably benefited from ``reverse discrimination'' in her four-year army career because the military is looking to promote women. She received airborne and air assault training following her graduation from Cornell University in 1986, then became a platoon commander in the demilitarized zone between North Korea and South Korea. She spent a year at Army Forces Command Headquarters at Ft. McPherson, Ga., before going to Panama, just before last Christmas' U.S. military operation to oust Gen. Manuel Noriega. Ms. Mills said she sees a lot of similarities between Saddam and Noriega, although Noriega ``hadn't built up his empire big enough to protect himself.'' Coming to Saudi Arabia and being selected to brief the high command was ``a big thing,'' she said. ``They don't necessarily want to hear the tactical situation from a woman,'' she said. ``Sometimes I think they'd just rather look at me than look at some guy briefing them - but hey, whatever.'' Despite the kudos, she said she has a love-hate relationship with the army. ``I think it's hard for women today in the army,'' Ms. Mills said. ``I want an equal chance. It's hard because there are certain things you have to do to get ahead, to be successful, and some of those things aren't available to women. ``It's hard when you get up top. The old boy network takes over sometimes.'' Ms. Mills said she wants to move forward but isn't sure whether to stay in the Army, work her way toward a command post or go to business school and pursue a civilian career in international relations. ``I'm really at the big spaghetti junction of life,'' she said. Meanwhile, she is jogging daily to relieve the stress of her job, and she just bought herself a golf putter to practice in her room.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Corps Plans Units Laos, Mongolia
DOC.TEXT: Peace Corps volunteers are expected to start work next year in Laos in a ``symbol of the healing'' war wounds in Southeast Asia, Corps Director Paul D. Coverdell said Tuesday. Top Laotian leaders approved the move in principle last week when Coverdell visited the country, one of the poorest in the world. It was the latest nation to be added in a record two-year expansion of the 30-year-old organization in Asia, Europe, Africa and Latin America. Coverdell said Laos and Mongolia - also scheduled to begin Peace Corps operations in 1991 - would be the first countries under Marxist rule to accept the U.S. organization. Talks are under way with China, Mozambique and Yugoslavia. Warsaw Pact countries began receiving Peace Corps volunteers over the past year after shedding communist rule. Coverdell said James Lehman, corps director for Laos, will go to Vientiane in mid-January to finalize details of the agreement, which requires formal approval of the council of ministers. Lehman was Peace Corps director in the Philippines, where operations were suspended after a communist insurgent group abducted and later released a U.S. volunteer. Discussions on resuming the program are continuing, Coverdell said. Plans to finalize a program for Bangladesh were postponed with the recent forced resignation of President H.M. Ershad. Negotiations with China, interrupted by the 1989 crackdown against the pro-democracy movement, are expected early next year, Coverdell said. The Peace Corps has more than 6,000 volunteers in six dozen countries. Volunteers returned this month to Panama, where the program was suspended in 1971. The agency also plans to re-establish ties with Nicaragua and Uruguay next year. Programs began this year in Bolivia, Ivory Coast, Haiti, Hungary, Namibia, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Sao Tome-Principe, a country off the west coast of Africa. Final or tentative plans call for new or revived programs in 1991 in Romania, Bulgaria, Congo, Guyana, Mozambique, Nigeria, and Uganda. In Laos, five specialists are expected to begin English teacher training in June. The number of U.S. volunteers there could grow to 60, Coverdell said.

DOC.HEAD: Physicists Recommend New Safeguards for Nuclear Weapons
DOC.TEXT: New safeguards are necessary to prevent an accidental nuclear explosion involving the nation's aging atomic weapons, three leading physicists told Congress on Tuesday. ``It's not a dangerous system now, but we can make it safer,'' Sidney D. Drell, who headed the panel, said in testimony before the House Armed Services Committee. There have been 32 accidents, only two in recent years, the panel said, adding that was a relatively low number. Since the 1950s when tensions between the superpowers grew, nuclear-weapon safety wasn't given the same urgency as modernization of those systems, the panel said in its report. In addition, modification has moved slowly and, because of budget limitations, the emphasis has been on acquiring new weapons. ``In anticipation ... many older ones remain in today's nuclear stockpile that do not meet present nuclear weapons design criteria,'' the report said. Recent technical advances have enabled scientists to use supercomputers to trace the development of a nuclear detonation in three dimensions rather than the previous limit of two, the report said. ``A major consequences of these results is a realization that unintended nuclear detonations present a greater risk than previously estimated (and believed) for some of the warheads in the stockpile,'' it said. The panel did not specify what the previous risk has been. Its members are Drell, deputy director of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center; Nobel laureate Charles H. Townes of the University of California at Berkeley; and John S. Foster, head of the Defense Science Board. The Armed Services Committee empaneled the three in May after questions were raised about the safety of several nuclear weapons systems, including the short-range, air-to-ground attack missile known as SRAM-A. Since then, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has taken the SRAM-A off Strategic Air Command alert bombers. The panel recommended, among other things, that all weapons be equipped with modern enhanced nuclear detonation safety systems and that all nuclear bombs on aircraft be equipped with insensitive high explosives and fire-resistant pits within the weapons. A point of contention is the Navy's Trident D-5 missile, whose nuclear warheads aren't equipped with insensitive high explosives. The warheads also are located near a third-stage rocket motor, which has a high energy propellant that could detonate in an accident. Drell suggested redesigning the D-5 missile with the special explosives and putting a non-detonable propellant in the rocket motor. The panel also recommended the creation of a special adversary group to examine and challenge nuclear weapons design; and a joint advisory committee to report directly to the secretaries of Defense and Energy. The agencies said in a one-page statement they would review the recommendations and called the panel's goals ``consistent with both departments' established priorities for safety.'' Rep. John Spratt, D-S.C., chairman of the Armed Services panel on Department of Energy Nuclear Facilities, said the committee's concern ``is not to condemn the nuclear community or establishment, but to see that safety is pushed'' to the limit.

DOC.HEAD: Police Recruits Have Ants in Their Pants to Graduate, But No Pants
DOC.TEXT: Ninty-nine police recruits may have ants in their pants to graduate, but the one thing holding them up is they just don't have their regulation blue trousers. The city is running out of cash and the next payroll is in doubt. To try to keep a bank balance, the city began deferring certain payments, including the one to the supplier of the regulation blue police uniform trousers. The Daily News says it's a case of ``pantemonium.'' The supplier won't ship until it gets the check for the regulation blues and the Police Academy says the officers can't graduate in their cadet black trousers because they are no longer cadets. Sgt. Terry Young, police spokeswoman, said graduation was first postponed until Dec. 26, the actual date when the recruit training program ends and the mayor and police commissioner can attend. Then it was delayed indefinitely until the pants arrive ``and we are hopeful that won't be long,'' says Capt. Richard Delise. If the made-to-order trousers aren't delivered, Delise said ``they'll try to see if there are enough pants in stock, even if not the exact made-to-measure sizes.'' That would make the uniform complete, though maybe not as spiffy. One unidentified recruit at the Police Academy said ``the mood is pretty low. To have this happen right before graduation is a real bombshell.'' It's not the first time the city's money shortage has affected operations at the Police Academy. The academy ran out of toilet paper earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Bus, Tractor-Trailer Rig Collide On Freeway; Six Reported Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with 7 dead, 16 injured. Picks up 6th graf pvs., `Two medical ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus collided with two tractor-trailer rigs near the Wyoming state line today. Seven people were killed and 16 were injured, authorities said. Summit County Sheriff's Sgt. Robert Berry said five of the injured were in ``very critical'' condition following the 9 a.m. crash. Blaine Whimpe, a witness, said a westbound truck apparently slid off Interstate 80 into the eastbound lanes, colliding with a second truck and the bus. It appeared the bus turned on its side and slid about 150 feet, he said, adding that the road condition was ``terrible.'' The National Weather Service said there was snow and wind gusting to 29 mph at Evanston, Wyo., at the time of the crash. The injured were being treated at Evanston Regional Hospital about 10 miles from the accident site, three or four with head injuries, said Craig Rasmussen of LDS Hospital, a sister facility in Salt Lake City. Two medical helicopters and a plane were sent from LDS Hospital, he said. Greyhound dispatcher Bill Moore said the bus left Salt Lake City at 8 a.m. en route to Chicago with more than 40 passengers aboard. Greyhound inspectors were dispatched to the accident. The Wyoming Army National Guard armory in Evanston has been opened for travelers who were on the bus, according to Sgt. Bob June, unit administrator for Battery C, Third Battalion, 49th Field Artillery.

DOC.HEAD: Bucking Farmers' Group, Yeutter Says '90 Farm Law Should Stand
DOC.TEXT: Any serious effort in Congress to rewrite the 1990 farm law would be a big mistake, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Tuesday. Last week in Denver, the board of directors of the National Farmers Union called on Congress ``to reopen and rewrite parts'' of the five-year law passed this year. The NFU directors said the 1990 law will devastate family farmers and rural areas unless changes are made. Yeutter told broadcasters in a telephone news conference that ``opening the farm bill would be a big mistake for everyone, including the folks from the Farmers Union.'' In the view of some critics, a problem with the 1990 legislation is that it was subject to federal budget-cutting restraints. This pared $13.5 billion from commodity program operations over five years. One result was to reduce the amount of acreage eligible for direct subsidies, or ``deficiency payments,'' under annual crop programs. Critics say this will cut into farm income. ``In my judgment, U.S. agriculture came out very well in the budget exercise, when one considers the circumstances under which that bill was legislated,'' Yeutter said. But he added, ``There are still some folks in American agriculture who believe that the $26 billion in federal subsidies that was provided in 1986 ought to be the norm and that if they just make a strong enough appeal in Washington, that would still be possible.'' That was a reference to the record $25.8 billion paid to farmers in fiscal 1986 under Agriculture Department commodity programs. Those payments since have declined to a fraction of that annual rate. Yeutter said he sees ``no chance whatsoever'' that Congress would return to the agricultural spending levels of the past. Rather, he predicted that if lawmakers reopen the farm bill debate the chances would be 50-50 that spending would be cut, not raised. Bob Denman, a National Farmers Union spokesman in Washington, said no one had suggested that commodity spending be boosted to $26 billion a year over the five years of the law. But the NFU does believe some parts of the law can be strengthened and adjusted to help protect family farmers more than the 1990 act does.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with comment from president of U.S. company promoting sweepstakes, and from company spokesman. Picks up 7th graf, `The winner ...' Should stand for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT2 of Dec. 17
DOC.TEXT: The official Soviet news agency said today a telephone sweepstakes offering an American a chance to travel to the Soviet space station was a hoax. But the president of the American company promoting the offer said the Tass report referring to the sweeepstakes as a ``cosmic canard'' was a misunderstanding. ``We basically have our contract in hand, so we know that we're basically straight. it's just a matter of of us finding out what's going on behind the scenes in the Soviet Union, to find out where the confusion lies,'' said David Mayer of Space Travel Services. Glavkosmos, the Soviet equivalent of NASA, said it did not know anything about the project, Soviet officials told Tass. Vladimir Zenkin, deputy commercial manager at the Energia agency, said there were no deals to allow an American to spend a week on the space station Mir in 1992 or 1993. Tass referred to the sweepstakes as a ``hoax.'' Space Travel Services offered callers to a 900-number a chance to win six months' training, a trip aboard a Soviet rocket and a week on the space station Mir. Entrants paid $2.99 a call. No-cost entries can be sent by mail. Thousands of calls Monday, the first day the line was open, overloaded the circuits. The line was working again early today. ``Space Travel Services Corp. has a legal contract with NPO Energia for a trip to the Mir Space Station aboard a Soyuz vehicle,'' spokesman George Nelson said. ``Two contracts are involved. One between Space Travel and Space Commerce Corp. of Houston and a second between Space Commerce and NPO Energia of Moscow.'' Mayer said the Tass report was ``obviously just a misunderstanding and I don't think it will be that difficult to clear up.'' The winner, to be selected in a drawing in December 1991, was to get the trip plus $500,000 in cash, or can forgo the trip and take $1.5 million. ``Our long-term business strategy is to arrange for space travel opportunities for anyone who wishes to go into space,'' said James Davidson, senior vice president of Space Travel Services. ``To introduce this service and our company to the general public, we've arranged for a little sweepstakes. The trip to the Mir space station is the ultimate adventure.'' Davidson said the company has signed a contract with Soviet officials but refused to disclose the terms. Mayer said the company would pay more than the $12 million paid the Soviets by the Tokyo Broadcasting Service for a Japanese reporter's recent ride. Sergei Zavgorodny, a spokesman for the international department of Glavkosmos, the Soviet equivalent of NASA, said he was unable to confirm the deal. ``I know nothing about this lottery,'' he said, ``but the Soviets are ready for commercial talks on launching any man into the Mir station. The only question is whether the winner is physically fit for the flight.'' In Moscow, a secretary who answered the phone at Energia, the Soviet rocket making company, said she knew there was an agreement with an American company, but she did not know any details. She said the person in charge was out of the office until Wednesday. Art Dula, whose Houston-based Space Commerce Corp. markets Soviet space services in the United States, said he negotiated the deal but also declined to release details. The Soviets, for a hefty price, have taken several passengers to Mir, but never an American. Space Travel Services keeps more than 50 percent of the phone charges and also hopes to sell advertising space aboard the spacecraft. Company officials said they chose not to attempt such a project with the National Aeronautics Space Administration. ``NASA has repeatedly made clear they they're not really interested in opening up the shuttle to the general public and definitely not for commercial purposes,'' Mayer said. The Soviets, however, ``realize there was a buck to be made and that's what they want to do with their space program,'' he said. NASA spokesman Dave Garrett was reluctant to comment on the competition. ``They're free to do what they want,'' he said. ``We certainly don't have a monopoly on sending people into space. I don't think we would ever do it on the basis of being selected by lottery, though. We would do it on the basis of people having something worthwhile to do.'' Space policy analyst John Pike, a member of the Washington-based Federation of American Scientists and a critic of the U.S. space program, was exuberant about the sweepstakes. ``That's fabulous. That's great,'' he said. ``Where can I buy a ticket?'' Because of local laws on sweepstakes, people listing addresses in New York, Florida or Rhode Island are ineligible. The deadline to enter is Dec. 1, 1991. --- Eds: The telephone number is 1-900-258-2MIR. In addition to calling a 900-telephone number to enter the space sweepstakes, entries also can be mailed. Entrants must print their name, address, city, state, ZIP code, telephone number and the words ``Space Travel Services Ultimate Adventure'' on a 3-by-5-inch piece of paper. Mail to: P.O. Box 580249, Houston, Texas, 77258-0249. No photocopied or mechanically reproduced entries will be accepted.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... a confrontation.
DOC.TEXT: And so, I think that if - if the United States had to do its part to implement the United Nations resolutions, I believe the country would support that. But I don't think there would - that support would last if it were a long, drawn-out conflagration. I think support would erode, as it did in the Vietnam conquest - I mean, conflict. So - but I can understand why some young kid would ask that question. I mean they keep hearing of this prolongation and that there'd be stalemate and all of this kind of thing. I don't believe that and one of the reasons that I moved this additional force, or had it moved was because every individual life is precious and if there had to be some confrontation, military, I would want to see - be able to assure the parents and the families there is enough force there to minimize the risk to every single American kid and coalition kid - the Desert Rats, the French Legions, and the Arabs that we'll be fighting side by side with. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, what prompted the administration's change of thinking - some might less kindly say flip-flop - on the question of whether financial aid can be targeted to minorities, and I have a brief follow-up on that. A: I don't think there was any flip-flop on it. There was a ruling made by a man of great integrity in the Department of Education and when we heard about it here I expressed a certain concern, asked that the policy be reviewed, and indeed today the department issued a policy statement that is - that I think has Mr. Williams, who was the promulgator of the original regulation - or ruling - happy and yet it does do what I want to see and that is to continue these minority scholarships as best we can. I met with a group of editors earlier on today and the question comes up, ``Well, will there be a legal test?'' I am not a lawyer and I don't know how the courts will rule. Eventually they will rule on it. But as for now we have worked the regulation so that we can continue to have these kinds of scholarships. I have long been committed to them, I have long been committed to affirmative action and so I hope the ruling, which is - some of it's quite technical, will accomplish that end. But I would like to think that the matter can be resolved with finality this way but I don't think that's what we've done. I think it's going to be - I think there'll probably be some court challenges to this. You wanted to follow up? Q: Yes, just briefly. I think there is some question how a decision of that magnitude in the civil rights arena could have been made without knowledge of the White House. A: Well, it was made without the knowledge of the White House and I would simply refer you to Mr. Williams, who is a very able attorney over there in the Education Department. I think he explained that in his press conference. Yeah? Q: I'd like to ask you about the moral consistency of the U.S. policy on Iraq. During the 1980s, Iraq waged an aggressive war of - a brutal - a war of brutal aggression against a different neighbor, Iran. It also used chemical weapons against Iranians and against its own Kurdish population. It also worked on its nuclear program. But rather than go to war against Iraq in that case, the United States took Iraq's side. In the case of the chemical weapons, the Reagan and then the Bush administrations opposed all efforts to impose sanctions in protest against the use of chemical weapons. And in the nuclear area, the United States condemned Israel for setting back Iraq's nuclear program. So my question is, is it hypocritical now to threaten war over conduct by the same regime when the similar conduct was condoned or even supported against different adversaries in the recent past? A: No, I don't think it's hypocritical whatsoever. Here you have the United Nations moving in concert. You have an unprecedented use of the peace-keeping function of the United Nations, and I was very proud that the United States was a leading component in what the Security Council did. And it is true that our administration and others previously tried to work with Iraq. But this brutal aggression, this - this - what they did here is such a clear violation of international law that the entire world was united in opposition to it. So, if there was a mistake made in trying to move them along a more civilized path by having contacts as we did, fine. But this kind of - this kind of revisionistic view that that makes what's happening today wrong, I'm sorry, I don't agree with it at all. And I think we're on the right path. I think the whole world is united against this. And clearly, I'd like to have been clairvoyant so I could have seen that the man was lying when he said he wasn't going to invade Kuwait, which he did say. And he told Hosni Mubarak this, for example. But we weren't quite that - it wasn't quite that clear at the time. Yeah?

DOC.HEAD: European Allies To Iraq: Settle Dispute Over Talks With U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comment, new Pentagon figures on troop strength. Pick up 5th graf pvs, ```Europe does...'; edits to TRIM.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BRU2, DHR1,3,4,5
DOC.TEXT: Both the United States and Iraq on Tuesday expressed the resolve, if not the wish, to fight a war in the Persian Gulf. European nations refused to receive an Iraqi envoy unless the Baghdad government talks with Washington. Less than a month before a United Nations deadline for Iraq to relinquish Kuwait or face potential attack, President Bush said he believed the American people would support a military strike. ``I think that if the United States has to do its part to implement the United Nations resolutions, I believe the country would support that,'' he told reporters in Washington. Bush acknowledged public backing would probably erode in the event of a ``drawn-out conflagration'' but added: ``This will not be, in my view, that kind of confrontation.'' The Baghdad government, too, gave every indication it was girding for war. Thousands of military reservists reported for duty in the latest Iraqi callup, and the ruling Revolutionary Command Council said Iraq was ``ready for the decisive showdown.'' The Pentagon said Iraq had deployed another 10,000 troops in and around Kuwait in the last week, bringing its troop total in the area to 510,000. Iraq seized the emirate 4{ months ago. An additional 10,000 American troops arrived in the region during that time, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. U.S. troops in the gulf will number more than 400,000 by mid-January. Nations allied with the United States in a coalition against Iraq now have about 220,00 troops in the area. That coalition reaffirmed its solidarity on Tuesday. European Community foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels, refused to meet with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz unless he first goes to Washington for talks. ``Europe does not want to lend itself to any bid by Iraq to drive a wedge between the EC and the United States,'' said Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek. Aziz had been tentatively set to go to Washington on Monday, but the visit was canceled after the United States and Iraq were unable to agree on a date for subsequent talks in Baghdad between Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Saddam. Baker, also in Brussels to meet with NATO allies, said the United States would not object to a European meeting with Aziz, as long as no ``mixed signals'' were sent about the allies' position. He said Saddam ``may well attempt further diplomatic sleights-of-hand in the days ahead,'' but ``we are all agreed that we must not allow his manipulations to divert us.'' The Bush administration has told Saddam not to stage a partial withdrawal from Kuwait as a ploy. Even with Baker's go-ahead to hold talks with Iraq, the Europeans said seeing Aziz - who had been invited before the U.S.-Iraqi talks were derailed - would send the wrong signal to Baghdad. ``We maintain the pressure on Iraq,'' said Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the community's executive body. The Iraqi Foreign Ministry said the EC was only trying to appease the United States. Iraq has tried to set Jan. 12 as a date for the Baker-Saddam meeting. The United States says that is too late, because it comes only three days before Jan. 15. After that date, the Security Council has authorized using ``all necessary means'' to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Even if the U.S.-Iraqi talks get back on track, a Turkish report quoted Saddam as saying they would be useless if the American side merely reiterates Security Council resolutions demanding a full pullout. ``We would not go to the United States to get orders,'' Saddam told a Turkish television journalist. ``If Bush is going to repeat to us the U.N. decision (calling for a complete withdrawal), there is no need to go there.'' The Bush administration has said urging Iraq to comply with U.N. resolutions would be the principal focus of any talks. ``We have already read them, we know them and we rejected them,'' Saddam said, referring to the resolutions. The interview was to be broadcast this week on state Turkish television, and excerpts were released Tuesday. In Iraq, thousands more reservists reported to their army units Tuesday as part of a major military mobilization. Most of the reservists involved in the latest callup served during the 1980-88 war with Iran. Iran, meanwhile, had some words of warning for its old enemy. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted President Hashemi Rafsanjani as saying the Baghdad government would have itself to blame if it were attacked. ``We are feeling very uneasy over the fact that the Iraqi people may be hurt by the Americans,'' Rafsanjani told a group of students. But he added: ``The responsibility for this rests with the Iraqi regime.'' In other developments: -Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Colin Powell, were to leave Tuesday night for Saudi Arabia to talk with officials and meet with troops. -Prince Charles will visit British troops in the gulf this weekend, Buckingham Palace said Tuesday. Princess Diana will not be with him, but she will fly to Germany Wednesday to visit families of British soldiers serving in the gulf region, the palace said. -Soviet Mideast envoy Yevgeny Primakov said the departure of 2,500 Soviet workers from Iraq has been delayed only by technical matters and the desire of many to remain until their contracts expire. There had been speculation Baghdad was trying to hold the Soviet contract workers as hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Kingpen Fabio Ochoa Surrenders in Colombia
DOC.TEXT: Fabio Ochoa, youngest of three brothers who the government says are major figures in the Medellin cocaine cartel, surrendered to authorities Tuesday in northwest Colombia, local radio reported. Ochoa, 33, became the first cartel leader to turn himself in, accepting a government offer of no extradition and reduced jail sentences for drug traffickers who surrender, RCN and Caracol radio networks reported. National police press spokesman Maj. Jorge Martin said he could not yet confirm the report. Ochoa is wanted on drug trafficking charges in the United States. He helped lead the Medellin drug gang along with his brothers Jorge Luis and Juan David, authorities say.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Posts Moderate Increase
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 6 grafs new with Federal Reserve cutting discount rate, picking up 6th pvs, Evidence that
DOC.TEXT: Christmas discounting, a sluggish housing market and a sharp moderation in the rise of energy prices combined in November to dampen inflation to 0.3 percent, the government said Tuesday. The seasonally adjusted increase in the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index represents an annual inflation rate of just 3.7 percent, down sharply from the 8.9 percent inflation rate during the three months after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The improvement allowed the Federal Reserve Board to take dramatic action to stimulate the economy and cushion the effects of the recession most private economists believe the nation has entered. The central bank cut its key bank lending rate, known as the discount rate, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, effective Wednesday. The move, announced about 30 minutes before the close of trading on Wall Street, sent stock prices surging. It was the first cut since August 1986. Lower interest rates help the economy by making it cheaper for individuals and businesses to borrow. But, by stimulating demand, that tends to increase inflationary pressures. ``The Fed ... needs to be worrying about the economy going down more than it needs to be worrying about inflation right now,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch in New York. Evidence that the economic downturn, including slow Christmas sales, is restraining prices was sprinkled throughout Tuesday's report, analysts said. Clothing costs fell 0.2 percent for the second consecutive month; home furnishing prices dropped 0.7 percent. And entertainment commodities inched down 0.1 percent. That includes most televisions, radios and other electronic equipment given as gifts. ``Retailers are making sales, but they're doing it at discount prices,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York. ``Sale prices are much more widespread and floor traffic appears to be much less dense than before past Christmases.'' Prices outside the volatile food and energy sectors, taken by economists as the best measure of underlying price pressures, also rose a moderate 0.3 percent, the same as in the previous two months. The effect of sluggish housing markets and even home price declines in some regions showed up in homeowners' monthly payments, which remained unchanged in both November and October. They account for $1 of every $5 spent by consumers. Brusca and other economists said the underlying trend toward tamer inflation had been masked by the shock to energy prices after the Persian Gulf crisis began. But in November, energy prices rose only 0.5 percent after jumping 15.1 percent over the previous three months. ``The oil bubble has really pretty well passed through now,'' said economist Robert G. Dederick of Northern Trust Corp. in Chicago. ``We're going to have some rather pleasant readings, temporarily, on the reverse side of the bubble.'' Gasoline prices rose 0.3 percent after a 7.7 percent jump in October. Fuel oil prices, which increased 50.8 percent in the preceding three months, fell 3.8 percent in November. But natural gas costs were up 3.2 percent and electricity charges rose 0.6 percent. Inflation of prices for services, as opposed to goods, has reacted less strongly to the slowing economy. Medical care, for instance, rose a hefty 0.8 percent in November and was 9.4 percent more expensive than a year ago. Overall, they were up 0.4 percent. Other higher-than-average price increases included: -New cars, up 0.6, but only the third rise in 10 months. -Airline fares, up 3.6 percent in November and 8.4 percent over the past three months after the rise in aviation fuel. -Tobacco, up 0.7 percent for the month and 11 percent over the past year. Food and beverage prices rose 0.4 percent, pulled up by a large 2.7 percent increase in fruit and vegetable prices. The cost of beef, pork, fish and eggs also rose. However, prices fell for poultry, cereal and bakery products and dairy products. ``Especially in the West, it was very, very dry and we struggled with the fall (fruit and vegetable) crops,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. ``But unless we have a big freeze, that shouldn't continue.'' The various changes put the index for all consumer goods and services at 133.8 in November. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services that cost $100 on average in the 1982-84 base period cost $133.80 last month, up from $125.90 a year ago. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' real earnings increased a seasonally adjusted 0.5 percent. Still, over the past year, wages have not kept pace with inflation. Average weekly earnings for both full-time and part-time, non-supervisory workers were $348.49 in November, up 3 percent from a year ago. For the first 11 months of the year, consumer prices rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.4 percent - the worst rate since 1981 and well above last year's 4.6 percent rate. However, economists expect the inflation rate to subside to between 3 percent and 4 percent next year as the slumping economy further weakens demand and as oil prices turn down.

DOC.HEAD: Curfew Shuts Most of Taj Mahal City, Seven Killed Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: More than half the city that is home to the Taj Mahal was under curfew Tuesday after three days of riots between Hindus and Moslems, but the 17th century architectural masterpiece reopened to tourists. At least 11 people were killed and 49 injured in Agra in riots that were the latest in a wave of sectarian clashes to have swept several cities across India, claiming at least 307 lives in 12 days. Residents stood watch on rooftops and alleys near the Taj Mahal, ready to sound alarms at the first sign of trouble. A curfew was in force in eight of Agra's 15 districts, police said. Elsewhere Tuesday, two people were stabbed to death in the southern city of Hyderabad and five people were killed in the western city of Ahmedabad, Press Trust of India reported. At least 16 people were injured in a bomb explosion, and 14 people were hurt in stabbings and stone throwing in Ahmedabad. Two weeks ago, a Hindu fundamentalist group revived a plan to build a temple on a site already occupied by a mosque in the sacred town of Ayodhya, 250 miles east of Agra. The temple campaign caused sectarian clashes in at least 12 other towns, the most violent in Hyderabad, more than 620 miles south of Ayodhya. Although Hindu-Moslem clashes have occurred frequently since India's independence in 1947, the brutality of the attacks this time numbed the country. In several towns, babies and women were targeted by masked men who roamed at night, defying police and a curfew to hack their victims with axes or to stab them with swords, knives and daggers. In Hyderabad alone, 28 children were among the 151 people killed since Dec. 7. More than 100 people have been killed in 11 towns of Uttar Pradesh state, where Agra and Ayodhya are located. Agra residents said it was the first time sectarian clashes took place in their city of 1.4 million people. Thirty-five percent of Agra's population is Moslem. Most of the rest are Hindu. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus account for 82 percent. Agra officials said many Moslems in the town fled their homes after Hindu mobs set them on fire. About 600 took shelter in a school, said Ahmed Hassan, a city councilman. ``All these people have lost their property. Most of their houses have been burned or destroyed,'' said Hassan, a Moslem. Mohammad Abdul, the 65-year-old owner of an iron factory in a predominantly Hindu neighborhood, said his Hindu neighhors urged him to stay when the clashes erupted, assuring him that he would be safe. But ``they also stoned us when the trouble started,'' Abdul said at the school where he had taken shelter. ``We are still in a dangerous position. We don't know what will be in the future.'' About a dozen foreign tourists went to the Taj Mahal Tuesday morning. On a normal day, hundreds of people flock to the white marble mausoleum, built by Mogul Emperor Shahjahan in 1648 in memory of his beloved wife, Mumtaz Mahal, who died giving birth to his 14th child. The manager of a luxury hotel nearby said he had 80 percent occupancy before the trouble started. On Tuesday, it was 6 percent and most guests were journalists, said the manager, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

Here is the text of President Bush's news conference Tuesday with regional reporters in the Old Executive Office Building. President Bush: Let me just make a quick comment, and then I'll be glad to take some questions. But I want to just comment once again on the situation in the Gulf, because, you see, ever since Aug. 2, the world community has been virtually united in its condemnation and in its rejection of Iraqi aggression. I've been talking about the Security Council resolutions, but the General Assembly of the United Nations, with only one vote against it - Iraq - joined in condemning what has gone on by Saddam Hussein, and I think that's a very significant point, because those who were saying, ``Well, it's only the Security Council'' now have to recognize that what we've been saying all along is true, that it is not Saddam Hussein against - and the Arab world against the United States, but indeed it is - it is Saddam Hussein against the rest of the world. And so, I mention this because we're coming down towards this UN-mandated deadline. I still want to see a peaceful solution to this question. You keep hearing about new initiatives, President Bendjedid of Algeria, but I gather that that has gone about as far as those initiatives that others have undertaken. Bendjedid, good credentials on all sides of this dispute, but unable to talk sense to Iraq's dictator. So, I would just simply say that we will keep trying to find an answer. It cannot be an answer of concession. It cannot be an answer where Saddam Hussein is rewarded with one single concession, because that would fly right in the face of the rejuvenated United Nations peace-keeping effort and it simply is unacceptable, not just to us, but to the rest of our coalition partners. And you look at what the EC said yesterday - or today I guess it was - regarding the visit of Tariq Aziz, when they said there would be no point in his coming to see them unless the visits with the United States had taken place. It shows a real solidarity, because the temptation might have been the other way. So, I think the coalition is holding. We are determined, more determined than ever. Yesterday I had a meeting with 27, I believe it was, other - ambassadors from other countries. The 28 standing together in the gulf represented a show of solidarity that I think was read loud and clear halfway around the world. So, that's where we are, and there is no news to report on the proposed Secretary of State's visit - the visit of the Secretary of State to Baghdad or indeed of the Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz coming here. So, with no further ado, I'd be glad to take questions on any subject. Yeah? Let me get these first. One, two. Q: Are you more optimistic or less optimistic at this point about the possibilities of going to war compared to when you made the proposal to send Mr. Baker to Iraq? A: Well, if I had to quantify my degrees of optimism or pessimism, I'd say it's about in the same mode as when it was there. I do not believe that Tariq Aziz (sic), one, knows - or has digested what he's up against in terms of this - of this coalition force, and secondly, I think he basically is at best uncertain as to whether this force will be used against him. And so, I can't - what I think is essential to get the peaceful resolution is that he realizes that he simply cannot prevail. So, I guess I'm about where I was a couple of weeks ago when I made that proposal. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, I'd like to ask you a question that one of our readers of the Detroit Free Press suggested I ask you. And it's from an 18-year-old from Birmingham, Mich. His question is if the war in the gulf escalates, how will you get the American people to support the war? And it's a common theme of our readers' questions. It seems to ask whether you think the American public is as willing to accept war as an option as your policies seem to be. A: I'm out - I don't want war as an option; I want peace as an option. Secondly, I think some of those questions stem from the fact that some believe this, quote, ``will be another Vietnam,'' unquote. And the agony of Vietnam is still with us. People remember a protracted war. They remember a war where individuals were asked to fight with one hand tied behind their back, in essence. This will not be, in my view, that kind of a confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: `Goodfellas' Named Best Film By New York Film Critics
DOC.TEXT: The Mafia film ``GoodFellas,'' its director, Martin Scorsese, and its co-star, Robert De Niro, won top awards Tuesday from the New York Film Critics. ``GoodFellas,'' based on Nicholas Pileggi's book ``Wiseguy,'' about a hood named Henry Hill who turns on his former pals and joins the federal witness protection program, was named best movie of the year by the group, comprising 28 critics for New York-based publications. Scorsese was named best director for ``GoodFellas.'' De Niro was named best actor for his work in that film and in ``Awakenings,'' in which he plays a coma patient who awakens years later. Ruth Prawer Jhabvala won for best screenplay for ``Mr. and Mrs. Bridge,'' the story of an affluent mid-America family starring Paul Newman and Joanne Woodward. Woodward, who plays Mrs. Bridge in the film, was named best actress. The best supporting actress award went to Jennifer Jason Leigh for ``Miami Blues'' and ``Last Exit to Brooklyn,'' a harsh and startling look at the Brooklyn waterfront during the 1950s. Bruce Davison of ``Longtime Companion,'' a poignant portrait of a group of homosexual friends living through the AIDS crisis, won the award for best supporting actor. The critics gave an award for best first film, to Whit Stillman, director of ``Metropolitan,'' about the existential meanderings of Park Avenue preppies.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... time. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, on the question of the economy, you yourself have mentioned that you would support some economic stimulus perhaps, and I'm wondering if in the new year you're going to propose any tax cuts, capital gains in particular, or perhaps a cut in the payroll taxes for Social Security? A: Well, I haven't changed my view on the fact that capital gains would be stimulative and not costly to the taxpayer. I am hit regularly on the fact that this is a tax break for the rich. I don't believe that. But the problem you have on this is that we have under this budget agreement, rigid caps and we have to score capital gains under existing law the way, I think it's the CBO or the Joint Committee or somebody, says it has to be scored. So we're talking about a $20 billion hit. What I'd love to think is that we could change the way we score it to a more realistic - I would say realistic view - the Treasury's view, for example, that shows this would lift people up, would encourage investment and would not be a revenue loss. So I haven't given up on my philosophical commitment to the idea that capital gains would stimulate growth. And when you have a slow or - certainly a slowed-down economy, in some areas recessional - it would be good. But we're faced with this practical problem as to what we can do, not just on capital gains, but on other stimulants that cost money. There is, remember, an enormous stimulant; one that I'm not very happy about, and that is about a $300 billion federal deficit. So I don't know where we're going to come down on our State of the Union message. But in concept of growth and opportunity, I can guarantee you the emphasis is going to be on that. And if I can find a way to change this - this stultified thinking that this is - this is deficit creating, a capital gains cut, why, then, I'd be all for that. So we're looking at it; I don't know where we're coming out on it. Q: Are you sympathetic to the idea of cutting the Social Security payroll tax at all? A: Well, if I can figure out a way to pay for it. One of the good things about the deficit agreement that was very controversial and which had a lot of - you know, for which I got a reasonable amount of criticism, I'd say, is that you have to pay for these things. And whether the same argument can be made; I haven't seen the dynamic argument made on that that I have on capital gains. So I just don't know the answer to that one. If the offsets were there, you might. I'm a little worried - I'll be honest with you - having laid this - this tax question down for a while to reopen many, many aspects of it. I've tried to draw the exception because I feel so strongly on the capital gains account. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, Saddam Hussein knows, and you know, that his best shot at cracking the cohesion of the coalition arrayed against him is to draw Israel into it by direct attack or otherwise. General Scowcroft indicated that there have been specific discussions with the Israelis and the coalition partners about that contingency. Can you tell us whether there's been any assurance or commitment, either by the Israelis or our coalition partners, that they would not crack apart if that were to happen? A: If - he - Q: If he attacked Israel. A: If he attacked Israel? I'm convinced the coalition would not fall apart. I can't give you the specifics on it, but I'm absolutely convinced of it, and you can assume, the way I've answered the question, that we've - we've inquired about that. Secondly, Israel has had a - what I would call a ``low-profile position'' on all of this, for which I salute them. It is not easy. They have - their - their security they feel could well be at stake from some radical act by Saddam Hussein. But I have no argument with Mr. Shamir over the way that the Israelis have conducted themselves, nor do I think that the coalition partners, on that particular point, regardless of what their historic relationship with Israel may have been. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, as the Cold War began to wind down, first in Congress and then in your own administration, there was talk of a peace dividend. And, in fact, on the very day that Saddam Hussein invaded Iraq, you gave a speech in which you proposed a major shift in the structure of the American military, a 25 percent drawdown over the next five years. With the way the force has been stretched in Operation Desert Shield, are you rethinking that? As this ends, are you going to have to take another look at whether that big a reduction in our active-duty military force is actually possible in a post-Cold War world?

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... War world?
DOC.TEXT: A: I believe we will be able to live with the reductions, and they were substantial, that have been worked out in the last budget agreement. And I think the fact that we have been able to move this much force this dramatically is, of its own weight, a very - a marvelous thing. But as we restructure the defense and as defense has taken substantial hits, not, I would argue, in a peace-dividend mode, but just more of a fiscal mode, I think we can - I think I will be able to represent to the American people that we will still have this ability to rapidly deploy the best-trained forces in the world. So - yeah? Q: If this crisis had occurred five years from now, when this drawdown that's been agreed on had already been largely completed, would your options have been as unlimited as they are now? A: Good question, and I'm not sure I can answer it. But, if the question is, would we have been able to deploy this much force this rapidly, I think the answer is yes. I'd want to hedge just a little bit, but I think it is yes. Gen. Scowcroft is shaking me off a little. (Laughter.) But - because we were talking about this with Gen. Powell and General - and Dick Cheney. But this is not the - you know, this is not the average disturbance, you might say, that calls for the average deployment of force; this is pushing it up to the edge of the envelope. But I think the answer is yes. I'd like - wish I could get back to you to be sure I'm not misleading you, but I felt comfortable when we had the briefing from Cheney and Powell - I think it was yesterday - on this question. Yeah, way back there. Q: Yes. Will the - will the forces that have been taken out of Germany and deployed to the Gulf be sent back to Europe once this crisis - A: I'm not sure of the answer to that question. I can't answer it. I don't know. But one thing I will say about them is the earliest day possible, I would like to have every single American soldier out of the Gulf, for a lot of reasons. And I'd - I think that - in the first place, I think the status quo ante, the return to where we were before Saddam invaded his neighbor, is unacceptable. Because I think you're going to see a cry for stability and order there, security and stability that cannot be met simply by a return to the pre-invasion borders or the status quo there. So, I think you're going to have to have some kind of peace-keeping force, and I think we're going to have to cope with the question this gentleman raised of nuclear - increased nuclear capability today beyond what it was several years ago. And so, we're - it won't be just the way it was before. And - but I would like to think it would be with some international peacekeeping force, because I think there's a problem if US forces remain on the ground in the Gulf for some time. This is - I don't feel that way about naval forces. We've been there for a long time; we will continue to stay there, our mission being to protect freedom of passage through the Straits of Hormuz, and we have a history there of helping keep the peace and of keeping the Straits open. So I would not see any change in that force. But on whether these forces return to Germany, we've got - I think we'll have some - obviously, you know, might be different people - but we're going to have some big discussion over levels in post - post-Iraq forces in Europe. We're discussing that anyway right now. Staff: One more question. Q: Mr. President, are you - A: Make it four more - one, two, three, four. No, you regulars, no. (Laughter.) Four - one, two, three, four. Q: Mr. President, are you prepared to initiate offensive action against Iraq without a declaration of war from Congress? A: I'm having the darnedest consultations with Congress you've ever seen. I was very pleased when the leaders, at the last meeting, told me that it was the best in terms of consultation they've been - ever had, and I'll continue to do that. And I will look at - I hope I don't have to cross that bridge, because I want a peaceful solution to this question. But there are so many contingencies that it's very difficult to answer that question in one definitive way. And I'm not going to try. Yes? Q: An article in the recent issue of Time magazine, Mr. President, says that no one in your Cabinet has a child serving in Saudi Arabia, and that a disproportionate number of U.S. troops stationed on the front line hail from minorities and the working class. Is this accurate? And if it is, why does this condition exist? A: Well, I don't know about the profligacy of my - I mean the proliferation of my Cabinet and where their children are, but I - I don't have any service-age kids myself. But I don't think this concept, that this is a discriminatory army, or an army that is discriminating and thus sending more blacks to their fate, or minorities, Hispanics, or something, is proper. I've heard it, and I reject it. And the reason I reject it is, we have an all volunteer army. We have great opportunity in this army. We have the finest kids, the best trained, the best motivated, the high achievers - not the low achievers. And so this argument that there's some kind of racism, which I think your question implies, in this deployment, I reject it out of it's - the whole cloth. It is simply not true. And if you don't believe me, believe Colin Powell; and he has pretty good credentials in this field, outstanding credentials. So I want to gun it down just as hard as I possibly can and I don't know about my Cabinet, I am sorry I can't answer that. I just don't know where their kids are. Yeah.

DOC.HEAD: Fitness Buff Proposes Transbay Commute By Boat
DOC.TEXT: Row, row, row your boat - all the way to work. That's Marshall McGregor's idea of the best way to beat the commute backup on the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. McGregor, 36, wants to form a catamaran club of several men and women who like the idea of grabbing an oar and rowing across the bay every morning and night. And are willing to pay for the privilege. Depending on the route, the trip could run four to seven miles each way. ``I'm looking for some athletically minded commuters who would want an alternative commuting club that combines a health club with mass transit,'' said McGregor. ``The bay is a great source for transportation - you don't have to build any roads or rails, and it's free.'' McGregor's vision includes four or five 35-foot aluminum-hulled catamarans complete with canopies to protect oarsmen and women from saltwater spray. Rowers would depart from points in Berkeley, Emeryville or Oakland, he said, and arrive near the Ferry Building in San Francisco. To complete the picture, McGregor needs crews of sporting types willing to change from business togs into sweats for the transbay row. Shower facilities would be available at the other end, he said. But there are plenty of details yet to be worked out, including costs. ``With the rowing club you no longer have to spend the extra time each day going to a health club, and you've avoided sitting on the Bay Bridge for 45 minutes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Would Like Autobahn Fee to Help Finance Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT `change' to `charge.' Pickup 3rd graf, `We don't...'
DOC.TEXT: Once the haven of German speedsters, the autobahn is now plagued by traffic jams and clogged with slowpoke sedans. As if that weren't enough, the government said Tuesday it wants to charge money to use the highway system. The Bonn government, seeking cash to finance German unification, agreed in principle to charge an annual fee to use the 6,325 miles of autobahn. However, concerns about violating European Community agreements prevented the Cabinet from reaching a final decision. ``We don't want to decide on something that isn't fully guaranteed,'' said Volker Ruehe, the No. 2 official in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union. He did not specify the possible conflict. Some say the autobahn fun - the days of blasting down the highway for hours at a stretch with no speed limit to rein in your Mercedes, Porsche or BMW - is already over. Traffic jams abound, some extending as long as 35 miles, construction causes delays and there are speed limits near cities. And puttering eastern German Tabants, along with Ladas, Skodas and other East European makes, get in the way of western German power cars. Under the autobahn fee plan, passenger vehicles would pay $66 a year, with higher amounts for trucks and buses. Motor vehicles would sport an annual sticker to show the owners had paid. Foreigners would not be exempt. Protests already are being heard. The German automobile club ADAC said the fees would amount to a ``clear break'' of Kohl's promise not to raise taxes to finance unification. Kohl had indeed made such a promise, but he also made clear that he planned to raise ``fees'' to finance the historic merger. That in turn has led to a debate over what is a fee and what is a tax, in a country where ordinary workers already hand over more than 40 percent of their salaries to the government or government-mandated social programs. Even the railroad workers union criticized the autobahn plan, saying it amounted to an unfair tax that ``fails to take account of the individual's ability to pay.'' Yet the Germans will pay one way or another, as the expensive rebuilding of eastern Germany goes forward. Besides the autobahn fee, the government already has plans to raise the cost of telephone calls.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... are. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: You've spoken of this - A: This is an all-volunteer Army. They are not draft-dodging. Remember Vietnam and the allegation, which I think had a lot of truth to it, that the kid that got disproportionately there was the guy that couldn't get the exemption and that came out of the - you know, kind of the lower rungs of society. This is different! Totally different, yeah. And we ought to get you figures on this because it is very, very important as to how high a quality this Army is. And you'll read about one or two that say, ``Well, I didn't sign up to do this, I signed up because I thought I could get a free education.'' He gets on the Phil Donahue Show, a big hero, but that's a - that's the tiny fraction of these kids that are over there. The morale is good and they are motivated and they are well-educated and they are dedicated, and if you'll excuse an old-fashioned reference, they are patriotic. And so it isn't some cop out armed services that they are now getting caught up in something that they were unaware of. I am glad we got that one because I really feel strongly on that question. Yeah? Q: You've spoken of this crisis as being not the U.S. against Iraq but rather the world against Iraq. A: Yes. Q: And I'm wondering then why the talks with Baghdad aren't being conducted by the Secretary General of the UN but rather by the American Secretary of State? A: Good question. And the answer is the Secretary General, as you may recall, tried and he went to Baghdad - or I think it was in Baghdad, maybe it was in Amman, but he went there and he went to talk within his mandate, and his mandate were the UN resolutions. This was before 678 or whatever the last one was. So he has tried hard and I salute him for that. And he would be willing - I talked to him about this in Paris - while I'm up for your question - and when we were over there for the CSCE meeting, and I asked him. He's an old friend of mine, he and I were UN Ambassadors at the same time, and I said, ``Javier, do you think it would be worth trying this again? We're all trying for the extra step.'' He said, ``If I felt we could make some progress within my mandate I certainly would try again.'' But it's not that people haven't tried. I referred you to - just touched on it in passing about Chadli Bendjedid of Algeria. You've heard over and over again various people calling, as King Hussein of Jordan did, for an Arab solution. You had Tariq Aziz go to Moscow to talk. It isn't though people haven't tried. It is simply that as recently as today, I think it was - the last wire clip I saw - Saddam Hussein is still referring to a nation that is a member of the Arab League and a member of the United Nations as ``Province 19 of Kuwait.'' And therein lies the difficulty. It isn't that people haven't tried to go the extra step, but I have to give the UN credit for having - the Secretary General - for really having tried on this one, and I'm sure he's quietly tried as well as through this public mission that he undertook. Q: Do you think Mr. Baker will have any more luck? A: I don't - I'm not sure he will. I'm not sure he will, but if he can do what I've referred to in the beginning, if he can convince Saddam Hussein of the truth, it'll be worth the effort because, as I've said, it's not a negotiating session or - it's certainly not a concession session. We're not going there to concede one single inch because if you do that, and you want to put it in theoretical terms, you have diminished instantly the new peacekeeping function of the United Nations. And the coalition is demoralized and falls apart, and that will not happen. So, what he's going to do is go there and make this very clear - that there can be - there's no concession, that the world is united and that this force, which is overwhelming, is there for a purpose. And I would hope - I still hope - that gets the message through to Saddam Hussein. Who had the last one? Somebody? Rita? Q: Thank you. Mr. President, as you mentioned on the civil rights - or the minority scholarship issue - the possibility of court challenges, what is your position on whether or not scholarships should be earmarked for minorities in general? And would you perceive some fine-tuning of the current new policies which, I believe, now ban federal monies to be earmarked for minorities, but not private funds? A: Well, as Mr. Williams pointed out, there's a legal question. My own view has been all along - in my own life and everything else - committed to this concept of minority scholarships. Clearly, it should be valid privately and indeed, the support that we give to the historically black colleges, that should - maybe someday will get challenged. I hope it isn't and I hope it would sustain the challenge.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... the challenge.
DOC.TEXT: Clearly, the support that we give to these institutions privately should be above - beyond challenge. But I don't know the answer to your question as to how - you know - how that'll work out in the courts. I don't know. We had a fascinating, almost philosophical, discussion at lunch with some of the most prominent black editors and publishers in this country. And I got into a very lively discussion on this whole question of philosophy and what happens to some kid from one minority group if the scholarships are all allocated to one and not to another. And I don't know that answer because I'm not a lawyer. What I do know is that I am for affirmative action and I am for trying to help the groups that have been the most disadvantaged, through scholarships. And that's what I think has been resolved in the Department of Education at least in the foreseeable future, and I hope it - I hope it stands. But, it's - I don't want to mislead people in the country by suggesting that this may not receive a challenge, and then the courts are going to have to make that determination. And then, if somebody can legislatively correct it fairly, why, I'd be open for that. But I don't want to buy into a - into a court solution question that might happen way down the road. But I would recommend that everybody take a look at the policy statement that just came out a little bit earlier, and I think it will define where this stands now and what - what the likelihood is of it's - and for how long it will continue. Last one. Yes? Q: Mr. President, you said the Persian Gulf will not turn into another Vietnam. A: Absolutely. Q: Could you give another - give us some projection of how long you believe the conflict would last - A: No. Q:- as far as weeks, months - A: In the first place, I don't want to get - you guys want to get me into talking about conflict all the time, and I - I understand it, and as we go down towards the 15th, it'll probably intensify.
