But, I want to still talk about hoping that we can get a peaceful resolution to this question. But that means making Saddam Hussein understand what's at stake. Secondly, I just simply cannot help you on the hypothesis. But it - I can - I have looked into it enough and talked to enough of the planners and those responsible, not only in our country, but the leaders around the world to have - to be totally confident and tell the American people, ``We are not looking at another Vietnam.'' That the analogy is totally different in who's supporting you, what the topography is, what the force is, what the determination of the - of the military is - it's a whole array - the coalition. All of these things come together and argue very forcefully, this is not another Vietnam. And so, again, I get back to this very penetrating question by the kid that wrote you - 18-year-old - because I can understand it. I can tell where a guy like that's coming from. My own kids ask that - a few grandchildren and stuff - What is this? What does it mean? And so, it isn't. It is not going to be another Vietnam. And you can get ranges from - all kinds of ranges in terms of how quick this guy would fold. But none that I know of are predicting anything like the long, drawn-out, bitter experience of Vietnam. Q: Are there going to be far less casualties, sir, in the Persian Gulf than there were in Vietnam? A: Yes. But I can't document that. And you know, they asked the question - some of you all weren't here for it - but in the pressroom across the street, how many, and what's - how many can you cope with? What's your - what's your - you know, how many is enough, or how many is too much? One is too much, and so what do you do? You plan that if you have to use force, to safeguard every single precious human life, and that is exactly what our - Colin Powell and his cohorts are doing over there. And that's what I owe the parents and the kids and the spouses. And particularly I like to say that at this time of year, with our holidays coming up and all of that. I mean, it's a very emotional time for these families, and I have to understand it. I've got to understand where this 18-year-old correspondent's coming from and I've got to understand when I get these letters - mostly supportive still, but some fraught with anxiety about their own loved ones. And I can say to them: We - if force has to be used, we will have done everything in our power to guarantee the life of every single one of our soldiers, and so with sailors and marines and airmen. And I will have that off my conscience, and then clearly it won't work out in a sanitary fashion like that, but I would - I never would want it said that we didn't go the extra mile. So I took some hits on moving this additional force, and that's fine, that goes with the territory. But at least I have the satisfaction in my heart of hearing from our - Chairman of our Joint Chiefs and our Commanding Gen. Norm Schwarzkopf, Hey, we're doing it right. You've seen these kids out here on Thanksgiving, and we owe it to them to give them the best, give them the most, to get this job done.'' And the Brits are looking at it that way, I think the French are looking at it that way. The training that's going on and has gone on with some of our other coalition partners are aimed to that end, too. Listen, thank you all for coming and Merry Christmas to everybody.
DOC.HEAD: END TEXT
Gorbachev Urges Votes on Union Treaty, Land Reform
LaserPhoto MOSB6,7
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Tuesday that Soviets should vote this winter on private land ownership and a Union Treaty because the issues were too important to be decided solely by lawmakers. But both plans already face opposition from leaders of some republics. ``Such questions as the fate of a government, self-determination, and the land on which you and your children live - these are questions for the people,'' Gorbachev told reporters and legislators on the second day of the 10-day Congress of People's Deputies parliamentary session. President Boris Yeltsin of the Russian Federation, the nation's largest republic, said Russia will not agree to a land reform referendum because its parliament already approved private ownership of land. ``Russia took a decision, and that's it,'' Yeltsin said. Yeltin's opposition to the initiative was considered a major blow to the Kremlin. Earlier Tuesday, officials from Estonia and Moldavia joined those opposing the Union Treaty, which Gorbachev said is needed to hold the nation together. ``We won't sign the Union Treaty. There is no chance of that now,'' said Dimitru Matkovsky, a parliamentarian from Moldavia. He and about two dozen other Moldavian deputies stormed out of the cavernous Congress hall because lawmakers had invited representatives of two ethnic groups demanding autonomy within Moldavia. Matkovsky said Moldavians would not participate until the groups left. Meanwhile, news reports said that explosions rocked the Latvian capital of Riga before dawn Tuesday. The blasts smashed windows in the Latvian Communist Party building, the Soviet Army prosecutor's office and the Latvian prime minister's office. No injuries were reported. Authorities said they had no suspects or motives. The Russian Federation's Congress of People's Deputies voted Dec. 3 to allow farmers to own land for the first time in 61 years. That reversed a policy in effect since dictator Josef Stalin carried out a bloody collectivization of land from 1929-32. Many economists agree with Russia's approach, arguing that private ownership of land is indispensable to the creation of a free market economy. Gorbachev has proposed that citizens of the 15 republics vote on the issue and on the concept of a federated union. ``I introduced a suggestion to hold a referendum, and those who don't want a union, let them go and secede,'' Gorbachev said. Calling secession ``a divorce process,'' he reiterated that any separation by a republic must take place under Soviet law. ``If Estonia takes the position, `Yes, we'll leave the union, we want to be like this,' then this divorce process will occur.'' Gorbachev wants the Congress to endorse a treaty that would redefine the relationship among the republics and the central government. ``If it's a renovated federation ... no one would leave it, I think, because it will mean cooperation, because in the entire world it's just the opposite,'' the 59-year-old Soviet leader said. Russia, however, has continued to press ahead without waiting for a new Union Treaty. On Tuesday, it signed its third bilateral trade and political pact with another republic, Byelorussia. Russia has similar agreements with the Ukraine and Kazakhstan. All the republics have declared some form of sovereignty since last March. The declarations and subsequent anti-Kremlin laws have paralyzed power in the country, worsening food shortages and hastening economic collapse. The Union Treaty would preserve central control over national security and such key industries as transportation and energy, and natural wealth such as gold and diamonds. Most republics are demanding that the national government also hand over the power to make economic decisions. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel on Tuesday flatly rejected the Union Treaty. Byelorussian Communist Party chief Anatoly Malofeyev urged the deputies to support it as a way out of the political and economic crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition to Fight Tougher Fuel-Economy Standards
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of 53 business groups is girding to battle tougher automobile fuel economy standards, fearful that the proposal will gain momentum if war erupts in the Middle East, spokesmen said Tuesday. The Coalition for Vehicle Choice was founded by the auto industry, which this year led a successful fight against legislation to require that new car fleets average about 40 miles per gallon by the year 2001. But spokesmen said the coalition had a diverse membership - from the American Farm Bureau Federation to the International Professional Rodeo Association. Other members represent iron and steel manufacturers, electrical contractors, police chiefs and cattlemen. ``This debate has been perceived as between the auto industry and the environmental movement,'' said Jeffrey B. Conley, executive director of the coalition. The coalition will try to convince an array of business and consumer groups that they have a stake in the issue, he said. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., sponsored a bill that would require new car fuel efficiency to improve 20 percent by 1995 and another 20 percent by 2001. The current minimum required efficiency is 27.5 mpg. The typical manufacturer's fleet of new cars would have to average about 40 mpg within a decade. The bill, opposed by the Bush administration, died in the Senate after supporters fell three votes short of the 60 needed to break a filibuster. Bryan, who argued that his bill would reduce U.S. reliance on Middle Eastern oil and reduce the air pollution that causes global warming, will reintroduce the measure early nextyear, spokesman Jim Mulhall said. ``The Persian Gulf situation has given the argument against dependence on foreign oil an emotional element that didn't exist prior to Aug. 2,'' when Iraq invaded Kuwait, Mulhall said. The coalition, Conley said, will sponsor briefings for journalists, officials, and business and consumer organizations. The coalition will not lobby Congress, although individual members will do so on their own, he said. The group's message will be that proposals such as Bryan's would have a significant impact on Americans' lifestyles. Automakers say they cannot meet his requirements without reducing car weight so drastically that only the smallest vehicles can be sold, a contention Bryan and environmentalists deny.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Minority Scholarships, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, Williams, 37, to clarify what types of scholarships are still allowed.
DOC.TEXT: Michael L. Williams' vigorous prosecutions of Ku Klux Klansmen and other racial-terrorism cases during the 1980s won him awards at the Justice Department. But his assertion last week that colleges receiving federal funds can't legally reserve scholarships for minority students found little favor with his bosses in the Bush administration, much less the civil rights community. Williams, 37, an assistant secretary of education, softened his position in accordance with White House wishes Tuesday and said universities still could offer minority-only scholarships with private money designated for that purpose. His policy declaration a week ago had startled some civil rights leaders who had come from earlier meetings impressed by Williams and his record. ``There was uniform disappointment at what happened last week,'' said Ralph Neas, executive director of the 200-member Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. Williams, 37, is a Midland, Texas native and childhood friend of President Bush's son George. His parents and his wife, who is a pilot and mechanical engineer, all attended historically black colleges. While studying at the University of Southern California, he challenged the school to admit more blacks by weighing socio-economic factors as well as test scores. His resume is near-perfect. He's got three degrees from USC - a law degree, a B.A. and a masters in public administration. He was once a Big Brother; now he is a reading tutor at a local elementary school. And as a Justice Department trial attorney from 1984 to 1988, he prosecuted an array of high-profile cases: North Carolina Klansmen who conspired to obtain stolen military weapons; an Idaho white supremacist who tried to drive black and interracial families from their homes; a Kentucky Klansman who firebombed the home of a black family; and law enforcement officers in Alabama, Arizona, North Carolina and Oklahoma who assaulted private citizens. ``He went after them with a vengeance and was very successful,'' said William Bradford Reynolds, who was assistant attorney general for civil rights from 1981 to 1988. ``He was a very savvy lawyer, a thoughtful, level-headed kind of guy who learned very quickly and did exceptionally well.'' Personally, Williams is described as having Texas charm and a sense of humor worthy of Eddie Murphy. He wears lizard cowboy boots and likes to collect things - including baseball caps and a plate from each state in which he's had a trial. Politically, Williams served as a domestic policy adviser to the Bush-Quayle campaign in 1988. Neas said the scholarship controversy fits into a Bush and Reagan administration pattern of construing civil rights statutes so narrowly ``that they in effect strangle the life out of them.'' But Reynolds said Williams was simply ``going after discrimination. ... He was concerned that scholarships exclusive to one race are discriminatory. You can't really argue with that proposition.'' Williams owned up Tuesday to being politically naive, but not to being wrong. ``I haven't been a lackey for anyone,'' he said. ``The position I took was a position I took because I thought it was right.''

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Act to Avoid Taxpayer Bailout of Risky Thrift Investments
DOC.TEXT: Bank and thrift regulators, in separate actions, took steps Tuesday aimed toward protecting taxpayers from paying for financial institutions' risky investments. The Office of Thrift Supervision, which regulates 2,389 savings and loans, proposed a rule that would require the stockholders of an institution gambling on interest-rate changes to put more of their own capital behind the institution's investments. S&Ls with more capital are better able to absorb losses and avoid failure, thus avoiding a bailout paid for by the government's deposit insurance program. Since November 1989, S&Ls have been required to hold more capital against loans and other investments with a higher risk of default. And, a similar risk-based system takes effect for banks on Jan. 1. However, Tuesday's proposal is the first by a financial regulator to link capital levels to the danger posed by interest-rate swings. Meanwhile, the board of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. voted 5-0 on Tuesday to ask Congress for the power to tie deposit insurance premiums to risk. Currently, all banks and S&Ls pay the same premium, no matter how risky their operations. Banks, starting Jan. 1, will pay 19.5 cents per $100 of deposits, up from 12 cents this year. S&Ls have and will be paying 23 cents. Critics contend this unfairly forces sound institutions to subsidize high-fliers. Other kinds of insurance give breaks to better customers. Safe drivers, for instance, pay less for auto insurance and non-smokers pay less for life insurance. A study prepared by the FDIC for Congress recommends exploration of two approaches for varying premiums. One would charge lower premiums to banks and S&Ls that hold a larger capital cushion. The theory is that institutions willing to risk more of their owners' money before failure should pay less for their insurance, much as a homeowner willing to pay a larger deductible should pay less for theft insurance. Another approach outlined by the study is having private insurance firms set premiums based on the principal of market competition. Under that concept, the FDIC would use government funds to directly cover 90 percent of a bank's deposits. It would purchase coverage from private firms for the remaining 10 percent and set the premium paid by the bank according to the best rate it could get from private firms. The Treasury Department, which has been working closely with the FDIC, is likely to include one of the risk-based deposit insurance schemes in a proposal it plans to release next month calling for the most dramatic overhaul of the banking system since the Depression. Small banks, represented by the Independent Bankers Association of America, generally favor the insurance plan linked to capital, since most small banks have a proportionately more capital than large banks. The smaller banks fear that private insurance would not be available to banks too small to be publicly rated. The thrift office's proposal on risk-based capital would force banks to raise their capital by half of the amount it would lose in the event of a 2 percentage point swing in interest rates. For instance, an S&L that would lose $10 million from such a swing would have to hold $5 million more in capital than an S&L not subject to that risk. Fixed-rate loans and bonds held by S&Ls generally lose value when interest rates rise. At the same time, the institutions have to pay more for their deposits. ``This is the latest in a series of steps taken ... to see that thrifts safely manage their interest-rate risk,'' said thrift office director Timothy Ryan. The agency noted that in the early 1980s, when interest rates soared, most S&L losses were caused by rising interest rates, not - as is the case now - by defaulting loans. The agency is accepting written comments on the proposal for 60 days. It plans public hearings on Jan. 31 in Washington and Feb. 14 in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Bjt
More Reserve Cargo Ships Activated for Gulf Duty
DOC.TEXT: The Maritime Administration will activate 20 more cargo ships from its Ready Reserve Force fleet for use in supporting Operation Desert Shield, the agency announced on Tuesday. Filling the new request by the Navy's Military Sealift Command will bring to 67 the number of reserve ships activated in the Mideast crisis since Aug. 10. The agency said that activation of the ships has required 2,340 merchant mariners so far and has created pressure on seafaring labor organizations to fill the positions. But it said that of the first 40 ships activated, only one sailed without a full crew.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Threatens Stealth Contractors With Default
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department on Tuesday said it may cancel as early as January its $4.8 billion contract for development of a stealth warplane for the Navy. The department notified the developers, McDonnell Douglas Corp. and General Dynamics Corp., that they will be held in default of the contract terms unless they present a new plan for resolving the project's problems by Jan. 2. The announcement was the latest sign of serious trouble for the Navy's proposed A-12 Avenger aircraft, a deep-strike bomber with radar-evading capabilities. It is meant to be the service's main carrier-based attack plane for the early 21st century. The Navy plans to buy 620 of the planes for about $50 billion. The Pentagon's action also is a further blow for McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics. Published reports Tuesday said a Pentagon audit of A-12 contract payments found that the government had overpaid the companies by hundreds of millions of dollars. The St. Louis Post-Dispatch and the Los Angeles Times also reported that a separate Pentagon audit concluded that the A-12 contractors have a ``possible chance of bankruptcy.'' Al Spivak, a General Dynamics spokesman in Washington, said ``We don't agree'' with the audits' findings. McDonnell Douglas also contested the results. Spivak also took issue with the Pentagon declaration that the A-12 contractors could be found in default. ``There is no way we can be considered in default of the contract,'' Spivak said. ``In our view, the contract itself is the major problem, and we hope that it will be restructured so that the program can continue effectively.'' McDonnell Douglas issued a statement in the name of its chairman and chief executive officer, John F. McDonnell, which said: ``We believe that we are not in default, and we are having discussions with the Navy and Office of the Secretary of Defense to try to assure the continuation of this vital national defense program on a mutually satisfactory basis.'' Just eight months ago, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney assured Congress that the A-12 project was on schedule and within its then-classified budget. A Pentagon Inspector General's report released earlier this month said Cheney was not aware of the project's serious problems because senior Navy and Pentagon officials failed to pass on information that clearly showed the contractors to be far behind schedule. Last Friday Cheney told Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett that he would order a halt to the project unless Garrett could ``show cause'' by Jan. 4 why it should proceed. In Tuesday's announcement, spokesman Pete Williams said the Pentagon formally declared the performance of the two St. Louis-based contractors to be unsatisfactory. That gives the Pentagon the legal basis for declaring the contractors in default in the event that their Jan. 2 proposals are judged inadequate. ``Everything about the A-12 is on hold,'' Williams told reporters. The project is at least $1 billion over cost and at least 18 months behind schedule. Among the chief technical problems is excess plane weight due to the thickness of the construction material needed to make the plane strong enough for carrier landings, according to a Navy report released earlier this month. Williams said he could not immediately explain the financial consequences of a default declaration. Williams also disclosed that the Pentagon's No. 2 procurement officer, Donald Yockey, and the Navy's assistant secretary for procurement, Gerald Cann, met with unidentified representatives of McDonnell Douglas and General Dynamics today. Williams said he could provide no information about the discussions or the meeting's results. Spivak of General Dynamics also declined to comment on the meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Says There's New Evidence In Case Of Convicted War Criminal
DOC.TEXT: New evidence casts doubt on part of the case against John Demjanjuk, the Ohio man convicted of running a Nazi gas chamber as ``Ivan the Terrible'' and now appealing an Israeli death sentence, the congressman who took up his cause said Tuesday. Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, said, ``They are holding the wrong man.'' Traficant said he believes he can prove Ivan Marczenko was the real name of Ivan the Terrible and not an alias used by Demjanjuk, as Israeli prosecutors claimed in court 2{ years ago. A newly discovered marriage certificate of Demjanjuk's parents helps prove that Marczenko and Demjanjuk were different people by refuting the prosecution contention that Demjanjuk took the alias Marczenko because it was his mother's maiden name, the congressman said. Demjanjuk, who was born in the Ukraine, had been unable to argue that point in court because he did not remember his mother's birth name, Traficant said. The certificate shows her name before marriage was Iulianiya Tabachyk. The congressman said he wants to collect enough evidence to force Israel's Supreme Court to discount the testimony of witnesses who said Demjanjuk and Ivan the Terrible are the same man who ran a gas chamber at the Treblinka death camp in Poland, where 850,000 Jews were slaughtered. Traficant said he hopes the court will consider statements from Marczenko's former driver and a woman who told a BBC interviewer she was compelled to have sex with Marczenko. Both have said Demjanjuk doesn't resemble Marczenko, according to Traficant.

DOC.SECOND: BC-AP Arts: Film Review, 2nd Ld-Writethru a0658,0605
DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: `Awakenings'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates MPAA ratings with NC-17 in last graf. No PMs planned. Movie opens in New York, Toronto, Chicago and Los Angeles on Thursday. Opens wide Jan. 11.
DOC.TEXT: ``Awakenings'' is a ``feel good'' movie. It wants to make you laugh. It wants to make you cry. It wants to make you feel good about yourself, although nothing could match the self-satisfaction of the filmmakers themselves. The movie is based on Dr. Oliver Sacks' book about post-encephalitic syndrome, a neurological disorder that left victims trancelike, virtually immobile for decades. The syndrome was a result of an epidemic of encephalitis lethargica, or viral sleeping sickness, that occurred from 1917-27. The illness was considered incurable until the late 1960s, when a ``miracle'' drug, L-DOPA, was discovered. Sacks, working at Mount Carmel Hospital in the New York City borough of the Bronx, tried the drug on his patients in the summer of 1969. The results were, truly, a miracle. Within days many of them were up and about, walking and talking, touching and smelling, functions most people take for granted. Without condescension or pity, Sacks wrote of their sheer awe and gratitude for having another chance: ``There is nothing alive which is not individual: Our health is ours; our diseases are ours; our reactions are ours. ... '' But the downside was just as strong. Some patients were horrified to learn they had ``slept'' for so many years, gasping as they looked in the mirror and saw their now-elderly faces. One woman, who had been ill for more than 40 years, awoke believing it was still 1926. Soon, side effects set in. Patients developed severe tics or experienced drastic mood swings. Some regressed to their earlier conditions and died. Others lived somewhat better than they had before the emergence of the drug, but never as well as they had that first summer. The cases of many of those patients are effectively re-enacted in ``Awakenings,'' notably ``Leonard L'' as played by Robert De Niro. Unfortunately, the simple truths about illness and aging are not enough for director Penny Marshall (``Big'') and screenwriter Steve Zaillian (``The Falcon and the Snowman''). They slap on a contrived love story and good vs. evil melodrama, using stereotypes straight out of daytime soap operas: the kindly doctor (Robin Williams), the lonely nurse (Julie Kavner) and the unfeeling bureaucrat (John Heard). They recruit the world's nicest hospital staff and arouse Leonard's interest with a girl sweet enough to live up to the name of the actress who portrays her: Penelope Ann Miller. The story is built for applause, such as when Heard insists there is no money for the drug and quickly finds a check placed in front of him by the ever-noble Kavner. ``Heartwarming'' may have worked for ``Big,'' but applied to ``Awakenings,'' it turns a dignified, moving story into a Jerry Lewis telethon. Mercifully, it's much shorter. Produced by Walter F. Parkes and Lawrence Lasker, with Marshall, Arne Schmidt and Elliot Abbott as executive producers, the Columbia Pictures release is rated PG-13. Running time: 120 minutes. ---= Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G - General audiences. All ages admitted. PG - Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 - Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R - Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. NC-17 - No one under 17 admitted.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Joins Security Council Resolution Attacking Israeli Deportations
With AM-Israel Deportees, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel's plan to deport four more Palestinians has pushed the United States into co-sponsoring a Security Council resolution criticizing the Jewish state, diplomats said Tuesday. Israel's action gives the United States a way out of a diplomatic dilemma. For weeks, Washington has tried to avoid vetoing another anti-Israel resolution, a move that could alienate Arab allies arrayed against Iraq. That resolution contains an endorsement of an eventual Middle East peace conference, which Washington fears could be seen as a concession to Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein says he will discuss Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait only in the context of a comprehensive Middle East peace conference that would include discussing Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. A U.S. draft resolution would lift the issue from the resolution itself and relegate endorsement of a peace conference to a separate, non-binding statement by the Security Council president. The statement would also say anew that the Persian Gulf crisis and the Mideast peace conference are entirely separate issues and must not be linked, the diplomats said, speaking on condition of anonymity. It would have the council ``deplore'' Israel's resumption of deportations of Palestinians as violating the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 on the treatment of civilians under military occupation. Israel, which signed the convention, holds the charter bans only mass expulsions. The convention's exact words, however, are that ``individual or mass forcible transfers ... are prohibited.'' For Palestinians, mindful that 700,000 of their people fled or were driven from their homes when the state of Israel was created in 1948, deportation is the worst punishment. The four men ordered deported are all from the occupied Gaza Strip. On Tuesday, a military panel heard their appeal and the case could go to the Supreme Court. But Israeli courts have never overturned deportation orders. Israel has deported 60 residents of the West Bank and Gaza during the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising. It stopped the practice in August 1989, reportedly under U.S. pressure. Israel and America are major allies and Israel is the largest recipient of U.S. foreign aid. The resolution now favored by Washington would define parts of Jerusalem as under military occupation, although Israel claims all of Jerusalem as its capital after capturing Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Arab-Israeli War and subsequently annexing it. Classifying east Jerusalem as ``occupied'' raises questions about its status. Council president Abdalla Saleh al-Ashtal of Yemen said the council would meet again on the occupied territories issue on Wednesday. He said he was not sure if it would take up the U.S.-favored draft or the tougher draft sponsored by Cuba, Yemen, Colombia and Malaysia.

DOC.HEAD: Northern California County Bans Most Pet Breeding
DOC.TEXT: A Northern California county Tuesday became the first in the nation to approve a law banning unlicensed pet breeding to reduce the number of unwanted animals killed each week. San Mateo County supervisors approved the ban on a 3-1 vote while a group of citizens protested outside with their dogs, carrying signs that read: ``Sniff Out The Truth'' and ``Don't Hound Responsible Dog Owners.'' ``The intent was never to go after any group of people, but to rectify an untenable situation in which we kill 10,000 pets a year,'' Supervisor Tom Nolan said after the vote. ``We're entering a new territory.'' Nolan said he hoped the measure, which he wrote, would inspire other jurisdictions to approve similar laws. The breeding ban was initiated by the Peninsula Humane Society, which is forced to kill thousands of animals a year, officials said. The ordinance will allow only dogs and cats owned by professional and hobby breeders to reproduce. All other dogs and cats in the county would have to be spayed or neutered. Violators would be fined $500. ``The whole thing is going to end up an enormous legal battle,'' said Susan Clough of Redwood City, a show dog owner. ``We're not causing the problem and this is not going to solve a single thing.'' Other protesters said the law should be aimed at cats. ``Seven thousand cats and so few dogs,'' Lois Frank said of the death toll at the Humane Society. ``You are not getting to the right people with your legislation.'' The organization ran full-page ads in local newspapers showing photos of drums packed with cat corpses.

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Cholesterol Damage Reversible in Women
DOC.TEXT: Cholesterol-reducing drugs can help unclog women's coronary arteries and reduce the risk of heart attacks, just as the treatment does for men, a new study showed. The study is the first to document the reversal of atherosclerosis in women through the use of the drugs, researchers said. ``Critics have pointed out that no previous studies have provided data on the response of atherosclerotic disease in women to (blood-cholesterol) lowering therapy,'' study author Dr. John P. Kane wrote in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Cholesterol kills by clogging the blood vessels that feed the heart with lesions - a combination of cholesterol deposits and scar tissue. Previous studies have shown that lowering blood cholesterol levels can reduce coronary artery lesions in men. In their study over several years, authors looked at 41 women and 31 men with atherosclerosis. Subjects took bile acid-binding resin and niacin daily, which along with dietary changes reduced their blood-cholesterol levels an average of 38.1 percent. After 26 months, coronary artery lesions shrank just more than 2 percent among the 22 women enrolled in the treatment. Lesions diminished under the treatment program at about the same rate as they originally developed. The 19 women in the control group, whose blood cholesterol levels were reduced about 10.6 percent through diet changes and less-intensive drug treatments, showed just more than a 1 percent increase in coronary artery lesions, the study said. ``There are lots of other risk factors besides cholesterol. But one of the most important risk factors is high cholesterol, and reversal of atherosclerosis can reduce the chances of a heart attack,'' said Dr. Mary Malloy, co-author of the study. The treatment's effect on men in the study showed the same trends, but did not result in a statistically significant difference among men, the study concluded. Kane is a professor of medicine and biochemistry at the University of California at San Francisco. Earlier studies concentrated on men because coronary diseases occur much more frequently in males between 40 and 60 years old than in women, said Dr. David Blankenhorn of the University of Southern California. Blankenhorn said doctors ``use the same medicines in women as in men, but they're less likely to prescribe (cholesterol-reducing) medicines in women, because the evidence wasn't in regarding what would happen.'' Women who haven't undergone menopause also get some protection because the level of estrogen in their bodies slows the formation of coronary artery lesions, Malloy said. Because of the effects of estrogen, researchers have been slow to show that coronary artery lesions can be reduced in women, said one critic, University of Wisconsin nutritionist Laura Vailas. ``We do know regression of atherosclerosis can be shown in men, and I think we've been complacent in showing it in women. Women do suffer risks just as men do,'' Ms. Vailas said.

DOC.HEAD: Revere Fire Labeled Arson
DOC.TEXT: A fire that swept through a neighborhood of three-family houses last week, displacing more than 100 people, was arson, fire officials said Tuesday. ``The conclusion was based on witness statements, fire scene examination and analysis of physical materials taken from the scene,'' said Cpl. Dennis Galvin of the State Fire Marshal's office. Chemical analysis was still under way to determine the exact substance used to start the fire in a vacant building early Friday. The 10-alarm blaze was fanned by high wind that swept embers to neighboring buildings and homes a block away. It destroyed or damaged 11 buildings, burning 132 people out of their homes. Galvin said a $5,000 award had been posted for information leading to an arrest in the case. ``Several leads are being followed. But the investigation is not focused on any specific suspect at this time,'' Galvin said. ``We are appealing to the public for assistance, and we would like to see the same outpouring of support in catching the suspect that has been shown in aiding the fire victims.'' Donations for the fire victims have poured in from around New England.

DOC.HEAD: Mustang Ranch Brothel Prepares to Reopen for Business
DOC.TEXT: Two months after the county vowed that Nevada's most notorious legal bordello had seen its last prostitute, and a month after it was sold at auction, the Mustang Ranch prepared for business Tuesday. ``We reopened this morning,'' former owner Joe Conforte said. ``We could have opened the day the IRS left.'' Conforte, who now is listed as general manager rather than owner of the brothel 10 miles east of Reno, appeared before the Storey County commissioners as a ``courtesy.'' ``I didn't have to show up here at all,'' he said. ``I'm not here to ask for a license. I'm here as a common courtesy to this board to tell you how it is.'' Conforte claimed that even though the Internal Revenue Service padlocked the 104-room brothel in September and sold it two months later to recoup some $13 million in taxes owed by him and his wife, Sally, his license to operate the business remained in effect. Storey County Sheriff Bob Del Carlo said although prostitutes began moving back into the brothel during the morning, no business would transpire until health cards administered through his office were issued. A few weeks after the IRS seizure, the county commission agreed to cancel the special permit that allowed the Mustang Ranch to operate as a brothel because of the circus atmosphere surrounding it. But at least two commissioners earlier this month said they would reconsider that action after county revenues lost the $60,000 annual license fee and the 2 percent tax from each of the Mustang's occupied rooms. Conforte said he paid the county $16,500 for his quarterly license fee two weeks ago, including a 10 percent late fee. While the commission debated whether it could accept Conforte's quarterly payment for his licenses at the Mustang Bridge Ranch and the adjoining Triangle River Ranch, both part of the Mustang Ranch compound, Conforte sweetened his offer for them and a third, small operation run by his nephew. ``We would like to make a proposal that the license fees for all three places, whether they're open or not, be raised to $35,000 if and when the dust settles. That would provide $105,000 to the county.'' The county commission took no action. Peter Perry, Conforte's lawyer, said because of building code deficiencies, only the smaller Triangle River Ranch part of the Mustang Ranch compound will resume operations. Perry happens to be listed with the Nevada secretary of state's office as the sole officer of the ranch's new owner, Mustang Properties Inc. The Mustang closed Sept. 18 when it entered Chapter 7 liquidation. Bankruptcy trustees spent three days trying to reopen the bordello to sell it for the taxes owed by the Confortes, but the IRS seized and padlocked the property Sept. 21. The brothel and its contents were sold at a tax auction in mid November, with Victor Perry the successful bidder on the brothel buildings and about 400 acres of land at $1.49 million on behalf of Mustang Properties Inc., the company where his brother, Peter, is the only listed officer. Although he appeared with Conforte at the commission meeting, Peter Perry refused to answer questions about investors. Peter Perry was a member of a group of attorneys and investors known as Mustang Ranch Inc., which relinquished its corporate status after twice failing to buy the property through public stock offerings of nearly $20 million, then $10 million. Peter Perry filed his incorporation papers the middle of August.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Critical of Continued Pressure by Opposition Groups
DOC.TEXT: In an escalating war of words, President F.W. de Klerk lashed out at the African National Congress and other opposition groups Tuesday for fanning the ``flames of confrontation.'' The speech was likely to increase tensions between the government and ANC, coming two days after the anti-apartheid group closed a conference by endorsing the continuation of mass protests, economic sanctions and other hard-line stances. It also threatened to break off talks with the government unless it meets several key demands by April 30. De Klerk's televised Christmas message was moved up a week to respond to the ANC, whose leaders include Nelson Mandela. ``The time has come for the ANC to decide what they want,'' de Klerk said. ``Are they prepared (for) ... peaceful and negotiated solutions, or do they want to revert to the confrontation and conflict of the past?'' The ANC had little response to the speech. Spokeswoman Gill Marcus said the group has ``taken note of the points raised'' by de Klerk and would clarify its position on various issues if the government so desired. At the conference, the ANC also demanded the return of exiles, the release of political prisoners, an end of ``political'' trials and the scrapping of security laws. De Klerk has agreed in principle to most of the demands. De Klerk said his reforms have opened the door for grievances to be discussed democratically, and there ``can no longer be any excuse'' for political violence and intimidation. ``Some movements are still caught up in these undemocratic and unacceptable strategies,'' he said. The ANC was the only group de Klerk mentioned by name. But he clearly referred to the militant Pan Africanist Congress when he said: ``Slogans such as `One settler, one bullet' ... are absolutely unacceptable.'' The slogan, referring to white descendants of the Dutch settlers, is chanted at Pan Africanist rallies. De Klerk's harshest criticism was reserved for the ANC, which has been holding talks with the government over the past year intended to clear obstacles to full-scale negotiations on a new constitution. ``It is disappointing that at its recent conference, the ANC appeared to have reverted to outdated rhetoric and policies that form the flames of confrontation,'' de Klerk said. ``They continued to talk of the transfer of power, while they know that the purpose of the proposed negotiations is to determine how ... power should be shared and domination avoided,'' he said. De Klerk has pledged to dismantle apartheid and give political rights to blacks, who outnumber whites 30 million to 5 million in South Africa. But he opposes a simple one-man, one-vote system, saying it would replace white domination with black domination. The president said the ANC had ``refused to acknowledge that any fundamental changes had taken place in South Africa - this despite the fact that for the first time in 30 years they ... could hold a conference ... within the republic.'' Earlier Tuesday, de Klerk formally offered amnesty to thousands of South Africans who left the country illegally when the ANC and other opposition groups were banned. According to the offer, citizens who fled the country illegally before Oct. 8 may return to the country without fear of prosecution. The offer will clear the way for the return of most of the 20,000 ANC exiles. However, ANC members who took part in the group's bombing and sabotage campaign and will have to request amnesty for violence and other acts that could be prosecuted as crimes. Those cases will be judged individually, the Justice Department said. The amnesty offer applies to exiles from other, smaller opposition groups and people not associated with any particular political movements.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Clashes Kill Six in Soviet Caucasus
DOC.TEXT: Clashes in the ethnically troubled Caucasus region of the Soviet Union have killed six people since last week, the Tass news agency reported Tuesday. The latest deaths occurred Monday night when two policemen were killed and another was gravely wounded in an armed ambush in Azerbaijan's Nakhichevan region, between the republic of Armenia and the Iranian border. On Saturday, Armenian assailants fired on a motor vehicle en route to Shushu, in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh, killing three Azerbaijanis, Tass said in a report from Baku, capital of Azerbaijan. The sixth death occurred Dec. 13 when an Azerbaijani was killed and two people were wounded after a truck convoy was ambushed en route to the Azerbaijani village of Umudlu, Tass quoted Azerbaijani KGB chief Vagif Guseinov as saying. He said extremists had tried to inflame tensions in Nagorno-Karabakh by blocking access to the airport in its principal city, Stepanakert, according to Tass. Similar attempts to heighten tensions often occurred before important political events in the country, Tass quoted Guseinov as saying, apparently referring to Monday's convening of the national parliament, the Congress of People's Deputies. The past two years, more than 200 people have died in ethnic clashes over control of Nagorno-Karabakh. The area is populated mostly by Armenians but Azerbaijan has held it since 1923.

DOC.HEAD: Passport Examiner Indicted; Linked to Jamaican Drug Ring
DOC.TEXT: An employee of the U.S. Passport Office in New York has been indicted for conspiring to obtain passports for a Jamaican drug gang that distributed substantial quantities of drugs in various U.S. cities, the State Department said Tuesday. The arrest last week and the indictment Monday of Kenneth R. Weatherspoon, a passport examiner, followed a three-month investigation by the Department of State's Bureau of Diplomatic Security. The department announcement alleged the Jamaican gangs distributed substantial quantities of heroin, cocaine, crack and marijuana in Brooklyn, Washington and Dallas. It alleged that Weatherspoon conspired with the Jamaicans to obtain U.S. passports for gang members. More than 35 fraudulent passport applications were approved from 1986 through 1988, it said. Weatherspoon has been a passport examiner since 1984. He faces a maximum of five years in prison if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: `I Could Have Been a Dictator'
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Tuesday defended his need for more power to hold the Soviet Union together by saying he could have been the strongest dictator in the world. In an emotional 45-minute chat with reporters in a Kremlin lobby, Gorbachev also gave a rare glimpse of his inner thoughts about the suffering endured by his father and grandfather. If the nation forgets its past, ``we should be swept away to hell,'' he said during a break on the second day of the Congress of People's Deputies parliamentary session. The Soviet leader spoke about the fragmentation of the Soviet Union, saying national authority was being ``dragged apart piece by piece by the republics and at local levels.'' ``The chain is broken, electricity stops flowing down the wire . .. and the executive power is stalled. Even if a decision is made, it's killed.'' That is why, Gorbachev said, he has raised the issue of greater presidential power. ``It doesn't mean a return to dictatorship. Everyone knows that I am not going to be a dictator,'' Gorbachev said. ``I could have become a dictator. The power of the general secretary was such as no one else had in the world - none of the Pinochets,'' he said, referring to Chile's former military leader, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, and similar strongmen. He indicated that any decision to seize such absolute power would not be an easy one for him. ``I made my choice. If a dictatorship were to come, the greatest drama would be mine. I can't step on my own throat,'' Gorbachev said. He said he was trying to ``unfold'' presidential power gradually, ``so as not to destroy democracy itself.'' Gorbachev said the country was on ``the brink of chaos.'' ``If anyone thinks I cannot see this - I do see this.'' Gorbachev later became emotional when talking about the need to remember the suffering and hard work of past generations. In a new book about Gorbachev, author Gail Sheehy writes that his paternal grandfather, Andrei, was sent to a labor camp during the Stalinist terror of the 1930s. Gorbachev's father, Sergei, was wounded on the Ukrainian front during World War II. Gorbachev recalled, ``The life of my family was full of injustices. But when my grandfather returned after 1938-39, we once sat an entire day and wept when he told us what they had done to him. ... He worked for established collective farms, headed them. ``And can I go against it? ``And my father, he fought near Kursk on the Dnieper, and was badly wounded. It undermined his health. ``Are we going to announce that we didn't live then?'' he said, his voice rising with emotion. ``We should be swept away to hell if we do!'' Asked about the personal attacks against him by other political leaders, Gorbachev said: ``I am not hurt by criticism.'' ``But I must tell you that even I, a person who likes satire and humor - it's my weakness - I can see how badly we lack cultured criticism. ``Sometimes I am ashamed, but I always think, `Need I defend myself?' Let society defend me. Society will eventually understand that lack of respect to the president and authorities who were elected democratically means disrespect to the people.''

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslavia Moves to Bar Slovenian Vote on Independence
DOC.TEXT: The Yugoslav presidency on Tuesday termed unacceptable Slovenian plans for a weekend referendum on independence and instructed the federal government to take steps to preserve national unity. The collective federal presidency did not specify the steps to be taken. The presidency of Slovenia, the northernmost of this Balkan country's six republics, denounced the statement and said the federal presidency ``once again has shown that a democratic way of resolving the Yugoslav crisis and relations among its peoples is alien to it,'' Tanjug news agency reported. Slovenes will ``give an adequate reply to such a behavior and pressures, at the plebiscite'' it said. The Dec. 23 referendum on full independence for Slovenia runs counter to federal plans for this diverse country about 24.1 million people to settle its worsening political and ethnic quarrels in a peaceful way, Tanjug said. The state presidency - a collective eight-member body, including one representative from each of the six republics and two provinces - serves as supreme commander of the armed forces. Defense Minister Gen. Veljko Kadijevic created a stir this month when he suggested the army might intervene directly to preserve the federation. Earlier Tuesday, the influential constitutional commission of Yugoslavia's Parliament appealed for a peaceful, negotiated solution to the power struggle between different republics. It said Parliament should meet Dec. 27 to discuss how the country could stay united while the six republics work out Yugoslavia's future. An agreement should be ratified by mid-1991, after elections for a federal parliament, it said. Fear of an imminent breakup or of an armed struggle has grown since Serbia's President Slobodan Milosevic and his former Communists resoundingly won the first round of the republic's free elections Dec. 9. The U.S. Central Intelligence Agency recently predicted Yugoslavia may disintegrate within 18 months and civil war could break out. The second round of elections Sunday in Serbia and pro-Communist Montenegro coincides with Slovenia's scheduled vote on whether Slovenia becomes fully independent. Croatia and Slovenia, where center-right parties ousted Communists in spring elections, have threatened to secede. Serbia and Montenegro favor a strong federal government. Slovenia's senior leaders on Tuesday told a news conference in their capital of Ljubljana the plebiscite ``does not mean secession,'' Tanjug said. It said President Milan Kucan, Prime Minister Lojze Peterle and the chief of Parliament, Franc Bucar, assured reporters ``nothing earth-shaking or undemocratic'' would happen after the referendum. Opinion polls have suggested Slovenians will vote overwhelmingly for independence. But the plebiscite is seen as a last-ditch effort to get other republics to agree to a new, loose confederation rather than a step toward immediate secession. The presidency acknowledges that each republic has a constitutional right to secede, but only after consultations with the other five republics. It said that ``implementing the principle of self-determination of the people'' without going by regulations set out by the constitution and the law ``is unacceptable.'' Slovenia's plans ``crudely reject and practically thwart the initiative launched by the Presidency of Yugoslavia, to rearrange . .. (Yugoslavia) ... in a peaceful, democratic, legal manner, based on the constitution,'' it said. The presidency decides by majority vote and never announces whether there are dissenting votes. The other two republics are Bosnia and Herezegovin,a and Macedonia.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Wins Network Race, `Cheers' the No. 1 Show
LaserGraphic
With AM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: NBC, aided by the season's best ratings for its Tuesday night lineup, won the latest network battle for television viewers. ``In The Heat of The Night,'' ``Matlock'' and ``Law & Order'' each won their Tuesday time periods and landed in the top 20 for the first time in the 13-week-old fall season. NBC earned a 12.4 average rating for the week, followed by ABC with an 11.6 and CBS with 11.4, showed figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. Each ratings point represents 931,000 television homes. The top-rated network had seven of the top 10 shows, with longtime favorite ``Cheers'' grabbing the most viewers of any television program last week. A bag full of holiday specials failed to make the top 20. Even NBC's ``Bob Hope's Christmas Special'' from Bermuda got left out in the cold. The 60-minute Saturday night special ranked 22nd. A repeat and colorized version of the CBS ``I Love Lucy Christmas'' tied for 30th place with ABC's ``Sunday Night Movie: The Witches of Eastwick.'' CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was the No. 2 show, followed by a two-way tie for third place between NBC's ``A Different World'' and ABC's NFL ``Monday Night Football'' match-up between the Los Angeles Raiders and the Detroit Lions. ``Empty Nest'' on NBC was fifth. NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``In The Heat of The Night,'' spun from the Oscar-winning 1967 film of the same name, tied for sixth. A repeat featuring the wisecracking mom of ABC's ``Roseanne'' was No. 8. ``The Golden Girls'' on NBC was No. 9, followed by the network's ``Unsolved Mysteries.'' The network news victory went once again to ABC and Peter Jennings with an 11.6. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 10 and NBC and Tom Brokaw finished third with 9.9. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 22.6; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 20.6; ``A Different World,'' NBC and ``Monday Night Football,'' ABC (tie) 18.2; ``Empty Nest,'' NBC, 18.1; ``The Cosby Show,'' and ``In The Heat of The Night,'' NBC (tie) 17.7; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 17.5; ``The Golden Girls,'' NBC, 17.2; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 16.9.

DOC.HEAD: ICC Bans Smoking on Buses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after penultimate graf pvs `It said ...' to UPDATE with bus trade association position. Picks up last graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: The Interstate Commerce Commission voted unanimously Tuesday to ban smoking on all regularly scheduled interstate buses in the United States. Bus companies were given the option of allowing charter passengers to smoke if the chartering group agrees it should be permitted. The ban will take effect soon after the issuance of the commission's decision in writing and its publication in the Federal Register, according to ICC spokesman A. Dennis Watson. Lawyers for the ICC said the change was supported by a wide variety of groups but was opposed by the tobacco industry. John Banzhaf, executive director of Action on Smoking and Health, the organization whose request initiated the ICC action, praised the decision. ``Smokers can refrain from smoking for several hours and light up at bus stops, but non-smokers cannot similarly refrain from breathing,'' Banzhaf said. The ICC lawyers contended that smoking has been proved to be injurious to health and that tobacco smoke cannot be adequately ventilated from buses to assure the health and comfort of non-smokers. The commission began its consideration of a smoking ban last March at the request of the American Bus Association and United Bus Owners of America, the national trade associations for the intercity bus business. In April, Action on Smoking and Health (ASH), an anti-smoking association, filed a similar request but asked that it be imposed on all buses, including charters. Officials for the bus industry contended that operators of charter buses should be permitted to regulate smoking based on their passengers' desires. The commission lawyers said officials of the nation's charter bus industry said they feared some business would be lost i they were compelled to enforce a uniform non-smoking ban. The ICC no-smoking rule affects passengers served by about 300 bus companies that provide service on interstate routes. In 1990, these companies are expected to serve some 24 million passengers. Greyhound, the nation's largest bus company, banned smoking on its own initiative shortly after the ICC began considering the issue. As the regulatory process unfolded this year, ASH contended that bus passengers are entitled to the same protection from tobacco smoke in the air as those who travel by plane and train. It noted that Amtrak recently banned smoking in the last four rows of its Superliner lounge cars and in most of its train stations. There are still smoking cars on trains. Smoking is banned on almost all domestic airline flights. The only exceptions are flights to Alaska and Hawaii, each lasting more than six hours. Overseas flights are not affected. ASH said that a recent study of air quality in airline passenger cabins showed that as many as 440 non-smokers a year would die of cancer if smokers were to continue to light up aboard flights lasting two hours or longer. The anti-smoking group said bus passengers would be at even higher risk if smoking were to continue. It said the smaller seating capacity of buses forces non-smoking passengers to be seated closer to smokers than on planes. It also said ventilation on buses often is inferior to that on airplanes. And it said buses are often the only affordable means of long-distance transportation for the poor and elderly. The bus trade associations also cited the health issue, but they contended a clear federal prohibition would also eliminate any misunderstanding in the effort of individual bus companies to enforce limitations on smoking. They said the current rule limiting smoking to no more than 30 percent of bus seats is hard to enforce and that efforts by some companies to ban smoking could place them at a disadvantage if competitors advertised that smoking was permitted. The tobacco industry contended that health hazards posed to non-smokers on interstate buses are not proved.

DOC.HEAD: Czechs No Longer to Act for Cuba in Washington
DOC.TEXT: The Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington will stop representing Cuban diplomatic interests in the United States by March, the state CTK news agency reported Tuesday. CTK quoted the Foreign Ministry as saying the grace period should permit Havana ``to cope with the new situation, without jeopardizing its interests in the U.S.A.'' The Czechoslovak Embassy has represented Cuban interests in Washington since 1977. Diplomatic and consular ties between Cuba and the United States were severed in January 1961. Interests sections enable countries to maintain diplomatic contact without having to have full-fledged embassies. A senior Cuban diplomatic official in Washington, speaking on condition he not be identified, said the Cuban government has no alternate plan in mind at present to replace the current arrangement with the Czechoslovak government. He said he assumes both the Cuban and U.S. governments wish to maintain a diplomatic presence in each other's capital and that Cuba will seek a new arrangement. The official said he had seen news reports about Prague's decision but had heard nothing officially. U.S. diplomatic activities in Havana have been carried out under the auspices of the Swiss embassy. One diplomatic source suggested that Cuba may ask the Swiss to perform that function for Cuba in Washington. The source spoke on condition of anonymity. The news agency quoted an unidentified Foreign Ministry source as saying that ``the different opinions of the two countries on the exercising of human rights'' and other fundamental differences prompted the Czechoslovak decision. Czechoslovakia has become a democracy following the revolution that toppled the Communist leadership one year ago; Cuba remains Communist-ruled. The ministry source suggested that deteriorating relations after Czechoslovakia embraced democracy contributed to Prague's decision, CTK said. He singled out the storming of Czechoslovak embassy premises in Havana in July by Cubans who claimed they were dissidents but who the Czechoslovaks believe were in the pay of the Cuban government. The invasion of the embassy ``can be rightfully presumed to have been intended to discredit the new Czechoslovak regime in the eyes of the Cuban public,'' CTK quoted the source as saying. Efforts to contact the Czechoslovak embassy in Washington by telephone were unavailing.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Up New Offices
DOC.TEXT: NASA administrator Richard Truly said Tuesday the agency will create two new divisions, an Office of Exploration and Office of Human Resources, as recommended last week by an official committee on America's future in space. Truly did not announce who will head the offices. The exploration office will work on options for returning to the moon and mounting a manned expedition to Mars, a goal set by President Bush last year. The human resources office will have charge of insuring engineering, scientific and administrative talent is available to NASA in the future. The NASA administrator made the announcement in a holiday message broadcast to agency employees.

DOC.HEAD: Psychologists Plead for Help for Disaster Rescuers
DOC.TEXT: Researchers who studied disasters and terrorist crimes said Tuesday that rescue workers can be as emotionally affected as survivors and relatives, and need careful counseling. Police officers, ambulance workers and firefighters have quit their jobs because nobody talked to them about the mental strain, speakers told 700 delegates at a London conference of the British Psychological Society. Margaret Mitchell, psychology lecturer at Glasgow University, said, ``We need to learn how rescuers can finally put these traumatic experiences behind them and continue to operate effectively in their jobs.'' Britain suffered a dozen disasters that claimed 1,000 lives within four years in the 1980s - including 150 deaths in two soccer stadiums, 188 on a capsized English Channel ferry, and 167 in a North Sea oil platform explosion. Some rescuers involved also went abroad to help after earthquakes in Armenia, Iran and the Philippines. On Tuesday, four London firemen who fought the 1987 King's Cross subway station fire in which 31 people died were awarded a total of $66,000 in damages for injuries that were almost exclusively psychological. The claim was settled out of court and the men became the first members of the emergency services to receive compensation for such injuries. The psychologists' meeting was held three days before the second anniversary of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, which killed all 259 people on the airliner and 11 others on the ground in Lockerbie, Scotland. ``Mre than 2,000 police from Strathclyde (Scottish region) were sent to Lockerbie, so that only limited psychological debriefing could be carried out,'' said Ms. Mitchell, who studied police officers working in the Lockerbie morgue. ``Many of them still think about what they saw and some of them say they could have got over the stress if there had been structured debriefing after each day's work. But that wasn't possible. ``There is often a feeling of alienation among the rescue services who have seen things that others cannot imagine.'' Dr. David Duckworth, a Leeds University consultant psychologist to three police forces, said he knew of officers so affected by horrors they saw that they were physically sick in the mornings before going to work. ``The effects of disaster on rescue workers can be as traumatic as shell shock and combat fatigue in warfare and as long lasting,'' said Dr. James Thompson, a psychologist at London's Middlesex Hospital who also runs a stress clinic helping disaster survivors. ``In every disaster, some people involved are mentally disabled because they are carrying such a burden,'' Thompson told a news conference. ``All the evidence we have suggests it is helpful if those working on a disaster are encouraged to talk about their reactions and decisions with psychologists and social workers, even within the team with someone who has done it before.'' Thompson added, ``We find some people are not helped by counseling. That's a challenge for which we are still trying to find the real factors and the real therapy.'' He said authorities should tell relatives whatever they wanted to know even if the details were very painful, and they should have a legal right to information. ``They should be told everything - it would help them get over the shock,'' he said. Iris Suzuki, a medical student who studied stress among 40 London ambulance workers, said, ``The public expects ambulance crews to be superhuman and act like it, but deep down they react like any other human beings.'' Dr. Jim Swire, a country doctor whose daughter Flora was killed on Pan Am Flight 103, said a deliberate effort was made to stop relatives from finding out what had happened. ``There were official moves to ensure that available information should not go to the relatives and it took a lot of pushing and shoving to change it,'' he said. Swire is campaigning for Flight 103 families to be told everything about the bombing. He expressed disappointment that the Home Office, which runs the police, has not set up professional and coordinated support groups to help relatives in future disasters. ``Some people believe the right thing to do is to hide things from relatives but nothing can happen to a relative to compare with the disaster. It is beneficial to relatives to talk about it,'' Swire said.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Hostage Freed After Eight Months' Captivity
DOC.TEXT: A 35-year-old Italian merchant was released Tuesday by his kidnappers in the Apromonte Mountains after eight months in captivity, police said. ``It's over, it's over,'' Rocco Surace said when a police patrol found him wandering in the woods near this city in the Calabria region of southern Italy. Looking haggard with a long beard, Surace was taken to the police station in Gioia Tauro where doctors pronounced him in relatively good condition. Police said they had been searching for Surace in the area in recent days and speculated the kidnappers might have released him because they feared being captured. It was not immediately known whether any ransom had been paid. Surace, whose family runs a clothing business, was kidnapped April 12 near his home in Rizziconi. His release leaves six other Italians in the hands of kidnappers. Longest held is Andrea Cortellezzi, abducted in Varese in Febuary 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Presley Guitar And Hendrix Lyrics Sell At Auction
DOC.TEXT: Elvis Presley's acoustic guitar sold for $24,200 and Jimi Hendrix's handwritten lyrics for the rock anthem ``Purple Haze'' brought $17,600 at an auction, Sotheby's said Tuesday. The Rock 'n' Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland placed the winning bid for the lyrics, the auction house said. The 1966 draft in black ball-point pen on yellow-lined notepaper is the earliest known to exist of ``Purple Haze,'' which appeared on Hendrix's debut album ``Are You Experienced'' in 1967. The lyrics were valued at $8,000 to $12,000. Only four of 60 Hendrix lots failed to sell at Monday's sale. The collection of handwritten lyrics, essays, song notes and personal belongings was consigned by an anonymous collector, said Laura Stewart, a Sotheby's spokeswoman. The Hendrix collection brought $176,000. The total for the sale of entertainment and rock 'n' roll memorabiia was $293,269, the auction house said. An anonymous buyer placed the winning bid for the Presley guitar, which was estimated to sell for $15,000 to $20,000. The custom-made guitar from the 1970s was finished in black with ``Elvis Presley'' inscribed in a mother-of-pearl inlay across the fretboard. The guitar was sold by an anonymous consignor, Stewart said.

DOC.HEAD: Olszewski Quits Mission of Gelping Form Next Polish Government
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer picked to help form a new government announced Tuesday he quit because of ``significant differences'' with President-elect Lech Walesa over major appointments. Jan Olszewski, 60, who was favored to become prime minister, said his two weeks of talks settled ``the main principles of the program and tentative decisions on the future composition of the government.'' ``Because there were significant differences in opinion between the president-elect and myself on the composition of the government ... I resigned from the mission,'' he said in a statement read on the evening television news. Walesa spokesman Andrzej Drzycimski denied the resignation posed any problem in naming the next government and said Walesa will announce his choices for main government posts by Saturday. Olszewski said Walesa chose him on Dec. 2 to hold the talks on forming a government. Walesa scored an overwhelming victory in a presidential runoff Dec. 9 and is to be sworn in Saturday. A source close to Olszewski, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the disagreement was over the role of Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz in a new government. The source said she could give no details. Balcerowicz, architect of Poland's tough economic reform program, is considered essential to persuade Western creditors that Poland is sticking to its program to switch to a market economy. But published reports say he demanded complete independence in running the economic program. The state PAP news agency quoted Zdzislaw Najder, chairman of the national Solidarity Citizens Committee and a longtime friend of Olszewski, as saying Olszewski's attempt to form a government turned into a ``fiasco.'' Drzycimski said in a telephone interview that Walesa is considering at least three alternatives to Olszewski for prime minister. He said Walesa has made up his mind about most of the positions in the government, and will stress concern for the economy and young people. Walesa cannot officially nominate a prime minister before he is sworn in. In the meantime, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and his Cabinet stay on in caretaker roles following their resignations last week. Poland's government-in-exile on Tuesday agreed to hand over its historic symbols of authority to Walesa, the nation's first popularly elected leader. The London-based government-in-exile never recognized Poland's 45 years of Communist rule. It goes back to the leaders who fled Poland in 1939 ahead of the invading Nazi German army.

DOC.HEAD: Not Many Drug Users In Aviation, FAA Says
DOC.TEXT: Fewer than one-half percent of more than 120,000 recent drug tests in the aviation industry showed the presence of drugs, the Federal Aviation Administration said Tuesday. The tests were conducted among commercial aviation employees ranging from pilots to airport security screening personnel as well as people applying for such safety or security sensitive jobs, the FAA said. An analysis of the 120,642 tests showed drugs in 561, just 0.47 percent of the total, the FAA said. Of the 51, 345 were in pre-employment tests, and those people were not hired for sensitive jobs. Persons already employed who tested positive were removed from sensitive positions, the agency said. ``These statistics indicated that drug use in aviation is not widespread, but even one drug user is too many and will not be tolerated,'' said James B. Busey, the FAA administrator. Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, the trade association for commercial U.S. airlines, said the industry was pleased by what he called ``these exceptional results.'' ``While employee drug use remains a concern of the airlines, these results show we have an effective program for screening out drug users before they enter the industry and turning up users already employed,'' Aaronson said. ``The results also indicate that the major airlines have far, far less of a drug problem than our society at large, where one in 10 people use illegal drugs, according to government estimates,'' he said. John Mazor, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, said the analysis bore out ``what we have been saying all along, that they were not going to find any significant amount of drug abuse by airline pilots.'' ``We would hope that the government and industry would refocus their efforts away from heavy-handed methods,'' Mazor said. Aaronson said that 90 percent of employees testing positive have resigned with those remaining entering rehabilitation programs. The drug tests were conducted between January and the end of June. They were required under a new Department of Transportation anti-drug program initiated last year. Under the program, 3.2 million other transportation workers also will be subjected to drug testing. They include interstate truck and bus drivers, railroad workers, sailors on commercial vessels and pipeline workers. Some 538,000 aviation industry employees are subject to drug testing - before employment, at random or periodically on the job, after accidents and whenever there is reasonable cause to suspect drug abuse. Included are pilots, mechanics, flight attendants, airport security screening personnel and aircraft dispatchers. A breakdown of the test results that showed drug use among both applicants and employees revealed 18 pilots or other flight crew members, 116 flight attendants, 300 maintenance personnel, 48 aircraft dispatchers, 41 security personnel, five flight instructors, and four private air traffic control personnel. Twenty-nine persons were not identified by job function. Of the positive tests, 346 were attributed to marijuana use, 196 to cocaine, 13 to opiates, one to the use of PCP, and 15 to amphetamine use. Those numbers add to more than 561 because of multiple drug use by some people tested.

DOC.HEAD: Medellin Drug Kingpin Fabio Ochoa Surrenders to Authorities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to RECAST lead to CORRECT attribution to `officials' sted `president,' ADDS background on Ochoa, Seal murder, communique statement. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The youngest of three brothers who allegedly help run the Medellin cocaine cartel surrendered Tuesday under a govenment offer not to extradite drug trafficking suspects, officials said. Fabio Ochoa Vasquez became the first cartel leader to turn himself in under the 3{-month-old offer, which also promises reduced jail sentences for drug suspects who surrender and confess. The U.S. extradition request for Ochoa alleges he led the cartel's cocaine distribution center in Miami. He is also accused of participating in the 1986 murder of Adler ``Barry'' Seal, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration informant whose testimony helped indict several leading traffickers. ``The government is very satisfied that decree 2047 is having all the effects it should have in Colombian life,'' President Cesar Gaviria said, speaking over the Caracol radio network, after the surrender was announced. Justice Minister Jaime Giraldo confirmed the surrender and said, ``We hope that they all turn themselves in.'' In the past month, four mid-level drug traffickers surrendered. Ochoa left a communique with family members explaining his decision. ``I hope this contributes in the best way to peace and understanding in Colombia,'' Ochoa said in the statement read over local radio. A communique from the Ochoa family said the drug lord surrendered to a court official at a church 12 miles south of Medellin, Colombia's second largest city and home base to the world's most violent cocaine cartel. Ochoa will have to confess at least one of his crimes if he is to avoid extradition. Further legal guarantees were offered in another presidential decree Monday, including human rights safeguards for surrendering traffickers. Ochoa, 33, has been named in three federal indictments in the United States, and was cited by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh as one of the ``Dozen Most Wanted'' Colombia drug defendants in August 1989. He allegedly helped run the cartel with his brothers Jorge Luis and Juan David. ``My brother decided to turn himself in to Colombian justice because he believes in it,'' said Marta Nieves, Ochoa's sister, speaking on the RCN radio station. She added that the family plans to release a videotape of Ochoa surrendering in Caldas. Jaime Cordoba, human rights director at the attorney general's office, said that rights delegates will be appointed to oversee Ochoa's case. Radio reports said Ochoa was taken to a maximum-security prison near Medellin. In late November, the Medellin drug bosses said as many as 300 traffickers were willing to surrender in return for government guarantees they will not be extradited to the United States and not be treated as common criminals. Ochoa was named in a 1986 federal indictment in Baton Rouge, La., linking him to the slaying of Seal. The same year, he was indicted on drug trafficking-related charges in Miami. In 1989, he was also named along with his brother Jorge Luis Ochoa and cartel leaders Pablo Escobar and the late Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in an 11-count indictment in Jacksonville, Fla., that grew out of the successful drug trafficking prosecution of Carlos Lehder Rivas. Escobar, reputedly the cartel chief, remains at large. It was not clear if Ochoa's brothers were also preparing to surrender. The Medellin cartel has been blamed for killing 550 Colombians since the government and traffickers declared war on each other 16 months ago. Thousands of others have been killed in gang violence and score-settling in the drug trade. The cartel has released four of nine journalists it kidnapped recently. The cartel said earlier the kidnappings were a response to rights abuses by police in Medellin. They were also apparently trying to pressure the Gaviria administration to gant pardons.

DOC.HEAD: Rate Cut Coming
DOC.TEXT: AT&T Corp. plans to reduce weekday long-distance rates starting Jan. 1, the long-distance company said Tuesday. The reduction, about $33 million in annual revenue to the company, reflects lower fees that will be paid to local telephone companies for access to customers' telephonen lines, AT&T said. Basic customer-dialed long-distance calls by individuals and small businesses will be reduced 1.1 percent between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. Monday through Friday, AT&T said. Some other reductions: -Some calls to Mexico and calls from Hawaii to 17 countries or geographic areas will be cheaper. -Calls to the former East Germany will be reduced to the same price as calls to the former West Germany. -Some lower prices under the Reach Out World international calling plan. AT&T handles about 70 percent of the nation's long-distance calls.

DOC.HEAD: 8-Year-Old With Ponytail to Remain Isolated From Classmates
DOC.TEXT: An 8-year-old boy separated from his classmates because he wears a ponytail will continue his studies in isolation and keep up his legal battle with school officials, his mother said Tuesday. Officials say Zachariah Toungate's 7-inch ponytail violates his school's dress code, but he and his parents claim the code discriminates against boys because girls are allowed to wear long hair. State District Judge H.R. Towslee denied a temporary order to put Zach back into class last month. Tuesday, the judge gave the family's attorney until Jan. 10 to file expanded arguments telling how Zach's isolation has harmed his mother, September Toungate.
