Attorney Charles Beall said he will appeal Towslee's denial of the temporary order. Zach, a third-grader, has been taught in an 11-by-13-foot room for the past 2{ months. Mrs. Toungate said after the hearing her son is frustrated in the room, but wants to keep his ponytail and continue the battle. ``He's hanging in there,'' she said. School Superintendent Paul Flemming said the issue is whether students must obey the rules. ``The question is not a kid with a ponytail,'' Flemming said. ``The question is can a school district allow a student to willfully and continuously disobey rules.'' Zach has received letters from people who support him, Mrs. Toungate said. ``We are overwhelmed from the response from around the world. From the Persian Gulf to Canada to Germany, it's truly amazing,'' she said. Flemming said he was amazed too. ``I think it's amazing that this much attention has been paid by the media to what is basically a violation of a simple dress code,'' he said. Bastrop, a town of about 3,700 people, is about 30 miles east of Austin.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasters: Recession Likely Through First Half of 1991
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economic recession probably began in August and will continue through the first half of 1991, a group of California forecasters said Tuesday. How much the economy shrinks, and for how long, will be determined more by banks and the Federal Reserve Board than by Saddam Hussein, said economists at the UCLA Business Forecasting Project's year-end conference. Lenders' cautiousness could keep a lid on real estate and other industries despite actions such as the Fed's lowering of the key discount rate to 6.5 percent Tuesday, said David G. Hensley, the acting director of the forecast. ``Even if the Fed does bring rates down, financial institutions might be so risk-averse that they will not lend money,'' rendering Fed policy ineffective, Hensley said. ``Construction is an important avenue of recovery from recessions, and a shutoff of real estate lending would likely inhibit the vigor of the recovery,'' he said. The economists said current economic indicators point to a short downturn. They estimated the core annual inflation rate at just 3.6 percent in September and October, and said manufacturers' inventories have been well-managed. Consumption spending and business fixed investment were strong in the third quarter of 1990 despite a plunge in consumer confidence, they said. The UCLA forecast, generally well-regarded, is also known as one of the gloomiest put out by California's economic forecasters. It said California's economy is in recession along with the nation's, dragged down by aerospace industry trauma and the stalled housing industry. ``The bleak evidence on employment, housing, help-wanted advertising and retail sales - reflected in budget problems throughout the state - strongly suggests that California will participate fully in the national downturn,'' Hensley said. The forecast said the gross national product was expected to decline by 0.9 percent in 1991, with a sharp downturn in the first half followed by recovery later. UCLA forecasters currently assume that a diplomatic solution will be reached to the confrontation in the Persian Gulf over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Even if war comes, they feel it will have less effect on the economy than might be expected. ``Some economists have argued that war would provide a huge boost to the economy,'' Hensley said. ``But - considering that any conflict would follow the biggest military buildup in U.S. peacetime history - the near term stimulus is likely to be marginal.'' He said a temporary spike in oil prices resulting from a shooting war would offset any possible uplifting effects on the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister: Moscow Apologized for Downing Jet, Korea War
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets have apologized to South Korea for the Korean War and for downing a Korean airliner in 1983, the national news agency reported Tuesday, quoting Korea's foreign minister. The Soviet Union supported Communist North Korea against the South during the 1950-53 Korean War. In 1983, the Soviets shot down a KAL airliner when it strayed into Soviet air space, killing all 269 people aboard. The Yonhap news agency said Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong told a parliamentary committee of the apologies during testimony Tuesday about his talks last week with the Soviet foreign minister. ``It is true that Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze conveyed an official apology,'' Choi was quoted as saying. Choi accompanied President Roh Tae-woo to Moscow last week for summit talks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The two nations normalized relations Sept. 30. On Saturday, Roh told reporters in Moscow that he and Gorbachev discussed the downing of the jetliner and the end of the Cold War in the Pacific. ``We promised each other that everything that happened in the past should be a thing of the past, and we should start a new chapter in the history of our bilateral talks,'' Roh said. Choi told the National Assembly's Foreign Affairs and Unification Committee that Shevardnadze expressed regret for the ``unfortunate incidents.'' In response to a question from a lawmaker, Choi said the expression of regret was an official apology. ``President Roh's visit was not aimed at hearing a Soviet apology for the unfortunate incidents,'' Choi was quoted as sayng. ``But when I told reporters after my meeting with Shevardnadze that the Soviet minister had conveyed an official apology to our government, the Soviets neither raised issue with it nor objected.''

DOC.HEAD: Duvalierists: Will Fight Aristide Presidency With Legal Means
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUB for 7th graf `With 96,540' to UPDATE with later figures. Picks up 8th graf `Dejoie conceded' with minor editing
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Supporters of the former Duvalier dictatorship said Tuesday they would fight to overturn the expected presidency of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide using legal means. ``We'll decide after the results are in how we are going to act, but it won't be in a violent way,'' said Serge Conille, executive secretary of the Union for National Conciliation, the Duvalier political party. Two days after Haiti's first democratic elections, the independent Electoral Council had released only a fraction of the vote because of difficulties communicating with remote areas. International observers said, however, that Aristide was a clear winner, and a council source said on condition of anonymity that he agreed. Under Haitian law, the Electoral Council has 10 days from the election to publish the results. It was expected to complete the count by the week's end. Aristide, 37, a leftist priest and champion of the poor, has made no public appearances since Sunday's election. Electoral law prohibits candidates from declaring victory on the basis of projections. With 194,820 votes - or about 10 percent - counted, Aristide had 127,099 votes, or 65.2 percent. Former World Bank official Marc Bazin had 22,320, or 11.5 percent; agronomist Louis Dejoie Jr., 21,437, or 11 percent; and evangelical preacher Sylvio Claude, 6,044, or 3.1 percent. Seven other candidates also were in the race. Dejoie conceded defeat. Bazin made no statement, but his sister-in-law, Danielle Bazin, a party official, said: ``We are very disappointed, but we are democrats. If that's what the people want, it's OK.'' After a day of huge victory celebrations, the capital of Port-au-Prince returned to normal Tuesday with streets and markets crowded as usual. The celebrations came to an abrupt end Monday when a pregnant woman was killed at a rally outside Aristide's former church in the slum of La Saline. Radio reports said the woman was shot by police who pulled up in a pickup truck and opened fire on the crowd. The army, however, said the woman had been run over by a vehicle. Police had intervened in the area and fired into the air to disperse demonstrators who were about to attack an unidentified person, an army statement said. An autopsy was scheduled on the dead woman, said to have been seven months' pregnant. The woman's death heightened fears that right-wing supporters of the 29-year dictatorship of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier and his son, Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc,'' would instigate violence to prevent Aristide from taking office. But Conille said the Duvalierists would use only legal means to overturn the election, which international observers said was free and fair. He did not elaborate. Conille is the right-hand man of Roger Lafontant, the self-proclaimed former leader of the hated Tonton Macoute militia that enforced the Duvalier rule. Lafontant returned last summer from five years' exile in neighboring Dominican Republic to run for president. The Electoral Council, however, disqualified him on technical grounds, including his alleged failure to produce a birth certificate and because he had not been cleared of financial wrongdoing when formerly in office as interior minister. Lafontant is fighting the ruling in the courts. Former President Leslie Manigat, who won army-controlled elections in January 1988 and was deposed by a military coup five months later, has brought a similar case in the Supreme Court. He was barred on grounds that the constitution prevents any president from serving two consecutive terms. The Duvalier dictatorship ended on Feb. 7, 1986, when the younger Duvalier fled into exile in France after a popular uprising. Since then, Haiti has been ruled by five governments, four controlled by the army. The new administration is to replace the interim civilian government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court judge appointed in March to lead Haiti to its first fully democratic elections.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Attorney General Faults Police Actions in Stuart Case
DOC.TEXT: Boston police violated individual civil rights in using stop-and-search tactics and appeared to have coerced witnesses to testify in the Stuart murder case, the Massachusetts Attorney General said Tuesday. In a report based on a nearly yearlong investigation, James Shannon said he found a broad pattern of civil rights infringements in search tactics, in which police randomly stopped and frisked minority youths in Boston's inner city. Police Commissioner Francis Roache called Shannon's allegations ``totally unjustified and completely lacking in due process.'' The murder of seven-months-pregnant Carol Stuart, who was white, in October 1989 generated widespread publicity. Her husband, Charles, who was seriously wounded, told police a black mugger abducted them in their car and shot them. William Bennett, a black man whom police were investigating in connection with the shooting, was absolved when Charles Stuart jumped to his death off a bridge and police implicated him in his wife's slaying. Shannon, who leaves office Jan. 3, stopped short of bringing court action, saying such a move would prove time-consuming and ineffective. Instead, he recommended that a civilian review board be established to monitor police. Before the Stuart slaying, black community leaders complained that police wrongly stopped and searched black youths. The outcry intensified when police, seeking a suspect in the Stuart case, kicked down doors and strip-searched young black men. ``There is no excuse for forcing young men to lower their trousers, or for a police officer to search inside their underwear on public streets and hallways,'' Shannon said in the report. ``That practice must be condemned in the strongest possible terms.'' Roache, in a statement issued after Shannon's report was released, stressed that no one has filed a complaint against the department. ``It is crucial to note that the attorney general has concluded that there are no grounds for any legal action,'' the statement said. The report found that homicide detectives appeared to have threatened, coerced or offered favors to obtain testimony that would implicate Bennett. Shannon said his report on the allegations of coercion was incomplete because police had refused to cooperate with the probe. But two men who were picked up by police for questioning, Dereck Jackson and Eric Whitney, told investigators police threatened them with jail and denied them access to attorneys. Jackson and Whitney were questioned by police after Jackson told Whitney he had heard William Bennett's nephew jokingly say he thought Bennett killed Stuart. Shannon said complaints about searches should be referred to his office or the U.S. Attorney's office to be evaluated. In the past, the police department's Internal Affairs Unit has overseen such inquiries. ``But Internal Affairs has not done the job here,'' Shannon said. ``Until the BPD has demonstrated that it can police its own officers effectively, it must be carefully scrutinized by an independent law enforcement agency.'' Shannon denied that his report was little more than a slap on the wrist for police, who are under no obligation to abide by its recommendations. ``Litigation would accomplish nothing,'' Shannon said. ``I think the public is going to demand these changes. The findings are so substantial that they cannot be ignored.'' Louis Elisa, head of the Boston chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, praised Shannon for his ``comprhensive review.'' But he said the report came so late in Shannon's term and suggested that Shannon pass his findings on to the U.S. attorney to take action. Shannon alleged in the report that Frank McGee, a lawyer for the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, advised officers not to cooperate with the investigation. McGee said the allegations were false and that Shannon was retaliating for the union's endorsement of Scott Harshbarger, who defeated Shannon in the attorney general race.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Daily Viewing Image at Auto Supply Store
DOC.TEXT: Reynaldo Trevino spends more time preaching than selling auto parts now that hundreds of people daily ignore his fan belts and radiator hoses to view what they believe is the Virgin Mary's image on a bathroom floor. The image - varying shades of gray that Trevino said used to be one color - appeared Dec. 3 on the cement floor of the shower stall in the rear of his Progreso Auto Supply. He said something within his heart told him to spread the message that the presence on the floor symbolized the way many neglect their faith. ``So I started telling every customer who came in,'' Trevino said Tuesday. ``Before I sold them a part, I took them back.'' The word spread quickly. A steady procession of faithful and curious now enter the store daily in the tiny town by the Mexican border in the Lower Rio Grande Valley. Some days more than 1,000 visit. About 100 per hour stopped at the store Tuesday morning. Only a few came to buy auto parts. Over and over, Trevino told visitors the message he believes the Virgin told him to spread: ``Share with your brothers, pray the rosary, fast and look for Jesus and put him at the center of your hearts.'' They had to wind their way behind the counter and down a narrow corridor past the shelves of inventory before reaching the restroom at the back corner. Some knelt to pray by the shower stall, next to a toilet. Others made the sign of the cross or touched the image they saw. They see the Virgin's image in the varying shades of gray cement. A dark area about a foot wide appears in the shape of common representations of the Virgin. What could be interpreted as facial features are vaguely discernible. Others see more, including a woman Tuesday who said she saw an earring, flowers and an angel to the side. ``She's so beautiful, so beautiful,'' 14-year-old Bonnie Maldonado said, tears flowing from her eyes after leaving the store. Her mother, Ernestina Maldonado, said she found it painful to see the Virgin on the floor. ``I feel guilty,'' she said. ``I feel very, very guilty because I feel like I'm part of this world. I'm part to blame for where she is. In the process of trying to get ahead, we have lost our values.'' Trevino, 45, is Roman Catholic, like most who believe they see the Virgin Mary at his store. Some don't see anything special, he said. To aid viewing, Trevino placed in the shower a small picture of the Virgin, along with a fluorescent desk lamp. He said he plans to make no money from the image and that his business actually has suffered from his devotion of so much time to his new religious mission. Trevino planned to sell the store until he saw the image. Now, he said, he awaits guidance from God on what to do with the business. He discourages photographs. ``I want them to take the image home with them in their hearts,'' Trevino said.

DOC.HEAD: Space Trip Sweepstakes Up in the Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Texas grand jury investigating contest. Pick up 3rd graf, `So many ...' SUBS 14th graf, `Davidson said ...' with 6 grafs of details of grand jury probe, comment from company. Pick up 15th graf, `The contest ...' DELETES 22nd graf, `Sweepstakes rules...,'' now redundant. ^By MICHAEL GRACZYK
DOC.TEXT: The chaotic start of a sweepstakes promotion that promised to put an American aboard the Soviet space station became even more tangled Tuesday when the official Soviet news agency called the contest a hoax. Complicating matters still further, Texas officials said they were investigating to see whether the contest by Space Travel Services violated state lottery laws. The Houston-based company announced Monday that callers to a 900 number had a chance to win six months' training, a trip aboard a Soviet rocket and a week on the space station Mir. So many callers dialed the number to enter the sweepstakes - at $2.99 a shot - that they knocked the Dallas-based phone system out of service periodically Monday and Tuesday. ``We've been rather overwhelmed,'' James Davidson, senior vice president of Space Travel, said Tuesday. The company's glee turned to confusion later in the day when Tass denied reports of any deal involving Americans and Glavkosmos, the Soviet space agency, and said it was a hoax. ``The Glavkosmos does not know anything about this project,'' Tass reported. Organizers in Houston termed the denial a misunderstanding. ``There's a limit to how much we can do to control Soviet bureaucracy, and there's a limit to what we can do with Tass,'' said David Mayer, president of Space Travel. ``We basically have our contract in hand, so we know that we're basically straight,'' he said. ``It's just a matter of us finding out what's going on behind the scenes in the Soviet Union, to find out where the confusion lies. It's obviously just a misunderstanding and I don't think it will be that difficult to clear up.'' ``Space Travel Services Corp. has a legal contract with NPO Energia for a trip to the Mir Space Station aboard a Soyuz vehicle,'' company spokesman George Nelson said. ``Two contracts are involved. One between Space Travel and Space Commerce Corp. of Houston and a second between Space Commerce and NPO Energia of Moscow.'' Space Commerce Corp. is the company that negotiated with NPO Energia on behalf of Space Travel. NPO Energia is the Soviet agency that builds rockets and negotiates commercial deals for the Soviet space program, but Glavkosmos must approve any contracts. Nelson said the Energia contract was signed by Uri Pavelovitch Semenov, general designer in Energia's Moscow office, and was delivered to Space Commerce with a cover letter signed by V.P. Nikitskiy, deputy chairman of NPO Energia. Space Travel also has a letter from Alexander I. Dunaev, chairman of Glavkosmos USSR confirming that Energia has full authority to sign and execute that contract. ``There were no deals on the subject,'' Tass quoted Vladimir Zenkin, deputy commercial manager at the Energia agency. A Harris County assistant district attorney said Tuesday that Mayer and Davidson were subpoenaed to appear before a grand jury Wednesday for questioning about the contest. ``Nobody's been charged with anything,'' said Russell Turbeville, head of the district attorney's consumer fraud division. ``There's just so much information coming from so many sources so fast we just had to look into it.'' ``We were concerned that even if it was not a hoax and the arrangements were made properly with the Soviets, (the sweepstakes) would violate state lottery laws,'' Turbeville said. It is a felony in Texas to charge people for a chance to win something. Davidson said because people could enter the sweepstakes by mail at no charge the contest did not violate state laws. Mayer said he would submit to the grand jury a written opinion from his lawyers saying the sweepstakes did not violate Texas laws. Earlier, Davidson said if the project fell through, callers would get refunds. The contest is to culminate in December 1991 when an American is selected in a random drawing for six months' training, a trip aboard a Soviet rocket and a week on the Russian space station in late 1992 or early 1993. Thousands of calls made to the 900 number Monday caused the circuits at Wholesale Telephone to overload. ``We got a little bit buried, but I'm not embarrassed. We're getting a lot of calls,'' said Larry Summers, president of Wholesale Telephone. I'm kind of a space nut myself so I'm real excited to see that.'' He estimated that about 5,000 calls were missed overnight from the service disruption. He said he worked all night to expand his computer system's capacity to handle the volume. Summers and Davidson said they didn't know how many calls had been received. Davidson said the system was able to handle 200 phone calls at once. ``For 200 people to call and lock up the system would require several thousand people calling every hour,'' Davidson said. Summers said the calls to the 900 number are stored on digital tape, with 17,686 messages per tape. Winners will be chosen by an accounting firm that will randomly designate a location on a part of the tape, he said. The grand prize includes the space ride plus $500,000 in cash, Space Travel said. Or the sweepstakes winner can opt to stay on Earth and collect $1.5 million in cash. A backup astronaut will be picked from 11 potential candidates selected in the drawing, Davidson said. Contest rules require that entrants be at least 18 and residents of the United States. They are not required to be U.S. citizens. Space Travel said because of local laws, residents of New York, Florida or Rhode Island would not be eligible for the flight. Deadline for the contest is Dec. 1, 1991. The exact cost of the trip was not disclosed, but Space Travel officials have said it was more than the $12 million paid by a Japanese broadcast company to put a reporter aboard the station. Besides income from the 900 number, for which Space Travel gets more than 50 percent of the $2.99 per call, the company hopes to lure advertisers eager to put their logos on the winner's spacesuit and on the spacecraft or have the American cosmonaut endorse certain products from space.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq: 2,000 Children Have Died Because of U.N. Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi official on Tuesday claimed that more than 2,000 children aged 4 or under have died because of shortages in baby food and medicine caused by the U.N. embargo on trade with Iraq. Health Minister Abdul-Salam Mohammed Said blamed President Bush for the deaths in a statement distributed by the official Iraqi News Agency. ``Documented evidence of this high rate in childrens' death will stand to condemn the crimes committed by Bush and his partners,'' INA quoted the minister as saying. He said 600 of the 2,042 children died in hospitals this month, mainly due to shortages of vaccines that caused the spread of contagious diseases like measles, diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough. Said claimed on Dec. 3 that 1,416 children had died because of shortages resulting from the sanctions the U.N. Security Council imposed on Iraq as punishment for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Western diplomats in Baghdad have discounted the reports of shortages, noting that the Security Council decided in October to allow shipments of essential food and medicines to Iraq. The diplomats note that since mid-October, nearly 120 tons of medicine have arrived from humanitarian groups worldwide, earmarked for Iraqi children. Most of the shipments were in exchange for Western hostages helped by Iraq until President Saddam Hussein announced a blanket release on Dec. 6. Last week alone, Iraq's Red Crescent, the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross, announced it had received 22 tons of medical supplies from Italy and another 28 tons from the United Nations' Children Fund, UNICEF. But government hospitals still report shortages of vaccines, antibiotics and baby formulas. Iraqis say they can buy medicine at pharmacies and on the black market but the prices are at least five times higher than normal. Some diplomats and medical personnel in Baghdad suggested last month that Iraq might be stockpiling medicine in case of war and that some of the reported shortages resulted from profiteering. A government rationing plan enforced in September limits each child under age 1 to three 16-ounce cans of baby formula a month. At government subsidized stores, each can costs $2.25 at the official exchange rate. Iraqis are forced to supplement their babies' diet with powdered milk bought on the black market at prices well beyond the means of most Iraqis.

DOC.HEAD: FNN Anual Report: $72.4 Million in Losses for 1990
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version is running on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Financial News Network Inc. suffered losses totaling $72.4 million for its 1990 fiscal year, the cable television concern disclosed Tuesday. The reasons for FNN's reversal of fortune included accounting changes totaling $65 million. The company said the changes regarded improperly documented lease transactions, new product development costs and payments to its sister company, United Press International. FNN and UPI are subsidiaries of Infotechnology Inc. FNN said it was in the process of revising its quarterly reports for the first three quarters of 1990 to reflect a review conducted by by FNN and its new accountants, Coopers & Lybrand. Last month FNN said it expected a net loss of $72.5 million for the 1990 fiscal year. Last year, for the fiscal year ending in 1989, FNN recorded a profit over $3 million, but those figures were unaudited. The company's fiscal year ends June 30. Financial News Network provides business, sports and market data to cable systems in the United States and Canada. FNN and Infotechnology collectively own 51 percent of the Learning Channel, and Infotechnology also has investments in other media, communications and biotechnology companies. In October, FNN dismissed C. Steven Bolen, chief financial officer, for improper financial dealings. FNN also dismissed its auditors, Deloitte & Touche in a disagreement over accounting methods. The FNN annual report stated that a company investigation concluded Bolen had payments made to himself totaling $794,061 that were ``not properly authorized and not properly identified on (FNN's) books.'' ``Through his counsel, Mr. Bolen claimed that such payments were earned by him as incentive compensation for arranging financing for the company,'' the filing stated. FNN said it was considering suing Bolen to recover the money. Originally at issue in the dispute with Deloitte & Touche was how FNN was reporting its $28 million investment in a new service. Deloitte contended the investment should have been deducted from quarterly earnings - which would have put FNN in the red - rather than spread out over several years. Because of the dispute, FNN was unable to file its annual financial reports with the SEC for the fiscal year ended June 30. In addition, Deloitte withdrew its opinions on FNN's and Infotech's 1989 financial statements. Last month FNN said it expected a net loss of $72.5 million for the 1990 fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Donates Half of Nobel Prize Award to Cancer Center
DOC.TEXT: Dr. E. Donnall Thomas, whose pioneering bone marrow transplants offered new hope to leukemia patients, donated his half of the more than $700,000 Nobel Prize award to a cancer center. Thomas gave the money to Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, where he is a physician and a researcher. Thomas shared this year's Nobel in medicine with Dr. Joseph E. Murray of Boston. Thomas and Murray were credited with performing critical experiments that opened the door to successful organ transplantation in humans. Thomas, 70, announced his gift to the cancer center at a reception and dinner Monday night. Thomas said he felt he couldn't keep the money for himself because the decades of research that led to his prize were the sums of efforts involving many Hutchinson staff members and several other Seattle hospitals. ``We even want to pay income tax on this money,'' Thomas said. ``We thank all of you for this wonderful occasion.'' He was given two long standing ovations. Thomas, also a professor of medicine and oncology at the University of Washington, performed the first human bone marrow transplant in 1956 on sets of identical twins in which one twin had severe leukemia. While the transplant was successful and not rejected, the patient with the cancer eventually died from the disease. Most medical researchers then dismissed marrow transplantation as impossible, but Thomas and his colleagues persevered. Thomas helped refine the procedure, during which cancerous bone marrow is replaced with healthy marrow from a donor. Today, bone marrow transplantation is considered the preferred treatment for some leukemia and lymphoma patients who otherwise would not survive. Thousands of such operations have been performed at Hutchinson. Murray, 71, and a retired Harvard Medical School professor, in 1954 performed the first successful kidney transplant in identical twins at what is now the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Lawyers Ask World Help To Block Deportations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir comments on proposed U.N. resolution. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `At a news ...' edits to conform and trim
DOC.TEXT: Arab lawyers from Jerusalem and the occupied West Bank on Tuesday urged the international community to intervene to stop Israel from deporting Palestinian activists. The plea came as an army judicial panel considered the appeal of four leaders of the Moslem fundamentalist Hamas movement who have been ordered expelled by the Israeli government. The expulsion orders also gave America room to back a proposed U.N. resolution criticizing the Jewish state, diplomats said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. The deportation orders were issued after Hamas slogans claimed responsibility for the stabbing deaths of three Israelis last Friday. The government has not accused the four men of involvement in the killings but said they incited others to violence. All four are from the occupied Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said U.S. support of the U.N. resolution ``opposes the American interest at this time.'' ``Because in essence any decision against Israel in the Security Council is liable to be an achievement for Saddam Hussein,'' Iraq's president, Shamir said. Saddam has tried to link a resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis with the Palestinian issue. A non-binding section in the resolution would endorse a Mideast peace conference, but it stresses the gulf crisis and the conference are not linked. At a news conference in Arab east Jerusalem, Palestinian lawyers said they feared Israel planned extensive deportations. ``News and reports have confirmed the existence of another list containing tens of Palestinians who will be candidates for deportation,'' said Ali Ghuzlan, president of the Arab Lawyers Committee. The committee charged Israel was ``paving the road before the collective transfer'' of Palestinians from their homeland. ``We as lawyers strongly condemn this policy and urge the local, Israeli and world opinion ... to ask for the immediate cancellation of the emergency regulations'' under which the deportations are ordered, its statement said. Israeli had been reported planning 14 expulsions in all. Later reports said the number was scaled back because of U.S. objections. Nazem Oweida, a Gaza lawyer for the Hamas activists, complained Tuesday of insufficient time to prepare his case. ``We were surprised to get hundreds of pages of material, some of it blurry and not translated,'' Oweida said. ``We asked for a week to look at it, and we got only 24 hours.'' Oweida said he would appeal to the Supreme Court if the military panel ruled against them. Deportation orders have never been overturned by Israeli courts. Israel reinstituted its deportation policy after a lapse of 16 months to try to calm rising public fears over Arab attacks on Jews. The decision drew immediate criticism from the U.S. State Department, which said the expulsions violated the Fourth Geneva Convention protecting the rights of peoples under occupation. Before deportations were suspended in August 1989, reportedly at U.S. urging, 60 Palestinians had been expelled for alleged involvement in the now 3-year-old uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Shops and offices in the West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem were closed Tuesday in a strike called by Hamas to protest the expulsion orders. The Israeli government also drew criticism from its right-wing supporters. Agriculture Minister Rafael Eitan of the far-right Tsomet Party described the planned deportation of four Moslem activists as ``very late and in a very small amount.'' He urged the government not to make public in advance its deportation plans to avoid any international outcry. ``Let the press find out about it two weeks later,'' Eitan said on army radio. Eliahu Ben-Elissar, a senior member of Shamir's Likud bloc, was quoted in Israeli newspapers as saying the government was failing to protect Israelis. ``The government's policy will, in the end, bring about the abandonment of Judea and Samaria,'' he said, using the biblical terms for the West Bank. Retaining control of the West Bank and Gaza, which Israel seized in the 1967 Middle East war, is a pillar of Likud's platform.

DOC.HEAD: White Supremacist Re-indicted in Civil Rights Leader's 1963 Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Beckwith said ...' to UPDATE with complete quote.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY25
With AM-Evers Case-Chronology
DOC.TEXT: A segregationist who has stood trial twice in the 1963 ambush slaying of civil rights leader Medgar Evers faces a third trial after being indicted on new evidence. Byron De La Beckwith, 70, of Signal Mountain, Tenn., is charged with murder in the shooting death of Evers, field secretary for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``Justice can be only served if there is a final conclusion, once and for all,'' District Attorney Ed Peters said Tuesday. Peters said the re-indictment was issued Friday by a grand jury in Jackson. Beckwith, who is in poor health and advancing years, still espouses white supremacy and flies the Confederate flag outside his home. He was arrested Monday at his house on a fugitive warrant issued by the state of Mississippi. Beckwith was released on $15,000 bond after a court appearance in Chattanooga, Tenn. His next court appearance was set for Feb. 22. Beckwith said he intends to fight extradition. ``I'm going to resist tooth, nail and claw because I think all this is nonsense, poppycock and something to stir the people up ... and incite the lower forms of life to force and violence against the country clubs,'' he said during his court appearance. If extradited, Beckwith will stand trial in the June 12, 1963, death of Evers, 37, who was shot while standing in the driveway of his Jackson home. Beckwith can be tried again without double jeopardy because no verdict was ever reached. His two previous trials ended with deadlocked juries. Also, no statute of limitations exists in murder cases. ``Although Beckwith was vigorously prosecuted in 1964, those prosecutions did not have the benefit of certain evidence accumulated during the course of our investigation,'' Peters said. Peters did not disclose the new evidence and refused to answer questions from reporters. He did say, however, that individuals, both black and white, ``have taken the courageous step of coming forward.'' He said their identities would not be revealed but that they had agreed to testify. Evers led black voter registration drives in Mississippi and filed complaints with the federal government concerning civil rights violations. The assassination helped focus national attention on the civil rights struggle in Mississippi and helped push forward civil rights reforms. Beckwith's fingerprint was found on a rifle discarded near the scene; he claimed the rifle had been stolen from his home. After his two trials in 1964, both times before all-white juries, the murder charge against Beckwith was dismissed in 1969. The investigation was reopened amid allegations of jury and evidence tampering by the state Sovereignty Commission, a state segregationist watchdog agency that went out of business in 1973. Prosecutors later said they found no evidence of jury tampering. ``Without a conviction in this case we must believe that everything Medgar fought and died for was meaningless,'' said Evers' widow, Myrlie Evers of Los Angeles. ``I hope that it is the foreteller of the kind of justice attitude that becomes a reality,'' said Aaron Henry, president of the state NAACP since 1960. ``It's about time for us to clean up our act and see that justice is done in this case,'' said Vicksburg Mayor Robert Walker, who was field secretary of the state NAACP during 1980-84. In a telephone interview Saturday, Beckwith said another trial would be a popularity contest but that he expected to be cleared. ``Whites are the most numerous. ... I know where the power and the authority in Mississippi lays because I was raised in the middle of it,'' he said. ``If I didn't know what was going on down there, I wouldn't be so cheerful up here,'' he said from his home. Beckwith has been an outspoken opponent of integration since 1954, when he joined the pro-segregation Citizens Council. After his trials in the Evers slaying, Beckwith ran for lieutenant governor in 1967, collecting 34,675 of the 665,539 votes cast and finishing fifth among six candidates. In 1973, he was convicted in Louisiana of possessing dynamite without a permit and served five years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: British Ambassador to Kuwait Returns to London
DOC.TEXT: The last two British Embassy staffers in Kuwait, who held out against isolation and intimidation for nearly four months, on Tuesday arrived in London to be reunited with their families. Ambassador Michael Weston and Consul Larry Banks were greeted by their wives and colleagues at Heathrow Airport after arriving from Amman, Jordan. The two traveled via Baghdad. ``It is tremendous to be home - if a little cold,'' said Weston, who hugged his wife, Christine. ``The last time I spoke to my wife was on Aug. 1, so it is wonderful to be back.'' Iraqi forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. A U.S.-led multinational force has since assembled in the Persian Gulf to demand Iraq's withdrawal by Jan. 15. The Westons and Larry and Elizabeth Banks were welcomed by Foreign Office Minister Douglas Hogg, who said, ``Their efforts have been magnificent. They have done an extremely good job both in supporting the residents in Kuwait and also in keeping us fully informed as to what is going on.'' Weston has said Banks grew vegetables to feed them and dug wells for water. After the Aug. 24 deadline by which all embassies in Kuwait were to close, Iraqi forces cut water and electricity to embassies, and troops were deployed outside their gates. Earlier on Tuesday, Prime Minister John Major warned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that time was running out. ``Insofar as a solution of the gulf crisis is concerned, I must say that that rests squarely with Saddam Hussein,'' Major said in Parliament. ``Time is running out for him. The international community has made it quite clear that force will be used if Iraq has not withdrawn totally and unconditionally from Kuwait by Jan. 15,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Still Searching For New GOP Chairman
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4th graf: ``Arriving in,'' with Carruthers declining to say if job offered
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday was still mulling over a list of candidates for national Republican Party chairman and a top aide said he was not likely to make the selection before the end of the week. Among the names emerging as strong contenders, according to administration officials were those of GOP political operative Rich Bond and outgoing New Mexico Gov. Garrey Carruthers. Carruthers was summoned to the White House on Tuesday by Chief of Staff John Sununu, his New Mexico office said. Sununu earlier asked him to replace outgoing drug policy director William Bennett, but Carruthers turned it down, said his press secretary Eddie Binder. Arriving in New Mexico Tuesday evening, Carruthers said he made a commitment to help in the Bush re-election campaign, but he declined to say whether he was offered to position of party chairman. However, the administration sources, speaking on condition of anonymity said other names were still live prospects for RNC chairman as well. They said Bush was keeping very close counsel on the matter and was likely to announce the decision on very short notice. One senior official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there was a chance of less than 20 percent that Bush would make a final decision on the matter before leaving at the end of the week to spend the Christmas holiday at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md. The official said there was no real pressure to make a quick decision, since the Republican National Committee, which technically will choose its chairman does not meet until Jan. 25. The RNC is expected to rubber stamp Bush's choice. The official said aides had given him a list of 12 to 15 possible candidates, and that Bush was adding and subtracting his own candidates. The search has resumed since Bush's first choice, outgoing drug policy director Bennett, accepted and then rejected the offer saying he had too many financial aspirations that might pose conflict of interest questions. Many White House officials are lining up behind Bond's candidacy, going with his strength as a political strategist in lieu of a bombastic public speaker like Bennett, according to some sources. After Bennett rejected the post, administration officials were divided on whether it would be better to find a flashy public personage or pick someone who had more campaign strategy credentials. Among the potential candidates in the former category, the names of Transportation Secretary Sam Skinner, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp and outgoing Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., were mentioned, along with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. In the political operative category, names that still were mentioned on Tuesday were former Rep. Tom Loeffler, now a Texas attorney, and Michigan GOP Chairman Spencer Abraham, a political aide to Vice President Dan Quayle. Bond who organized the Iowa caucuses for Bush in the 1988 presidential campaign and then served as political director, is credited with helping to solidify the Republican base for Bush. He now has a Virginia consulting business. Carruthers was elected governor in 1986 and was barred by law from seeking a second term this year. His term is up Jan. 1, and he has indicated he would like to take some time out from public life. He told Sununu that when he was offered a chance to be considered or drug czar, said Binder. Carruthers also served as state GOP chairman in new Mexico and was an assistant interior secretary from 1981 to 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Revokes Bail in Kahane Case; Says His Own Life Threatened
DOC.TEXT: A judge Tuesday revoked $300,000 bail for the accused murderer of Rabbi Meir Kahane and said he received death threats for his handling of the case. The judge, Alvin Schlesinger, said virtually all of hundreds of letters and telephone calls he got urged him to keep El Sayyid Nosair in jail, but he said they had no influence on his decision to revoke bail. He had stayed the bail pending the hearing and Nosair was never released. Schlesinger said he changed his mind because he was able ``to drag out of'' Assistant District Attorney William Greenbaum information that Nosair had used five different addresses for questionable reasons. ``With respect to the threats on my life, my reaction to those has been revulsion, contempt and outrage,'' the judge said. Schlesinger refused to say who or where the threats came from, but said some of the individuals who contacted him ``ought to know better.'' Greenbaum told the judge Nosair had manuals on gun use and bomb making in his Cliffside Park, N.J., home. And police recovered a bullet-pocked wall that had apparently been used for target practice. Schlesinger said he noticed that the last name of Nosair's wife and child on their passports were different from his. He said Nosair's passport had the last name Abdul-Azziz. All were United States passports. A vial of sodium cyanide that Greenbaum said was in Nosair's locker in the courthouse basement where he worked in Manhattan could be used to poison someone or to commit suicide, Schlesinger said. Greenbaum told Schlesinger perfect ballistics matches were made between the gun found on the street next to Nosair when he was captured and the bullets that came out of Kahane and other victims. ``It appears to me that the prosecutor has what we refer to in the courthouse as a rather strong case,'' Schlesinger said. The judge chided the prosecutor for not giving him enough information in the first bail hearing two weeks ago to make an intelligent decision about whether Nosair ought to be remanded. Nosair, 35, is an Egyptian immigrant who came to this country in 1981. He is charged with murder for allegedly shooting the Zionist rabbi through the neck Nov. 5 as Kahane finished speaking to a Jewish group in Manhattan. Nosair is also charged with the attempted murder of two men he is accusing of wounding as he allegedly tried to get away. One of the defendant's alleged victims, U.S. Postal Service Police Officer Carlos Acosta, shot Nosair in the neck between his chin and throat. Nosair recovered and has been moved from Bellevue Hospital to Rikers Island. Schlesinger scheduled Nosair for another hearing March 5.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Defends Contributions
DOC.TEXT: Japan's financial contribution to the Gulf crisis was defended by a senior Japanese diplomat Tuesday as not less than what the United States requested. ``I think the Japanese contribution is comparable to the whole of Western Europe's,'' which has an economy twice the size of Japan, said Takayuki Kimura, deputy chief of his country's Washington embassy. He appeared at a news conference to answer accusations that Japan was shirking a fair share of crisis burden, considering its status as the world's second strongest economic power and its heavy dependence on Middle East oil. Kimura was asked repeatedly if the $4 billion Japanese financial contribution shown in tables handed reporters was considered enough in light of the possibility that U.S. and other lives may be sacrificed if the crisis brings war, and a reported $30 billion cost to America for the military buildup. The tables and other information disclosed that much of the contribution pledged by Japan has not yet been disbursed and much of $2 billion to help Egypt, Turkey and Jordan as countries particularly hurt by the international trade embargo against Iraq is in the form of loans rather than grants. All the loans are ``untied,'' meaning they need not be spent in Japan, Kimura said. Grants would have required time-consuming law changes while low one percent interest rates and long 30-year repayment terms make the loans worth 80 percent as much as grants, he added. To suggestions that approximately $2 billion in financing, equipment and transportation for U.S. forces is ``too little and too slow,'' Kimura said the Pentagon prefers payment in kind, and military procurement simply takes time. About $600 million of the first $1 billion has been spent or contracted and an additional $1 billion just approved by parliament will soon be paid, the embassy said. The U.S. government has ``a general idea'' of how much more Japan would contribute if the crisis led to war, Kimura said. It was up to the United States to disclose the amount of its requests, he said, adding in answer to a question that the Japanese conribution was ``not less than what they asked.'' The U.N. Security Council and the U.S.-led multinational military force have set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Japanese and German forces are not part of the 27-nation multinational force as a result of restrictions on sending soldiers overseas that stem from their defeat in World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Passport Processer Arrested on Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: A State Department employee at a passport office was arrested on charges of helping violent drug dealers get illegal passports, authorities said Tuesday. Kenneth R. Weatherspoon was charged Monday in a federal indictment with helping heroin and cocaine dealers illegally obtain passports between June 1986 and February 1988. Federal agents arrested Weatherspoon Thursday at the passport office in Rockefeller Center in Manhattann, prosecutors said. He pleaded innocent and was freed on $50,000 bail. Andrew Laine, a spokesman for the State Department, said Weatherspoon was no longer working at the passport office, but said the agency had not yet determined if he would be fired. U.S. Attorney Andrew J. Maloney said Weatherspoon conspired with Eric Vassel, the alleged leader of the ``Gulleymen'' gang, and others to obtain passports for gang members. ``State Department records reveal that between 1986 and 1988, Weatherspoon knowingly processed and approved over 35 fraudulent passport applications,'' Maloney said. He said that at least two of the passports went to members of Vassel's Jamaican gang. In a crackdown earlier this month, federal agents arrested 17 members of the Gulleymen gang, an organization that allegedly controlled crack houses in Brooklyn and Dallas. The drug ring has been linked to at least 10 killings. Drug dealers, illegal aliens and others who wanted passports allegedly paid $2,500 to a middleman who assisted them in getting the documents through Weatherspoon, prosecutors said. Weatherspoon, 53, of Brooklyn also was indicted on charges of helping Edwards and members of his crack gang illegally get passports. Edwards was convicted in 1989 of federal racketeering charges that included six murders and was sentenced to seven consecutive life sentences. If convicted, Weatherspoon faces a maximum of five years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Extends Order Allowing Daily News Hawkers in Transit System
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday extended the Daily News' right to employ hawkers in subway and railroad stations in an eight-week strike. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum granted the tabloid a preliminary injunction that replaces a previous order, which was to expire Thursday. The Daily News says it depends on hawkers to distribute the newspaper because virtually all newsstands stopped carrying the paper after nine of its 10 unions went on strike Oct. 25. The judge said the injunction would remain in effect until the News' lawsuit against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is resolved. The lawsuit claims the Daily News' First Amendment right to free speech was violated when the transit authority rescinded permits late last month that had allowed hawkers to sell the News in the transit system. The transit authority said it terminated the permits because of concerns that striking newspaper employees would set up picket lines that would be honored by transit workers. The judge noted that it would be illegal for the transit workers to honor picket lines because public employees are barred under law from striking. Transit authority spokesman Tito Davila said lawyers were likely to appeal Cedarbaum's ruling. The News has published daily during the strike but has had major problems in circulation and advertising. Before the strike, it was the third-largest metropolitan daily, with circulation of 1.09 million. The News' circulation is now about 600,000.

DOC.HEAD: Former Assessor Accused of Using Taxes for Payback Against Ex-Girlfriend
DOC.TEXT: A former member of the Hull Board of Assessors was accused Tuesday of taking revenge against an ex-girlfriend by helping raise her property tax bill. The State Ethics Commission accused Stephen Malcolm of violating the Massachusetts conflict-of-interest law. According to an order filed by the commission, Malcolm became romantically involved with a Hull resident in March 1987 and the relationship ended a couple months later with bad feelings on both sides. Later that year, Malcolm told a subordinate that the ex-girlfriend wanted her tax assessment increased because she was planning to put her house up for sale and she wanted to ask a higher price than what was reflected by its assessment at the time, the order said. The woman had no plans to sell her house and didn't request a reassessment, the order said. The assessment on her property rose from $40,300 to $122,700, resulting in a $2,000 tax increase. Later, the Board of Assessors re-evaluated the property and approved a tax reduction. Malcolm said the charges were ``ludicrous.'' He said the home was assessed too low and his actions had nothing to do with his feelings about the woman.

DOC.HEAD: State's Chief Justice Violated Constitution, Federal Judge Finds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with judge planning appeal, quote. Pick up 4th graf, `Wilentz barred ...'
DOC.TEXT: The state's top judge violated the U.S. Constitution when he banned the filming of ``The Bonfire of the Vanities'' from the Essex County Courthouse, a federal judge ruled Tuesday. U.S. District Judge Nicholas Politan harshly criticized Robert Wilentz, chief justice of the state Supreme Court, saying he violated the First Amendment by banning the filming. Wilentz said he would appeal. ``I have advised all assignment judges that pending the outcome of the appeal, no filming will be allowed in the courthouses of New Jersey. This order does not apply to the filming or televising of actual court proceedings, which may continue as in the past,'' he said in a statement. Wilentz barred filming of the movie scenes inside the ornate courthouse in May. He argued that the depiction of rioting black characters would undermine what little faith blacks have left in the justice system. Wilentz said in an affidavit that he is constitutionally permitted and even duty-bound to consider whether the content of a movie scene is ``inappropriate for the judiciary to be associated with.'' Essex County Executive Nicholas Amato sued Wilentz in May, claiming the chief judge trampled on the First Amendment and deprived the county of a $250,000 donation from Warner Bros. Politan ruled in the county's favor, but did not grant the $250,000 monetary award the county sought. ``By acting to further his concern for the welfare of the black community, (Wilentz) egregiously trammelled a fundamental bulwark against the spread of governmental despotism,'' Politan wrote. Wilentz had offered to let the company film if they would change a scene, but producer Fred Caruso declined. The film, based on Tom Wolfe's novel, looks at New York's legal system, illuminating the city's racial and class divisions. ``The film is not about, nor is it designed to document rioting blacks any more so than it is designed to malign drunken English reporters or greedy philandering white men,'' Politan wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Army Prosecutor Recommends Death Penalty for Rebel Leaders
DOC.TEXT: An army prosecutor recommended to the nation's highest military court on Tuesday that five leaders of the Dec. 3 rebellion be shot by firing squad. The recommendation by Carlos Dominguez, a retired general, applies to retired Col. Mohamed Ali Seineldin, Col. Luis Baraldini, retired Lt. Col. Osvaldo Tevere, Maj. Pedro Mercado and retired Maj. Hugo Abete. Ten other officers ranging from captain to colonel would be cashiered and sentenced to prison terms of three to 22 years. The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, which operates under the Military Code of Justice, has been taking testimony from loyal and rebel officers for two weeks. It is expected to issue a ruling by year's end. President Carlos Menem and army chief Gen. Martin Bonnet have endorsed the death penalty for rebel leaders. They claim the rebels intended to assassinate them both and topple the government in the fourth such insurrection in less than four years. However, the rebels have the right to appeal the council's verdict in civilian court, where the most severe punishment is life imprisonment. Seineldin, a former commando who led an uprising in December 1988, accepted responsibility for the latest revolt even though he was locked in a military prison 1,000 west of Buenos Aires. Baraldini led the takeover of the joint chiefs-of-staff headquarters in downtown Buenos Aires, from which shots were fired that hit Vice President Eduardo Duhalde's helicopter as it landed atop Government House 150 yards away. Until two weeks ago, Baraldini was chief of the Buenos Aires Military District. Abete and Tevere led the takeover of the Palermo infantry base 8 miles north of downtown. The base's second-in-command, Lt. Col. Hernan Pita, and a private, were shot and killed. That helped propel the government to fight the rebels rather than negotiate a settlement, which it did in the three previous insurrections that have occurred since April 1987. Thirteen soldiers and civilians died during the one-day insurrection.

DOC.HEAD: Court Strikes Down State Rule On AIDS Test
DOC.TEXT: The state's highest court Tuesday struck down a state rule forbidding health insurane companies from considering HIV test results when deciding on applications. The Court of Appeals unanimously affirmed, without comment, lower court decisions against the state Insurance Department regulation. The policy banned insurance companies from considering the results of HIV blood tests in deciding insurability for small group and individual plans. A person testing positive for the human immunodeficiency virus is considered likely to develop symptoms of AIDS. The department argued there were questions about the reliability of HIV tests. Testing positive for the HIV virus also doesn't mean a person is sick with AIDS and should be denied insurance, the department said. ``We're disappointed in the decision,'' said Kevin Foley, spokesman for the Insurance Department. ``We obviously saw it in a different way. We're going to review our policies and continue to look for ways to make sure the health insurance system is as inclusive as possible.'' A lawyer for the Health Insurance Association of America, which challenged the rule, said he believed the decision was fair to the group's clients and customers. The lawyer, Chris Petersen, said the Legislatere should decide such policy questions. ``If they're going to talk in terms of social policy, it's more important to go through the legislative process,'' Petersen said. The department adopted the new rule in 1987, but it was challenged by the insurance industry before it could ever take effect. While the rule has been tied up in litigation, insurance companies have been allowed to take HIV test results into account when making decisions, Foley said. Since test results aren't taken into account in large group insurance policies and people who already have insurance who develop AIDS symptoms remain covered, Petersen said the rule was likely to affect a relatively small number of people. New York state, with 33,674 reported AIDS cases since the epidemic started through the end of October, has more AIDS patients than any other state in the country, the state Health Department said.

DOC.HEAD: Fishing Boat Sinkings Kill 11 off Canada
DOC.TEXT: Rescuers hauled bodies from the icy North Atlantic and brought back five survivors suffering from hypothermia Tuesday after two fishing boats sank about 500 miles apart off eastern Canada. The sinkings left 11 people dead or presumed dead. The survivors owed their lives to enclosed life rafts or in one case, a survival suit. Eight people were dead or believed dead from the Nadine, a 100-foot dragger out of Cap-aux-Meules, chief port of Quebec's Iles-de-la-Madeleine. The vessel took in water and sank in the Gulf of St. Lawrence about 18 miles south of its home port Monday morning. The captain, Robert Poirier, and his brother survived and were being treated for subnormal body temperatures after spending eight hours in the water, said Iranae Bernard, fleet manager for the company that owned the dragger. The skipper was plucked from a life raft and his brother was found floating in open water in a survival suit - an insulated rubber outfit that encloses the body from head to toe, except from the eyes to the chin. In the second sinking, the 60-foot-long Strait's Pride from O'Donnell's, Newfoundland, went down at 3:30 p.m. Monday, roughly 30 miles northeast of St. John's, Newfoundland. Three crew survived by launching an inflatable life raft and zipping themselves in. Three didn't make the life raft and perished in the open sea. Planes and ships searched for survivors and bodies. Four bodies from the Nadine were recovered and four people aboard were missing and believed dead, including Estelle Laberge, 40, a federal fisheries observer. Bernard said some Nadine dead were wearing survival suits but may not have been experienced enough to ensure they were properly sealed against the cold. ``There's no further sightings and we're really not expecting to find anybody alive at this time,'' said Capt. Pat Phelan of the rescue co-ordination center in Halifax. The Strait's Pride's life raft was spotted by a rescue plane, then picked up by a coast guard ship shortly after Monday midnight. The raft was tossed by 15-foot waves and 55 mph winds for about nine hours. The bodies of the three other crew were found just before noon Tuesday, their life jackets still on.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in the West; Rain in the East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Storms dumped ...' to UPDATE with up to 3.5 inches of rain in West Virginia.
DOC.TEXT: An Arctic cold front Tuesday brought winter to much of the West and Northwest with heavy snow and strong winds that created numbing windchills to 50 degrees below zero. A blizzard raged in northwestern Montana and an avalanche bulletin was issued in southern Montana. Temperatures in northern Washington state plummeted and snow began to fall as the arctic weather front plunged into the state with winds up to 75 mph. Winter storm watches through Wednesday were posted from northern Arizona up through Nevada, the northern half of Utah, western Oregon, and the interior of northwest Washington state. Storms dumped up to 3.5 inches of rain in West Virginia, flooding roads and shutting schools. In Kentucky, flooding forced the evacuation at least 20 homes in low-lying areas of Hopkinsville near the Little River as steady rain fell on already soggy ground, sending many other streams over their banks across Kentucky. In Lynnville, Ky., a man was killed and two others were injured when a bridge collapsed into a creek swollen by rain. At midday rainshowers were scattered over Mississippi, northern Alabama, Georgia and northwest Florida. Rain fell over much of New England, New York state, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Ohio, Tennessee, Kentucky, southern Indiana, southern Illinois and western lower Michigan. Rain also extended along the northern half of the Pacific Coast. Snow extended from east central Illinois across the remainder of Indiana, northwest Minnesota, North Dakota, Montana, Idaho, western Wyoming, northwest Colorado, northeast Oregon, southwest Washington and the Washington Cascades. Heavier rainfall totals included 2.32 inches at Jackson, Ky., and 1.27 inches Nashville, Tenn. Snowfall totals included 6 inches at Helena, Mont., 3 inches at Glasgow and Kalispell, Mont., and 2 inches at Great Falls, Mont. High temperature records were set in Bristol, Tenn., 73, Huntsville, Ala., 73, Roanoke, Va., 68, and Cape Hatteras, N.C., tied 72. Tuesday morning's low for the Lower 48 states was 17 below zero at Alamosa, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 6 below zero at Great Falls, Mont. to 86 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Two Detained in Connection With Deaths During Religious Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Police detained two people in connection with the deaths of 12 worshipers who suffered carbon monoxide poisoning during a religious ceremony, authorities said Tuesday. The two, including a daughter of one of the victims, may be charged with abandonment, said Jose Nunez de Carceres, the Tijuana state judicial police chief. The pair found the victims Thursday in a shantytown home where the group had been participating in a religious rite, but they failed to notify authorities, Nunez said. ``Instead of calling the authorities when they found the people lying on the floor they went to look for a medium to see if she could revive them,'' Nunez said. ``But when they returned the police were there.'' The pair were held at a Tijuana jail. Nunez said the case would be turned over to the district attorney's office, which will determine whether charges will be filed. Meanwhile, San Diego FBI agents were unable to confirm reports that the state government of Baja California has asked for assistance in identifying and locating two U.S. citizens who reportedly participated in the ceremony. ``That is possible but we haven't received any formal request,'' Special Agent Bob Harmon said Tuesday. Baja California police released a report Monday confirming that the 12 victims had died of carbon monoxide poisoning. Authorities also said tissue and blood tests indicated that the victims had not consumed alcohol or another toxic substance as first suspected. Those findings should end speculation that they were poisoned deliberately through food or a fruit punch served at the ceremony, said Jaime Sam Fierro, the state judicial police commander in Tijuana. ``There is no evidence that the food or punch was contaminated,'' Fierro said. More tests will be conducted on organ tissue samples of the three female victims. Those results are not expected to indicate another cause of death, Pallares said. Doctors at the Tijuana hospital where five survivors were taken have said that the patients' symptoms indicated they had ingested some type of poison. The all-night ceremony - which began Wednesday on the feast day of the Virgin of Guadalupe, the patroness of Mexico - was led by Federico Padres Mexia, a self-styled spiritual leader. Padres, 61, had conducted similar sessions for about the past month at his house in a shantytown east of Tijuana. Authorities say the carbon monoxide that asphyxiated the victims was emitted by a leaky butane gas lamp used to light the unventilated residence. Homes in the neighborhood don't have electricity, forcing residents to rely on gas tanks inside their homes for heating and light. Three survivors, including Padres, were still in a coma and listed in grave condition Tuesday. Two other survivors, Alfredo Osuna Hernandez, 22, and his 8-month-old daughter, Ana Karina, were discharged Monday and returned to their family home in Culiacan, Sinaloa.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Issues Decree Legalizing Non-Communist Parties
DOC.TEXT: A leader of Albania's first non-Communist party predicted Tuesday it may soon be granted official recognition. Gramoz Pashko said three Democratic Party representatives met with Justice Minister Enver Halili after a parliamentary commission headed by President Ramiz Alia approved a decree legalizing politicalparties. Halili said the new party's application for registration would ``probably be approved soon,'' Pashko said by telephone from Tirana, the Albanian capital. He said he expected the government to help his party get started by providing a headquarters, telephones and other communications equipment. By law, the government must act on the application within 30 days. After four days of student protests, leaders of Europe's last Stalinist nation decided last week to break with 45 years of one-party rule and allow formation of non-Communist political organizations. The Democratic Party was created Wednesday. The Democratic Party of Albania estimates it is supported by about 20,000 Albanians. The Communist Party claims more than 120,000 members among the Balkan nation's 3.2 million residents. On Thursday and Friday, thousands of anti-government protesters rioted in four cities. More than 150 people were reported arrested, but there was no word Tuesday on when their trials would begin. Pashko said that under the new decree all parties can apply for registration, provided their platforms are not fascist or racist. Their membership must be limited to Albanians living permanently in the country and the parties may not receive funding from abroad. Another Democratic Party member, Rama Shinasi, said by telephone that more than 1,000 students rallied in Tirana on Monday to urge the party's swift legalization and the release of political prisoners. They petitioned Alia to disband local Communist Party committees, remove a statue of Stalin from Tirana and agree to talks with opposition leaders and intellectuals, Shinasi said. In other developments, 28 Albanians used improvised rafts to cross the Bojana River and enter Yugoslavia early Tuesday, the official Yugoslavian news agency Tanjug reported. More than 600 Albanians have crossed into Yugoslavia this year without government permission. The Communist daily Zeri i Popullit, meanwhile, reported police arrested two men who had a total of 30 sticks of dynamite and 25 grenades. One man was arrested in Tirana and the other was detained in Fier, 90 miles south of the capital, the paper said. It gave no further details. In Geneva, British and Albanian officials met Tuesday to discuss resuming diplomatic relations, said a British Foreign Office spokesman. Relations were severed in 1939 when Italy occupied Albania. Postwar attempts to restore relations were dashed when two British warships were sunk by mines near Corfu, Greece, off Albania. The International Court of Justice ruled that Albania should pay compensation of $1.6 million for the warships, but the Albanians refused. Britain has held some Albanian gold pending resolution of the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Refuse Food Aid from Iraq
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's offer to donate 550 tons of dates to the Soviet Union was rejected because Iraq also is incurring food shortages, Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Tuesday. Churkin told a news briefing the decision to turn down food aid from Iraq's Red Crescent was made by the Soviet Red Cross and Red Crescent organizations. ``Iraq itself is suffering from food shortages,'' he said. More than a dozen countries have offered to donate food to help feed the Soviets this winter or guarantee loans so the Soviet government can buy food. The Soviet Union was Iraq's close ally and major arms supplier until Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Moscow has since supported all U.N. Security Council resolutions and economic sanctions against Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Lawmakers Battle in Taiwan's Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Opposition lawmakers battled police and ripped out microphones during a rowdy session Tuesday of Taiwan's Parliament to demand amnesty for a dissident leader. Officials said one policeman was hospitalized with fractured ribs, but none of the legislators was injured. Members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who control 19 of Parliament's 244 seats, have often triggered fights to oppose bills proposed by the governing Nationalist Party, which has 199 seats. Tuesday's brawl broke out when Speaker Liang Su-yung of the Nationalists tried to end a filibuster by Democratic Progressive legislators by calling for a vote on government bills on the employment and salaries for civil servants. Opposition members shouted protests and legislator Wei Yao-chien rushed to the podium and tore out microphones. Liang called in about 100 police, but other Democratic Progressive legislators joined the fray. Some butted heads against policemen's chests trying to get to the podium and legislator Peng Pai-hsien fought a policeman. Order was restored after more than an hour and the bills were passed. The government wanted passage now so civil servants can get annual bonuses. The Democratic Progressives are trying to force the government to grant amnesty to opposition leader Huang Hwa, 51, sentenced to 10 years' imprisonment this month for advocating Taiwan's independence from China. Both the Nationalists and China's Communist government oppose an independent Taiwan, which they regard as a Chinese province. The Nationalists, who lost a civil war in China in 1949, continue to claim they are the legitimate government of all China.

DOC.HEAD: Public Television News Magazine Renewed After Protests
DOC.TEXT: Public television station KCET on Tuesday renewed ``South Africa Now,'' a news magazine whose recent cancellation generated protests. The renewal announcement came one day after a conservative media watchdog group, which had claimed credit for the show's cancellation, asked the Federal Communications Commission to yank KCET's license. The Committee on Media Integrity filed a petition Monday with the FCC requesting that KCET's license not be renewed and that a KCET request for a new transmitter also be denied. William Kobin, KCET president and chief executive officer, called the group's demands preposterous. David Horowitz, a spokesman for the conservative group, said the petition would be withdrawn if the Public Broadcasting System station establishes an elected board of directors and hires an ombudsman. Kobin said the group's requests were part of a longstanding effort to control the station's programming. ``These charges and demands are preposterous, and are clearly an attempt to use the processes of the FCC to further their private interests, certainly not those of the general public,'' Kobin said in a prepared statement. ``South Africa Now'' was originally canceled in October after KCET judged it did not meet journalistic standards for objectivity. The news show, presented from a black perspective, was temporarily renewed for six episodes. Tuesday's statement announcing the show's longterm renewal said the station would continue to air the show in its 9 a.m. Sunday time slot, but with a disclaimer identifying it as a ``point of view'' series, the station said.

DOC.HEAD: Pushing and Shoving, South Korean Parliament Adjourns
DOC.TEXT: Parliament adjourned in an uproar shortly before midnight Tuesday, with opposition lawmakers shouting and pushing in vain to stop passage of a rice bill. The bill calls for reducting the amount of rice purchased by the government. The measure passed easily with votes from the governing Democratic Liberal Party, which controls the 299-member National Assembly. Opposition lawmakers accused the government party of railroading the bill. Shouting deputies from the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy rushed toward the podium as House Speaker Park Jyun-kyu read the bill. They tried to push and shove governing party members out of the way. One opposition lawmaker slapped a parliamentary staff member, news accounts said. Another grabbed the hair of a governing party deputy, newspapers said. The bill provides for a 29 percent cut in the amount of government- purchased rice. Many opposition legislators represent rural areas and say farmers cannot make a living with rising costs.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Will Not Help Prosecutors Bring Cheyenne Brando Back from Tahiti
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday refused to summon Marlon Brando's daughter from Tahiti to testify in the trial of her brother, who is charged in the slaying of her former fiance. U.S. District Judge Terry Hatter said he didn't have the authority to issue an international subpoena, which could help prosecutors force Cheyenne Brando to return to Los Angeles. Hatter said he would be ``creating new law'' with such an action and could not do anything until Superior Court Judge Joel Rudof asks Tahitian authorities to assist prosecutors. Rudof had not yet decided whether to seek Tahiti's help. He was expected to make that decision Friday. Prosecutors say Miss Brando is a key witness in the case against her half-brother, Christian, 32, who is accused of shooting her Tahitian boyfriend, Dag Drollet, 26. Miss Brando, 20, was seven months pregnant with Drollet's child when Drollet was killed in Marlon Brando's mansion May 16. A month later, she left for Tahiti, where she gave birth to a son. Miss Brando, who reportedly made two suicide attempts in November, was hospitalized for emotional distress and has since been placed under her mother's care. Prosecutors wanted to know if French Polynesian authorities would allow Cheyenne to travel to the United States before the Jan. 14 trial date. She is being held as an accessory in the death of Drollet, a French citizen. ``To be quite honest, we're almost out of time in this case,'' said Deputy District Attorney Steve Barshop. Miss Brando's attorney protested the request. ``She is a mentally ill person, she cannot proceed and yet the district attorney has insisted on hounding her,'' said the lawyer, Michael Nasatir. Deputy District Attorney William Clark said Miss Brando has indicated she would testify if she could. ``She is a victim in this case,'' Clark said. ``She lost her lover, she lost the father of her child.'' A month after Drollet's death, Miss Brando told police she believed the killing was premeditated. Christian Brando claimed it was an accident. Miss Brando has given police several versions of events regarding the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Student Charged with Manslaughter in Death of Newborn
DOC.TEXT: A college student who gave birth in a dormitory bathroom was charged with manslaughter for allegedly suffocating the newborn by stuffing toilet paper down his throat, police said. Stephanie Wernick, 20, of West Orange, N.J., was arraigned Tuesday at her bedside at Nassau County Medical Center. Police said Wernick gave birth to a boy Monday in the bathroom on the campus of C.W. Post College. Detective Sgt. Robert Edwards said Wernick concealed her pregnancy from family and friends. The baby was placed in a plastic bag and dropped in a trash can down the hall from Wernick's dormitory room after toilet paper was stuffed down his throat, Edwards said. Police said Wernick returned to her room and passed out from loss of blood. The 4-pound 12-ounce infant, born about one month premature, was found by a janitor as he emptied garbage cans. Several girls in the dorm led detectives to Wernick after telling police of her suspected pregnancy. She was found asleep in her room and taken by ambulance to the hospital, where she was listed in satisfactory condition. Wernick was arraigned on a charge of first degree manslaughter, but no plea was entered.
