Her attorney, Stephen Scaring, said her family intends to post her $5,000 bail when she is released from the medical center. ``It appears that there was no intentional criminal activity,'' Scaring said. ``It's unfortunate the case has received so much attention in the press.''

DOC.HEAD: French Party Assesses Communism's Woes
DOC.TEXT: The leader of one of the West's largest communist groups Tuesday proposed an international conference to help redefine communism and overcome its troubles since the collapse of East Bloc regimes. Georges Marchais opened the five-day French Communists' national congress by proposing a talks between ``revolutionary parties'' to help give communism a ``a second wind.'' But he also promised support to the Soviet Union as it struggles with Western-style reforms. Marchais ruled out any resumption of cooperation with the governing Socialists, saying President Francois Mitterrand has forsaken the left and implemeneted ``the policies sought by big money, the policies of the right.'' Marchais, in a nearly four-hour speech to more than 1,700 delegates, said his party had been a longstanding advocate of reform in Eastern Europe, but had underestimated the extent of the crisis faced by the toppled Communist regimes there. ``With us, there was shortcoming of analysis and understanding,'' he said. The French Communist Party claims 600,000 members and holds 26 of 577 seats in the National Assembly. Communists control municipal councils in 1,097 communities, including dozens of working-class suburbs around major cities, but their support in recent national elections has dropped below 10 percent. The party congresses, held every three years, are the highest-level forum for choosing leadership and setting policy. This one marks the 70th anniversary of the party's founding and was the first since the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe. The French Communists envisioned a society ``completely different from the socialist societies that exist now or used to exist,'' he said. Referring to the Soviet Union, Marchais said the situation there is ``far from attractive.'' He also criticized the Soviets' decision to authorize use of force against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis, saying this move ``deeply disappointed the people of France.'' ``This war cannot be our war,'' he said. Marchais, however, expressed empathy for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform initiatives. Marchais defended his party's decision to invite a Chinese delegation to the congress, but reiterated his denunciation of ``the murderous repression'' against pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing last year. Marchais is heavily favored to win re-election as party leader.

DOC.HEAD: 19 Protesters Arrested Trying to Reach Nancy Cruzan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 14th graf, `If you're ...' to UPDATE with court rejecting a petition filed by two protesters. Pick up 15th graf, `Don Lamkins ...'
DOC.TEXT: Nineteen protesters were arrested Tuesday after trying to reach the hospital room of Nancy Cruzan, who was disconnected from her feeding tube last week in a landmark right-to-die case. The protesters clutched rosaries and Bibles as they were pushed from the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in wheelchairs and taken to jail on charges of trespassing and unlawful assembly. The 19 people arrested were among about 25 protesters who showed up at the hospital Tuesday morning. At least 11 made it to the second floor. They were stopped by a small army of police officers from getting to Ms. Cruzan's private room. They knelt and prayed in the hallway before being dragged off the floor. Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1983 car accident. A judge granted her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan, permission Friday to disconnect her feeding tube. Doctors predict she will die in six days to two weeks. Ms. Cruzan was the subject of the U.S. Supreme Court's first right-to-die decision in June when the court blocked her parents from halting food and water in the absence of ``clear and convincing'' evidence she would want to die. The parents later presented to a state court testimony from co-workers who recalled Ms. Cruzan saying she would never want to live ``like a vegetable.'' The Rev. Ted Coleman, hospital chaplain, said the Cruzans were with their daughter when some protesters reached the second floor. ``They said they were aware. They said, `We're private people. We just want to be left alone,' '' Coleman said. The Rev. Joseph Foreman of Montreat, N.C., director of Prisoners of Christ, which he described as a pro-life group, was among the protesters arrested. If he could meet the Cruzans, Foreman said, ``I would plead with them that for whatever reason they won't feed their daughter, there are many, many people who are volunteering to care for her. Be merciful and let them do it.'' ``She's going to be dead soon if someone doesn't intervene,'' Foreman said. ``Citizens have got to stop standing by silently and letting people die.'' One of the protesters carried a cup of water he said he wanted to take to Ms. Cruzan. ``If you're going to kill her, just put a pillow over her head,'' said the protester, who identified himself as Gary Tebbets of Kansas City. A state appeals court rejected without comment a petition from Tebbets and Gary Rickman that Ms. Cruzan's food and water immediately be restored. Don Lamkins, the hospital director, initially said the protesters could stay in the first-floor chapel and in the stairwell. But he later decided to have them arrested after talking with police. ``They were blocking the fire exit and essentially the hallway,'' Lamkins said. ``They wouldn't talk to us. They wouldn't move. And they indicated they were staying because they wanted to be arrested.'' The protesters were held on a standard $500 bond on each count. Lt. Ken Perkins, the chief jailer for Lawrence County, said the protesters were fasting and all claiming to be Nancy Cruzan, refusing to give their real names. ``They can't make bail until we get their names. They are all Nancy Cruzans right now,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Says Captain of Dredge Was Negligent
DOC.TEXT: The captain of the barge that broke loose from its moorings and slammed into a bridge in October may have been negligent because he failed to drop a second anchor, the U.S. Coast Guard said Tuesday. The barge knocked out a 370-foot section of the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, the only link between Hatteras Island and the mainland, on Oct. 26, stranding thousands of residents and tourists. State transportation officials say the bridge will be out at least until the end of January. A ferry now shuttles people and cars from the island to Wanchese, on the mainland, but service is intermittent. The Coast Guard said unexpected rough weather drove the barge, a dredge called Northerly Island, from its moorings and was the cause of the accident. But the barge captain apparently contributed to the accident because he failed to use the dredge's second anchor after the vessel became grounded about 250 feet from the bridge, the Coast Guard said in a statement from its office in Portsmouth, Va. In its report, the Coast Guard said the barge's captain, William Cliett, chose to try to free the vessel rather than secure it with a second anchor. ``Under the circumstances, it would have been prudent to use all means available and a second anchor may have added sufficient holding power to prevent the (accident). The master's failure to use the second anchor constitutes evidence of negligence on his part,'' the Coast Guard statement said. Cliett, who lives in Savannah, Ga., has an unlisted telephone number and could not be reached for comment Tuesday night. He told investigators previously that he didn't think a second anchor would have prevented the dredge from drifting toward the bridge.

DOC.HEAD: Carnation to Defy Baby Doctors, Advertise Infant Formula Direct to Moms
DOC.TEXT: Carnation Co. will begin advertising Good Start baby formula directly to mothers next month, joining Gerber Products in a strategy opposed by the American Academy of Pediatricians. The academy and other health organizations maintain such ads may discourage mothers from breast-feeding. They support only ads directed at doctors, who in turn recommend products to nursing mothers. ``We have certainly opposed (consumer ads) with the Gerber formula and would oppose it with the Carnation formula,'' said Denver pediatrician James E. Strain, the academy's executive director. Carnation President Timm Crull said the move is necessary to compete with the giants of the infant formula industry, Abbott Laboratories' Similac and Bristol-Myers Squibb's Enfamil, which dominate the $1.5 billion yearly business. In November 1988, Carnation introduced its Good Start formula for younger infants and Good Nature, for infants who have begun to eat solid foods. Crull said the pediatric academy guidelines banning consumer advertising benefit the Abbott-Bristol-Myers ``oligarchy'' at the expense of new competitors. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating possible unfair competitive practices by the infant food industry, including a review of the voluntary ban on consumer ads. Carnation is a Glendale-based unit of the Swiss foods giant Nestle, which was the object of a worldwide boycott over formula marketing practices in Third World countries.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Signs Potty Parity Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Robert P. Casey on Tuesday signed the ``potty parity'' bill to help cut long lines women endure when using public restrooms. New public buildings and those undergoing extensive renovation will have to include sufficient restrooms for women. The law applies to buildings leased or owned by the state and certain other public facilities. The law, which takes effect in four months, leaves it to the Department of Labor and Industry to determine how many more toilets are required for women than for men. The law doesn't apply to hotels and restaurants. Supporters said the shortage of restrooms for women force them to stand in long lines at concerts, sporting events and other recreational activities. Rep. Ruth Rudy, D-Centre, a sponsor of the bill, said it was a step forward for women. ``I'm very pleased that we finally achieved something for women in the commonwealth,'' she said. ``I'm hoping that it will lead to fewer lines at women's restrooms, even though it's going to be a long, drawn-out process.'' The law requires the added women's toilets in renovations of 50 percent or more of a building, but Ms. Rudy said she hoped owners of buildings undergoing less extensive renovation will add more women's restrooms anyway.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Students Protest Education Rules
DOC.TEXT: More than 50,000 students marched through the capital on Tuesday demanding that the education minister resign and asking repeal of new rules that include punishment for classroom absences and sloppy dressing. Riot squads used tear gas to disperse about 200 people who set fires and attacked officers outside Athens Polytechnic University. A police spokesman said no one was hurt or arrested and that no students were involved in the clashes. He spoke on condition of anonymity. High school students complain that new education regulations are vague about discipline, fail to outline teaching methods and do not explain the grading system. They are want the government to spend more money on education. University students oppose a proposal to allow private universities, now banned by the constitution. Education Minister Vasillis Kontoyannopoulos said Monday the rules will not be enforced, but the students still want the legislation scrapped. Teen-agers have taken over more than 2,000 high schools. Several students who stormed the Education Ministry building last week were injured when police fired tear gas into a crowd.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Killer Wins Stay Just Hours Before Scheduled Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with stay granted. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Danny Ray Harris won a stay late Tuesday just hours before his scheduled execution for the slaying 12 years ago of a man who stopped to help him and his brother when their car broke down. Harris faced lethal injection for the killing of Timothy Michael Berka, a Texas A&M University employee who was fatally beaten with a tire iron in what became known as the ``Samaritan'' slaying. Harris received a stay from the 5th Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans. Earlier in the day, a state appeals court and a federal judge rejected requests to delay his execution. Assistant Texas Attorney General Bob Walt had said the state would not oppose requests for a stay. Testimony showed Danny Harris, 30, devised the plan to kill Merka so the brothers and their companions could steal Merka's pickup truck. Witnesses said he held down Merka while his brother beat him with a tire iron. Harris' brother, Curtis Paul Harris, also was sentenced to death. One of their companions, James Manuel, received a 25-year prison term. The other, Valarie Rencher, testified against the Harris brothers and received no prison time. No date has been set for Curtis Harris' execution. The federal appeals court issued the stay at 9:45 p.m. Danny Harris had faced lethal injection shortly after midnight. He said in a recent interview that his death would not make up for Merka's death and would not achieve justice. ``What justice is there in that?'' Harris said, speaking about his execution. ``Is it taking one life for another life?'' Harris would be the fifth Texas inmate put to death this year and the 38th since the state resumed capital punishment in 1982. The total is the highest in the nation among states with the death penalty. It would be the 144th execution in the United States since the 1976 U.S. Supreme Court ruling allowing states to resume use of the death penalty.

WASHINGTON - President Bush says a mandate for using military force against Iraq must be fulfilled ``right on schedule'' unless Saddam Hussein meets a Jan. 15 deadline to withdraw all his troops from Kuwait. Bush said the Iraqi leader apparently doubts that the United States will use force, and believes instead that this country is too divided to stand behind military action. ``And he's just as wrong as he can be,'' the president told reporters Monday. Bush went out of his way to intensify pressure on Saddam to back down in the face of a massive - and still growing - military force aligned against him in the Persian Gulf. ---= WASHINGTON - Today's ``volunteer'' Army is looking for more than volunteers. For the first time in nearly three decades, the Army is searching out military retirees - especially those with medical skills - and forcing them back into uniform. As the buildup of U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf surges toward the 400,000 level and the United Nations deadline nears for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, the Army is digging deep into its personnel records for help in supporting the force. Lt. Col. Henry H. Hanrahan, an Army planner, said Monday that an initial callup of 15 retired physician assistants was approved last week, and about 200 other retirees probably would be involuntarily recalled for active duty over the next month. ---= SAN FRANCISCO - The nation's toughest law protecting users of video display terminals was sent to Mayor Art Agnos after winning approval from city supervisors, who called it cutting-edge legislation for a high-tech age. Union leaders and victims of VDT-related injuries cheered when the ordinance was approved 7-4 Monday. The Board of Supervisors approved it 8-1 in a preliminary vote last week. ``I'm ecstatic,'' said Becky Hogue, a Pacific Bell operator who wears plastic splints on her wrists because of weakness from years of using computer keyboards. ``I suffered so much, but now maybe others won't have to go through the same pain.'' The Chamber of Commerce opposed the measure, saying its high costs would drive businesses away. The mayor has not said whether he will accept it. He supports the spirit of the measure, he says, but has misgivings about its cost. ---= KNOXVILLE, Tenn. - Lamar Alexander, a former governor and president of the University of Tennessee, may well be the man who can make George Bush the education president, say those who know him. Even detractors of his reform programs credit Alexander with generating interest in improving public schools and higher education in Tennessee, where as many as one in five adults is functionally illiterate. Bush on Monday nominated Alexander, a 50-year-old lawyer and son of teachers, as education secretary. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Lauro Cavazos, who was forced to resign last week. ``No governor in the country is so clearly identified with the imperative to improve education in America,'' the president said. He said the former two-term governor was ``at the forefront of the movement to restructure our nation's schools.'' ---= JERUSALEM - For nearly three years, the Palestinian uprising consisted mainly of street battles in the occupied territories, a war of stones far removed from most Israelis' daily lives. But a series of fatal stabbings on the streets of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem has brought the Arab revolt closer to home. Growing fear among Israelis has prompted calls for harsh punishment of Arabs who attack Jews. It also has renewed debate over whether Israel should continue to occupy the West Bank and Gaza Strip, home to 1.7 million Palestinians. The independent Israeli newspaper Yedioth Ahronoth called this week for a solution ``based on physical separation between us and the Palestinians.'' ---= VIENNA, Austria - Stalinist Albania seems to have taken a giant step by permitting its first non-Communist party, but many emigres and others are skeptical the change is genuine or sufficient to contain popular anger. Caught between a reluctance to relinquish a 46-year monopoly on power and a desire to avoid mass violence, the Communist leadership has sent a series of contradictory signals in the past week. President Ramiz Alia, who a month ago denied any need for competing political parties, has now pledged that reform is irreversible. Yet his government has to date kept all but a handful of foreign journalists from reporting independently on the historic events in his land. It has also so far failed to accord the new Democratic Party of Albania legality. ---= NEW DELHI, India - Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar suggests that hidden hands are manipulating the frenzied religious riots ravaging India and has threatened to use a heavy dose of force to end the fighting. ``Any amount of force that is needed will be used in order to stop this situation,'' he said Monday in an interview with The Associated Press at the official residence. ``There's no limit.'' At least 300 people have been killed in fighting between the Hindu majority and Moslems in the past 10 days. Another 300 people died in rioting in October and November. The ferocity of the violence has little parallel since the slaughters that accompanied the 1947 division of the British-ruled subcontinent into predominantly Hindu India and mostly Islamic Pakistan.

DOC.NOTE: For release Weds PMs, Dec 19, and thereafter
DOC.BYLINE: `It's A Wonderful Life' - Beloved American Film or Holiday Hell? ^By SCOTT WILLIAMS
DOC.TEXT: It started sometime last week, America; the first few salvos of the television onslaught that has become a yuletide ritual: the annual ``It's a Wonderful Life'' marathon. There's no way to count how many times director Frank Capra's 1946 classic will reach television sets this holiday season, whether by terrestrial broadcast, satellite, coaxial cable, videocassette or laserdisc. It's 129 minutes of classic Americana: Boy finds savings and loan; boy loses savings and loan; taxpayers bail out boy, saving the savings and loan. Why do we like it so much? How could we NOT like it? We're Americans! As in previous years, the Fear, Greed & Power Incarnate cable system plans to air the movie continuously from 6 p.m. tonight to midnight Dec. 25. ``Naturally, we expect some viewer burnout,'' said one FG&PI publicist, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But, hey, we're giving them what they want. And want. And want.'' FG&PI will air the original black and white version, the colorized version where Donna Reed's graduation party dress is yellow, and the OTHER colorized version where the dress is blue. Then they'll show the descriptive narrative version for the vision impaired. (``George looks down into the torrent, a world-weary pain settles across his face. Above him, Clarence jumps. George dives in after him.'') And, in a final mind-boggler, FG&PI will air the aberrant 1977 made-for-TV remake, ``It Happened One Christmas,'' starring Marlo Thomas as a kind of ``Georgina Bailey,'' co-starring Cloris Leachman and Wayne Rogers. Other, less-imaginary cable operators are reducing their exposure of ``It's a Wonderful Life'' this season, possibly fearing just the ``viewer burnout'' that four viewings in as many days can induce. So why do we like this film so much? ``It's a Wonderful Life'' is the dark, haunting story of a decent man named George Bailey, who dreams of building skyscrapers and mile-long bridges once he flees his hometown, Bedford Falls, N.Y., where his father runs the local S&L. Then Life happens: His father's death forces George to shelve his dreams and run the S&L; he marries; settles down and scrapes along, his dreams getting dustier, until he is financially ruined by a drastic reverse on Christmas Eve. Then, in a frightening outburst of neurotic rage, he curses his life, wishes he were never born and stands on a bridge at a river, contemplating suicide. Enter the angel, Clarence, sent from above to thwart his suicide. He grants George his wish: A nightmare vision of Bedford Falls transformed into a sleazy nighttown of alienated hard cases who don't even recognize George Bailey. George, sweaty, panicked, eyes rolling like a crazed horse's, finally understands the influence that one good man has on the world. He begs to be restored to his life and his family and, miraculously, he is. All ends well. Yes, but why do we like it so much? ``Capra-corn'' was what the director's sneering contemporaries called his movies' wholehearted embrace of American values: home, church, community. This is the '90s, man! The movie opened Dec. 20, 1946, was nominated for five Academy Awards and, against ``The Best Years of Our Lives,'' won none. It broke even at the box office - some said the suicide was off-putting - and lapsed into obscurity. So why do we like it today? ``We like it because it's free,'' said one television executive, speaking on condition that he be fictional. In 1974, you see, someone forgot to renew the film's copyright. It went into the public domain. That meant that any station, anywhere, could air the film as many times as it cared to, without paying a thin dime. They did. That's why the TV stations showed it to us all these years. That it happens to be good cinema is just our luck. Awful ``colorized'' versions of the film can be copyrighted, but the classic black and white is still anybody's game. Yes, but what is there about this film that would prompt, say, an exotic dancer to take the stage name Zuzu Petals? ``It's a Wonderful Life'' is probably one of James Stewart's greatest films. It is a comedy masking as a drama - or perhaps the reverse. It is full of magic, angelic behavior and good feelings. And, worse, it's a unabashedly sentimental treatment of many aspects of love. It celebrates the love of family, of wife and husband, of parent and child, the love of country, love of community. It is exalts of basic virtues: that nice guys don't finish last and that life is, indeed, worth living. Take that away and, yes, it's just another movie. Get out your handkerchiefs and tune in FG&IP, now playing in your neighborhood. Zuzu Petals??? --- Elsewhere in television . . . PLATINUM? HOW ABOUT CHROME YELLOW? DEPT.: After only one week in release, the record album ``The Simpsons Sing the Blues'' went platinum, selling more than 1 million copies, publicists said. The record, featuring the cartoon voices of Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and (thwocka-thwocka) Maggie Simpson opened on the charts at No. 26 with a bullet. ``The Simpsons,'' their eponymous, animated hit sitcom can be seen Thursday nights on the Fox Broadcasting Co.
