DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said that banks must soon ump billions of dollars more into the fast-dwindling government fund guaranteeing customers' deposits. ``Action should be taken early next year,'' FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman told the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions. Figures included in his testimony indicate he believes banks should be required to pay a one-time assessment totaling $24 billion to $25 billion. Bankers reacted cautiously to the proposal. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Mortgage delinquencies rose sharply from July through September, the Mortgage Bankers Association reported in a survey that it said was further proof the economy is in a downturn. The association survey found the delinquency rate was 5.0 percent, up from 4.52 percent in the second quarter and 4.41 percent in the first. The rate in the third quarter of 1989 was 4.96 percent. The survey also found that foreclosures had risen slightly. The 0.33 percent rate compared with a 0.31 percent rate in the previous quarter. --- HONG KONG (AP) - The largest bank in Hong Kong announced it was transferring all assets offshore, a move that was likely to damage confidence in the British colony reverting to Chinese rule in 1997. Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. Chairman William Purves said the decision reflected the bank's global reach and did not signal abandonment of the territory where it has flourished for 125 years. Nonetheless, stock brokers and others with a feel for Hong Kong's financial pulse said the move would be interpreted as another sign of eroding confidence in the future of the teeming capitalist enclave on China's southern tip. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Trans World Airlines Inc. will get desperately needed cash by selling valued London routes to American Airlines, but the retrenchment will make TWA a smaller, weaker carrier facing an uncertain future, analysts said. TWA Chairman Carl C. Icahn said a day earlier he was selling six London routes for $445 million to American. Further agreements bring the total package to $625 million. Analysts said that in the short run the deal gives TWA needed cash. But in the long run, it could cause problems as one of the nation's weaker carriers surrenders its traditional strong suit. --- NEW YORK (AP) - NBC News and Nippon Television Network have agreed on a joint newsgathering venture, the third agreement this year between a U.S. network news division and a Japanese broadcaster. NBC News will have exclusive U.S. rights to all Japanese and international news material of NTV, Japan's largest private broadcast network, NBC said in the Monday announcement. In return, NTV, with which NBC has had a working relationship for almost 40 years, will get exclusive rights to news material from the NBC News Channel, the 24-hour affiliates' news service that NBC will start on New Year's Day. --- NEW YORK (AP) - RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. said it will offer cash and stock in exchange for more than $750 million in costly junk bonds as part of an expanded effort to lower the food-tobacco conglomerate's debt load. RJR Nabisco, taken private in a record $24.53 billion leveraged buyout last year, has been reducing its most expensive debt to try to avoid finance problems that have plagued other heavily indebted companies in recent months. The announcement on Monday follows the completion last month of a $6.9 billion recapitalization effort that included retirement of more than $4 billion in junk bonds and a $1.15 billion bridge loan. --- LONDON (AP) - Asil Nadir, chief executive of troubled Polly Peck International PLC, faced a third night in jail after failing to come up with $6.8 million in bail The 48-year-old Turkish-Cypriot businessman, who was arrested Saturday, faces 18 charges of theft and false accounting in connection with the affairs of his troubled fruit and electronics conglomerate. The company, which is $2.5 billion in debt, continues to operate under court protection from creditors. --- THE HAGUE, NETHERLANDS (AP) - Iran agreed to pay $9 million to a subsidiary of the American oil giant Arco, the last of hundreds of millions of dollars in so-called Consortium claims of Western oil companies against Teheran. The settlement on Monday was for expropriation of Arco's operations in Iran during the 1979 Islamic revolution that overthrew the regime of Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi. Total compensation to the 14 British, French and American oil companies in the Consortium has amounted to $320 million since 1982, according to figures broadcast over Teheran Radio, monitored in Nicosia. --- CHICAGO (AP) - Zenith Electronics Corp. and the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said they are jointly developing an all-digital high-definition television system as Zenith's entry in the HDTV sweepstakes. The system, touted on Monday as an improvement over a partially digital system previously announced by Zenith, keeps the manufacturer in the running for the coveted HDTV standard to be selected by the Federal Communications Commission. The standard will be the sole format used by cable, satellite and major commercial networks to provide Americans with the crystal-clear pictures and compact-disc-quality sound of HDTV. ---

Stock prices staged a quiet retreat Monday in the face of renewed Middle East worries. The Dow Jones industrial average closed with a loss of 0.49 points at 2,593.32. Bonds edged up. The dollar gained. Gold rose slightly. Oil rose, livestock futures advanced, pork bellies retreated, corn futures rose moderately and soybeans settled.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Cautiously Eye Deposit Insurance Plan
With PM-Bank Crisis, Bjt
Graphic of Dec. 17
DOC.TEXT: Some bankers say they're willing to chip in more to help rescue the government's ailing deposit insurance fund, but say they want substantial reforms in banking regulations. Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman William Seidman on Monday floated a proposal to boost the insurance fund by $24 billion. The proposal comes as industry officials and regulators ponder ideas to dramatically restructure the nation's banks, which have been beset by a stagnant economy, strong foreign competition, declining real estate values and rising loan defaults. In the past 3{ years, 734 banks with $102 billion in total assets have failed, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The failures have drained the government's deposit insurance fund from $18.3 billion in 1987 to an estimated $9 billion this year, the FDIC reported. The fund is used to repay up to $100,000 in individual deposits in the event of a bank failure. ``I think there's no question the fund needs to be replenished, that one way or another the industry is going to have to pay for it. That's been the history since it's been established,'' said John Rau, president and chief executive officer of LaSalle National Bank in Chicago. But bankers say if they're asked to help rescue the fund, they want federal banking laws reformed. They complain that current regulations hamper them from competing with securities firms and other large corporations that offer loans, credit cards and other such financial services. Richard A. Kirk, president of American Bankers Association, said any deposit insurance rescue must come with ``...modernization of the financial system if future problems are to be prevented.'' Kirk and others don't question the FDIC's grim predictions of the fund's solvency, but says the banking industry overall is healthy. The nation's 12,400 banks enjoyed a 13 percent increase in profits for the third quarter of 1990, he said. Seidman, in prepared testimony before the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions, fell short of endorsing the $24 billion plan. A similar strategy was used in 1984 when Congress voted to strengthen the credit union fund. Under the bill, credit unions were required to deposit 1 percent of insured shares into the fund, he said. Seidman also suggested annual deposit insurance premiums should be raised to 23 cents per $100 in deposits. He also discussed other options, such as requiring banks to buy preferred stock in the FDIC. He said the proposals would ``add only marginally to bank failures.'' That view was disputed, however, by three private economists - R. Dan Brumbaugh of San Francisco, Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution and James Barth of Auburn University - who presented a report to the House panel. Brumbaugh said a one percent assessment on deposits would cost banks the equivalent of two years of earnings. Litan said it would cause additional failures costing $3 billion to $8 billion. Seidman also raised the possibility that regulators may hold off shutting down weak banks that appear likely to recover, citing the success of such a policy toward struggling farm banks in the mid-1980s. Many bankers declined to comment on Seidman's statements until they had a chance to review the proposals in detail. ``Our reaction in general has always been that every participant in the financial services industry should be regulated by the same standards,'' said Fraser Seitel, spokesman for Chase Manhattan Corp. He, like others in the industry, endorses changes in banking regulations to provide a level playing field with non-financial corporations that provide some financial services. They object, for example, that AT&T can offer its Universal credit card without facing the same regulations as banks. Fritz Elmendorf, spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association in Arlington, Va., said most bankers are willing to pay more into the fund and avoid a taxpayer bailout along the lines of the savings and loan scandal. Failures of the nation's savings and loans are estimated to cost the nation's taxpayers billions of dollars. ``It's an argument on how much the industry can truly afford, and that's where it's unclear,'' said Elmendorf.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Raises Ante In HDTV Game, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. may have leapfrogged into the lead of the high-definition television race with a proposed all-digital system that offers better picture resolution than its competitors, analysts said. ``On paper, it still looks to me like the best of the proposals,'' James Magid, an analyst with Needham & Co. in New York, said of the project that Zenith and American Telephone & Telegraph Co. announced Monday. The HDTV system that Zenith is developing jointly with the AT&T would transmit 1,575 horizontal picture lines every one-thirtieth of a second compared with competing systems based on 1,125 or 1,050 lines. The pictures on today's TV sets are composed of 300 horizontal lines. The companies are competing with four other groups for the coveted HDTV standard to be selected by the Federal Communications Commission. The standard will be the sole format used by cable, satellite and major commercial networks to provide Americans with the crystal-clear pictures and compact-disc-quality sound of HDTV. Analysts said Zenith had to come up with an all-digital system to keep pace with two other contenders - General Instruments Corp. and a consortium of N.V. Philips of the Netherlands, Thomson of France, the NBC network and the David Sarnoff Research Center - which previously made all-digital proposals. The other contenders for the HDTV standard are the Japan Broadcasting Corp. and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Fully digital systems can transmit HDTV signals in the ones and zeros of computer language, making for clear reception even on the fringe of a broadcaster's range. Zenith previously had proposed a partially digital system. David Lauchenbruch, editorial director of Television Digest, an industry journal, said Zenith appears to have caught up with its competitors in the all-digital area and may have surpassed them in picture resolution. But he noted that the systems' relative merits won't really be known until the FCC tests them, one by one, beginning next April. ``These things, I think, exist mainly on computers,'' Lauchenbruch said. Zenith spokesman John Taylor said Zenith and AT&T already were working toward an all-digital or mostly digital system prior to the proposals made earlier this year by General Instruments and the Philips consortium. ``We did it to reap the benefits of digital technology, to provide interference-free and snow-free pictures,'' Taylor said. The test period for Zenith's system begins in late October, Taylor said. The FCC hopes to select a standard by June 1993. Backers of HDTV say it could revitalize segments of the U.S. electronics industry and - through military, educational and medical spinoffs - be the linchpin for U.S. economic growth in the next century. Zenith, the last major U.S.-based television manufacturer, is gambling heavily on its system being chosen as the HDTV standard. The company sold its computer division in 1989 and has committed $50 million to HDTV research, in which it is cooperating with AT&T and its Bell Labs subsidiary.

DOC.HEAD: American and United Want Heathrow
DOC.TEXT: American and United airlines are lined up to fly into London, but questions about whether they will be allowed to land at the city's choice airport, Heathrow, cast doubts on the carriers' plans. United agreed in October to buy most of Pan Am's London routes for $400 million. American said Sunday it would buy TWA's London routes and others overseas for $445 million. A treaty between Britain and the United States says only TWA, Pan Am and their ``corporate successors'' can fly trans-Atlantic routes from Heathrow, which is the closest airport to London and served by the city's subway system. Negotiators for the British and U.S. governments are scheduled to meet later this week in London to discuss whether that means United and American can gain entry to Heathrow. Since 1977, the British government has disallowed any new carriers at Heathrow, forcing them to Gatwick and other airports. Several British carriers also want slots at the airport and argue that American and United qualify as new carriers, rather than as two that are merely assuming existing routes. ``Whether they're right or wrong for doing it, (British carriers) will try to read more into this,'' Paul Karos, an airline analyst for First Boston, said Monday. Entry to Heathrow is key to both the United-Pan Am deal and the American-TWA deal. ``All we're suggesting is one airline be allowed to substitute or take the place of another, which does not seem unreasonable to us given the changing fortunes of companies in the world of business,'' said Robert Crandall, president of Fort Worth-based American. United chairman Stephen Wolf has also said the carrier's agreement with Pan Am would not proceed without access to Heathrow. Both airline executives think they will be allowed to fly to Heathrow. ``This matter is likely to be resolved at least in part on the longstanding goodwill between the United States and the United Kingdom and by ... the fact we're not really asking for anything except to substitute one carrier for another,'' Crandall said. American already flies to Gatwick from Miami andDallas-Fort Worth. Gatwick has fewer connections than Heathrow. If the deals are completed, United and American will both serve London from Los Angeles and two New York airports - Kennedy and Newark. American will also fly between London and Chicago, Boston, Philadelphia, St. Louis and Baltimore, while United will also fly between London and Washington, San Francisco and Seattle. American bought a Chicago-London route from TWA last December, but the deal has not been finalized pending the outcome of negotiations over Heathrow. It was United's purchase of Pan Am's routes that got American dealing with TWA, Crandall said. ``When the United-Pan American deal was announced, that raised our awareness and that raised TWA's awareness,'' he said. American plans to help finance its purchase by issuing new common stock during the first three months of 1991, Crandall said. He did not say how large the stock offering would be but expected preliminary registration papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission late this week. American's deal with TWA also gives it an option for TWA's unused overseas routes a year after the deal is complete. Six to 10 routes are likely to be picked up, said Donald Carty, American's executive vice president of finance and planning. He said the routes to Italy, Spain and Portugal are the most attractive.

DOC.HEAD: Some Want To Put Federal Deposit Insurance in Private Hands
With PM-Bank Crisis, Bjt and PM-Bank Fund, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Private deposit insurance funds have not had a tremendous track record. Bank runs have brought down insurers in Ohio and Maryland and now the collapse of a small Rhode Island bank threatens another. Nonetheless, as Rhode Island regulators piece together the remnants of Heritage Loan and Investment Co. - and the private agency that insured it - proposals are being floated to spin off federal deposit insurance to the private sector. Proponents say the idea is to reform a system that allowed a debacle such as the savings and loan scandal. ``Our first line of belief is private insurance can handle the whole thing,'' said Dwayne Welsh, general counsel of the National Deposit Insurance Corp. of Dublin, Ohio. ``The way you're going to solve this insurance problem is privatize this thing and charge people (depositors) for the insurance.'' Welsh, whose firm is the largest of 10 private insurers of credit unions in the country, warns that without reform, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. - protector of Americans' commercial bank deposits - could go the way of the now-defunct Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. He thinks the S&L-like failures in Ohio, Maryland and Rhode Island were anomalies created by criminal wrongdoing or by state and federal regulators more intent on satisfying politicians' demands than on policing an industry. A private company, he argued, would be insulated from that kind of pressure to prop up a failing institution. His opinion is far from universal. ``People are just looking around for ways to bring market discipline to the system and private deposit insurance is a thing that a lot of academics have suggested,'' said Ellen Lamb of the Conference of State Bank Supervisors based in Washington. ``It's a good theory, but we've seen a lot of cases where it doesn't work.'' The most recent case has been at Heritage Loan, a small operation in Providence's Federal Hill neighborhood, the base for New England organized crime. News reports have linked bank president Joseph Mollicone Jr., for whom an arrest warrant has been issued, with mob figures. But law-enforcement authorities shy away from revealing details of their investigations. Heritage's insurer, the Rhode Island Share and Deposit Indemnity Corp., pumped cash into the bank. But that seriously drained RISDIC's $25 million fund covering $1.6 billion in deposits at 35 credit unions and 11 banks in the state. Most of the members of RISDIC since have applied for federal coverage, although some of the credit unions are looking to Walsh's private fund. Peter Nevola, RISDIC president, said he believed his members applied to the federal system ``reluctantly'' because state regulators suggested that otherwise ``they would sometime down the line have no insurance.'' But he argues the Heritage crisis proved the soundness of his type of fund. When its reserves dipped below 1 percent of all member institutions' deposits, the banks and credit unions were reassessed to replenish the capital and all Heritage depositors are recovering their money. And no taxpayers are footing the bill, he said. ``I think we're demonstrating that it's probably the best idea yet,'' he said. Nonetheless, the crisis has led Rhode Island leaders to wonder whether the private insurance fund has outlived its usefulness and whether federal coverage should be required. ``I think those kinds of questions are going to be asked again this year,'' said Gov. Edward D. DiPrete, who conceded that simply transferred potential problems onto the backs of taxpayers. ``That's who pays for most things around here,'' the governor said. Business Regulation Director Frederick J. Franklin said he has seen a trend away from private insurance to federal insurance. That was largely what happened after private funds in Ohio and Maryland were seriously depleted by crises in 1985. But as Rhode Island's small banks and credit unions look toward protecting their deposits with the Treasury-backed funds, fundamental questions about the soundness of the federal insurance are being debated. Three separate studies examining the health of the nation's deposit insurance are to be completed during the next several months. Reforming the existing system is likely to dominate the next session of Congress. ``It's No. 1 on the agenda for the (House) Banking Committee. Everybody's going to jump into it,'' said Tom Seppy, a staffer on the panel's subcommittee regulating financial institutions, which commissioned one of the studies. Either supplementing or replacing the existing funds with private insurance is just one of the many ideas being offered, but it is one that has aroused plenty of interest among people who believe the government failed to safeguard taxpayers when the S&Ls spun out of control and took a big chunk of the Treasury along with them. ``Currently the mood, if you will, on Capitol Hill seems to be to find some way to limit the government's risk or exposure due to bank failures,'' said David Barr, an FDIC spokesman in Washington. ``To this point, nothing is really being endorsed over another idea.''

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Says All His Koito Stock Pledged as Loan Security
DOC.TEXT: Texas financier T. Boone Pickens' Boone Co. says all of the shares it holds in a Japanese auto parts maker are pledged as security for a loan, the Finance Ministry said Tuesday. Boone, the largest stockholder in Koito Manufacturing Co., had said in a report filed on Dec. 7 that an unspecified number of shares were used as collateral for the loan from Japanese stock speculator Kitaro Watanabe. Watanabe was the source of a large block of the shares. The Finance Ministry asked Boone to specify how many shares were pledged as collateral. An official of the Finance Ministry's Security Bureau, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the ministry received an amended report Monday specifying that all of Boone's 26.4 percent stake in Koito was used. Pickens has demanded seats on Koito's board of directors and charged that the company is unfairly discriminating against foreign investors. Koito has refused the demand for seats, saying it questions Pickens' intention in buying the shares. Noting the report that all of the shares were used as security, Tamotsu Aoyama, Koito's director and general manager, said, ``Our claim was justified. Boone Co. isn't a real stockholder that bears the responsibility for a risk.'' Koito contends that Watanabe actually holds the shares, and that Pickens is a front for a greenmail attempt. In greenmail, a company, fearing a takeover attempt, pays a premium to buy out some shareholders. Under a Japanese law that took effect Dec. 1, investors who purchase more than 5 percent of the ttal shares of a public company must report information such as the source of funds and purpose of the investment to the Finance Ministry.

DOC.HEAD: Government Clears Satellite TV Merger
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday cleared a merger between Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television and British Satellite Broadcasting. Trade Secretary Peter Lilley said he would not refer the deal to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. The Conservative government's decision sparked criticism from opposition parties. ``It is detrimental to the public interest that Sky should be allowed to establish a satellite television monopoly without penalty,'' said Labor lawmaker Robin Corbett, the party's spokesman on broadcasting matters. Sky Television, which had four channels, and BSB, which had five, announced the merger in early November to stem mounting losses from both operations. The renamed, five-channel British Sky Broadcasting, is 50 percent owned by Murdoch's News International and 50 percent by BSB's existing shareholders, the publishers Pearson PLC and Reed International PLC, the entertainment company Granada Group PLC, and the French conglomerate Chargeurs SA. Until the launch of Sky in 1989, Britain had four land-based channels. BSB began operating earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: Documents Say Kerkorian Refused to Limit Chrysler Stake to 10 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A California billionaire ignored Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca's plea that he promise to limit his stake in the automaker to less than 10 percent, documents say. Chrysler has tightened its anti-takeover provisions despite Kirk Kerkorian's assurances he has no plan to seek control of the nation's No. 3 automaker after buying 9.8 percent of its stock for $272 million. On Monday, Kerkorian filed papers with the Securities and Exchange Commission that said he bought about 22 million shares of Chrysler stock during the last two months for investment purposes. In the filing, Kerkorian said he bought about 5 million shares of Chrysler stock on Nov. 19 and met with Chrysler officials Dec. 9. At that meeting, he rejected Iacocca's request he sign a promise not to acquire 10 percent or more of Chrysler stock. Following the meeting, Kerkorian bought 10 million shares in two transactions, Dec. 10 and lst Wednesday, through his Tracinda Corp., the filing said. Chrysler Motors Chairman Bennett Bidwell said Monday that Chrysler's board tightened its ``poison-poll'' provisions on Friday in response to Kerkorian's stock purchases. ``I don't think the action of Mr. Kerkorian and the action of the board are coincidental,'' Bidwell said. The board lowered to 10 percent from 20 percent the amount of stock an investor may hold before triggering a provision offering Chrysler stock to shareholders at a discount. That, in turn, prompted shareholder Arun Shingala of New York to file suit in Delaware on Friday seeking to overturn the poison-pill provision as harmful to shareholders' interests. He also asked the suit be made a class action. Chrysler officials ``just seem very insecure to me,'' said Terry Christensen, Kerkorian's Los Angeles attorney. ``Kerkorian and Tracinda have offered to be consistently supportive of Lee Iacocca, both before, during and after the furor.'' Chrysler officials told The Detroit News the company last year discussed business deals with Kerkorian, including his possible purchase of its Gulfstream aircraft subsidiary. No deal materialized, the officials said in a story in today's editions of the paper. Chrysler was the most active stock onm the New York Stock Exchange with 1.88 million shares traded Monday. It closed at $12.87{ a share, up 62.5 cents a share from Friday's close. Bidwell, in charge of Chrysler's car and truck operations, said Chrysler has no idea what Kerkorian's motives may be. ``All we know is the track record of the guy,'' he said. ``We're playing wait-and-see.'' Kerkorian, a 73-year-old billionaire, last month sold MGM-UA Communications Co. for $1.3 billion to Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. He is also known for his investments in airlines and Las Vegas hotels and casinos. In the past, he has bought the companies, sold off divisions or subsidiaries, and then sold the organization, making millions of dollars along the way. Kerkorian said in the SEC documents that he has no plans for ``an extraordinary corporate transaction such as a merger, reorganization or liquidation, involving the company or any of its subsidiaries.'' Kerkorian also said he has no plans to boost his Chrysler holding beyond 9.8 percent, but noted he may increase or decrease his holding depending on general economic, money and stock market conditions. Analysts recently have viewed Chrysler's stock as undervalued. At $12 a share, Chrysler is valued at about $2.7 billion, just a shade more than Ford Motor Co. paid for the British luxury car maker Jaguar PLC early this year.

DOC.HEAD: News Sues Unions Over Interference With Dealers, Advertisers
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News has sued its striking unions on charges they have used violence to disrupt the publication and sale of the newspaper. The News on Monday accused the unions of violating federal labor law in a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. It was the second lawsuit brought by the newspaper against the unions since the strike began Oct. 25. The first lawsuit, brought Nov. 29 under the civil racketeering statute, accused the nine striking unions of coordinating a violent conspiracy to force a favorable labor settlement or the sale of the newspaper. The new complaint claims the unions violated the Labor-Management Relations Act, which prohibits unions from interfering with the business of parties not involved in a labor dispute. ``The defendants and agents acting on their behalf have mounted a campaign of violence and intimidation against the News' dealers and advertisers in an effort to disrupt the publication and sale of the newspaper,'' the lawsuit said. The lawsuit asks for more than $50 million in losses the News claims it incurred as a result of the campaign, which it said included ``many hundreds'' of incidents of arson, assault, vandalism, threats and harassment. Theodore Kheel, a labor attorney and adviser to the unions, denied the allegations. He cited recent testimony by senior police officials who said investigations found the violence was committed by individuals and was not part of a coordinated conspiracy. Kheel said the News' lawsuits against the unions constituted ``harassment.'' He said ``the suits will, if successful, destroy the unions or come close to destroying the unions by the cost in time and money the unions will have to spend defending themselves.'' The News has published every day during the strike, but the majority of the city's 12,000 newsstands and vendors have stopped selling the paper and many major advertisers - such as Macy's, Alexander's and A&S - have pulled their accounts.

DOC.HEAD: IBM and Cummins Engine Get No. 1 Rankings for Charitable Efforts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. and Cummins Engine Co. were the top corporate donors to charity in 1989, according to a survey. IBM, which contributed $135 million to charity in 1989, gave the most money, while Cummins Engine was first in percentage of pretax income. The Indiana diesel maker's $3.4 million in contributions last year represented 16.5 percent of net income before taxes. Public Management Institute of San Francisco listed the top givers among U.S. businesses in its second annual ``Generosity Index.'' Among dollar leaders, Hewlett-Packard Co. of Palo Alto was second with $74.5 million in donations, and General Motors was third with $62.2 million. Behind Cummins in percentage leaders was Adolph Coors Co., which donated $4 million, or 15.6 percent of 1989 pretax income. Safeway Stores Inc. of Oakland was third with $14 million in contributions, or 14.9 percent of pretax income. Despite a looming recession, Public Mangement Institute President Kenneth Gilman predicted contributions will remain steady this year. He said most companies have told PMI their 1990 contributions are about the same or a little higher than last year's.

DOC.HEAD: Economists and Politicians Part Company on Who Should Add to FDIC Fund
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 16th pvs, He and, to explain difference of opinion among economists; also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Regulators, bankers, politicians and economists agree: The fast-fading government fund that guarantees bank deposits will soon need an infusion of billions of dollars to keep it alive during a recession. But they are vigorously debating who should be the donor. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady says the banking industry is healthy enough to bail itself out, and he got backing Monday from L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. ``Any strengthening of the Bank Insurance Fund can and should be financed by the banking industry, not by the American taxpayers,'' Seidman told the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions. Banking's problems do not amount to another savings and loan crisis, he added. Subcommittee members, with memories of voters' reaction to being forced to pay for the $500 billion S&L debacle, generally welcomed his words. ``We need to make certain that the taxpayers of this nation ... are not asked to bail out the banks,'' said Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., the panel's chairman. However, several other members noted a similar determination within the Reagan administration regarding S&Ls and wondered if it would be better to face up to hard truths now. ``You only have two choices. You pay a little now or a lot later,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. Seidman is advancing a plan that would transfer $24 billion to $25 billion into his fund by assessing banks a fee equal to 1 percent of their deposits. He also would raise the industry's annual insurance premium to $6 billion, nearly triple last year's rate. That should be enough to handle failures in all but a deep and long recession. In that case, the FDIC could borrow from the Treasury, Seidman said. In addition, Seidman suggested that some weak banks be permitted to remain open under tight supervision by regulators, a tactic known as forbearance that was adopted successfully to handle troubled farm banks in the mid-1980s. ``If economic conditions continue to erode, we must ... explore means to reduce losses and improve credit availability by preventing failures. We cannot let weakness in the financial system bring on recession or worse in the economic system,'' Seidman said. However, three economists who prepared a study on the health of the insurance fund for the subcommittee said forbearance would allow bank managers to take a chance on resurrection by gambling with deposits. ``It could be that forbearance would work. ... But it's a high-risk gamble. A very high-risk gamble,'' said Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution. He and his colleagues, James Barth of Auburn University and R. Dan Brumbaugh of San Francisco, said it is better to inject taxpayer money into the insurance fund so failed banks can be closed promptly and consolidated into healthier institutions. Lita and Barth favor a loan from the Treasury to the fund, to be repaid by banks if they are able. Brumbaugh said surviving banks should not have to repay the money. Seidman estimated his fund will lose $4 billion this year and $5 billion next year, when around 180 banks will fail. That would reduce reserves to $4 billion - to guarantee $2 trillion in deposits - by the end of next year. ``Our best assessment of the situation is that the Bank Insurance Fund remains solvent, and will be solvent at the end of 1991. But it is very weak,'' he said. ``Refunding should be in place before it is actually needed. In other words, action should be taken early next year,'' Seidman added. The economists say even a mild recession likely would produce bank failures through 1993 costing $31 billion to $43 billion, enough to bankrupt the fund. A severe recession would cost up to $63 billion, they said, a figure Seidman called too low.

The stock market bounced back in choppy trading this morning after a modest drop on Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 11.63 points at 2,604.95 after a half hour of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Advancers outnumbered decliners by about 10 to 9, with 517 up, 447 down and 564 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.48 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up .36 at 178.58. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .30 at 304.29. Among the most active NYSE issues were Atlantic Richfield, down 2\ at 124{; IBM, up ~ at 112]; Chrysler, up \ at 13[; and Compaq, up | at 55. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.49 points to 2,593.32. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 492 up, 1,016 down and 516 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 118.56 million shares, against 150.88 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Christie's Auction House To Cut 146 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Christie's International PLC plans to eliminate 146 jobs following a 50 percent drop in its autumn season sales, the auctioneer said Tuesday. Christie's said it would lay off a tenth of its worldwide work force, from clerks to art experts, over the next few weeks. The company said in a statement that it also would freeze the salaries of senior staff members as part of the cost-cutting program. Christie's sales sank to $645 million in the months of August to December from $1.3 billion in the same period a year ago. Chairman Lord Carrington said that Christie's has ``decided to take prompt action to reduce our cost base significantly enough to weather the current climate, but in a way which will not erode our ability to take full advantage of the next upturn in the market.'' Despite the sales dip, Carrington added that the medium- to long-term prospects for the company and the art market were encouraging as a whole, particularly in continental Europe and Asia.

DOC.NOTE: For release Monday, Dec. 24, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Will a Slow Christmas Zap Nintendo?
DOC.TEXT: Is 1991 the year we learn how high Mario can jump? ``Mario,'' that high-stepping hero of video games, has helped Nintendo of America Inc., remain the top toy in America for the past three years. But how will Nintendo hurdle a recession? Some toy experts think the video game craze has peaked, at least in its latest incarnation. But even if sales do fall off, they say, Nintendo won't vanish from the scene, especially if it launches a planned new entertainment system next year. Executives at Nintendo's North American headquarters here say the Nintendo Entertainment System now is in nearly one out of every three U.S. households. This year, they estimate, Nintendo and its licensees will sell $4.1 billion worth of game systems, cartridges and related products. That's $1.4 billion more than in 1989. Nintendo of America, a subsidiary of Japan's Nintendo Co. Ltd., has more than 80 percent of the entire U.S. home video market. Nintendo projects the entire U.S. video game industry will tally $5.1 billion in sales for 1990, a $1.7 billion gain over last year. Toy and Hobby World magazine has listed Nintendo's game machine as the nation's top-selling toy since January 1988. Last month, the trade magazine also listed four other Nintendo products in its top 10: The ``Super Mario Brothers 3'' game as No. 2, the Game Boy hand-held set at No. 4, the ``Tetris'' game in sixth place and ``Super Mario Brothers 2'' at ninth. Nintendo won't make its 1991 forecasts until after the Christmas season, spokesman Tom Sarris said. But a shaky economy and the prospects of poor retail sales this Christmas don't add up to good news, says analyst Paul Valentine, of Standard & Poor's Corp. ``There's no question, the signs are unmistakable that the video game fad is slowing down,'' he says. Valentine notes that some video game cartridges are now selling for $20 apiece when they sold for $35 or $40 a year ago. Sales of the game sets also are down, with Nintendo predicting it will sell 7.5 million units this year, compared with 9.1 million in 1989. ``Nintendo has been sizzling for the past few years,'' Valentine said. ``It's unrealistic to think that sort of momentum to support video games will go on indefinitely.'' David Leibowitz, an analyst with American Securities Corp. in NewYork, disagrees. ``Taken as a totality, Nintendo will be the biggest seller this year. This Christmas will do nothing to diminish the appeal of the line,'' he said. Sure, times are tough, Leibowitz said, but ``the children of America will not be denied.'' Toy retailers are hedging their bets. The Child World chain has slashed prices, Kay-Bee stores has offered 10 percent discounts, and Toys ``R'' Us has held a $100 million clearance. Sales for the Nintendo game system have slowed, but demand for the games and for Game Boy is strong, said Angela Bourdon, a Toys ``R'' Us spokeswoman. Though older game cartridges such as ``Zelda'' and ``Punch Out'' are included in the clearance, ``the hot ones like Super Mario Brothers 3 have not been discounted,'' Bourdon said. Peter Main, Nintendo of America's vice president of marketing, says things may be tougher this holiday season, ``but Christmas still happens.'' Nintendo games are ``big value items'' - stuff that gets played with beyond Dec. 26 - which should strengthen its appeal to money-tight consumers, Main said. He also noted that the last video game boom, led by the Atari system in the early 1980s, came in the middle of a recession. To help boost first-quarter 1991, Nintendo is launching a major new game, ``Startropics,'' the day after Christmas, Main said. The game is a fantasy adventure similar to past hits ``Legend of Zelda'' and ``Zelda II: The Adventure of Link.'' Main said Nintendo also has been targeting adults more in its marketing, with people over 18 accounting for 50 percent of the hardware purchases this year. Game Boy especially is a hit with adults, he said, and new games such as ``NES Play Action Football'' and ``Dr. Mario,'' a sequel to ``Tetris,'' were designed to appeal to older players. Nintendo, which employs about 1,500 people in this Seattle suburb, is betting on its future with plans for a 300,000-square-foot automated warehouse on a 110-acre site in North Bend, about 25 miles east of Seattle. The warehouse, to open early next year, will double Nintendo's plant space in the Seattle area. Valentine and Leibowitz said Nintendo could recharge its business with a planned new entertainment system, a 16-bit machine that offers substantially better graphics, sound and action than the current 8-bit device. The new machine was launched in Japan this fall and was well received, Leibowitz said. Nintendo's main competitors, Sega and NEC, already have 16-bit players on the market. Main said Nintendo has been criticized for the past two years for not bringing out the new machine. But he said Nintendo didn't want to do that while demand remained high for the older entertainment system. Existing Nintendo game cartridges can't be played on the new machine. Sarris said Nintendo ``is looking at the second half of 1991'' to introduce the game, but no specific date had been chosen. Valentine said even if video games fade, Nintendo won't vanish. He said he has made predictions before that Nintendo would suffer the same fate as other fads in the volatile toy industry. ``I've always felt that the history of the toy business is cyclical,'' he said. ``I've been maybe 18 months early predicting the end of the video game fad while Nintendo was laughing all the way to the bank.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Monday, Dec. 24, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Japanese Business Lending Hand To Soviets Despite Official Chill
DOC.TEXT: Japanese businessmen are extending a tentative lifeline to the ailing Soviet economy even though their government has avoided wider ties pending resolution of a long-standing territorial dispute. A number of companies have signed contracts or worked behind the scenes to aid the Soviets' herculean task of converting to a market-oriented economy, experts say. ``If Gorbachev is ousted and perestroika fails, it will be a very big setback, so some politicians and corporations have decided they must help it succeed,'' said Hiroshi Kato, a professor at Tokyo's Keio University who specializes on the Soviet economy. Kato said these groups feel it's in their best interest to help even though there has been no breakthrough in a dispute over a group of islands north of Japan seized by Moscow at the end of World War II. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is widely expected to make a major concession on the islands when he visits Tokyo next spring. ``If perestroika fails,'' Kato said, ``Japan will have to help with refugees fleeing from Siberia. Inflation will become terrible and cause a complete economic failure. ``And then the Japanese will have to pay even more than now to bail the Soviets out.'' Foreign Ministry officials say the business community has not applied direct pressure on the government to drop recommendations against expanding contacts with Moscow before the island dispute is resolved. Still, Tokyo appears to be going along. ``The government is doing what it can to help the Soviets, and the private sector is doing what it can,'' one senior ministry official said on condition of anonymity. While Japan continues to rule out official financial aid to the Soviets until the islands are returned, it is providing some emergency medical relief. And major Japanese trading houses and banks are carefully finding ways to help Moscow that won't entangle them in unprofitable trade deals, experts say. Trading companies also seem to have abandoned their traditional fear that doing business with the Soviets will lead to harassment by extreme right-wing groups. ``It is natural for the Soviet Union and Japan to consider more cooperation,'' said Yohei Mimura, chairman of Mitsubishi Corp., Japan's largest trading house. ``We should do what we can to help ensure the survival of perestroika in this historical age.'' Mitsubishi recently signed a $300 million contract to build 18 cargo ships for the Soviet shipping firm Sovcomflot. Mitsui Busan, another major trading firm, said it reached a preliminary agreement with the Soviet Ministry of Oil and Gas Industry for two offshore oil and natural gas projects near the eastern Soviet island of Sakhalin. The project will provide the Soviets with offshore oil extraction technology and boost Soviet petrochemical exports, the company said. In mid-November, five commercial banks agreed to lend the Soviet Union $400 million to buy steel pipes and pay for goods already imported from Japan, industry sources said. The loans will be guaranteed by trading houses involved in Japan-Soviet trade. Seiji Tsutsumi, head of the Saison Group of retail and travel companies, says he is writing a book with other major businessmen to help the Soviets follow the Japanese example of rebuilding after the war. The two-year-old Soviet policy of allowing 14,000 enterprises to make their own deals with foreign companies without going through the central government has bred great confusion. ``No one knows who's in charge. In the past, you could depend on the government to back up Soviet firms, but now you can't trust the system,'' said Michitaka Hatori, economist at the Japan Association for Trade With the Soviet Union and Socialist Countries of Europe. Soviet businesses also have been told to become self-sufficient because they can no longer rely on the state to bail them out. Foreign creditors have been unwilling to come to the rescue of ailing Soviet firms, and as a result some exporters have stopped shipments to the Soviet Union. Estimates of unpaid Soviet trade debts to Japan range from several hundred million to as much as $1 bilion. When Soviet companies sought delays of up to nine months to pay for steel from Japan, supplies were cut off until a partial payment was made, Japanese officials say. Matsushita Electric Co. started requiring advance payment for exports after Soviet buyers fell behind in payments. Direct trade fell 6.4 percent in the first nine months of 1990 from the corresponding period a year earlier because of such embarrassments. ``If you read the newspapers, it looks as if a lot is going on. But it's not trade,'' Hatori said.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Finds Problems in New Mainframes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-5 to give more details about troubles; uppicks 4th graf pvs: David Lynch...
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. has found some technical problems in its new line of mainframe computers, prompting the company to retrofit the machines to make them more reliable, a spokesman said today. Digital unveiled its VAX 9000 machines last year, entering the mainframe market that has been dominated by rival International Business Machines Corp. But some customers have reported troubles with the machines, which are designed to handle massive amounts of information. According to Digital, the problems caused the machines to ``crash'' every few days in certain applications. Mark Steinkrauss, director of investor relations for Digital, said the problems arose in a ``handful'' of customers who run the machines for lengthy periods. He said many customers did not experience the trouble, although Digital expected there might be some problems when the company introduced the machine. ``It would be unrealistic to think you're not going to get a glitch here or there,'' he said. David Lynch, a Digital spokesman, said the enhancement was being made on all VAX 9000s. ``It's important that they be at top reliability,'' he said. Lynch said Digital did not consider the situation a serious problem. The company has been looking to the VAX 9000 to help boost weak revenues that led to Digital's first-ever quarterly loss earlier in the year. Some analysts say the VAX 9000 has been hurt by production delays, although the company insists the machines are being well-received. ``This is a headache, but not a disaster,'' said Terry Shannon, a consultant with International Data Corp. ``Digital is bending over backwards to make sure these things run right.'' Michael A. Guider, a vice president at Litel Communications Inc., a regional long-distance carrier in Worthington, Ohio, told The Wall Street Journal that the retrofit ``eliminated a serious problem that had plagued our machine.'' But Guider also praised Digital's support and said the retrofit would not disrupt his operations.

DOC.HEAD: Two Comedy Channels to Merge ^Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Two all-comedy cable services that have battled each other since April Fool's Day said today they are ending their war of the chuckles and merging into a single cable network called Comedy TV. Home Box Office's The Comedy Channel, begun in November, 1989, and MTV Networks' HA! The Comedy Network, on the air since April 1, will start their merged service early next year, company officials said.. Each is a 24-hour operation, and each has faced difficulties getting onto cable systems due to a shortage of available channels. They made it official less than than a month after two proposed rival cable services devoted to law - ``In Court'' and ``American Courtroom Network'' - also said they would merge into one service called American Courtoom Network. Time Warner Inc., which had hoped to launch one of the all-law networks, owns HBO. The Comedy Channel is seen in 8.5 million homes. HA!, whose parent company is owned by Viacom International Inc., is in 6.5 million homes. Their union will give the new service 15 million homes, they said. All-sports ESPN serves the most cable homes, 55.9 million, followed by Turner's Cable News Network, which serves 54.4 million. The advertiser-supported Comedy TV Network that will result from HA! and The Comedy Channel will be a 50-50 venture, with a programming lineup drawn from each network, the two companies said. Each network will continue its respective operations until the new service begins ``in early 1991,'' HBO said. The president of the new network will be recruited from outside the two companies, and the new network will be staffed by HA! and The Comedy Channel employees. HBO chairman Michael Fuchs, in a statement, said the merged comedy service ``is not only a very positive move for both companies, but should have a salutary effect on the cable industry as a whole.'' About 12 new cable services plan start-ups in coming months, according to one estimate by Erica Gruen, a cable analyst at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. The hopefuls range from a 24-hour talk show channel to the Cowboy Channel.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Report Marks Biggest Imbalance In Almost Three Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf pvs with 4 new grafs to give economist reaction, picks up 4th graf pvs, Much of.; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit, hurt by a huge foreign oil bill and an unexpected surge in car imports, climbed to $11.61 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in almost three years, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said both U.S. exports and imports hit all-time highs, leaving the October deficit a giant 24.5 percent higher than September's deficit of $9.33 billion. The country's October trade performance surprised economists who had been looking for the number to remain virtually unchanged. Some analysts said the sharp deterioration would make the start of the new recession even more severe than had been expected. Economists said the October report suggested that what had been the one bright spot in a lackluster economy, a narrowing trade deficit, would not be available to help cushion the start of the downturn in the October-December quarter. They also said the big rise in imports suggested that retailers will be stuck with bloated inventories which could dampen production and make the length of the downturn last longer. ``This is a bad number,'' David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said of the October trade gap. ``It suggests that we are not going to get as much help from net exports as we had hoped and it suggests there is more inventory out there than we had thought.'' Much of the deterioration came from a 17 percent jump in America's foreign oil bill, reflecting the huge jump in world prices following Iraq's August invasion of Kuwait. Oil imports rose to $7.23 billion in October, the highest monthly total since April 1981. The total trade gap widened to its largest imbalance since a $12.56 billion deficit in February 1988. U.S. exports climbed 8.6 percent, hitting an all-time high of $34.77 billion. This increase was viewed as good news that America's export boom, the source of much of the economy's strength in the past three years, was continuing. But imports were up in October by an even larger amount, climbing 12.2 percent to $46.38 billion. The big jump in oil imports reflected a rise in price from $24.31 a barrel in September to $29.04 in October. The volume imported actually fell slightly to 8.03 million barrels a day, down from 8.48 million barrels daily in September. The other big increase in the import category came in shipments of new cars, which soared 39 percent to $4.51 billion in October. In other economic news today, the Labor Department reported that the cost of living rose a moderate 0.3 percent in November, the first inflation break for consumers since oil prices shot up after the invasion of Kuwait. The seasonally-adjusted increase in the Consumer Price Index followed an increase of 0.6 percent in October and even larger rises of 0.8 percent in September and August. The Bush administration had been hoping that the trade deficit would drop below $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. However, October's big surge left the deficit for the first 10 months of the year running at an annual rate of $103 billion, down only slightly from last year's $109.4 billion deficit. As usual, the biggest deficit in October was with Japan, a $4.90 billion imbalance which was the largest since a deficit of $4.91 billion in October 1989. The deficit with Canada, America's largest trading partner, rose to $1.4 billion in October while the deficit with China was $1.2 billion and the deficit with Taiwan was $1.1 billion.

The stock market bounced back in choppy trading this morning after a modest drop on Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 8.17 points at 2,601.49 after an hour and a half of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Advancers outnumbered decliners by about 6 to 5, with 657 up, 546 down and 584 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 50.66 million shares as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. There was no dominant pattern to today's early trading, but analyst Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said traders seemed to have been reassured by the latest inflation figures from the government. The Labor Department said today that the Consumer Price Index had gone up 0.3 percent in November, half of the 0.6 percent increase in prices in October and far less than the increases of 0.8 percent in September and August. ``Today's a bit of a respite and a bit of a sigh fo relief that the CPI didn't upset the apple cart,'' Solomon said. There was also a sense in the market that diplomats were trying to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis, he said. High oil prices brought on by the crisis have hurt stock prices in many trading sessions. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up .45 at 178.67. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .27 at 304.26. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Drift Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices drifted lower in quiet trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade as dealers awaited official word on rumored sales of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union. Grain prices ralled Monday on indications the Soviets may have bought as much as 600,000 metric tons of corn, but as of this morning there was no confirmation of any grain sales. Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said traders were hoping for an announcement to come out of London, where U.S. and Soviet negotiators were meeting to discuss terms of a U.S. food aid package. ``Something might come out of that, but so far it's just a quiet, dull day,'' he said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.54{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.25} a bushel; oats were } cent lower across the board with March at $1.18{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 1} cents higher with January at $5.87\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .10 cent lower with the contract for delivery in December at 81.10 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent lower to .18 cent higher with January at 89.10 cents a pound; live hogs were .20 cent to .80 cents lower with December at 50.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .17 cent lower with February at 62.90 cents a pound. Livestock futures rose on Monday; pork bellies retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Output In Eastern Germany Drops 50 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Industrial output in Germany's five new eastern states has dropped nearly 50 percent from 1989, the Economics Ministry said Tuesday. The figures clearly show that the new eastern states remain in a ``serious restructuring process'' as they move from a centrally controlled economy to a market economy, the report said. The industrial output dropped 35 percent from autumn of 1989 to July and decreased another 14 percent from July to August, the report said. However, output increased about 2.5 percent in September and another one percent in October. The report attributed the slight improvement to a 9.5 percent increase in energy production and a 21 percent increase in the production of foodstuffs. No data was available to determine if the big drop of output in the summer months was traceable to seasonal factors. It was also not clear whether the slight increase in production was due to a re-orientation of consumers toward eastern-made products after a rush to buy western products following monetary union on July 1, the report said. Separately, the report said that new orders for production dropped 15 percent in August from July and another 10 percent from August to September. However, new orders for industrial products increased by 2 percent from September to October. East Germany's industrial output started sagging last fall when tens of thousands of mostly skilled, young workers fled to the west. The problem was compounded when the borders were opened, giving easterners free access to better-quality western products in former West Germany, which for the most part had been denied them for four decades. After monetary union, when the West German mark became the official currency, western products took over many shelves in the east, further cutting demand for locally produced items. Experts have predicted that many of former East Germany's outdated factories and other businesses will be forced to shut down in the restructuring process, and that up to half of the estimated 8 million workers in the eastern states could be jobless by the end of 1991.
