DOC.HEAD: Accord Reported Near on Corn, Sorghum Exports
DOC.TEXT: Agreement is near between the United States and the 12 governments in the European Community on sales of $420 million worth of American corn and sorghum to Spain and Portugal, a U.S. official said Tuesday. A four-year accord was due to expire at the end of the year and would be renewed for another year, said an official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Renewal would remove a threat of retaliation by the United States against a similar amount of Europeanexports to this country. The proposal for a year's renewal was made to the 12 governments Monday by the European Commission, their joint executive. The dispute arose when Spain and Portugal became members of the Community, also known as the common market. Under Community rules, the two new members were bound to give preference to goods from the other members. President Reagan's administration protested that American farmers would lose sales. So it was agreed that Spain and Portugal would continue to buy an annual two million tons of American corn and 300,000 tons of sorghum for the four years. Expiration of the agreement and retaliation by the United States would have damaged hope for progress in the Uruguay round of trade talks among more than 100 countries on a wide variety of products and services. Negotiations were stalled earlier this month by a clash between the United States and the Community over subsidies for farm products. Another meeting has been called in Geneva, Switzerland, on Jan. 15 by Arthur Dunkel, head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Finish Slightly Higher
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday but with little conviction behind the rise, as investors shied away from taking any new, significant equity positions. Traders attributed the rise to end-of-the-year portfolio adjustments as well as a shortage of some blue-chip shares. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 3.9 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,161.8 at the close. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 3.8 points to close at 1,694.0. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 2.27 points to close at 1,146.08. Volume rose to 575.3 million shares, compared with the 333.8 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Pump Prices Unchanged for Week
DOC.TEXT: The national average price of gasoline at the pump was unchanged over the past week, the American Automobile Association said Tuesday. A gallon of self-service unleaded regular averaged $1.371, which was 31 cents higher than Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait, the AAA said in its weekly survey. The highest prices were in New England, where a gallon of self-serve unleaded regular fetched $1.437. The cheapest regional price was $1.298 per gallon in the Midwest. The AAA said that 84 percent of the nation's service stations will maintain normal operating hours on Christmas Day, with 33 percent planning to stay open 24 hours.

DOC.HEAD: Seeds of Rebirth Hidden in the Gloom
Graphics
DOC.TEXT: A barrage of evidence shows the nation sliding into recession, marring the holidays with grim economic reality. While the extent of the damage remains unclear, the repair work is already beginning. In a yearend package of stories, the Associated Press examines the seeds of the economy's rebirth. ---=

Like a party reveler sprawled on the dance floor after too many drinks, the American economy awoke to a sobering skull-thumper in 1990 from the indulgent 1980s. An addiction to foreign imports, corporate takeovers and debt finally took its toll on the longest peacetime expansion in U.S. history. The downturn, now official by almost any measurement, has put a million people out of work since June and caused thousands of companies to fail or seek shelter from creditors in bankruptcy court. Homebuying and construction have fallen to levels not seen since the last recession eight years ago. Banks are weak, the stock market is sick, car sales are anemic, and consumers spent sparingly for Christmas. ``People are postponing the postponable,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles. ``All over the place, people are just sitting on their hands.'' The U.S. economy, built on the free enterprise forces of supply and demand, is accustomed to cycles of boom and bust. But this time, things are different. External shocks to the economy - from the Persian Gulf crisis and the savings and loan bailout, for example - are exacerbating the slide. The Gulf standoff has added a ``war premium'' to oil prices and stoked the embers of inflation. The thrift bailout has added to the already enormous debt burdens of the federal government and increased the ultimate bill to taxpayers. Some experts worry that the pressures are too severe for the economy to bounce back quickly. A few expect the worst is yet to come. ``If somebody asked me not too many years ago whether we would have a major downturn similar to the Great Depression of the 1930s, I would have said no,'' said James Barth, a finance professor at Auburn University in Alabama and a former economist at the government's Office of Thrift Supervision. ``But now it's to the point where people are talking about it,'' Barth said. ``That registers on the economic Richter scale. I'm not willing to say it just won't occur.'' The hard times have inspired an aggressive hunt for scapegoats. The highest flyers of the '80s - Donald Trump, Michael Milken and S&L fraud defendant Charles Keating - have become targets of editorials and the butt of late-night TV monologues. The young baby-boomers on Wall Street have been generally cursed for sapping the productive energies of American businesses by weighing them down with excessive debt. ``There's a fixation on trying to blame some people, some institutions for excesses in which many of us shared,'' said Jerry Sterner, author of an off-Broadway hit play about a hostile takeover called ``Other People's Money.'' ``I think Trump, Keating and the boys were a reflection of what we were, taken to a much larger level,'' Sterner said. ``It's easier to blame `them bums.''' The question for 1991 is not who's to blame, but where will it end. What's going to happen to pull the economy out of its nose dive? Amid the gloom, some suggest the comparisons to the '30s are misplaced. For one thing, the economy is more diversified and efficient than it was 60 years ago, strengthened by an array of systems to transmit goods, services, knowledge and ideas that are the envy of the world. For another, the Federal Reserve, the central bank, recently has taken steps to loosen credit, rather than tighten as the Fed of the 1930s did. That classic blunder precipitated an avalanche of failures because even healthy businesses couldn't borrow to pay their bills. ``The Fed is keenly aware we're in a recession now,'' said David Bostian, chief economist at Jesup, Josephthal & Co., a New York investment firm. ``The Fed has woken up to the realization that it needs to aggressively ease.'' Some studies indicate the present downturn could be shallow and short. The University of Michigan's forecasters predicted at their recent economic outlook conference that growth would show a modest decline in the final quarter of 1990 but revive in early 1991. The Paris-based Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development released a surprisingly optimistic assessment in late November that said the United States is facing a period of slow growth, but not a downturn. Some economists suggest the national perception has been skewed by heavy reporting of bad news on the East Coast, where the economy is slowest. Meanwhile, Texas and its neighbors are rebounding, the West Coast remains relatively healthy and an export boom is strengthening vast parts of the Midwest, notably around the Great Lakes, which could become the catalyst for the next national economic resurgence. Milwaukee, for example, devastated by a loss of manufacturing jobs during the 1981-82 recession, is thriving because factories have since retooled with modern equipment. It is now one of the nation's leading job producers. In Cleveland, once a recession-scarred industrial hulk and now a model American city, companies learned the hard way to cut costs through automation and smaller work forces during the 1980s. ``Running lean and mean, running scared, has become a way of life,'' said Adrian Dillon of Eaton Corp., an electrical and automotive component manufacturer that is one of Cleveland's key industries. A recent study by the American Express Co. on the outlook for small and midsized businesses, the main generators of new jobs, showed companies in the Pacific states should fare well in a recession, while those in the Northeast and Middle Atlantic regions would be hit hardest.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: ... hit hardest.
DOC.TEXT: Some economists have dismissed recession talk altogether and argue that the United States is about to embark on a period of stunning growth. They base this outlook partly on the premise that many U.S. companies are much tougher than they were just a few years ago, battle-hardened by foreign competition and recent cost cutting. John Rutledge, senior economist at the Claremont Economics Institute, a forecasting concern in Claremont, Calif., contends the yawning trade deficits American manufacturers agonized over last decade masked a critical advantage they enjoyed: the availability of affordable foreign machinery to modernize and get back into the game of making money. ``A lot of turnaround stories of the 1980s were businesses using imported machines to retool,'' he said. ``If you look at what we imported, it wasn't all Hershey bars and Hondas. It was things we used to build other things.'' Now, Rutledge said, ``We have survivor managers, good managers. The capital stock has been groomed and rebuilt. We're all dressed up and ready for a party, if there's enough money to make that happen.'' Whether there's enough money is the key question. Federal government debt, driven by repeated budget deficits, has risen more than 60 percent in the past five years to $3.25 trillion, or more than $13,000 for every American. Business debt has swollen just as dramatically, largelybecause of the mergers, buyouts and restructurings of the last decade. DRI-McGraw Hill Inc., an economic forecasting firm in Lexington, Mass., said corporate liabilities totaled $2.2 trillion in 1990, about double the figure of five years ago and triple the total in 1980. ``A very substantial portion of corporate cash flow, 35 to 45 percent, goes into servicing existing debt, a historic postwar high,'' said Robert Hormats, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs & Co., a Wall Street investment bank. ``This means there is less money available for new investment. It also means companies are very vulnerable to interest rate increases or declines in earnings.'' On the personal level, debts have been inflated by the proliferation of plastic to finance credit-card purchases. By DRI-McGraw Hill's estimate, total consumer debt exceeded $735 billion in 1990, 42 percent more than the level in 1985 and 146 percent more than the level a decade ago. But the debt pileup has led to some natural corrections. Businesses are increasingly using bankruptcy court to reorganize. Federal figures show more than 725,000 bankruptcy cases flooded into the system for the year ended June 30, double the number of 1981. A Morgan Stanley Group analysis of companies that borrowed heavily in the 1980s shows a majority were stable businesses like public utilities and food processors. Cyclical industries like retailers increased their debt only modestly. That means the United States may be able to battle its debt hangover ``much better than the merchants of gloom believe,'' the Economist magazine recently speculated. Debt accumulation by consumers also is slowing along with spending, suggesting that Americans may be making healthy adjustments in their personal finances. Major banks, by putting billions of dollars aside as reserves against loan losses, are demonstrating the discipline needed to return to profitability. Even on Wall Street, which has been mired in a slump since the crash of 1987, some say prices have fallen so far, they could be poised for a rebound as investors look for bargains. A forecast from Jesup, Josephthal & Co. says the Dow Jones industrial average could double to 5,000 as early as mid-decade.

DOC.HEAD: As Economy Staggers, Bankruptcy Becomes Field for the 1990s
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Visions of pizza parlors danced in the heads of the managers at Pantera's, a small Midwest restaurant chain that borrowed $65 million during the easy-money '80s to buy much larger Pizza Inn Inc. But first they overvalued and then mismanaged the Dallas-based chain of 600 restaurants. Morale deteriorated, training evaporated, employees quit, franchisers pulled out. In October 1989, 2{ years after the leveraged buyout, Pizza Inn couldn't pay debts and sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code. New management was appointed and creditors were paid. About 150 restaurants closed, but today Pizza Inn survives. ``I was amazed at the opportunity this provides a company to save the baby and not liquidate the whole thing,'' company president Jeff Rogers said. ``The bankruptcy gave us a clean start.'' Pizza Inn is a parable for the 1980s, in which wide-eyed managements exploited loose credit to expand via LBOs financed by high-risk junk bonds. The moral is found in the company's recovery under America's benevolent bankruptcy code. The term bankruptcy is derived from the Italian ``banca rotta,'' which means broken bench. In medieval times, if a trader couldn't pay creditors, they smashed his trading bench. For centuries in Britain, debtors went to prison. But U.S. bankruptcy law was designed to allow companies to rise from the ashes of collapse. The belief that failure is a forgivable outgrowth of entrepreneurship is considered uniquely American. The 1990s are putting that notion to test. An ailing real estate market, LBO debts, tightening bank credit, increased foreign competition and new legal tactics are straining the nation's bankruptcy system as never before. Federal statistics show more than 725,000 business and personal bankruptcies were filed in the year ended June 30, double the 1981 figure. Ten of the 25 biggest bankruptcies in history have occurred in the last 18 months, Beard Group Inc., a Washington research firm, reports. Dun & Bradstreet Corp. says 55,000 businesses failed in the first 11 months of 1990 - 165 a day. ``We just ran out of space in our file room in Phoenix for 1990,'' said Kevin O'Brien, clerk for Arizona's two bankruptcy courts. ``If nothing happens soon we won't have anywhere to put '91.'' Arizona is inundated with bankruptcies stemming from the collapse of the real estate and savings & loan industries. Annual filings have more than quadrupled since 1980, to a projected 18,500 in 1990. The state's five judges handled 216 Chapter 11 cases apiece in 1989, three times the national norm. In New York, hand-written signs point to rooms containing the files of big-name bankruptcies such as Eastern Airlines, Drexel Burnham Lambert, Lomas Financial and Ames Department Stores. Boxes of documents are stacked in hallways. Bankruptcy, ironically, has spawned a vibrant industry. Corporate debt restructuring is one of the few growth areas at Wall Street investment houses. ``Workout'' firms help companies repackage debt to delay payments without declaring Chapter 11. Businesses even have sprung up to help manage the regulatory and paperwork maze. Finding opportunity in others' misfortune, speculators invest and trade in the debt of distressed companies. Law firms are bulking up what 10 years ago was a necessary but unglamorous area. Many specialists in the field say bankruptcy law is to the 1990s what mergers and acquisitions law was to the 1980s. ``It's a hot area because of economic necessity,'' said Alan Miller, a partner at the New York law firm of Weil, Gotschal & Manges, which has the nation's largest bankruptcy group. The first permanent federal bankruptcy law was enacted in 1898, but was based on the British model under which creditors forced companies into liquidation to collect debts. The idea of using bankruptcy to help companies survive wasn't enshrined in the law until 1938. U.S. bankruptcy statutes remained unchanged for another 40 years, until Congress in 1978 overhauled the Depression-era laws to account for the nation's more sophisticated business environment. Under the reform, business reorganizations of all sizes were combined into Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Existing management was allowed to run a company during bankruptcy instead of a court-appointed trustee. But none of the reformers envisioned today's multibillion-dollar cases with multiple tiers of complicated debt and more creditor committees than teams in the National Hockey League. ``When I became a judge in 1973 I never heard of a junk bond,'' said Robert L. Ordin, who stepped down from the Los Angeles bankruptcy bench in 1983 and now is with the law firm Loeb & Loeb. The costs of reorganizing in bankruptcy court also have escalated. A typical case spins off big paychecks for attorneys, investment bankers and accountants. Those fees can siphon millions of dollars from a debtor's estate that could otherwise be used to pay creditors. ``The costs for big companies are simply off the charts,'' said Stephen Weinroth, chairman of Integrated Resources Inc., which staggered into bankruptcy court 10 months ago $1.6 billion in debt. The financial firm expects to spend more than $50 million on professional fees during its reorganization. Drexel is paying up to $18 million every three months to professionals hired by three creditors' committees and a shareholders' committee. Including those hired by Drexel, about 20 law firms, four accounting agencies and three investment advisers are involved in the bankruptcy. Some judges are fighting back. In the Drexel case, Judge Howard Buschman III slashed lawyers' fee requests by 25 percent. In North Carolina, judges are forcing debtors and creditors to streamline cases to save time and money for smaller companies. ``The Chapter 11 law was designed for the large corporation,'' said Judge A. Thomas Small in Raleigh, N.C., who has cut case completion time to six months from the national average of 18 to 24 months. ``It just doesn't fit for small ones.'' In a Chapter 11, companies continue operating but all debts and other legal obligations are put on hold. Creditors fight with the debtor and each other over who gets how much. Secured creditors such as banks are first in line; shareholders typically are last. The two sides negotiate and vote on a reorganization plan. But the process can be nasty. Bankruptcy disputes increasingly are feeding a wave of legal wrangling that can prolong cases, sometimes by years. ``It's become way too litigious,'' said Harry Dixon, chairman of the American Bankruptcy Institute. ``Even as recently as five years ago lawyers and judges got together and these things got settled with a great deal less expense than today.'' One increasingly popular method of speeding the process is the prepackaged bankruptcy, in which the debtor and creditors agree on a reorganization plan before declaring Chapter 11. Southland Corp., owner of 7-Eleven stores, is in a prepackaged bankruptcy now. ``It cuts down on the amount of fees and costs involved. Judges love them,'' said Thomas Salerno, a Phoenix lawyer who shepherded sign-maker Kroy Inc. through a prepackaged bankruptcy in six months. But new techniques alone aren't enough. Demand is growing for reform and more judges. Experts predict the number of Chapter 11 filings to increase as more companies fail to honor debt obligations. About $23 billion in high-interest junk bonds went into default in 1990, said Richard Lehmann, editor of the Defaulted Bond Newsletter, a Miami Lakes, Fla., trade publication. Another $50 billion is expected to default in 1991 and 1992. ``There's a lot of this stuff out there and we don't know how it's going to shake out,'' said Nathan C. Thorne, head of restructuring at Merrill Lynch & Co. ``It's like a snake just swallowed a great big animal.''

DOC.HEAD: Hopes That Wall Street Pain Yields Gains
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: For stock-market investors and people who work in the securities industry, it hasn't been easy to see much bright promise in the early days of the 1990s. Stock prices have spent most of 1990 in a bear market that surpassed the Crash of 1987 in duration, if not in severity. At the same time, Wall Street itself languished in the fourth year of a stubborn industry slump. The end-of-an-era signals in 1990 seemed hard to miss. In February the firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert, kingpin of the '80s junk-bond boom, abruptly collapsed and disappeared from the scene. Nine months later its foremost financier, Michael Milken, drew a 10-year prison sentence. But in the midst of these backward-looking events, many analysts argue that the ground is being cleared and the seeds being sown for more bounteous times in the investment world as the decade progresses. ``The economy has tumbled into a serious recession,'' said Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Co. in New York. ``The financial structure is at risk. Even so, the year ahead could be surprisingly good for Wall Street. ``With an assist from the Federal Reserve, we expect the economy to rebound during the second half of 1991. This has exciting implications for financial markets.'' To put a number on his optimism, David Bostian at Jesup, Josephthal & Co. forecasts that the Dow Jones industrial average will climb to 5,000 as early as mid-decade. ``This recession is providing painful, but valuable, lessons to governments, corporations and individuals that will improve their economic conduct in the 1990s,'' he maintains. ``The new decade will see savings and investment favored relative to consumption and equity favored over debt, to cite only two critical changes.'' Like many optimists in other areas of the economy, Wall Street's bulls are counting on the present crunch ultimately to serve as a purgative and restorative, rather than destructive, force. One central theme in this kind of argument is that the debt mess of the 1980s, with all the problems it has caused, will be cleaned up before too long, but not forgotten. Says Bostian, ``I think the banks may have learned a long-to-be-remembered lesson on the importance of lending for productive economic activity rather than financial speculation.'' What is more, some observers argue, a reborn distaste for credit excess is likely to help foster a long-lasting decline in interest rates. ``Now that recession is clear to everyone, anxiety about inflation will evaporate,'' contends Robert Barbera, economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``Back-to-back decades of low inflation are likely to break the back of inflationary expectations. As a consequence, interest rates should decline more than inflation, as `real' rates fall as well. ``For investors who spent the past 10 years in money market funds or certificates of deposit, the collapse of high real rates on cash instruments is not good news. ``We believe that to obtain higher returns in the 1990s, investors will need to accept the volatility associated with stocks and bonds. And these of course would benefit from such a change in strategy.'' Whether they accept such reasoning or not, some analysts suspect there is more pain to be endured before any party gets started. To establish a bona fide bottom to the bear market, they assert, investors in greater numbers will have to be driven from the scene in discouragement or disgust. This ``never again'' mood is not yet manifest in such important arenas as mutual fund activity. Indeed, through the first 10 months of 1990, while the stock market was sagging, investors snapped up $56 billion in new shares of stock mutual funds, challenging a record of $67 billion set in 1987. At past market bottoms, hardly anybody wanted any part of stock funds. Observers looking for extremes of pessimism say the requisite gloom is much easier to find, however, within the securities industry itself, where talk abounds that the good days are forever gone. Aside from the business of money management, executives in the brokerage business these days seem hard-pressed to find any facet of their operations that promises much money to be made. ``Wall Street has been through its own private recession for the past three years,'' says Heinemann. ``Firms have cut back. They have pared their costs.''

DOC.HEAD: Recession May Produce a Better and Wiser Consumer
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Not so long ago Americans were carefree consumers. Armed with credit cards, they went cheerfully into debt, satisfying needs and whims with few worries about the future. But the broadening recession has made once-spendthrift shoppers timid, as evidenced by a sharp downturn in spending. Yet some observers see a silver lining to these hard times and say consumers may emerge as wiser and more demanding customers. ``If consumers start retrenching and saving more, that might make more money available for investment,'' which could stimulate the economy, said Sandra Shaber, an economist with Futures Group in Washington. The slowdown in consumer spending may just be a mixed blessing. ``It's bad in the sense that it's going to aggravate the downturn in the economy in the short-term,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, a senior adviser with DRI-McGraw Hill Inc., a forecasting concern in Lexington, Mass. ``But in the long-term, a lot of families have been loaded with debt, and they need time to make an adjustment.'' Still, consumer spending - which accounts for two-thirds of the gross national product - must remain buoyant enough for the economy to recover. Over the past few months, growth in consumer credit has dropped sharply. In October, consumer credit was growing at an annual rate of 2.4 percent, down from a 4.6 percent growth rate in September and 5 percent in August. A year earlier, Americans were taking on debt much more freely. Credit rose at an annual rate as high as 6 percent in August 1989. ``The great heyday when consumers were borrowing even more rapidly than what their income growth was came in '86,'' Ms. Shaber said. But for the next two years debt continued to grow but at about the same pace as income, and since the beginning of 1990, it has fallen behind the rate of income growth, she said. Ms. Shaber attributed the recent slippage in consumer debt to a slowdown in income growth that began in 1989 and continued into this past year. ``People have less money to spend and they're going to buy less,'' she said. Other factors also have helped bring consumer spending levels in line with income. The Tax Reform Act of 1986, which phased out the deduction for most consumer debt, made some Americans realize they had to take a more responsible attitude toward spending. Many consumers have put spending on non-essentials such as clothing, furniture and appliances, on hold as the unemployment rate climbs and the Middle East crisis looms as a huge uncertainty. The reluctance to spend money in department and discount stores has forced retailers to become more lean by cutting their inventories and buying less merchandise. With less demand for goods at U.S. factories, production is down, and that has meant layoffs for hundreds of thousands of workers in recent months. It doesn't end there. Consumers who are not working have even less money, so they are scaling back spending and the cycle begins all over again. Harry L. Davis, a professor of marketing at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, found another silver lining: People, having little money to waste on goods that wear out or break down easily, are becoming better consumers. They ``have learned how to say, `No, this quality isn't high enough,''' Davis said. A consumer's decision to put off a big purchase ``may be the result of being to some extent better informed and wanting to buy things that are going to be longer-lasting values,'' he said. This growing sophistication among consumers is putting pressure on U.S. manufacturers to come up with better ideas and products. Automakers must now market their cars based on durability and safety instead of image, while ``McDonald's is spending a lot of time grappling with consumer demands for healthier food,'' Davis said. Manufacturers are not the only ones having to shape up. Retailers, facing tougher competition for fewer consumer dollars, must come up with better merchandise at the right price. They have to improve customer service and make their stores convenient and attractive. ``The consumers are providing more challenge to companies,'' Davis said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Higher Taxes, Saddam's Higher Oil Hits Families Hard
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: If you read the lips of George Bush and Saddam Hussein in 1990, you're probably wondering how you're going to pay the oil and tax bills this coming year. Those two elements of the economic equation suddenly turned into wild cards, but the news isn't all bad. Higher taxes, for one, could help trim the U.S. budget deficit, which many economists call the main problem. Others fear a bigger tax bite will hamper economic expansion. Higher oil prices might revive energy conservation, but it seems doubtful they will last. The Persian Gulf crisis also has prompted the government to speed efforts at developing a national energy policy. But in the short run, the higher tax and fuel bills won't be much fun for anybody except perhaps the tax collectors and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. ``Consumers have to cut back on their spending because they're spending more money on fuel and heating oil,'' said Edwin S. Rothschild, of Citizen Action, a Washington-based consumer group. ``Businesses are having to spend more and people are being laid off. The airlines are having a hard time.'' Rothschild estimated that before this cold season ends, the average household that uses home heating oil will have to pay between $300 and $500 more to keep warm. Consumers also were paying about 30 cents a gallon more for gasoline as the year drew to a close. Experts pointed out, however, that when inflation is taken into account, fuel prices were much cheaper in 1990 thn they were in the early 1980s, when the aftershocks of the Iranian revolution pushed oil prices higher. Regardless, the effects of the expensive oil will ripple through the economy, which is already running into hard times. ``It is a major contributing factor to the recession that we are entering,'' Rothschild said. Although many economists and Wall Streeters were proclaiming a recession throughout the fall, the government carefully avoided uttering what has become known as the dreaded ``R-word.'' The administration's deeds spoke louder than words, however, when Bush abandoned his ``read my lips'' pledge of no new taxes. The government instituted a sweeping package of higher taxes on income, gasoline, cigarettes and liquor. The gasoline tax increase of 5.1 cents a gallon added to the burden of higher fuel costs brought on by the Persian Gulf crisis. Economists say it will hit working people and the poor hardest. During 1990, Americans had to work full-time from Jan. 1 to May 5 before they had paid off their entire tax burden, according to the Tax Foundation, a Washington watchdog group. It's too early to pinpoint the date of ``Tax Freedom Day'' for 1991, but the foundation estimates it will be pushed back again. ``It really can't help but make it even worse,'' Tax Foundation spokesman Bill Ahern said. ``The only thing that could prevent the day from getting worse would be a phenomenal economic recovery for 1991 that doesn't seem to be in the cards. If you look at the taxes ... they are substantial.'' Many economists see the tax burden as a bigger threat to the family budget than expensive oil, because oil is plentiful despite the Gulf crisis. In December, OPEC ministers agreed to reinstate production quotas once the turmoil ends, but oil analysts predict the cartel will have a tough time executing that plan. The American Petroleum Institute, a leading industry trade organization, said if crude prices come down and stay down, the prices of refined petroleum products will have to follow. As 1991 progresses, it could reveal whether the United States has changed any of its energy priorities after suffering the oil shock of 1990. The Energy Department is expected to release a long-awaited energy strategy that will include expanded uses of alternative fuels as well as proposals for drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

DOC.HEAD: Hard Times For Nation's Banks
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: After years of haggling with the Third World over unpaid loans, commercial banks began a new decade with a new crisis in their own backyard. A recession, higher oil prices, sagging real estate markets and growing corporate debt put the industry in more red ink over the past year. Many were forced to tighten lending, cut dividends, lay off staff and restructure operations to stay afloat. ``I'd say the banking industry is probably overall in the worst shape it's been since we've been rating banks in the early 1970s,'' said Christopher Mahoney, a banking analyst for Moody's Investors Service in New York. ``We have more troubled banks, more large troubled banks, than ever before.'' While others agree, they say current problems aren't likely to escalate into another savings and loan fiasco. Nor are they making many comparisons to the 1930s, when the list of bank failures was as long as bread lines. In fact, some say a healthy dose of cost-cutting and lending discipline could rejuvenate the industry. ``We have weathered this kind of storm before and we will weather this one as well,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said recently. Stephen Berman, banking analyst with County Securities USA in New York, agreed: ``This is a troubled industry coming to grips with its problems. ``They're establishing reserves for the (weak) real estate cycle, which will cause losses this year and next year. (But) they will be stronger.'' Experts recall the real estate recession in the mid-70s, the collapse of the oil states and the rust and farm belts a few years later, and the Third World debt crisis in the last decade. Banks dumped billions of dollars into special reserves to cover losses from developing countries, whose deteriorating economies forced them to put off or halt bank loan payments. By the start of 1990, big banks had amassed reserves to cover, on average, about half their total loan exposure, according to a Moody's report. Just as they did with Third World debt, banks have set up reserves or written off troubled real estate loans. By Sept. 30, these loans made up 61 percent of the nonperforming loans of 23 large bank holding companies studied by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Loans that are nonperforming may be delinquent or in default. During the third quarter, bank earnings slid 29 percent over the previous quarter, according to the latest data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., itself under financial strain. The FDIC report noted, however, that 89 percent of the nation's 12,400 commercial banks made money in the quarter and that the money losers were largely comprised of banks in the recession-plagued Northeast. But it said that was likely to change by 1991 as more banks, particularly on the West Coast, report problems with real estate loans. Two-thirds of the nation's loan officers admitted to tightening lending standards on construction and land development loans, a recent Federal Reserve survey found. About a quarter restricted credit for residential mortgages by requiring higher down payments and bigger household incomes. ``Consumers can still get money, unless they're over-leveraged,'' County Securities' Berman said. Overleveraging, or piling up more debt than one can easily handle, was the name of the game during the '80s, and banks were all too eager to accommodate the binge. But the buying spree ended as the economy worsened. ``Banks are recognizing that maybe they did go beyond the bounds of conservative lending,'' said Charles J. Orabutt, a vice president at Duff and Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Bad loans from highly leveraged transactions made up 12 percent of the nonperforming loans of the 23 banks surveyed by Prudential-Bache in the third quarter. Some experts predict that as many as 20 percent of highly leveraged companies will require some form of debt restructuring. Chase Manhattan Corp. charged off $35 million of a loan to an unnamed ``highly leveraged corporate borrower'' in the third quarter. Analysts believe it was a reference to cash-strapped developer and casino owner Donald Trump, who restructured some of his bank loans. Banks scaled back foreign operations while consolidating and strengthening domestically to save money and to meet stricter standards for capital reserves, which take full effect in 1993. Citicorp, for instance, announced a major reorganization just before the holidays that included laying off as many as 8,000 employees and cutting its dividend to shareholders by 44 percent. The nation's largest bank also decided to close two-thirds of its commercial real estate and corporate banking offices in North America. Security Pacific Corp. eliminated its entire merchant banking division, which lent money to large corporations and underwrote securities overseas. Chase reduced its staff by about 5,000 and halved its dividend, while Chemical Banking Corp. slashed its dividend 63 percent. ``Through the 1990s we'll see most banking companies concentrate on establishing strong domestic operations,'' said Robert Dugger, chief economist for the American Bankers Association trade group. Dugger also predicted more bank marriages of convenience. ``I suspect there will be many mergers of banks to economize on their operations - interstate and intrastate - and improve profitability,'' he said. ``This consolidation process will continue through the 1990s.''

DOC.HEAD: For Big Three Automakers, New Contracts, New Management, Old Problems
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers have fresh management teams and their employees have new contracts, but don't be fooled: The U.S. auto industry is facing old problems requiring action. Car and truck sales tumbled in 199, profits fell and the specter of losses reappeared. Blue-collar workers wondered weekly if they would be at home or on the assembly line. The industry was declared to be in a recession. In a climate of unprecedented competition that includes Japanese companies building cars in the United States, executives and labor union leaders are looking for new ways to make money. ``We are facing ... an extremely competitive struggle which is not going to go away,'' Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz said. ``The economy can turn around, but the Japanese transplants and the offshore producers will still be there.'' ``We've got to tell the Fords, the Chryslers, the Hondas, the Nissans that we've got a product for them,'' said Joseph Hasenjager, union president at a General Motors Corp. brake component plant in Dayton, Ohio. ``That's the only way you get job security.'' Union and management leaders are hopeful that new three-year contracts between GM, Chrysler Corp. and Ford Motor Co. and the United Auto Workers will create harmony and avoid disputes that could further hurt the industry. The contracts cover more than 450,000 active autoworkers. The companies have committed billions of dollars to provisions for full wages for workers laid off from plants closed because of sales slumps. ``It is essential that we retain the good will we have,'' Ford President Philip Benton said. ``The contract has reinforced that atmosphere.'' The industry will need all the good feelings it can muster - and more - to reverse losses in market share. At the end of November, the Big Three held just over 70 percent of the U.S. car and truck market to about 24 percent for Japanese automakers. In 1989, GM, Ford and Chrysler had a 73.7 percent share to 22.4 percent for the Japanese. The industry appeared to be ready for a recovery in the late summer when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Oil prices skyrocketed, and car and truck sales fell. In the last three months of 1990, the Big Three companies are expected to record their first quarterly loss since 1981. ``Profits are under enormous pressure in North America, and they started out from an abysmal level,'' Benton said. Analysts expect Big Three profits to fall about 75 percent in 1990 from $8.4 billion the previous year. That means intensified competition for the fewer car and truck buyers. GM's is making the challenge from Spring Hill, Tenn., site of its Saturn car project. The seven-year, $3 billion effort is aimed directly at the Honda Civic, Nissan Sentra and Toyota Corolla. But car buying tanked as the first car rolled off the assembly line. Executives predicted that up to one-third of first-year sales would come from owners of other GM vehicles. Saturn's quality control resulted in far fewer cars being shipped to dealers than expected. Some dealers, who had invested millions in Saturn, were asked to delay openings or had only one or two cars on the showroom floor. It didn't make for good public relations in an industry that has stressed vehicle quality, recognizing the reputation of Japanese automakers for reliability. Management shakeups also are part of the Big Three's hopes for revival. Within 10 hours of officially succeeding Roger Smith in GM's top job, Robert Stempel unveiled a new management structure. At Ford, Harold Poling took over from Donald Petersen, but only for three years. At Chrysler, vice chairman Gerald Greenwald took early retirement to head a union effort to buy United Airlines. The bid failed, but Greenwald still received a reported $9 million. As the industry worried about the erosion in Americans' devotion to American cars, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca faulted Greenwald for leaving the struggling automaker. ``He grew up with me. He'd been in the car business for 32 years, same two companies as me - Ford and Chrysler,'' said Iacocca, who delayed his 1991 retirement plans. ``Isn't there anything sacred anymore? Isn't there any loyalty to anything?''

DOC.HEAD: After Billion-Dollar Losses, Steel Industry Rebuilds To Rebound
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Ten years after a flood of low-cost imports devastated America's steelmakers, one of the nation's historic core industries is competitive again. ``It took a great deal of pain and suffering, but the industry is now awake and in some cases remarkably astute and smart,'' said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants in Philadelphia. The pain came in the form of 200,000 job reductions, hundreds of mill closings and billions of dollars in spending to increase efficiency. The gain is evident in falling imports and rising profits. Lower production costs and a weaker dollar have boosted American steel's competitiveness. U.S. steelmakers now produce a ton of steel in about 5{ man-hours, lowest in the world and nearly half the time it took in 1980. Still, the United States remains the world's biggest steel importer. Foreign rivals - especially Japan and the European Community - aren't standing still. ``The Japanese already were further ahead and they're running at a much faster pace,'' said Hans Mueller, an economics professor and consultant at Middle Tennessee Stae University. ``The Americans are just catching up.'' In the first nine months of 1990, imports comprised about 17 percent of the U.S. steel market, making America the world's largest importer, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute, a Washington trade group. Most imports came from Europe and Japan, followed by Canada, South Korea, Brazil and many other countries. The EC and Japan are the world's leading exporters of finished steel. The United States exported about 4.6 million tons in 1989, far less than the top exporters. The relative value of international currencies, more than anything else, will determine the global competitiveness of American steel in the 1990s, said Charles A. Bradford, a metals expert for Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. ``The steel industry may be the biggest beneficiary of the weakness in the dollar,'' he said. ``The biggest cost of an integrated steelmaker is wages. If you compare wages around the world, it's all a matter of the value of the dollar.'' The United States was the dominant force in the international steel market following World War II and led the world in steel production in the 1950s. But Japan and European countries rebuilt their postwar industries from scratch using modern technology. As U.S. mills rusted, imports cracked 15 percent by the 1970s and reached an all-time high of 26.4 percent in 1984. American steelmakers lost about $11.9 billion from 1980 to 1986, when hundreds of mills closed and more than 200,000 workers nationwide left the payrolls. The picture is brighter now. Steelmakers made about $1.5 billion in profits in 1989. The cost of halting production while plants were modernized was a major factor in 1989 and will continue to hurt profits. ``The cost of modernization is taking its toll, but in the long run they're much better off,'' Bradford said. ``This is what you need to do if you want to be competitive.'' In 1980, about 20 percent of American steel was made in modern continuous casters, which turn molten steel directly into slabs, skipping costly and time-consuming steps. Today about 66 percent of American steel is made that way and the figure is expected to reach about 90 percent by the year 2000, said Sheldon Wesson, a spokesman for the American Iron and Steel Institute. In 1989, Japan made about 94 percent of its steel and Belgium about 91 percent in continuous casters. ``The effort goes on. Nobody is satisfied,'' Wesson said. ``The industry says it has spent in the last 10 years perhaps half what it would have liked to spend on mill modernization.'' ``You look at the profit picture and you wonder where the next billion is going to come from,'' he said. ``This is all self-financed. This is all pulling yourself up by the boot straps.''

DOC.HEAD: Automaking, Services Put Nashville Ahead of Recession Curve
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: A city that relies on the auto industry to avoid the recession gripping the rest of America? It's happening in Nashville. Economists said this Southern city took its economic lumps early and has settled into a period of stability as other regions are forced to retrench. The consolidation and weeding out already has occurred. ``I think what has happened in Nashville is that the boom growth levels have slowed down,'' said William Fox, an economist at the University of Tennessee's Center for Business and Economic Research. ``And in that sense, Nashville might have taken its economic lick early,'' he said. Leading the way in Nashville are a budding automotive manufacturing industry, a diversified services sector and an early brush with negative growth economists said. ``Construction, for example, took a beating (in 1989) and a little into (1990),'' Fox said. ``But at a time when manufacturing is generally going down, Nashville is being held up by the auto industry, which is kind of odd.'' Car and truck sales and industry profits dropped in 1990, but two big manufacturers have chosen sites near Nashville for new factories on which they are pinning hopes for buoyant sales. General Motors Corp. built its $1.9 billion Saturn Corp. plant in Spring Hill, about 40 miles south of Nashville. The plant and its more than 3,600 employees and 700 contract workers began making the car in October. More than 3,500 people are employed by Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. U.S.A. in Smyrna, about 25 miles southeast of Nashville. Nissan is in the midst of an $490 million expansion that will add 2,000 production jobs for total employment of 5,500 by 1992. The expansion will raise Nissan's Smyrna investment to $1.2 billion. GM embarked on the seven-year Saturn effort to develop a car that could compete with the Honda Civic, Nissan Sentra and Toyota Corolla. Saturn is in the early production stages and has not yet reached full output, unlike aging plants that automakers are closing elsewhere in the country. ``Nissan and Saturn don't look like they'll be a factor in recession,'' Fox said. ``(Saturn) intended to start slowly. Nissan is still in its expansion mode, so they are not influenced by the business cycle,'' he said. ``They very well may be influenced three years from now.'' Nissan plans to build 165,000 Sentras at Smyrna in the 1991 model year. The plant has a production capacity of 180,000 cars a year, Nissan's manufacturing president Jerry Benefield said. The Japanese automaker, which also produces light pickup trucks in Smyrna, will add a third vehicle line - which has not been disclosed - with theexpansion. Nashville also is weathering the decline facing other big cities because of a broad and ``recession-proof'' services sector of insurance companies, hospitals and the headquarters of Hospital Corp. of America. ``It has a nice diversified economy, and it's very well located,'' Fox said. ``This place is very well situated for growth and there's no reason to worry about it.''

DOC.HEAD: After the Binge, A Return to Our Senses
An AP News Analysis
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Viewed as a mechanical structure, the U.S. economy needs retooling, reconditioning, rebuilding. Parts have to be rehoned, bolts and rivets tightened, and the whole works needs a lube job. It hasn't collapsed like the Soviet system, and it isn't likely to do so. It doesn't need junking either, because nothing better has been invented to replace it. But it is badly worn, abused by the greed and grind of the 1980s. The greatest erosion was from debt, and the Resolution Trust Corp. has the job of liquidating or selling off hundreds of collapsed savings and loan associations, with the total bill conceivably reaching $600 billion. Throughout 1990, banks were forced to write off billions of dollars in failed corporate deals, and loans with real estate developers and Third World nations. The total bank bill could only be surmised, but the extent of the damage was illustrated when just one, Chase Manhattan Corp., took a $1 billion charge against earnings to cover bad debts. One of the oddest twists in the credit disaster was that banks themselves found it difficult to raise money; bankers, accustomed to hearing tales of woe from would-be borrowers, had worse problems of their own. Chase, the nation's second largest commercial banking enterprise, was forced to offer 13.017 percent to sell $200 million of notes. Citicorp, parent of the largest bank, suffered the indignity of having its own credit rating lowered. Industrial companies, many loaded with debt, showed the strains. Standard & Poor's Corp. found that dividend increases in 1990 fell to their lowest levels in 20 years, 23 percent fewer than in 1989. The payout money just wasn't there. Dun & Bradstreet said that in the first 11 months of 1990, 55,000 companies failed, up 19 percent from 1989. Also disturbing was that the size of liabilities was up sharply, indicating that more large companies were filing for protection from creditors. Nearly every industry was affected by failures. Failures among real estate companies, which floated the debt; among financial institutions, which helped them raise the funds; and among insurers, which bought the high-yielding debt, rose more than 30 percent. What was the extent of that corporate debts? This: -Nonfinancial corporate borrowing as a percentage of gross national product rose to 67 percent in 1989 from 47 percent 20 years earlier and 39 percent 30 years ago. -In the late 1980s, half the funds raised by nonfinancial corporations came from debt issues, with the other half from equity offerings. But as recently as the 1960s and 1970s, the average was only 24 percent debt. -In the 20 years through 1989, the ratio of interest expense to corporate earnings more than doubled to 40 percent. Since the market plunge of 1987, securities firms had been shrinking their own businesses - disbanding departments that had helped arrange takeovers and junk-bond offerings, laying off workers and closing entire offices. The pace quickened in 1990. With the economy sinking, deal-making was done, and rather than Christmas bonuses, many high-paid employees received pink slips. Consumers were in debt, up to the limit of their Visa cards or the caps on their home equity loans. Personal bankruptcies rose 15 percent in 1990, and would likely rise again in 1991. Late in the year home mortgage delinquencies also rose. Uncle Sam, of course, remained in debt, unable to balance his budget. By some estimates, the budget deficit could exceed $300 billion in the coming year. This, after a tortuous round of so-called budget trimming. Economic growth inevitably succumbed to such impossible circumstances, and the big question now is how deep the downturn will be. The consensus of forecasts, including that from the White House, is that any recession will be shallow and brief, probably ending during the summer. However, many of the forecasts come with a caveat - that never in the post-World War II era have similar conditions been encountered. Forecasters point to the rickety condition of the financial underpinnings and ask if those loans can be repaid in an orderly way; or whether the structural rivets will give way. Clearly, a new era is here. In the old era, credit was cool; in the new, debt is dumb. Businesses seeking to rid themselves of debt are offering lenders equity instead. RJR Nabisco Inc., taken private in the biggest debt-financed buyout ever, offered just before Christmas to trade stock and cash for some of it high-yielding junk bonds. Lenders are biting the bullet and writing off loans that once they claimed were still collectable. Consumers are cutting consumption. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady hinted that legislation affecting banking would be on the agenda for 1991. The administration of President Bush, he said, was committed ``to promoting legislation and encouraging regulations that will allow banks to reshape their activities to operate profitably and soundly in business environment made new by technological changes.'' Meanwhile, businesses and households are seeking to cut waste, work more productively, and get those bills paid. In short, America is banking on a return to the old verities - chief among them the exercise of common sense.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Continues To Innovate, Though Recession Poses Threat
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: Hard times could put a squeeze on research and development spending by U.S. businesses, but experts warn against cutbacks that divert Americans from the global technology race. ``It's an easy but foolish place to cut,'' said Richard Shaffer, editor of Technologic Computer Letter, a computer industry newsletter. Despite gloomy talk, many experts say U.S. scientists and engineers continue to make breakthroughs in a variety of fields and hold their own in a number of technologies. ``I don't think we're any less innovative and creative than we were 20 years ago, even though some people think we're becoming soft and the Japanese are going to run over us,'' said Donald Wilson, an assistant professor of management at Rochester Institute of Technology. Still, some financially struggling companies have little choice. ``It's self-defeating in the long run, but if you're worried about surviving this year you don't worry about the long run,'' said David Wyss, research director of the economic consulting firm DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc. The need for U.S. companies to maintain research and development spending is especially acute in light of stepped-up research efforts by Japanese companies, particularly in this country. In recent years, many Japanese high-technology companies have opened U.S. research centers, to which they attract U.S. scientists with high salaries. Japanese companies also have boosted research spending at U.S. universities. Wilson said these moves are an admission that the United States is a hub of innovation. ``We're seen as kind of the creative leaders,'' he said. U.S. companies overall spend more than twice as much on research and development as their Japanese counterparts, but a smaller amount as a percentage of gross national product. Japan's Science and Technology Agency says that nation's research and development spending equaled about 2.85 percent of its GNP in 1989, compared with 2.53 percent in the United States. In 1990, U.S. corporate R&D spending is expected to total about $108 billion, with $35.7 billion of that coming from the federal government, the National Science Foundation says. As for the year ahead, a trade group called the Industrial Research Institute is optimistic. Its survey of 137 major research-oriented companies shows 41 percent plan to spend at least 6 percent more on R&D than in 1990. Only 16 percent expect a decline. But, the group notes, ``The respondents' combined R&D as a percent of sales is not expected to change from 1990 to 1991. A sluggish economy, therefore, would restrain actual R&D spending increases.'' The National Science Foundation says it began detecting a drop in annual growth of R&D spending by U.S. companies as early as 1986. Such spending grew 4 percent to 10 percent a year in the early 1980s after adjusting for inflation, but fell to 2 percent to 3 percent a year since 1986, the group says. ``One of the main reasons was simply a slowdown in sales and profit expectations,'' said foundation spokesman John Jankowski. An additional drag on corporate R&D spending has been the decline in the federal defense budget, he said. Some xperts believe the recession will force U.S. companies to change the emphasis of their research. ``I think they will try and do more with less, which really means we will see a substantial focusing down. Peripheral areas or (research with) longer-term horizons will disappear,'' said G. Steven Burrill, director of high technology for Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm. David Methe, another Rochester Institute of Technology management professor, says the real danger in a recession is that U.S. companies may lay off research workers. These employees represent ``repositories of knowledge and receptors of knowledge from outside'' that could not easily be replaced, he said. Experts say they don't expect the recession to have the same impact on R&D in Japan, where companies are said to have a much longer-term focus. ``I see them going the other direction,'' with increased research spending, Burrill said. While the total amount of U.S. corporate research spending is important, experts say they are equally concerned - if not more so - about the ability of U.S. companies to turn innovations into products. U.S. companies have long excelled at basic research, but have a spotty history of capitalizing on these breakthroughs in the marketplace. That is an area in which the Japanese appear to have a clear lead. ``When you look at almost any product, the basic work of it was done in the U.S. and Europe, and when the products came out they were Japanese, whether it's CDs or video tapes,'' said Wyss. Experts trace part of the reason to the greater number of engineers in Japan as a percentage of the population than in the United States. Another factor they cite is that Japanese research is often more pragmatic and product-oriented.

DOC.HEAD: Tide of Bad News for Real Estate in 1990
With BC-YE--Seeds of Rebirth
DOC.TEXT: It was the year Manhattan apartment prices actually went down and some California builders, staggering under unsold inventories, gave away a new car with each house sold. In Florida, new homes and condos sat empty because retirees could not sell their homes up North. Would-be home sellers in affluent New York suburbs slashed asking prices by $100,000 and more, and still no takers. It was the year when Lucille Ball's mansion in Beverly Hills - an enclave where common economic trends aren't supposed to apply - sat unpurchased even after the asking price was cut from $7.8 million to $5.6 million. It was the year in which even the red-hot Seattle market turned as cool as the squalls off Puget Sound. In short, it was a time when regional weaknesses in home sales - the Northeast since the stock market crash of 1987, the oil states before that - threatened to engulf the country in a national real estate recession. Or at least both coasts. In many parts of the South and Midwest, home prices and sales levels have remained at more modest levels. Sales were up 3 percent during the first 11 months of 1990 at RE-MAX of Northern Illinois, said Betty Hegner, the president of the operation with 116 offices and nearly 2,000 agents. ``I have to say, there are some markets where there definitely is a softening of the market, especially during the last quarter,'' she said. Expensive homes, those priced above $200,000, were selling slowly recently, in part because their owners won't reduce prices, she said. ``But we have a lot of bright spots, too. We think it's a good time to buy.'' Even on the coasts, was it a recession or merely the end of a cycle? That was still unclear in many regions. Take the Northwest, where few could believe that 1989 and early 1990 sales and prices could long be sustained, any more than the increases in California in 1988 could go on forever. ``We had phenomenal appreciation,'' said Maria Bunting, executive vice president of Windermere Real Estate in Seattle. ``For a real estate agent, it was as good as the wildest dreams of what they would like it to be.'' By spring, houses flooded the market as prices peaked. Buyers pulled back. Sellers panicked. And home prices began to fall over the summer. ``It was an adjustment period,'' Ms. Bunting said, describing the region as now having a normal buyer-seller balance. Lower prices brought home ownership closer to millions of people. National Association of Realtors statistics showed a decline from July to October of $98,300 to $92,800 in the median price of a home, the price at which half of the sales were for more, half for less. Jill and Robert McCarty saw both sides of the equation and figure they came out ahead. The couple - he an accountant and she a manicurist - bought their dream house in December - a four-bedroom, 2,100-square-foot new home with a three-car garage in Saugus, an outer suburb north of Los Angeles. They sold their first home, a ``fixer-upper'' they bought six years ago for $105,000 in the working class Sun Valley area of Los Angeles, for $207,000. ``We listed it at $229,000, which would have been the fair price a little while ago, but after two weeks we dropped the price when we saw what was happening,'' she said. Meanwhile, they returned to the tracts in more comfortably middle-class Saugus and found builders cutting prices and throwing in extras with abandon. ``We had been looking for two years up there, and couldn't find anything we could afford,'' she said. ``So when the market got slow, we said let's see what we could do. We got a $310,000 home for $250,000.'' That price included $5,000 in closing costs paid by the builder and another $5,000 in luxury carpet. ``We're never moving again,'' McCarty said. ``We would never have been able to do it if the market hadn't been like this.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip on Lack of Export Sales
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders waited in vain for confirmation of rumored sales of U.S. corn and soybean meal to the Soviet Union. Trading volume was light and the session was ``relatively dull,'' said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Prices rallied Monday amid talk that the Soviets were looking to buy as much as 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn and 100,000 metric tons of U.S. meal, using credit offered last week by the Bush administration. But no official confirmation of grain sales surfaced during Tuesday's session. Lespinasse said traders were hoping for new developments from London, where U.S. and Soviet negotiators were meeting to discuss terms of the aid package. At the close, wheat futures were 1 cent to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.51} a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.25 a bushel; oats were 2{ cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.06{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent to 5{ cents lower with March at $5.83\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Cuts Discount Rate For First Time Since 1986
DOC.NOTE: Eds: combines pvs, add byline. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve Board announced today it was lowering its key bank lending rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, effective Wednesday. ``Action was taken against the background of weakness in the economy, constraints on credit and slow growth in the monetary aggregates,'' the announcment said. ``The reduction, in part, realigns the discount rate with market interest rates.'' The Fed said the board acted on requests from Fed banks in Boston, New York, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City and Dallas. The vote was 6-0. A decrease in the Fed's discount rate often signals that other short-term loans such as adjustable-rate mortgages and car loans also will become less expensive. It was the first change in the discount rate since the central bank raised it from 6.5 percent on Feb. 24, 1989, and the first reduction since August 1986. The discount rate epresents the interest the Federal Reserve charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions. The board acted on the same day its monetary arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, met behind closed doors to consider whether to ease credit conditions. The reduction also came amid signs the already weak economy may be sliding into a recession. The Fed began boosting the rate three years ago to slow the economy and thus dampen inflationary pressures. As evidence mounted that the economy was becoming dangerously weak, the central bank slowly eased short-term rates that peaked in the spring of 1989. The Bush administration had been pressuring the central bank to ease interest rates aggressively in an effort to lessen the severity of the recession that many economists think has begun.

DOC.HEAD: Mail Order Company Faces Difficult Rebound During Recession
DOC.TEXT: Lands' End Inc. is performing a difficult juggling act this Christmas: Like most retailers, the company is trying to keep its sales buoyant despite the recession, but it's also gambling on new merchandise lines and a new marketing scheme aimed at expanding and reinvigorating its business. The catalog giant, known for its turtleneck shirts, denim jeans and soft-sided luggage, ran in the red for the first three quarters of its current fiscal year following a disastrous Christmas 1989. The firm is resting its hopes for a rebound on a shift in its strategy. After selling for years through a general catalog, one that included all of its stock, Lands' End is putting out specialty catalogs featuring particular lines, such as men's shirts and ties, children's wear or bed and bath products. The company has also expanded its main catalog to add novelty gifts and pet products including a $75 pillow for dogs and a $10 brass silent dog training whistle. Analysts said the strategy is positive and appears to extend the firm's reach into upper class markets already served by two big Lands' End competitors, Spiegel and L.L. Bean. The new approach also delivers products more efficiently to traditional customers by creating special catalogs for consumers with special needs, the analysts said. ``This company is not changing from polka dots to stripes. They're seeking to raise their appeal level to core customers,'' said Paul Shain, vice president of research for broker Robert W. Baird and Co. in Milwaukee. Richard C. Anderson, Lands' End's president and chief executive officer, agreed with the analysts, predicting significant sales boosts from the specialty catalogs and their new products. He said the company would update its styles with new colors and fabrics, but does not plan any radical fashion changes. ``We are classic and simple and generally understated,'' Anderson said. ``It's our belief that classic clothing will never go out of style.'' Lands' End, founded in 1963 in Chicago, initially supplied sailboat hardware and equipment by mail. But in 1976, the company changed its focus to leisure clothes. While the company is enthusiastic about its new strategy, it is tempered somewhat by the fact that it will difficult to increase sales while consumers are cutting back their spending in a weak economy. ``They need to expand and they're moving in that direction. But when the economy's lousy, people are cutting back on purchases,'' said Marsha Raley, an analyst with Dain Bosworth in Minneapolis. For the first nine months of this year, sales rose 9 percent to $374.6 million, but Lands' End recorded an operating loss of $259,000. The company has blamed its troubles in part on the consumer spending slowdown that has afflicted most retailers. ``We saw some fairly early signs of the recession,'' said Anderson. ``We experienced some softness in sales. It was something we couldn't do a heck of a lot about.'' Lands' End also lost money because of the costs of selling off large inventories after a disappointing Christmas 1989. A year ago, the company overestimated its sales and ended up saddled with $85.7 million in inventory, up 28 percent from the year before. Lands' End was forced to liquidate much of the overstock at bargain prices and at the expense of its profits. The company declined to comment on how it is doing so far in the current quarter. With the new strategy, the company's success will depend somewhat on its ability to forecast sales with greater accuracy and avoid being caught with too large an inventory, said Liz Armstrong, an analyst with Johnson Redbook in New York. The company's slump this year has been a disappointment for the 3,200 residents in Dodgeville, the rural community nestled in southwestern Wisconsin where Lands' End located its sprawling facilities in 1979. ``There won't be any profit sharing this year; there aren't any profits to share,'' said Hank Van Epps, an electrician and one of hundreds of Dodgeville residents who work for Lands' End. Company officials said it's too early to estimate profits for the current fiscal year, which ends Jan. 31, since the fourth quarter's holiday sales will determine how well Lands' End fares.

The stock market spiked higher today following a surprise announcement that the Federal Reserve was cutting a critical lending rate. Prices languished until the final hour of trading and then soared on news that the Fed was lowering the discount rate by 0.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The change in the discount rate, the interest the Fed charges on loans to banks and other financial institutions, marked the first time the rate has moved lower since August 1986. Although economists had been calling for an easing of credit to bolster the stumbling economy, the announcement was a surprise because it came while the financial markets were still open. Analysts lauded the Fed action. The Fed ``has got to get this economy turned around,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, a vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc. He likened the move to lighting a fuse that would allow money to flow into the stock market. ``This will put a cap on what was developing into a pessimistic attitude toward stocks,'' he said. But other market watchers were more skeptical over how much of an impact a half a percentage point cut can actually make. ``The immediate response in the economy will be long delayed, and we're going to have to slug through some very difficult quarters in '91,'' said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. ``This does not signal the end of the recession by any means,'' he added. Traders had hoped that today's Labor Department report showing the Consumer Price Index advanced a moderate 0.3 percent in November would give the Fed impetus to ease credit. The report indicated inflation was being held in check, giving the Fed more leeway to ease rates without fanning the fires of inflation. But traders still were surprised by the timing of the move, which came while the Fed's policy making arm was holding a private meeting in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Accounting Rule Change Leading to Cutbacks in Retiree Health Benefits
DOC.TEXT: The board that makes the nation's accounting rules has approved a far-reaching change in the way businesses report health-care costs for retired workers, a move spurring companies to reduce retiree benefits. The new rule, which takes effect in 1993, requires companies to subtract from their annual earnings a portion of the costs of the benefits they have promised to future retirees. Experts say a handful of large companies already have instituted cutbacks in retiree health benefits to reduce the rule change's financial impact on their earnings statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board, a federally sanctioned body that sets the standards for how companies report their financial condition, approved the change Dec. 7, said FASB project manager Diana Scott. The board gave preliminary approval to the new rule in October. Scott said detailed copies of the rule change will be made publicly available beginning Friday. ``There's going to be a lot of (cost-cutting) in the next 2-3 years,'' said Dale Yamamoto, a group actuary with Towers Perrin, a benefits consulting firm. Previously, businesses reported only the current year's outlays for retiree benefits in what was commonly called a ``pay as you go'' basis. But the accounting profession argued that this gave investors and other company stakeholders an inaccurate picture of a company's financial health by understating what their long-range obligations actually were. The new rule does not require companies to set aside money for future retirees. But it has the potential to slash billions of dollars from companies' financial earnings in the short term, hurting their appeal to investors, experts say. At the same time, it may help their long-term performance by forcing them to prepare for a fiscal future darkened by the rising cost of health care. Health care costs have been increasing at annual rates of about 14 percent for many large companies, consultants say, far exceeding the nation's inflation rate. For companies with particularly large numbers of retirees, such as automakers and steelmakers for example, the benefit obligations are enormous. For many future retirees, the rule-change is generally not good news. Benefits consultants say that companies that have already moved to reduce their health care costs include TRW, American Airlines, American Telephone & Telegraph and Pillsbury. While businesses do not have to start subtracting projected retiree benefits until their 1993 financial statements, many already have taken measures because ``the magnitude of the obligation has gotten a lot of companies to focus on what they have promised and to amend that,'' said FASB's Scott. The options that companies have instituted or are considering include having future retirees share the cost of paying for health benefits, requiring them to use cost-containing health management organizations, and relating the contributions retirees kick in to their number of years with the company. In the latter instance, workers who have worked more years would pay less. Another, more drastic cost-saving measure companies are exploring is capping the total amount paid per year in medical benefits to each retiree. Other companies may simply choose to report a significant liability on their balance sheets, but that option is not expected to be widely used. ``Some companies are very sensitive to reported earnings,'' said Jeffrey Gathers, a Towers Perrin consultant. Under the new rule, companies have the option of reporting their entire financial obligation to future retirees on the annual financial statement, or to amortize, or spread out, that expected obligation over the next 20 years, said Richard J. Poccia, a partner at Coopers & Lybrand, one of the leading U.S. accounting firms. ``It's hard to say which way companies will go,'' he said. ``Some companies could have the view it's worth getting behind them.''
