DOC.HEAD: Oil Rallies As Traders Who Bet on Peace Take A Hit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS four grafs at end with weekly API statistics
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices shot up late Tuesday as some traders made last-minute purchases of crude to cover their losses from erroneous speculation that peace prospects in the Persian Gulf would send prices down. ``You play the game, you get hurt sometimes,'' said Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``People looking for a down move didn't get it.'' Light sweet crude oil showed little change most of the day on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Near the end of trading, as the contract for crude delivery in January was about to expire, oil jumped up sharply, hitting $1.75 per barrel higher at the close. Crude settled at $27.86 per barrel, up 81 cents, for January delivery. The expiration of the next-month contract forced late buying by traders who had gone short, or agreed to sell oil on the theory that prices would drop. They got trapped into a round of ``short-covering'' as crude hovered at a higher level than they had hoped, analysts said. Before the late surge, oil prices had been fairly dormant as persistant war fears were not strong enough to lift the market out of some early holiday doldrums. The possibility that a peaceful resolution could end the Middle East crisis was keeping a damper on the generally bullish mood fueled by the continual failure of the United States and Iraq to set up meetings for discussing the turmoil. ``The market seems to kind of be stuck on the one hand by the perception that maybe war is more likely, but the fear is that if there is an eleventh-hour diplomatic solution, it would send it down,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Natural gas prices, which have taken a heavy hit lately amid warmish fall weather, tumbled another 12.9 cents, settling at $2.046 per 1,000 cubic feet on January delivery contracts, which also expired Tuesday. In October, natural gas for January delivery had traded as high as $2.90 per 1,000 cubic feet, but the weather has stripped away almost a third of that futures price by the time the industry was getting set to arrange deliveries of natural gas for January over the next week or so. ``Prices are declining in the cash market because of the very warm weather we've had so far,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Futures prices for refined petroleum products showed little change Tuesday. Home heating oil for January delivery was up .94 cent at 75.67 per gallon. Unleaded gasoline for January delivery was up .39 cent at 66.72 per gallon. Unlike crude oil and natural gas, their contracts for January delivery will be traded until later this month. After the oil market was closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported the nation's crude supply had risen last week, as had gasoline stocks, although the home heating oil supply was down a bit. The crude oil stockpile was at 341.5 million barrels, up from 332.1 million barrels a week earlier but down from 347.8 million barrels a year earlier, API said in its weekly survey. The gasoline stockpile was at 224.6 million barrels, up from 221.7 million barrels a week earlier and down from 226.5 million barrels a year earlier. The supply of distillates, which include home heating oil, were at 132.6 million barrels, down from 133.4 million barrels a week earlier but up from 116.2 million barrels a year earlier.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock price were whipped into a late rally Tuesday by a surprise announcement that the Federal Reserve will cut a key lending rate. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials jumped 33.41 points to close at 2,626.73 after languishing for most of the session. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 969 up, 577 down and 501 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 176.46 million shares, up from 118.56 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 214.56 million shares. Stock and bond prices spiked higher in the final hour of trading following the announcement that the Fed will cut the discount rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, effective Wednesday. The move, long sought by economists and politicians to prevent the economy from stumbling into an unnecessarily deep recession, marked the first easing of the rate since August 1986. The news caught the markets by surprise in part because it came while trading was still under way. Some analysts argued, however, that the cut was not important from a technical standpoint since it merely brings the discount rate into alignment with other interest rates that already have been reduced. But all agreed the Fed's action was critical from a psychological perspective. ``It sends a message to the markets and to consumers - a very loud and strong message - that the Fed is aware the economy is slowing and is doing something about it,'' said Hugh Johnson, a senior vice president at First Albany Corp. ``Therefore, it might be one of the many pieces that helps stabilize consumer confidence, which has been rapidly deteriorating,'' he added. The rate cut helped draw buyers, jolting the market higher. But analysts were divided over how long the cut might influence trading. Gene Jay Seagle, a vice president at Gruntal Financial Inc., likened the Fed action to lighting a fuse and allowing funds to flow into equities. He said it could put the Dow average on track to challenge the 2,700 level. But on the economic front, Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co., countered that ``this does not signal the end of the recession by any means. ... We're going to have to slug through some very difficult quarters in '91.'' Economists generally agree that it usually takes between six and nine months for a change in monetary policy to filter through and have an impact on the economy. The Fed announcement followed a Labor Department report showing a moderate 0.3 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index in November. Traders felt the report, which indicated inflation is restrained, gave the Fed room to ease rates. Among actively traded Big Board issues, Citicorp rose } to 14[, with more than 3.46 million shares changing hands. The nation's largest banking company announced it was lowering its dividend, taking a $300 millio charge to cover the cost of 8,000 job cuts. Manufacturers Hanover, which said it was not cutting its dividend, jumped 1~ to 20~. Elsewhere, AT&T advanced } to 31]; Philip Morris rose ~ to 51|; American Express was up { at 21}; General Motors rose 1\ to 35[, and General Electric jumped 1{ to 56~. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $31.97 billion, or 1.05 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.97 to 180.19. Standard & Poor's industrial index was up 4.10 to 386.06, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 4.03 at 330.05. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market advanced 4.45 to 370.17. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 305.03, up 1.04.

DOC.HEAD: OJ Futures Surge But Florida Freeze is Unlikely
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices soared in panicked buying Tuesday on the New York Cotton Exchange as forecasts for a frosty Christmas weekend in much of the country tripped memories of last year's disastrous Florida freeze. But analysts and meteorologists said fears of a similar killing frost in the next week were unfounded because freezing temperatures from the cold wave are unlikely to reach Florida and the orange harvest is running far ahead of last year's. On other commodity markets, oil futures rallied strongly; precious metals rose; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures prices settled 4.9 cents to 5.75 cents higher with the contract for delivery in January up 5.75 cents at $1.0975 a pound, a four-week high. Orange juice futures have climbed by nearly 10 cents, or about 10 pecent, since dropping below $1 a pound on Dec. 10 for the first time in more than four years. The market generally has been falling since mid-October, when the Agriculture Department projected a Florida orange harvest of 165 million 90-pound boxes, a 45 percent increase over a year ago. The forecast was unchanged in last week's USDA crop report. Orange juice prices spiked above $2 a pound last January after a Christmas Eve freeze ruined an estimated 30 percent of the Flrida orange crop. A Florida freeze looks unlikely for this weekend, although much of the central and western United States is in for bitter cold, said Peter R. Leavitt, executive director of Weather Services Corp. in Bedford, Mass. ``We're not expecting this to be a threat to Florida, at least over the next five days,'' he said. ``On the contrary, temperatures over the next few days in Florida will be well above normal.'' Judith Ganes, orange juice analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co., said the rally began when traders holding obligations to sell orange juice began buying offsetting contracts to even up their positions ahead of the four-day holiday weekend. She said that buying prompted rumors of a Florida freeze threat, ``and then you saw people starting to panic. It was a snowball effect.'' But Ganes said that even if a freeze similar to last year's did occur, the damage would be much less because the crop now is concentrated farther south than a year ago and at least 25 percent of it already has been picked compared with 8 percent at the same time last year. Oil prices shot up late in the session on the New York Mercantile Exchange as some traders made last-minute purchases of crude to cover their losses from erroneous speculation that peace prospects in the Persian Gulf would send prices down. ``People looking for a down move didn't get it,'' said Brendan Dolan, a broker with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Light sweet crude oil settled 40 cents to 81 cents higher with January at $27.86 a barrel; heating oil was .94 cent to 1.4 cents higher with January at 75.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .39 cent to 1.13 cents higher with January at 66.72 cents a pound; natural gas was 0.5 cent to 12.9 cents lower with January at $2.046 per 1,000 cubic feet. Gold futures fell slightly and silver edged higher in dull trading on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold ended 40 cents to $1 lower with December at $376.50 a troy ounce; silver was 0.1 cent to 0.4 cent higher with December at $3.96 a troy ounce. Grain and soybean futures prices fell modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders awaited confirmation of rumored sales of U.S. corn and soybean meal to the Soviet Union. After the close, the Agriculture Department said private exporters sold 266,500 metric tons of corn to the Soviets. Wheat futures finished 1 cent to 3{ cents lower with December at $2.51} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $2.25 a bushel; oats were 3\ cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.06{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 4{ cents lower with March at $5.83\ a bushel. Cattle futures were little changed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures fell. Live cattle were unchanged to .25 cent lower with December at 80.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent lower to .20 cent higher with January at 89.22 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent to 1 cent lower with December at 50.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .85 cent lower with February at 62.22 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls as Fed Cuts Discount Rate; Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell moderately against most foreign currencies Tuesday in a flurry of trading prompted by a long-awaited move from the Federal Reserve Board to lower its key bank lending rate. Gold prices were mixed. However, traders said the dollar's decline was cushioned by the continued potential for a war in the Persian Gulf to disrupt foreign economies heavily dependent on imported oil. ``In a normal market (the drop) would be a lot bigger,'' said Walter Simon, vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Co. The central bank's lowering of the discount rate from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, effective Wednesday, had been expected for some time. But traders took it as a further indication of the slumping U.S. economy, which generally erodes the dollar's value against foreign currencies. ``Action was taken against the background of weakness in the economy, constraints on credit and slow growth in the monetary aggregates,'' the Fed said, in announcing its first discount rate reduction since August 1986. A decrease in the Fed's discount rate often signals that other short-term loans such as adjustable-rate mortgages and car loans also will become less expensive. ``This is displaying to the market the lack of confidence in the economy the Fed has,'' said Simon. Traders said the dollar displayed its greatest weakness against the German mark amid a trend of rising interest rates in that country. They speculated that some European economies may move this week to firm up their interest rates to stabilize their currencies against the German mark. This could further weaken the dollar. ``The market's response has been stronger buying marks instead of selling dollars,'' said Chris Mendell, a vice president at Security Pacific National Bank. The dollar closed at 1.4780 German marks in New York, down from late Monday's 1.4870. In Europe, the late dollar rate was 1.4840 German marks, down from 1.4867 late Monday. The dollar decline on the Fed's move came after an earlier weakening on the worst U.S. monthly trade deficit numbers in almost three years. The government reported that the trade deficit climbed to $11.61 billion in October, the biggest imbalance since February 1988. It cost $1.9305 in New York to buy one British pound, unchanged from late Monday. In London, sterling rose to $1.9350 from $1.9290 late Monday. The dollar weakened in New York to a closing 132.72 Japanese yen, down from 133.10 late Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.07 yen to a closing 133.03 yen, and later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 13.25 yen. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's prices, included: 1.2667 Swiss francs, down from 1.2745; 5.0375 French francs, down from 5.0620; 1,118.00 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75; and 1.1554 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1579. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, included: 1.4840 German marks, down from 1.4867; 1.2695 Swiss francs, down from 1.2747; 5.0550 French francs, down from 5.0578; 1.6735 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6760; 1,121.25 Italian lire, down from 1,122.75; and 1.1563 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1572. Gold fell slightly in New York, down $1 a troy ounce to $376.50 on the Commodity Exchange. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a bid of $375.75 a troy ounce, down 75 cents from late Monday. In London, gold rose to a late bid price of $377.50 a troy ounce, up from $377.00 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $377.20 from $377.00 bid late Monday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 37 cents to close at a bid $377.31. Silver rose in New York to $3.96 a troy ounce, up 4 cents from late Monday. In London, the precious metal fell to a late bid price of $3.77 a troy ounce from $3.96 bid late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Pharmaceutical Company Names President from Financial Ranks
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. said Tuesday that William U. Parfet, who rose to executive vice president through the financial ranks, will become president of the pharmaceutical company on Jan. 1. Theodore Cooper, who had served as chairman, president and chief executive officer since Dec. 31, 1989, will continue as chairman and chief executive. ``This reorganization represents succession planning to prepare leaders for the future,'' said Cooper, 61. Cooper also said he was eliminating the company's current four-member office of the chairman and expanding it to an 11-member corporate management office, which he would use to evaluate succession candidates. Cooper, who became chairman in 1987, hasn't announced retirement plans, company spokesman John P. Lambrechts said. Parfet, 44, became an Upjohn executive vice president in 1989, responsible for its agricultural division, chemical division, consumer products and finance. As president he will also oversee worldwide pharmaceutical research and development. Upjohn, which had 1989 sales of $2.91 billion, employs about 20,000 people worldwide. It produces human and animal health care products and agricultural seeds and specialty chemicals.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Met With Icahn Following his Buyout Offer
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. officials met with Trans World Airlines Inc. Chairman Carl C. Icahn soon after getting his latest buyout offer, a Pan Am spokesman said Tuesday. ``We have had a meeting with him since then,'' Jeff Kriendler said. Kriendler declined to provide any details on who attended the meeting, when or where it had occurred or what, if anything, had been accomplished. Icahn did not immediately return a phone call placed to his office in Mt. Kisco, N.Y. Over the weekend, Icahn announced plans to sell all of TWA's London routes and other assets to healthier rival, American Airlines, in a package worth $625 million. At the same time, Icahn said he had written Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett in a letter dated Sunday in which he offered to buy Pan Am's 150 million outstanding shares for $1.50 a share in cash and $1 a share in either preferred stock or notes. ``In these extremely complicated and troubled times for the airline industry, a combination of TWA and Pan Am might offer both of us the opportunity to compete with the three major U.S. airlines,'' Icahn wrote, saying the offer was good through Friday. Some analysts had viewed a TWA-Pan Am merger as a good move for each of the struggling airlines, although others doubted it would ever come off. Pan Am has the movie scenes inside the ornate courthouse in May. He argued that the depiction of rioting black characters would undermine what little faith blacks have left in the justice system. Wilentz said in an affidavit that he is constitutionally permitted and even duty-bound to consider whether the content of a movie scene is ``inappropriate for the judiciary to be associated with.'' Essex County Executive Nicholas Amato sued Wilentz in May, claiming the chief judge trampled on the First Amendment and deprived the county of a $250,000 donation from Warner Bros. Politan ruled in the county's favor, but did not grant the $250,000 monetary award the county sought. ``By acting to further his concern for the welfare of the black community, (Wilentz) egregiously trammelled a fundamental bulwark against the spread of governmental despotism,'' Politan wrote. Wilentz had offered to let the company film if they would change a scene, but producer Fred Caruso declined. The film, based on Tom Wolfe's novel, looks at New York's legal system, illuminating the city's racial and class divisions. ``The film is not about, nor is it designed to document rioting blacks any more so than it is designed to malign drunken English reporters or greedy philandering white men,'' Politan wrote.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Report $86.7 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied department stores, which have been operating under bankruptcy court protection for nearly a year, said Tuesday they lost $86.7 million in the three months ending Nov. 3. The companies called the figure a sign of improved performance in the face of a weakening economy and lower-than-expected sales. They lost $92.5 million in the same period last year before they sought refuge from creditors. Federated Department Stores Inc. said total sales for Bloomingdale's, Lazarus and its three other store chains fell 6.2 percent to $1.1 billion for the quarter. Allied Stores Corp. said sales for its four store chains fell 2.8 percent to $624 million. For the nine months ending Nov. 3, Federated and Allied said they lost $312.6 million, a lower figure than the $330.1 million they lost in the year-earlier period. Federated said sales fell 5.3 percent to $3.1 billion for the first nine months of the year. Allied, whose chains include The Bon Marche and Jordan Marsh, said sales fell 2.4 percent to $1.7 billion. Federated and Allied sought protection from creditors Jan. 15 because of inability to service $7.7 billion in debts accrued when they were taken over by the Campeau Corp. of Canada in the 1980s. A bankruptcy court has given them until February to file a reorganization plan. After that time, creditors may propose their own plans. Individually, Federated lost $57.8 million during the quarter, 14 percent above the $50.7 million it lost in the same period last year. Allied lost $28.9 million, 30 percent below its $41.8 million third-quarter loss last year. ``The consumer has not demonstrated a great deal of faith in the nation's near-term economic future, and there is little indication that this will change significantly in the closing weeks of the year,'' Federated and Allied chairman and chief executive officer Allen Questrom said. ``Still, we expect our earnings from operations will be consistent with our plans for the season.''

DOC.HEAD: Fed Steps Up Recession Fight with Discount Rate Cut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 7th-8th grafs: ``The Fed,'' analyst comment. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Reserve cut a key lending rate by one-half percentage point on Tuesday, sending its strongest signal to date that it intends to battle the growing weakness in the American economy with easier credit. The Fed announced that it was lowering its discount rate, the interest it charges to make loans to banks, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. It was the first reduction in this interest rate in more than four years. Analysts predicted the cut would prompt a reduction in a variety of business and consumer loan rates, including banks' benchmark prime lendingrate. The announcement came hours after the release of two government reports showing that consumer prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent in November and that America's trade deficit soared in October to $11.6 billion, its highest level in 2{ years. Analysts said the good news on inflation gave the Fed room to lower interest rates while the trade report showed the urgent need to do so by raising the possibility that the new recession could be more severe than previously expected. The Fed took the unusual step of announcing its action 30 minutes before New York financial markets closed. The move prompted an immediate rally on Wall Street with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 33.41 points to 2,626.73. Many analysts interpreted the Fed's timing as an effort to impress upon investors how committed the central bank is to bolstering the economy. ``This aggressive and decisive easing move by the Federal Reserve is an attempt to stop a run-away downturn and to set the stage for recovery,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co., an investment advisory firm. ``The fact that the Fed acted before the close (of the markets) was a clear signal ... that the Fed is not going to stand by and let the economy dive into a severe downturn.'' For the last two months, the Fed had been making more modest moves at easing credit conditions by engineering reductions in the federal funds rate, the interest banks charge each other, from 8 percent to the current 7.25 percent. A reduction in the discount rate is the most dramatic signal the Fed can send of its intention to fight economic weakness with lower interest rates. The Bush administration, concerned by the signs of widespread economic weakness, had been pushing for some time for a more assertive credit-easing campaign on the part of the Fed. At the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater hailed the Fed decision as welcome news. ``It should be helpful in promoting growth in the economy in the months ahead,'' Fitzwater said. ``This move appears justified by the budget agreement and the general slowdown.'' Until Tuesday the Fed had resisted administration entreaties for an aggressive easing out of fear that financial markets would be panicked into believing the central bank was abandoning its fight to restrain inflation at a time when the Persian Gulf crisis had sent energy prices soaring. However, economists said that the December report on consumer prices, which showed them rising at a moderate annual rate of 3.7 percent, had given the central bank confidence that the initial oil shock following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait was beginning to abate. In addition, the steep widening of the trade deficit raised concerns that the already bleak prospects for the economy in the fourth quarter would be even worse by removing one of the few remaining sources of strength. Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said the Fed was pursuing the right course. ``It needs to be worrying about the economy going down more than it needs to be worrying about inflation,'' he said. The Fed's decision to lower the discount rate was the result of a 6-0 vote by the Fed's board of governors. The vote came at the end of a closed-door strategy session of the central bank's top policymaking group, the Federal Open Market Committee, composed of members of the board and presidents of the Fed's 12 regional banks. In advance of Tuesday's meeting, many analysts had predicted that the Fed would ease rates further, although few had been expecting a cut in the discount rate this soon. Many thought the central bank would wait until January to see whether a shooting war broke out in the Middle East, an event with the potential of greatly increasing inflationary pressures by pushing oil prices higher. In a statement, the central bank said it had taken the action ``against the background of weakness in the economy, constraints on credit and slow growth'' of the nation's money supply. It was the first change in the discount rate since the central bank raised it from 6.5 percent on Feb. 24, 1989, and the first reduction since August 1986 when then-Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker was fighting widespread economic weakness with lower rates. Economists said they had no doubt that the Fed policymakers are convinced the country has entered its first recession since the 1981-82 downturn although Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan has stopped short of using that term, instead calling the current weakness ``a meaningful downturn.'' The discount rate cut comes after a string of economic indicators pointing to widespread weakness. Industrial output has fallen for three consecutive months while the nation's unemployment rate has risen to 5.9 percent, its highest level in three years. Adding to the gloom was Tuesday's report on merchandise trade in October. Export growth and a narrowing trade deficit have been two of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster economy. Analysts said a rising trade deficit means even this source of strength will be removed in the final three months of the year, the period most forecasters are pinpointing as the start of the recession. ``This is a bad number,'' David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, said of the October trade deficit. ``It suggests that we are not going to get as much help from net exports as we had hoped and it suggests there is more inventory out there than we had thought.'' Wyss said he had subtracted an additional one-half percentage point from overall economic activity in the fourth quarter based on October's trade number, putting the decline in the gross national product according to his forecast at a sharp annual rate of 3.5 percent. Much of the deterioration in the trade deficit came from a 17 percent jump in America's October oil bill, which climbed to $7.23 billion, the highest monthly total since April 1981. The volume of imports was little changed at 8.03 million barrels daily, but the average price per barrel shot up $4.73, to $29.04. For October, imports rose 12.2 percent to an all-time high of $46.38 billion, while exports also set a record, rising 8.6 percent to $34.77 billion. The trade gap, the difference between imports and exports, was at its highest level since a $12.56 billion deficit in February 1988. Through the first 10 months of 1990, the trade deficit was running at an annual rate of $103 billion, putting the country on track for its seventh consecutive year of deficits above $100 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Completes Equity Sale
DOC.TEXT: R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. announced Tuesday it had completed the sale of $119 million in additional equity to several of its stockholders and received the proceeds from the transaction. Macy has said it planned to use cash from the sale to buy back some of its bonds. The retailer, which is still paying the bills from its $3.74 billion 1986 leveraged buyout, has taken steps including bond buybacks in recent months to reduce its debt load. Four Macy shareholders - GE Capital Corp., Loews Corp., Mutual Series Fund and Taubman Investment Co. - had given the retailer commitments to buy a minimum of $100 million in Macy stock. Some analysts had warned the company could face financial problems with suppliers early next year if it did not complete the equity sale. On Dec. 7, Macy announced it had lost $56.5 million in its first quarter, compared to a loss of $33.1 million a year earlier. The quarter ended Oct. 31. Macy has been under sharp scrutiny since it lost $39 million during its second quarter a year ago. That period included a disastrous Christmas season. The company has not commented on how it is faring this holiday season. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the retailer also owns the I. Magnin and Bullock's department store chains in California and the West, and specialty stores including Charter Club, Fantasies by Morgan Taylor and Aeropostale.

DOC.HEAD: Signs of the Time: Citicorp To Lay Off 8,000; Fed Stimulates Economy
Graphic
With AM-Economy
DOC.TEXT: A dramatic restructuring by the nation's largest bank and the Federal Reserve's first discount-rate cut in more than four years have underscored the deep troubles afflicting the banking industry. But some analysts predicted Tuesday that further action looms to nurse ailing banks and the economy as a whole back to health. Citicorp said it would lay off 8,000 workers, planned to slash its annual dividend 78 cents to $1 per share, and set aside $350 million to cover bad commercial loans. The shakeup is estimated to provide Citicorp $800 million in annual savings. The layoffs are planned over the next three years, Citicorp said. Later in the day, the Federal Reserve wielded its most powerful tool to stimulate economic growth by cutting the discount rate, the interest it charges to make loans to banks, by { percent to 6{ percent. Stocks and bonds rallied on the Fed announcement, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 33.41 points to 2,626.73. Citicorp's stock rose 75 cents a share in heavy trading. It was the discount rate's first drop since August 1986 and appeared to be part of a larger plan by the Fed to loosen credit to stimulate economic growth. ``They are obviously separate reactions to a similar problem,'' said Jim Chessen of the American Bankers Association in Washington. Falling real estate values and a widening national recession have led to problems in the banking industry not seen since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Many banks have closed, others are cutting operations and the federal insurance fund protecting depositor accounts is running out of money. Chessen, the ABA's deputy director for policy development, said the moves are a response to slackening demand for loans and problems with credit quality in parts of the country, particularly recession-struck New England and the Southwest. The economic downturn has been blamed on the failure of 734 banks nationwide in the last 3{ years, which has drained the government's deposit insurance fund. On Monday, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman William Seidman discussed proposals to revive the fund with $24 billion from a 1 percent assessment on all bank deposits. Wayne Ayers, chief economist for the Bank of Boston, said Cticorp's restructuring ``is symptomatic of much of the problems affecting the banking industry.'' ``Citibank is not alone,'' said Chessen, referring to the company's banking subsidiary. The banking company said the layoffs would lead to a one-time cost of $300 million, bringing a projected fourth quarter loss to $300 million to $400 million. It said it was making the announcement to keep stockholders ``appropriately informed.'' The announcement on loan loss reserves followed an detailed examination of its loan portfolio by the U.S. Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. A comptroller spokeswoman said banking audits are confidential and the results won't be released. The company said it would discuss the developments in greater detail following release of its year-end results in mid-January. Based in New York, Citicorp is the nation's leading banking company with assets exceeding $230.6 billion. The Fed's cut in the discount rate generally precedes a reduction in a bank's prime rate, an important rate that is often a benchmark for a range of other consumer loan rates such as mortgages. Norwest Bank of Minneapolis, Minn., cut its prime rate \ percent late Tuesday to 9.75 percent. Norwest president James R. Campbell said the company is the first major U.S. bank to lower their rate. Norwest Bank is the largest banking affiliate of Norwest Corporation, a financial services organization with $29.6 billion in assets. Three small banks cut their prime rates on Dec. 7 after the Fed dropped to 7\ percent the rate charges for federal funds, the rate which banks charge each other for overnight loans. How quickly other banks follow and cut their prime rates is open to speculation, analysts said. The ABA's Chessen said banks ``will take slow, measured steps in lowering their prime rate. There's a lot of uncertainty in the market and they will react cautiously.''

Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced a drastic reorganization plan that will slash stock dividends, quadruple projected layoffs to 8,000 and set aside additional money to cover bad loans, resulting in a fourth-quarter loss of at least $300 million. Tuesday's announcement followed similar steps taken by other leading U.S. banks that have been hammered by declining real estate values and a slumping economy. It was unclear when the layoffs would take place but the bank had said previously it intended to lay off 2,000 workers. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Reserve cut a key lending rate by one-half percentage point, sending its strongest signal to date that it intends to battle the growing weakness in the American economy with easier credit. The Fed announced Tuesday that it was lowering its discount rate, the interest it charges to make loans to banks, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent. It was the first reduction in this interest rate in more than four years. Analysts predicted the cut would prompt a reduction in a variety of business and consumer loan rates. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The United States suffered the worst monthly trade deficit in 2{ years in October, an $11.6 billion imbalance that analysts said would make the early months of the recession worse than expected. However, in a second report Tuesday, the government said consumer prices rose a moderate 0.3 percent in December, reflecting an easing of inflationary pressures. The bad trade news prompted some economists to revise downward their already bleak forecasts for overall economic performance in the current October-December quarter. --- NEW YORK (AP) - The board that makes the nation's accounting rules has approved a far-reaching change in the way businesses report health-care costs for retired workers, a move spurring companies to reduce retiree benefits. The new rule, which takes effect in 1993, requires companies to subtract from their annual earnings a portion of the costs of the benefits they have promised to future retirees. Experts say a handful of large companies already have instituted cutbacks in retiree health benefits to reduce the rule change's financial impact on their earnings statements. The Financial Accounting Standards Board approved the change Dec. 7. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Attorneys general from 23 states accused a pharmaceutical company of price fixing and other trade violations in marketing a new drug for schizophrenics. In lawsuits filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan on Tuesday, the states claim the drug, Clozaril, is available only if a patient also buys an expensive blood-monitoring package. The attorneys general sued Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. of East Hanover, N.J., and Caremark Inc., of Lincolnshire, Ill., which has an exclusive contract with Sandoz to provide the blood-monitoring package. --- CHICAGO (AP) - McDonald's Corp. has appointed a syndicated financial columnist and television reporter to its board of directors, raising conflict- of-interest questions among editors and experts in journalism ethics. The journalist, Terry Savage, said she does not see any problems with the situation because she reports mainly on personal finance and economic trends. --- SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) - Intel Corp. has developed a speedier version of its flagship microprocessor chip to challenge technology that could jeopardize Intel's market share, according to an Intel research paper. The new chip is about half the size of Intel's top-end 80486 chip, which is used in powerful personal computers and mid-range machines, but it is up to three times faster, the San Francisco Chronicle reported Tuesday. But the chip may operate too quickly for the way most computers are currently designed, analysts and competitors say. They add that Intel's factories may not be able to produce the chip in volume for at least three years. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - An administrative law judge has recommended that President Bush's son Neil be restricted in any future positions in the banking and savings industries, the Office of Thrift Supervision announced. Neil Bush, who was charged by regulators with conflict of interest in his role as a director of a failed Colorado savings and loan, could have drawn a recommendation that he be barred permanently from the industry. Instead, an administrative law judge proposed that Bush be required to meet certain conditions if he again becomes a director or officer of a bank or savings and loan. --- CINCINNATI (AP) - The Federated and Allied department stores, which have been operating under bankruptcy court protection for nearly a year, say they lost $86.7 million in the three months ending Nov. 3. The companies on Tuesday called the figure a sign of improved performance in the face of a weakening economy and lower-than-expected sales. ---

Stock prices were whipped into a late rally and bonds soared Tuesday after a surprise announcement that the Federal Reserve will cut a key lending rate. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 33.41 points to close at 2,626.73. The dollar fell moderately. Gold was mixed. Oil futures rallied strongly, orange juice prices soared, grains and soybeans retreated and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Asbestos Victims Appeal Judge's Approval of Class
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for asbestos victims asked a federal appeals court Tuesday to overturn a judge's approval of a class action in the Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. case. The victims, who have sued Eagle-Picher, asked the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to rescind U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein's approval earlier this month of the class action. In court papers, attorneys argued Weinstein did not have authority to approve a mandatory class action for those suing the company in federal and state courts. ``Judge Weinstein's attempt to stay and enjoin litigation pending in other state and federal courts clearly and dramatically exceeds his judicial authority,'' the papers said. The approval of the class action was seen as an essential step in settling nearly 70,000 claims against Eagle-Picher. Weinstein wants to fashion a nationwide settlement of an estimated 100,000 cases against dozens of companies whose asbestos-containing products helped cause cancer and other respiratory diseases in American workers. The battle over Eagle-Picher is important because it could shape the future of what is by far the biggest product liability problem ever to confront the U.S. legal system. Cases clog state and federal courts nationwide and new claims are being filed by the thousands. Asbestos was used widely in insulation, boilers, automobile brake linings and other products. Illness from inhaling asbestos fibers often takes decades to appear, and cases have been mounting since the early 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: Shearson Lehman Brothers and Prudential-Bache in Talks Over Back Offices
DOC.TEXT: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Tuesday announced they are discussing combining their back-office data processing operations. The deal, which stands to cut costs for handling securities transactions, would allow for other securities firms to join, the brokerage firms said in statements. Computer systems that provide researc information and support for financial advisers would not be part of the deal. Wall Street's back offices clear securities transactions, moving securities to the account of the purchaser and money to the account of the seller. The talks are aimed at creating a joint venture by combining the back offices of Prudential-Bache and Shearson Lehman Brothers. The venture would be structured to allow other firms to participate. The talks come as securities firms look for ways to cut costs to cope with a Wall Street recession. Employment industrywide has dived 17 percent to 216,000 at the end of June from 262,000 in October 1987, according to the Securities Industry Association. The reductions place the industry at 1985 levels, still about 55 percent above total employment in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: OTS Seeks Contempt Action Against Former CenTrust Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday sought a civil contempt order against former CenTrust Chairman David Paul for not posting a $30.8 million bond. Paul was ordered to post the bond to prevent him from squandering money from the failed thrift. He has challengd the administrative order, but a judge rejected his arguments and Paul's attorneys said they would appeal. The Office of Thrift Supervision alleged Tuesday that Paul has made no effort to provide any portion of the security required by the agency's temporary cease and desist order. Paul's Miami attorney, Sandy Bohrer, did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. U.S. District Judge Edward Davis earlier this month rejected arguments by Paul's attorneys that OTS was improperly pursuing enforcement actions without benefit of due process or trial, and cited an ``important governmental interest'' in protecting depositors' interests. Federal regulators took over CenTrust, once Florida's largest thrift, in February at an estimated loss of $1.8 billion. Spending that has been questioned by regulators includes purchases of Old Masters paintings, a $15 million legal defense fund for thrift officers and directors, and a private dinner at Paul's home, cooked by European chefs flown in for the occasion.
